column2:
Collision of Worlds
Declaration of War
Part 1
By Michael DeBuse

Chapter 1 
“Leadership comes not from blood but from bonds.” 
Ceil
Numerous villagers stood around the edges of Heivleil’s center square to see a sight most never imagined would happen in their tiny village.
Many covered their mouth both out of shock and to shield their breath from the plentiful dust blowing through their village.

The wealthiest family in the village of Heivleil, located at the far corner of the Filinceil plains on the northeast edge of the Amelian Empire, had the misfortune of moving to the formerly idyllic farmlands just before the beginning of a severe drought and famine that persisted for a year and a half and showed no signs of ending.
Driven into desperation, this family did the unthinkable.
They sold their only daughter, Ceil, then only a year and a half in age.
From the exquisite hand-drawn carriage to the High Elf honor guard dressed in polished white armor accentuated with golden tassels, the family must have sold Ceil for a high price to a noble family.
“No…” Ceil cried weakly.
She pulled back against the grip of the High Elf honor guard, but his grip only tightened, and she was lifted into his arms.
“No!
Mom!
Dad!
I’m sorry!”
Ceil cried and flailed, but her body was too weak from the endless days of famine she had known her entire young life.
She couldn’t free herself from her captor, and none of the spectating adults dared interfere with the royal guard.
They only watched the harrowing scene, the girl’s shrill cries piercing their ears.
The only villager who tried to interfere was Linoa, a young village girl only older than Ceil by a season.
She lost her younger sister to the famine at the end of summer and immediately clung to Ceil as a replacement.
The two were inseparable, until three guards were called over to pin Linoa to the ground in the center of the square with a knee in her back and her face pressed into the dust.
“I’m sorry I didn’t listen.
I’m sorry I wrestled and my tails showed!
I don’t want to go.
Don’t sell me!”
Arlen could not look at her daughter out of guilt, and Lum only watched, feeling that this was in his daughter’s best interest and benefited the village and the entire famine-ravaged territory.

The sale of Ceil would enable them to buy much needed food and supplies from the neighboring territories untouched by the famine, and perhaps, if what he learned was true, the famine might soon end with Ceil removed.
“Please!” Ceil pushed against the soldier’s chest, arms, and helmet as he tried to set her in the white, silk-canopied rickshaw.
Her hand pressed at his chin and neck through his helmet trying with all her might to separate from her captor.
For a brief moment in the height of her fear, she saw a skeletal hand enveloped in hers, dark and putrid.
Life distorted where she touched into something twisted and unnatural, rotting the royal guard’s skin.
The man pushed Ceil into the rickshaw before lurching over and vomiting uncontrollably.
He tossed his helmet off, and the next heave was mixed with blood.
He held his neck to heal whatever evil Ceil had done.
She huddled in the corner of the bench, grasping the silken fabric cover on the side with white knuckles and wide eyes, too terrified to question what happened or what she did or what she saw.
The honor guard recovered after strenuous effort and took a long swig from the water skin the Mountain Elf rickshaw driver handed him.
No one grew angry at Ceil.
No one accused her.
No one scolded her.
A fairy dressed in a simple white gown walked beside the rickshaw and mounted it, ignoring the ill guard.
She sat beside Ceil and bowed her head.
“Do not be afraid.
We will not hurt you.
I am your maid and caretaker, a gift from High King Dhurin of Vallen to Emperor Yuro Amel of the Amelian Empire for you, Ceil, future wife to the emperor.”

* * *
Two Whinhlem Years Later.
A somber air blew through a circular room carved out from the inside of the trunk of a giant tree in the Gallanvale, the fairy capital of Vallen.
The candlesticks on the wall held not candles but waxy and fibrous plants that flickered with a faint yellow-green flame.
Intricate carvings of plants and animals decorated the walls, but even they appeared to drown in the melancholy light.
Around a large oval table carved from that same trunk and still connected by its wooden legs to the floor of the room sat twenty short and slim figures with sweating, pale faces.
Their pointed ears drooped ever so slightly and twitched in the cold draft from the open windows.
The source of their sorrow came from a small torn strip of parchment that had appeared when a spatial pixie messenger teleported in and promptly left again.
The woman closest to the message picked it up and scanned the contents.
Her lips quivered, and she struggled to speak.
“How many are confirmed dead now?” An elderly fairy gripped his patchwork beard between his fingers, the tension threatening to pull the hairs from their follicles.
The fairy holding the message swallowed the hot coal that clogged her throat.
“Eighty and nine now, but more are expected.
Many of the races have yet to report, and they have only received partial reports from the others.” She hung her head in her hands and stared blankly at the table.
“If only that coward had come for me first!
Then at least our own High King would still be alive!”
The white-bearded fairy, Thorn General of Vallen, slammed his fist full of beard hair on the table.
He and Fairy High King Dhurin had been targets of assassination by the Human Kingdom of Tolmyur.
The king was the primary target and was found with his head impaled by a crude stone spike.
The assassin then targeted the Thorn General but found him a far more skilled earth mage and was promptly disposed of.
“What is of greater concern is the state of Amel,” the woman interrupted.
She was the chief advisor to the late Fairy High King and wife to the Thorn General, although by her appearance she looked more like his daughter, being youthful despite her years.
Her eyes fell on the young High Elf girl who stayed silent at the conference table.
“Not only the royal family but also the prominent voices of the council and military leaders were all assassinated in a single night.
We know the marshals are trying to keep public order, but…”
The young High Elf had arrived in the home of the chief advisor and her husband late that evening.
The young woman’s maid, a fairy and practitioner of spatial magic charged with the protection of the royal family, a Namie, had teleported the young woman there to save her life.
The young woman was Emperor Yuro’s newest wife, Ceil.
“Lady Ceil is the only survivor, but most of the empire does not know about her.”
A sense of dread spread over the room with another gust of wind chilled by the winter air.

The Amelian Empire was not traditionally a monolithic body under the iron rule of a Supreme Emperor but a gathering of independent sovereignties who sat in council united under an emperor who oversaw the council.
However, over the past few millennia, the strength of the council and influence of the emperor had grown immeasurably.

Each race under the banner of the empire kept their reigning chiefs, kings, matriarchs, and other ruling heads, but the council’s will became law for the sovereignties of the empire with the emperor’s words holding the strongest weight.
In the face of conflicting opinions and feverish arguments among the council, the voice of the emperor became the reality that the council must obey.
The influence of the emperor and council weakened the positions of the local ruling heads of the races, making them little more than figure heads.
Each race within the empire had become dependent on the emperor and council, but both had been eliminated all at once.
The monolith that bore the full weight of the Amelian Empire had been dealt a crippling blow, and the only one who remained to hold that crumbling pillar together with her small hands was Ceil.
“She was never raised in the court, so we cannot expect her to restore order to the Amelian Empire without any experience in governance let alone command in the midst of war.”
“And if we do set her on the throne, the few surviving council members will likely try to manipulate her or marry her to their sons in a buy for power.”
Others at the table nodded in agreement.
While strengthening the pillar that supported the empire was important, they needed to be certain that hasty repairs would not lead to the pillar weakening and breaking over time.
The assassinations would destabilize the empire, but the effects would not appear immediately.
While each race mourned and distressed over the loss of their leaders, they could recover before their enemy had time to muster enough forces to attack in their weakened state.
Immediate invasion by the Tolmyur Kingdom was impossible due to the mountainous Stollmuk Kingdom that acted as a wall between the Amelian Empire and the Tolmyur Kingdom.
The nation of golems provided a near perfect defense in exchange for much needed food and other organic resources that were scarce in their region.
They had time.
“Do we even know if there are any High Elves on the council who survived?
Marriage to other races would provide little, and producing a suitable heir would be impossible unless her husband was a High Elf or fairy.”
“Or a Pixie.”
“Don’t ask for the impossible.”
“The High Elves would not accept anything but another High Elf.
The purity of the bloodline has always helped with the stability of the empire.
If other races learn that they too can vie for power, conflict will only follow.”
Many heads nodded around the table.
All the while, Ceil sat silently, unable to voice her will as the council discussed her future and the fate of the Amelian Empire.
The discussion over the feasibility of Ceil succeeding the throne and what measures would be needed to preserve the existing royal authority continued past sunup and through the morning.
The stagnating conversation was interrupted by the appearance of a small spatial pixie warping in above the table.
He shivered, but whether it was from the cold air or the message he would soon deliver, no one could tell.
Every head at the table could only hold in their weary sighs.
How high would the death count climb now?
Only the Thorn General noticed the deep terror in the boy’s eyes.
“Amel is under attack by the Tolmyur Kingdom!
They are overwhelmed!
They call for aid!”
The air of the room froze in a chill far stronger that the darkest blizzard of the northern wilderlands.
“How is that possible?”
The Thorn General stood from his chair, causing it to teeter and almost fall.
“The Stollmuk Kingdom has been able to hold back against the Tolmyur filth for ages.
If it fell, we would have received word long ago!”
“What of the Asleids?
Oreads?” The marshal asked.
“Their mountains and glens would have been next before reaching Amel, and we have not received word of an invasion from them when they reported the assassinations of their sires.”
“The humans did not cross the mountains,” the pixie cried.
“They teleported directly to the city!”
The fairy council rose in an uproar.
Large scale teleportation of that magnitude was unheard of.
If nations could use spatial magic well enough to transport large armies into the center of a major city, the world would be in chaos.
The laws of spatial teleportation were immutable.
The larger the portal, the more unstable and prone to collapse it became.
The size limit prevented even the smallest of the colossal races from using spatial teleportation.
Teleportation formulas needed to factor in each person that would use it, and the complexity of the formula increased exponentially with each additional person.
Portals could not be created near each other without causing unpredictable and potentially lethal interference to each portal.
This included not only the portal’s entrance but also the exit.
Even if Tolmyur had an abundance of spatial mages, something that was also impossible due to the human ilk’s weak magic aptitude, teleportation required a large amount of ven.
According to all the knowledge of this world, a method to teleport a sizable army did not exist.
The pixie’s story would have been plausible if it was an elite task force, not an army large enough to overwhelm the capital.
“Did they appear outside the city, not inside?”
“Do you really think it would be possible to orchestrate a massive teleportation into such a populated city?”
“They shouldn’t have even been able to do it at all!”
“What of the capital’s defenses?”
“Yes, how long can they hold out?!”
The council members rattled off questions and comments with the pixie trying to find time to cut in.
He had to speak over the others, even if it meant shouting at those of higher status than he.
“The army is in disarray with the military leaders assassinated!
The city will not last the day at current!” The pixie was red-faced and breathing heavily.
“Then the fairies will come to their aid,” the Thorn General announced.
“We will show those accursed humans why the sovereign elfkind Kingdoms created the Amelian Empire.”
The council shouted in agreement.
“I will teleport immediately to Amel and organize the troops there to hold off until the armies of the Empire arrive,” the Thorn General announced.
“We will organize two thirds of our available troops and march on Amel.”
“Would that not leave us weakened?” the Gallanvale’s city marshal interrupted.
“I doubt they would have the manpower to attack two cities at once if they brought an army sufficient to assault the capital.
I also doubt they would attack a territory where the assassination of a military leader had failed.
Humans are cowards.”
The Thorn General’s reasoning appeased the marshal.
“Boy, send word to the other sovereignties of the empire.
They have one day to organize and march on Amel.
Also tell them that one member of the royal family yet lives.
We will not let the flame of our empire that has burned for over fifty-thousand years be extinguished!”
The council shouted once again, and the Pixie vanished having received a new message.
Ceil shuddered at the general’s proclamation.
She could not remain seated.
From the moment Ceil was brought to the council room upon her arrival, she sat in silence.
Her sudden movement startled those at the table.
She spoke through trembling lips.
“I am not royalty… Sorry, but I cannot lead the empire.”
Visible surprise and anger grew on the faces of many at the table.
The chief advisor wrapped her arm around the frail woman.
“We are not asking you to.
Not yet,” she said, leaning her head against Ceil’s shoulder.
Looking back at those glaring at Ceil, her face became rigid.
“You know what you must do.
Go!”
The room emptied.
The Thorn General joined the marshal who was a spatial mage and teleported to Amel.
Only Ceil and the chief advisor remained in the room.
The chief advisor held Ceil softly on the shoulders and looked up into her eyes.
Ceil was only a head taller than the fairy, being short for a High Elf, which only added to her youthful appearance.
Ceil could not muster the courage to look the fairy in the eyes.
Although the chief advisor’s face was calm and assuring, Ceil knew she was angry.
“I understand that you are scared and may feel inadequate, but you must learn to think before you speak.
These assassinations and the subsequent invasion could be the herald of the greatest disaster to befall the empire since its founding.
The people need something to place hope in.
We do not need a leader right now.
We need a symbol, a beacon, and you are that beacon.
Revealing to the council that you do not desire to lead the people is the same as telling them that their hope for the future of the Amelian Empire is lost.
Surely you see this.”
The advisor grew a brief smile before returning to her serious but calm expression.
“We will have you speak to the soldiers before they leave, so please take some time to think about how to inspire them.”
The advisor called in Ceil’s maid and ordered the maid to take Ceil to her personal quarters.
Ceil stared at the bare heels that would only just peak out from under her maid’s simple white dress as she walked.
The dimly lit corridor opened to a bridge tall enough to fit a large carriage or wagon underneath.
It was eloquently carved from a branch of the tree and connected to a similar yet thinner tree on the far side.
The short and incredibly stout trees of this forest were grown specifically for use as structures.
The foreign scenery of a city crafted from trees would have excited Ceil to no end if not for the events that had brought her here.
She did not even notice the verdant cityscape to her left or right.
She only continued to stare melancholy at the heels of the maid that led her.

The corridor at the end of the bridge promptly became a downward-spiraling staircase through the trunk of the tree and led to a small, grassy, and cobblestoned courtyard surrounded by a wall of large thorny vines and beautiful flowers with blue, diamond-shaped petals.
The branches of the trees along the thorny walls created a full verdant canopy that let in shining flecks of green sunlight through their transparent, almost glass-like leaves.
Not once did Ceil look up to admire the beauty of the garden court.
A stone structure with simple flowering ivy growing up its walls sat in the very center of the courtyard.
Beside the door fashioned from a single log of bright red wood stood two armored guards with long, leaf-like spears.
Ribbons of cerulean and the same verdant green of the trees fell from the links of their pauldrons and cuffs.
Until only the day before, they had guarded the Fairy High King.
Now they guarded the emperor’s widow.
The guards bowed their heads when the maid and Ceil approached, but Ceil did not so much as acknowledge them.
She still only looked at the heels of the maid that led her.
The maid greeted them lightly and opened the door to the small structure.
Once Ceil was inside, the maid bowed and left, locking the door behind her.
Ceil was left alone in the small stone room with floral walls and ceiling.
It contained nothing more than a bed, wardrobe, sofa, and in the far corner, a marble tub and polished silver mirror.
The room was eerily quiet.
The guards did not converse with each other.
The maid never spoke before leaving.
The silent air was suffocating.

If there was at least some noise, Ceil could distract her thoughts by focusing on it, but now her mind was free to process the events at the palace and the conversation in the fairy council room where the general and chief advisor talked about her future as if she was not there or her opinion did not matter.
Neither of them ever introduced themselves, so Ceil did not know their names let alone the names of anyone on the fairy council.
Ceil laid down on the bed and curled her knees to her chest.
She bit into the tip of her thumb so hard the skin threatened to break.
Angry tears grew in her eyes, but she stifled the cry in her throat that tried to accompany them.
Ceil was a political figure to the fairies, nothing more.
She had traded the regal prison of the High Elf palace for a guarded cell in a fairy garden, only this time, Eydis was not there and couldn’t be no matter how much Ceil wished she could.

Ceil pulled her two long and elegant tails up between her legs and began massaging their smooth tips with her hand, something she had seen Eydis do with her own tail on many occasions when Eydis was sad or troubled.
The shivers the message sent through her body helped Ceil calm down.
In this position Ceil fell asleep, having stayed up the entire night and through the morning in the council room.
Ceil was awoken abruptly by her maid shaking her shoulder.
She stated that someone named Kiri requested her presence.
The short rest Ceil managed was insufficient to recover her stamina.
What little physical recuperation she received was overpowered by the emotional and mental exhaustion that only grew from her restless dreams of Eydis and the terrifying night at the palace.
She felt far more tired than before lying on the bed.
Her maid led Ceil to a marble tub in the corner of the room and undressed her.
Ceil was unable to enjoy the quick, shallow bath and was asked to get out so she could be dried and dressed.
Ceil had become accustomed to such treatment in the palace and let her maid do as she pleased.
Ceil looked at herself in the tall, polished silver mirror beside the tub as her maid dried her hair, face, and shoulders.
The maid moved down her body to her tails.
The overstimulation of her tails being rubbed in the soft woolen fabric of the towel made Ceil cringe.
She had grown accustomed to it from childhood, but the truth was that Ceil’s tails were not only longer but also far more sensitive than most.
Even Eydis who also had a highly sensitive tail was surprised at how much more sensitive Ceil’s were.
Though Ceil learned to comfort herself with her tails, she hated them even more, since it was because of her tails that she was bought, like her tails were prized objects without a person attached.
It was a horrid feeling that she could never escape, not after being taken away to Amel.
Once drying was finished, the maid helped Ceil step into an underskirt which she pulled up and over her tails.
Her maid then tucked Ceil’s tails into a fabric cradle on the underside.
This was common for long-tailed girls like Ceil in order to prevent their tails from showing beneath a skirt or other clothing.
After all, a woman’s tail had to remain hidden to all men but her husband, but Ceil’s late husband had never seen them.
The dress the maid provided was simple silk with a faint purple hue.
Ceil liked the color and knew that her maid had chosen it out of consideration of Ceil’s tastes.
Although the maid kept herself distant, Ceil knew that the maid did care for her.
Ceil walked closer to the mirror.
The maid combed Ceil’s long, dark blond hair and wove it into a loose braid.
All that was left was to do something about the shadows under Ceil’s eyes.
Ceil channeled some life magic into her pointer and middle fingers and began massaging the soft skin.
The shadows slowly vanished.
This was only a temporary remedy, and the shadows would return if she did not get proper rest.
Ceil’s maid led her out the door, and the two guards accompanied them outside the forest city by hand-drawn carriage to a stone military garrison.
The person named Kiri who requested audience with Ceil was the same chief advisor from the council chamber.
She greeted Ceil at the entrance to the fort and brought her inside the crudely simple structure.
“The morale of the soldiers is high,” Kiri said.
“You do not need to say much.
Just tell them you are relying on them and that you are sending them your blessing for their victory.”
Kiri walked Ceil up stone steps lit by the same waxy plants that lit the council room.
They passed through a green curtain to a balcony looking over a large field.
Thousands of fairies stood in formation on the ground with the few hundred capable of flight with wispy feathered wings made from raw ven lined in formation in the air along the edges.
Ceil had never seen such a massive force of people.
The stout fairy at the head of the balcony spoke to the group explaining the situation in the capital city, Amel, and the assault by the Tolmyur Kingdom.
Another military officer beside him used wind magic to propel the man’s voice throughout the entire field, creating strange echoes to the left and right.
He then introduced Ceil as the only surviving member of the royal family and that she would address them.
After his introduction, Kiri walked Ceil forward with a soft hand and then returned to the entrance of the balcony.
The only other person who stood with Ceil was the unknown fairy tasked with sending her message across the field.
Ceil froze in silence.

A child from the countryside raised in a palace for no other purpose than bearing children for the now dead emperor had no place standing in front of an army giving words of encouragement to soldiers who could lose their lives.
The wrong person was standing here.
Ceil felt that she should have died and Eydis should have escaped.
Ceil balled her fists and closed her eyes.
Taking a deep breath, she shouted, “I am not royalty!”
Kiri was about to run up to Ceil but was stopped by Ceil’s maid.
“I am not royalty,” Ceil repeated.
“I was born on the plains of the north.
I am a common farm girl who has no ties to the government, royalty, or military.
I know nothing of people, places, or ruling, but by some fate and whim the emperor took me to wife.
He never showed me affection.
He never showed he loved me.
I was nothing more to him than some oddity he purchased.
I am not sad that he is gone.”
The wind mage sent Ceil’s message over the field but stopped in horror after her last sentence.
The concept of royalty or ruling was foreign to Ceil.
She was born as the sole daughter of a wealthy farming family--at least wealthy compared to the other families in Heivleil.
A long drought and famine in the Filinceil Plains threatened to bring ruin to her family and village.

Her father, Lum, chose to reveal the secret of their family--their daughter with two tails--to a few choice nobles with the hope that their family could obtain favor in exchange for the sale of their daughter.
The success of their announcement was far beyond Lum’s grandest dreams.

He had thought they might gain the interest of at least one lesser noble, perhaps a descendent of the royal family whose ancestor was sibling to the emperor or empress, but he could not have dreamt Emperor Yuro Amel would take personal interest in Ceil.
The Emperor’s bargain exceeded expectations.
He announced her family as nobility and provided a small estate within Amel.
Ceil was then married to the Emperor in secret due to her very young age of only a year and a half, and she lived inside the palace without ever seeing the emperor for an entire year.
Only after the changes in her body showed she had become able to bear children did the emperor call for her, but only to announce that her marriage to him would soon be made public.
Ceil was then left to wait another year without ever seeing her husband.
The only panacea for the grueling education, indoctrination, and conditioning that Ceil’s caretakers claimed she needed to be recognized as royalty was the first princess, Eydis FeAmel.
Eydis wrapped Ceil in her arms and showed her that the palace was not a prison.
The walls were cold and thick, but warmth could be found within the company of others, and fun could be had with only minor breaches of rules and protocol.
Ceil had found a loving older sister in Eydis.
As the day of Ceils marriage announcement approached, she grew apprehensive and desired with all her heart that this was all a mistake.
The man that was her husband had never shown her any affection and had never taken the time to know her.
He never visited her, not once.
The reason that the emperor had not shown any affection to Ceil became clear on the few opportunities she had to meet the other wives.
She was not yet ripe enough for him.
The other wives of the emperor were much older than the emperor.
Why he chose such a young girl for wife in direct contrast to his tastes would have been a mystery if not for Ceil’s tails.
All that man knew about Ceil was her two long tails, and that was apparently enough.
She was only one of two elves in the entire empire with two tails, the other being over one hundred years of age and widow of Emperor Yuro’s great aunt.
Perhaps two-tailed Elves marrying into the royal family whenever they appeared was tradition, but that did not matter to Ceil, and there were far too few like her through history to be certain.
What she was certain of was that the emperor only saw her as a rare specimen, a collectable object, an oddity.
And soon, Ceil would be forced to bear children to such a man.
The time of her public reveal approached.
Ceil confided with Eydis, spilling her heart day after day.
Eydis did her best to console Ceil and worked with her to plan ways to make marriage life enjoyable.
She even taught Ceil the bed manners and techniques she had learned from her first instructor, Evhial.
As a final precaution, Eydis taught Ceil simple life magic guaranteed to prevent pregnancy until she felt she was ready, even if Ceil could do nothing about the act itself.
That final night of consultation was the same night the assassin appeared.

Having practiced the contraceptive magic all evening under Eydis’s supervision, Ceil grew tired from ven exhaustion and left for her own chambers which formerly served as a guest room in the west wing of the palace.
When warning flares lit the sky and word spread that the twin sons of the king had been killed, that the royal family needed to escape, Ceil attempted to run to Eydis’s quarters.
Her personal maid grabbed her before she could fly out her door and teleported outside the palace grounds.
There they stayed hidden until the maid could fashion a teleportation formula to take them to the maid’s homeland of the fairies.
The night was mid-dark when the report from the palace reached the fairy council, and Ceil learned she was the only survivor of the attack.
Ceil’s prolonged silence worried all who stood on the balcony.
The wind mage exchanged glances between Ceil and Chief Advisor Kiri, wondering if he should continue broadcasting Ceil’s words after her last statement or if Ceil had finished what she had to say.
Then something changed.
A flame lit in Ceil’s eyes that compelled him to continue.
“I am not the one who should be standing before you,” Ceil spoke, her initial words almost too quiet to send across the field.
“First Princess Eydis FeAmel should have claimed the throne of the Amelian Empire.
Eydis was my rising sun and guiding moon, but she was stolen from me, from all of us.
Those humans took from me the last person who ever truly cared for me!”
Ceil gritted her teeth and grabbed the banister.
The breath she took caught in her throat and threatened to choke out the tears welling in her eyes.
“And now… those same humans have invaded to kill more of the people we love.”
Ceil slammed her fist on the banister hard enough to tear the skin of her hand on the rough stone.
“I am not royalty!”
The building tears trickled down Ceil’s cheeks.
“I cannot lead you and I will not rule over you!
But! I will fight with you and help you send these humans to the abyss so they will no longer make anyone suffer the same pain I am feeling.
Go! Protect our capital, protect our empire!”
Unable to bear her emotions any longer, Ceil fell to her knees and cried.
The thunderous rhythm of pounding spears and shields echoed over the fortress, but the sound still drowned in the throbbing of her heart beating loudly in her ears.
“See mother,” Ceil’s maid spoke to Chief Advisor Kiri.
“I told you she would do well.”
The maid walked over to Ceil and held the crying girl in her arms.
Together they returned to the city and Ceil’s room to let her rest from her long day and troubled emotions.

Chapter 2
 “The Herald of Calamity”
Ceil
Ceil sat at the fairy council table.
Over half the chairs were either empty or held a different face from the original inhabitant.
A somber mood persisted where the light of hope had once flared following Ceil’s emotional speech and the march to defend and ultimately retake the capital.
The army of the fairies, as well as those of the asleids and the few dryad tribes who were able to arrive quickly, had been eliminated in a one-sided slaughter.
The armies still in route to Amel returned to their own lands to prioritize the safety of their own people.
The capital had fallen and the hope of the empire with it.
The military advisors who joined the Thorn General in the defense of Amel either died or were missing.
All that remained in the fairy council room were the fairy public officials, Chief Advisor Kiri who lost her husband, the Fairy Thorn General, in defense of Amel, and Ceil’s maid seated beside Ceil.

The news of the fall of Amel was in the past, although the weight of the heavy loss still bore on their shoulders, but a new danger had reared its head like a terrible omen that threatened to snuff out the final embers of hope that lingered in the few.
The young but bearded fairy who had called the council to session addressed the council from the seat of his father, the former marshal of the Gallanvale.
“Just this morning, the farming town of Heivleil on the norther outskirts of the empire was destroyed.”
“Is there any significance to that village,” one of the council members spoke up from Ceil’s side of the table.
“It is where I was born.”
Ceil answered with a blank expression, not betraying any emotion.

She had fond memories of the small village--her friends she used to wrestle with during the long days of drought when no work in the fields could be accomplished--and the people who lived there were kind, but she knew the fairies expected her to be a leader, and a leader could not cry.
“Precisely,” the young marshal replied.
“From the information we received, there was no warning before the assault.
Like Amel, all the soldiers teleported directly into the village.
They could make no preparations.
They could not defend themselves.
And, there were no survivors.”
The young Marshal flipped to the next page of parchment and scanned it.
“From the bodies found, many young women were piled in the center of the village, each near Lady Ceil in age.”
Whispers of the council grew around the room.
Ceil gripped the arm of her chair to hold back her tears and anger.
Her past friend, Linoa, was likely among them.
Her knuckles grew white, and her fingernails dug into the wood.
“When Amel fell, the manor given to Ceil’s parents was raided, and her family was made a public example.
Given the situation, we can say with certainty that the Tolmyur Kingdom knows about Ceil and is searching for her.”
“They are following quickly on any leads they have,” Kiri mumbled loudly with her arms folded and one finger tapping irritably on her arm.
“How long until they come here?”
The young marshal stood.
“There is no way to tell if or when they will come, but there is a direct link between the fairies and Her Highness.
Her Namie is a fairy.
I oversee the safety of the people of this city, so I say this in no disrespect to Her Highness, but she should leave the city for the people’s sake.”
Anger erupted in the council room.

Voices accusing the marshal’s proposal as treason against the empire fought against those claiming that the empire was no more and that the fairies must prioritize their own like all other nations had.
“Silence!” Kiri shattered her slate tablet against the edge of the table.
The sharp sound of fragmented stone echoed around the room, silencing the disputing voices.
“This is the fortune that the gods have given us!

Her Highness Ceil has fallen into our protection, and it is our duty, not only as citizens of this empire but also as the nearest kin to the elves, to see that she survives and is once again placed on the throne of the Amelian Empire.”
Those of the council who stood in the preceding argument took their seats once more.
“That being said,” Kiri continued after clearing her throat, “keeping Her Highness in one location is dangerous.
We should decide upon a village for Her Highness to move to and then a rotation for her to follow.”
The marshal raised his hand.
“If I may be so bold, it is a miracle that word has not reached the humans that Ceil is here.
Under your direction, she revealed herself to the entire army, and I doubt it would take long before they learn that her Namie is a fairy.
What of other races?
Should we not move her between all members of the empire, not just between fairy cities?”
“Well thought.
However, fear is a powerful enemy.

Our armies may have faced the largest losses of the allied kingdoms in the fall of the capital, but other races may have already chosen to separate themselves from the conflict in fear of further loss.
If they are in contact with the enemy, they may agree to shelter Her Highness with the goal of turning her in for the enemy’s favor.
We cannot tempt such a risk.”
“If you doubt our allies to that extent, then the empire is already finished,” the marshal retorted.
“Our best option is patience.
We are far longer lived than the humans.
Waiting ten or even five years could give us time to gain an advantage in the conflict.
Right now, fear is fresh in the minds of the empire.
So long as we do not succumb to it, we will persevere.”
Nodding heads filled the room.
“For now, we must plan the cities Her Highness will move to.”
All Vallen cities large and small were brought to discussion, and both benefits and disadvantages were discussed.
Those with insufficient accommodations or lack of protection were rejected outright, as were those with very large populations.

After long deliberation, a list of fifteen cities was chosen with the plan to send messages to the elders or nobles of each to inform them that at any time Ceil may be hiding there unknown to them and to prepare for defense as if Ceil was always there.
The discussion then turned to deciding which of the cities should be first.
Almost immediately, three were chosen due to their defensive capabilities.
Before discussion could continue to decide which of them Ceil would go to first, Kiri silenced everyone.
“We will leave the decision to Ceil, and this will be the pattern going forward.
Only she and her Namie will know the next destination.
If an emergency arises, they will contact me directly.
None of us will solicit communication.”
Kiri turned to Ceil who had been silent for the entirety of the discussion, resting her hand on her shoulder.
“You have now heard about each of these cities.
Tonight, make the choice of which you will go to first.
Tomorrow, come to me when you have made your decision but do not tell me.
Do not tell anyone.”
Kiri adjourned the meeting with permission from the young marshal who had called it to session, and Ceil was again taken to her room.
Ceil walked over to her bed and buried her face in her pillow.
She hated politics, especially meetings like today’s where everyone planned her every action.
Deep down, Ceil understood that these discussions were for her safety, but she also knew that her safety was not important because of who she was but what she was, the empress.
She screamed into her pillow and pounded her fists on her bed.
She knew her small tantrum was childish, but she did not care.
No one was here to see her.
Even if her guards heard her, they would not tell anyone.
As usual, she was alone.
Tired and out of breath, Ceil rolled over to look at the floral ceiling.
The three cities decided by the council, Yeai, Ofaeth, and Hor, were all small with a population no larger than three thousand but were in defensible locations.
Yeai sat on an island in the middle of a river running through a dense forest to the southwest of the Gallanvale, nearly bordering the dryad forests of Dhuillir.
The river was rocky and deep with swift-flowing water.
Most of the fairies there could fly and did not need to use the two thin stone bridges crossing the river on each side.
The elder of the village was also a veteran of the army and would know how to fortify and defend his village.
The only negative to the city was that due to its small size, Ceil hiding unnoticed would be difficult.
The town of Ofaeth was constructed from ancient ruins leaning against a rocky bluff to the northwest.
Whereas Yeai had a primarily Fairy population, Ofaeth was home to many different races of elfkind, so blending in would go mostly unnoticed.
It was also the most populous of the three with just under 3000 residents.
The elevation of the town against the bluff gave a wide vantage point that could spot any approaching army, not to mention increasing its defensibility.
Hor was the least defensible city geographically.
It nestled into the eastern edge of the forests on one side and opened into a vast plain on the other.
The forest itself was not too dense and could be traveled with little difficulty.
What made it advantageous was the military base located within an hour’s travel that could react almost immediately to any threat.
Ceil rolled to her side and grabbed one of her tails to massage it.
Everyone from her home village was killed solely for living where she was born.
Anywhere she went could suffer the same.
“What am I supposed to do!?”
Ceil gripped her tail tight, causing a thread of pain to run up her tail, through her back, and to her abdomen.
When the pain built up enough in her abdomen to become nauseating, she released her grip.
“I suppose I do have a duty to save as many people as possible…”
Yeai had the smallest population due to being restricted by the size of the island.
If the humans were to attack, only 500 people or fewer would die.
Most could fly, so they had a better chance of escaping slaughter.
Ceil made her decision and continued lying in bed through the afternoon and until she fell asleep in the evening, still wearing the faint purple dress she wore to the council meeting.
Ceil was awoken by someone hammering on her door.
Her room was dark, and she did not know how close the sun was to rising or if the night was even half spent.
The hammering continued.
Ceil rolled off her bed and walked to the door to unlatch the lock.
The city marshal stood in front of her, winded and sweating heavily.
Her two guards stood beside him.
“We have an emergency.
We just received word that Ofaeth, Hor, and Yeai were destroyed by the humans.”
Ceil’s legs quivered.
Strength left them, and she fell to her knees.
All three cities, in one night?
The marshal grabbed Ceil’s wrist.
“We must go.
We need to get you somewhere safe!”
The marshal pulled Ceil out of her room into the garden.
Her guards followed with stern faces scanning for any danger.

Instead of running to the trunk of the tree that would lead them up the spiral steps, the only entrance to the garden Ceil knew, the Marshal led her around the small building to the back corner of the garden.
Behind a row of thriving, deep-green shrubs, the wall of thorny vines rose to create an emergency passage leading down below the ground.
Ceil gripped her free hand over her chest as if to grasp and contain her fear.
“What about Hor?
It has a military outpost.”
“Gone.
We don’t know the details.
I can only assume the base was destroyed or the city fell before they could respond.”
Ceil’s heart sank.
Again, innocent people died because of her.
The messages from the council stating that Ceil might be hiding there had not been sent yet, or if they had, the letters likely had not arrived.
Those innocent cities would not have known why they were targeted.
How did the humans even know to target them?
The marshal reached a dead end and pushed against the earthen wall.
Dirt scraped and fell from the walls and ceiling as it rotated to reveal steps to the surface.
They exited on the side of the city that contained many stone structures meant for residents other than fairies.
If the Humans knew about the cities, and only the council knew what cities were chosen…
“…a traitor…”
Ceil’s voice was so quiet that neither the guards nor the marshal heard her.
She stopped and pulled against the Marshal.
“Where’s my maid?
Where’s Kiri?”
“We don’t have time!
I need to take you to the barracks!”
In the dark of the night, quick flashes of light appeared all around the city, each brief enough to miss if someone blinked, but the vast number of them lit the city like an intense thunderstorm.
In the place of each flash stood a fully armored minum, dwarf, human, or giant.
“No…”  The Marshal’s lip quivered in panic.
His grip tightened enough to make Ceil cry out.
All at once the city erupted into chaos.
Spells of all elements flew from minums and dwarves while the humans and giants used their physical prowess to break into buildings and slaughter the inhabitants.
The marshal pulled Ceil away into an alley with Ceil’s guards following close behind.
“We need to get to the barracks!
Hurry!”
The appearance of a portal cut off the marshal and Ceil’s flight.
The two guards stood in front, and the marshal shielded Ceil from whatever might come through.
The one who exited the rift cutting down through the air was a female fairy in a simple white dress, Ceil’s maid.
“Out of our way, traitor!
I will not let you take her!”
Ceil’s heart stopped.
Her breath froze in her chest.
Traitor?
My maid is the traitor?
How?
Why?
This fairy had diligently served Ceil as a maid from the day Ceil was taken from her parents.
She had saved Ceil’s life the night the royal family was assassinated.
Ceil could not believe what she heard.
Something was amiss.
She tugged harder to release the marshal’s grip, jostling him, but he held firm.
The two royal guards pointed their spears at the maid.
Their strikes were quick and precise, befitting of a guard who once protected a king and now protected an empress.
The spear aiming at the maid’s stomach collided with something hard and deflected to the side with the loud ping of metal.
The second spear that was held back to catch where the maid might dodge was likewise deflected when it aimed for her neck.
“Hold her off!”
The marshal tried pulling Ceil away, but Ceil resisted.
The maid’s glare was a silent dagger.
“So you can take Ceil to the enemy commander?”
“You are taking me to the humans?!”
Ceil shouted at the marshal.
In fervent desperation, Ceil flailed and screamed.
She never knew the marshal until she arrived in the land of the fairies, but she had known her maid for two years, ever since she was pulled from her home and family.
If she had to choose who to trust, her choice was obvious.
No matter how she flailed, Ceil’s frail arms could not free herself from the marshal’s grip.
He was tall for a fairy but still smaller than Ceil.
Despite this, he was stronger and continued pulling Ceil away from where the two guards blocked her maid.
Her terror grew with every stumbling step that she was pulled further away until a dark and putrid skeletal hand reached over her shoulder and lay atop her arm.
When its fingers gripped the wrist of the Marshal, large blisters grew and ruptured, and his hand turned black.
The Marshal screamed out and released his grip.
No one saw the skeletal hand but Ceil.
She cried in fright.
Only once before had she seen this phantom hand when she was just as terrified as a young child, when the royal escort carried her away from her friends and family.
It had nearly killed the High Elf guard.
She thought it a daydream of her terror as a child and caused by the weakness of famine, but here it appeared again.
In Ceil’s horror of what she saw, she stopped resisting and was grabbed by one of the guards.
The Marshal held his puss-spewing and bleeding wrist.
His voice hissed through his teeth.
“I’m saving lives here!”
“How many of our people have died so far tonight, died because you told them where Ceil would be?” the Namie rebuked.
“If we only lose a few thousand of us, that is better than having city after city destroyed while they look for that peasant!
By not handing her over, you are betraying the fairies!”
“My devotion belongs to Lady Ceil and her alone.
From the time I took my oath as a Namie, I have forsaken my name, my family, and my people.
You know nothing of what is to come or the roll Ceil plays in it.”
An explosion erupted on the roof of the building beside them.
The wall cracked and crumbled.
A large section of stone fell between the marshal and the guards holding Ceil, and the impact sent a spray of rocks and dust that cut and stung Ceils arms as she covered her face.
Ceil’s maid used the surprise to erect two barriers between the guards.
She thrust the barriers to the side to push the guards into the walls.
She then grabbed Ceil from the pinned guard and ran down the alley.
They turned the corner to a narrower section of alleyway.
At the exit, Ceil could see armored humans slaughtering fairies, elves, nymphs, and other citizens who had escaped the crumbling buildings.
Ceil’s maid pulled Ceil back the other way, but an explosion in the building beside them caused it to crumble.
The maid created a quick portal to pull them through the wall of the adjacent building to avoid the falling debris.
This building appeared solid, so the maid moved Ceil to one of the corners and told her to hide.
“I’ll create a portal for our escape.”
Ceil peered around the small room.
In the corner across from her sat two dead bodies, a nymph mother with shimmering blue hair and rare nymph boy not even half a year old.
She did not even have the freedom to wonder what a nymph sire was doing in Vallen.
The mother had been run through with a sword, and the boy had been stabbed in the back while crying over his mother.
Ceil grabbed her arms and began to shake.
Her breaths grew quick, and she soon began hyperventilating.
She stared at the bodies and saw in her mind the panicked and fleeing mother trying to run from a human and dying after becoming a shield for her son against the soldier’s attack.
The young boy ignored the soldier as he cried, only to be run through by the laughing human.
Ceil shook her head again and again to try to clear her mind of the image until she became dizzy.
“No… I… I can’t.”
She ran out the room and towards the door.
Her maid hurried and caught her, pinning her against a chair by the window.
“Let me go!” Ceil screamed.
“No.
You are safer here.”
“I don’t want to be safe!”
Ceil stared her maid in the eyes with tears flowing down her cheeks.
“I don’t want anyone else to die because of me.
The marshal was right.
It’s better if I die.
No one else will get hurt!”
Before the maid could comfort the traumatized girl, the roar of slaughter ceased.
A girl’s cry echoed over the silence.
Ceil and her maid peered out the window to see the marshal dragging a young girl against her will to the middle of the street.
The girl in his grasp was a High Elf who looked the same height as Ceil but was clearly younger, little more than two years old.
The Marshal stood calm while two giants pointed halberds at him.
“Jethro!”
A robed human appeared in a white flash before the marshal.
“You were to meet me in the barracks, were you not?”
“I had trouble catching her.
Here is the emperor’s wife.”
The marshal tossed the girl in front of the human named Jethro.
The girl froze with fear, unable to speak in her defense.
The marshal then lowered himself and placed his face in the dirt.
“Please, I beg of you, stop this slaughter.
Spare my people.”
Jethro walked to the girl and lifted her by her upper arm.
She did not resist and stood in front of him quivering.
“Are you the late emperor’s young wife?”
The young girl hesitated but then nodded in affirmation.
Jethro grabbed the girl’s chin, lifted it, and then turned it to the side.
He then pulled her hair back to look at her long, pointed ears to confirm she was a High Elf and not a fairy with shorter ears or nymph with humanoid ears or some other race.
“I can never tell these things apart, let alone their age.
They all look the same to me.”
The girl rose into the air by some invisible power, and her arms were forced out to the side.
She struggled but could not move.
Jethro grabbed her waist and tore off her skirt, displaying her nakedness to the laughs and cheers of the watching soldiers.
The girl turned in the air to face her back to Jethro.
Her single tail was of average length if not a little shorter.
The report about the women of Ceil’s hometown seeped into her mind, the women who were most similar to her piled in the center of town.
Ceil struggled in her maid’s grasp.
She could not let this innocent girl take the fall for her.
She could not watch an innocent girl die in front of her or worse.
“I’m almost done,” the maid whispered.
“Endure it.
She is sacrificing herself so you can escape.”
The maid’s words only made Ceil struggle harder, cry harder, but she could not escape her maid’s grasp.
Jethro reached his hand over and lifted the girl’s tail between his thumb and forefinger as if touching something filthy.
“From what I understand, the girl was chosen as a wife due to her two tails.
Am I wrong?”
The marshal ground his face deeper in the dirt.
Jethro looked back at the eager and lustful eyes of his soldiers with disgust and sighed.
He extended his hand and the girl shredded apart.
Flesh, bone, and blood rained down onto the street, much to the shock of Jethro’s men.
“Still not concentrated enough.
Stability is proving rather difficult.
Maybe Emer knows a method to control it.”
Jethro turned to his stunned and disappointed men.
“Continue searching for the wife!”
At Jethro’s words, the thunderous sound of destruction continued.
He then raised his hand at the marshal, lifting him in similar fashion to the girl before.
Fresh gore dripped off him onto the ground.
“For trying to fool me, you will be the last to die.
You will watch as we kill every last one of your people.”
“Done.”
Ceil’s maid tore open a portal in the air beside her.
Jethro looked directly at the window, having sensed the use of spatial magic, and swiped his arm.
The maid felt the use of Jethro’s spatial magic and pushed Ceil into the portal as the invisible blade cut through the wall, severing the maid in half, and cutting the portal.
Ceil exited, and the damaged portal collapsed.
Her long hair was still in the rift during the collapse, and it severed not far from her head.
She looked back at the portal that swirled and faded.
Had she been a moment later, the collapsing portal would have removed her head.
The rapid sequence of events, the gory execution of the young girl posing as Ceil, the sacrifice of her maid whose name she never knew, and now almost losing her head…
Ceil collapsed on her back and wailed out a desperate cry.
Her chest ached from her screams and the pain in her heart.
She survived again when she fully prepared to die, when she wanted to die.
How much longer will I cheat death?
How many more people will give their lives for my sake?
How many more innocent people will be killed as the humans hunt me?
These thoughts circled her mind, poisoning her heart.
She was a plague to the world.
Only destruction followed her.
Ceil placed her hand on the side of her head and readied enough ven to shock her brain to death.
“Stay your hand, young Empress of the Amelian Empire.”
Ceil opened her eyes to see a tiny, light teal body floating above her.
The naked feminine figure emitted strands of green ven off her back that appeared as wings of ribbon.
Her fine, light-blue hair flowed freely as if constantly in a light breeze.
It was a wind sprite, a race of elfkind with no government or organized civilization and thus not a member of Amelian Empire’s ruling council despite residing within its borders.
Ceil’s maid had teleported her to the far western reaches of the empire, to Fiorrae.
Another wind sprite appeared, this time male.
“If you die here without the humans’ knowledge, they will forever search for you, and the number of those who die for your sake will only increase.”
A third, female wind sprite sat on Ceil’s left breast.
“Whether you live or die, it will make no difference to them.
They will keep killing your kind whether they know you are alive or dead.”
A fourth, male Sprite rested his elbows on Ceil’s forehead.
“Although, the Amelian Empire is partially to blame for its own destruction.”
Ceil swatted the fourth wind sprite away.
“What do you expect me to do?!”
The fourth wind sprite’s body scattered like mist but reformed again.
He nestled himself on her cheek and wiped her tears.
His caress felt to Ceil as a warm spring breeze.
“Live.
Live long enough to fight back.
If you want to save lives, you must first save your own.”
The sprite flitted up and looked Ceil in the eyes.
His gaze felt warm.
“You will stay with us.”
“I will only bring you death,” Ceil cried.
“Sprites are the elements themselves.
You cannot kill the wind.
You have nothing to fear with us and have no need to fear for us.
But you must promise, no matter what whispers on the wind you hear, you will not lose yourself.
Darker times are to come, but you have a purpose in this tale, Herald of Calamity.”
Ceil felt a gust of wind blow under her that raised her to her feet.
The Wind Sprites led the crying girl through the lush forest to a small hut that appeared to have grown naturally from the trees and shrubs.
There Ceil stayed in the care of wind sprites as the whispers told her of the ongoing genocide in Vallen, the Kingdom of the Fairies.

Chapter 3
 “Strangers in a Strange Land”
Sammy
Sammy watched the hand of death extend towards her.

The man who had assassinated an entire royal family, who had discovered how to teleport between worlds, and who had destroyed two Army attack helicopters singlehandedly, unarmed, and in a manner of seconds looked at her with a deleterious sneer.

When she received word from Dr. Shuman of the attack on Gullivan, she had taken Justin and Chloe to the hospital to escape with Miriam, Sean, and Eydis, the High Elf princess that this man pursued, but they were too late.
Eydis, Sean, and Miriam were on the other side of Jethro and trapped in his barrier.
Justin had confronted Jethro first and was shot in the stomach, acting as a shield for Sammy.
He, Sammy, and Chloe would be disposed of first.

She covered Justin knowing full well that her body would do nothing to protect him from Jethro’s magic, magic that could cut effortlessly through anything, and closed her eyes to await the end in terror-filled anticipation.
Instead of pain, she felt sucked inwards, and then an unknown force immediately pressed her down.
She could no longer hear the city.
The light wind changed direction.
The rustling of leaves and branches caressed her ears.
When she opened her quivering eyes, the bloody road full of death was replaced by soft soil and scattered grass.
The air was thick and suffocating and made her dizzy.
She tried to lift her head to look around, but her head felt 50 pounds heavier, straining her neck and aching her shoulders.
A small whimper rose from her throat and threatened to break into a fit of crying.
She was exhausted and scared.
Her body felt incredibly heavy and would not move.
The death she nearly avoided at the university, the five miles she ran, the massacre at the hospital, and the inevitable death she thought would come for her choked her mind.
She clung to the body beneath her and cried.
“Sammy… Where are we?”
The weak voice struck Sammy like lightning.
She realized to whom she clung and remembered what happened to him.
Finding strength in her panic, she pushed herself off Justin and nearly fell backwards from the immense weight of her body.
The barrier Jethro placed around Justin was gone, and blood flowed free from the bullet wound in his abdomen.
Behind Sammy, Chloe struggled on her knees looking around at the unfamiliar scenery.
“Were we teleported?”
“Forget that!
Justin is hurt!
Oh, God, no.
Oh, God.
This can’t be happening.”
Sammy pulled up Justin’s shirt and placed her hand on the wound just above his pants-line to hold back the bleeding.
What do I do?!
She looked around for anything that could help.
They sat in a shallow crater with the remains of a single dead soldier and half of another leaning against the edge of the crater.
Aside from their armor and a single sword, there was nothing.
“No!”
Sammy pressed harder, and Justin winced in pain.
He was already growing pale, but whether it was from the same dizzying nausea she felt, exhaustion, or blood loss, she did not know.
Perhaps it was a combination of all three.
“Chloe!
We need to stop the bleeding!”
Chloe shifted little by little over to them, unable to find the strength to stand.
“I can sear it closed.”
Sammy’s chest constricted at such a gruesome proposal.
“Do it…” Justin’s voice was nearly inaudible.
Sammy shook her head.
“The bullet is still in there.
We don’t know what damage it did.
If we just close it, it could create bigger problems!”
“How else are we going to stop the bleeding?”
Chloe looked at Sammy with panicked eyes.
Sammy realized now that neither of them knew any emergency first aid.
It was never taught in their self-defense classes, and Sammy had never learned it growing up.
Her father never let her do anything even minutely dangerous that would require the need to know it, and when she was finally on her own, she never thought to learn it.
“Justin!
What do we do?!”
They both looked at Justin, but he only winced with his eyes closed.
His head shook lightly back and forth.
“Damn it!
Why are you so useless?!”
Sammy’s tears dripped onto Justin’s exposed stomach.
Again, she looked around in frantic desperation for help.
“Someone!
Anyone!
Is anyone there?!”
All that answered was the wind whistling through the tightly packed trees.
Deep in Sammy’s heart, she wished that Eydis was with them, but Eydis was nowhere to be seen.
They somehow escaped Jethro, and Eydis might have been the cause, but then what would happen to Eydis now that Jethro was no longer distracted?
Sammy forced the thought from her mind.
She did not have the time to worry about what she had no control over.
Right now, Justin was dying in front of her.
He took the bullet for her.
Stupid!
Stupid!
Stupid!
“Damn it, Justin.
Why did you do that?!
I’ve been a complete bitch to you since we broke up.”
Justin forced a weak smile.
She could almost hear in her mind Justin saying, “You were the one who broke up with me.”
Sammy’s hands clenched into fists.
Her anger bubbled up until it forced tears from the corners of her eyes.
“When you get better, I’m going to punch you, so be ready for it!
Chloe, sear it closed.”
Sammy converted her ven into water and found the process far easier than normal.
She forced it out as a light stream from her hands and washed away the blood while she wiped the wound.
Chloe then pressed her thumb on the wound.
Justin’s skin sizzled as it burned, and steam rose from under her thumb.
Justin did not cry out, but he writhed.
Sammy grabbed Justin’s hand and held down his chest to keep him still the best she could.
He gripped her painfully tight to endure the intense burn needed to seal the wound, but then his hand fell limp.
“God!
No!
Justin!”
“He’s breathing.
He just passed out.
I think.”
Chloe removed her thumb.
The skin was brown and leathery with peeling blisters, but the hole was closed.
She sat back and looked at the wound.
“Did I overdo it…?”
She was visibly shaking, and her face was pale.
The feeling of Justin’s skin slowly burning under her thumb might have been hard to bear, but at least now Justin would not bleed out, or so Sammy hoped.
They could do nothing about the internal damage.
“We need to find somewhere we can get help, but…” Sammy looked around.
“Where are we?”
The portal sent them into the middle of a dense forest.
The lush white trees with coiling and interweaving branches were so packed together that visibility was impossible deeper than ten yards in any single direction.
It was a miracle that they had appeared in such a small grassy clearing.
The clearing itself was perfectly circular and about five yards in diameter, and although the ground cover looked like grass, it was not a species that Sammy had ever seen before.
Each individual blade was covered in bubbles like sea grapes, but the bubbles were soft and spongey to the touch.
The ground plants between the trees were not as bizarre as the grass, but she could not recognize them either.
They did have a mild tropical feel to them due to their large and oddly shaped leaves.
Sammy tried to stand, but her legs shook.
She was incredibly tired from running miles across the city and felt that she weighed two or three times as much as normal.
Standing upright made her dizzy, and she fell back on top of Chloe.
“You’re heavy…”
The pain of the impact showed in Chloe’s face.
“I am heavy,” Sammy realized.
The weakness of her legs and her exhaustion was not the reason Sammy found standing difficult, or at least it was not the main reason.
When she fell, she felt her body accelerate far faster than normal.
It was a strange sensation that just felt wrong, different from what she had known her entire life.
“Gravity is higher here.”
An impossible idea surfaced in Sammy’s mind.
The grass was some alien species that she had never seen.
The trees and shrubs were also new and unknown.
She never spent too much time outdoors and was not one to take time to admire nature, but the plants around them were unearthly.
That was it.
“I don’t think we are on Earth anymore.”
She looked down at Chloe under her for confirmation.
Chloe scanned their surroundings and nodded slightly.
She came to the same conclusion rather quickly.
Chloe pushed Sammy off her stomach and returned to her knees.
“If we are not on Earth, where are we?
How can we find help for Justin?”
Sammy tried to stand and felt lightheaded.
With higher gravity, blood was draining from her head.
To test the effect of the gravity, Sammy stood as straight as she could with her arms hanging down.
After a few seconds, her hands and legs began to tingle, the same as if she swung her arms around in a circle.
Her lightheadedness worsened, and she had to lie back down along the slope of the shallow crater.
“I can’t stand more than a few seconds without getting lightheaded.
Moving won’t be easy.”
“Can we at least get away from here?”
Chloe glanced to the side where one soldier and the lower half of another lay.
The nearby sword caught Sammy’s eye.
It was thin with a deep fuller along the center of the blade.
She reached over and picked it up.
The sword felt no heavier than what she imagined a thicker medieval replica might.
It could have been designed with the weight and gravity of this world in mind.
“Is this Eydis’s world?”
If this was Eydis’s world, then there was hope.
Sammy dropped the sword and grabbed Chloe’s shoulders.
“Eydis’s world has people who can use healing magic!”
She crawled out of the crater and along the grass.
The bubbles on the grass tore and released a mildly sweet scent.
Sammy’s nausea vanished, and her heart beat faster and heavier.
Fearing that there was something poisonous about the grass, Sammy pushed herself to her feet to distance herself from it.
She was still unsteady, but the dizziness from before did not return.
The blood in her body circulated better, causing her body to throb lightly.
Her fingers and toes still tingled, but she did not become as lightheaded.
She could walk around.
“Chloe, smell the grass!”
Chloe gazed warily at Sammy.
“Your eyes are dilated…”
“I feel fine.
The grass here helps with the dizziness.
I don’t think we should inhale too much, but it can help us move.”
Sammy walked around the perimeter of the perfectly circular clearing to look between the trees for any sign of a direction they should walk.
Nothing stood out except in one direction where the trees did not seem as closely bunched together.
If anything, it would make carrying, or dragging, Justin easier.
She did not know how long they would be able to lift him in this gravity.
Chloe finally succumbed to Sammy’s suggestion and grabbed a handful of the grass.
She squeezed it in her hand and smelled it.
She broke into a fit of coughing and turned her head away.
“Wow, that’s strong.
It’s like walking into a wall.”
She stood rather easily, having smelled it directly.
“Weird.”
Sammy looked back at Chloe and saw that her eyes were heavily dilated as well.
“Let’s take some of the grass with us, but we shouldn’t rely on it.
We don’t know exactly what it does, so we should only use it in emergencies.”
They returned to the center of the crater to grab Justin.
Sammy hooked her arms under Justin’s shoulders, and Chloe grabbed his legs.
In the increased gravity, lifting him up out of the shallow crater was incredibly difficult.
Not only was Justin dead weight, now worsened by the high gravity, but the sandy dirt at the edge of the crater also slid down with every step.
Chloe, who was standing in the crater, kept sliding and falling against him.
“Careful not to hit his stomach,” Sammy warned.
“I know, but this isn’t easy.
Can we pull him out?”
“We don’t know what this grass does.
If we pull him out over the grass, a lot of that stuff will get in the air, and he will breathe it in.
It might increase blood flow, which would be bad if he is still bleeding internally.
He’ll end up breathing some of it in anyway, but we should try to keep it as low as possible.”
Chloe put one foot up in the grass on the edge of the crater and lifted Justin’s legs to her shoulders while Sammy pulled up with all her strength.
With one stable foot supporting her, she raised Justin out of the crater but collapsed in exhaustion and immediately began coughing from the smell that wafted up from the grass.
She sprung to her feet, and helped Sammy carry Justin to the edge of the circular clearing away from the grass.
They leaned Justin against a tree and sat down to rest.
Sammy shook her head in bewilderment.
“How the hell did Eydis survive in this world?”
“Eydis was light.
And strong, right?”
Some of Eydis’s odd characteristics began to make sense.
Sammy had attributed Eydis’s light weight to her being an elf, but in a world with such high gravity, perhaps elves evolved to be lighter in order to make survival easier.
Even the humans that invaded Gullivan were light and nimble on their feet.
The soldier she tackled at the university felt as light as Eydis.
She also recalled the early self-defense classes when she was surprised by Eydis’s strength despite being thin and lacking excess muscle.
Humans from Earth were ill suited for this world with their dense bodies and weaker physique.
However, she was already exhausted from the events preceding their teleportation here, so that may have worsened their situation.
“I guess we will have to see how hard it is to move once we are rested.
We should find shelter first.”
Chloe nodded and then looked back at the crater.
“Should we take anything?”
Sammy stood for a better look down into the pit.
“Probably the sword?
You have fire magic, but I can’t protect myself with my water magic.
It’ll also help cut wood for fires and stuff like that.”
“The soldiers might have something useful on them too,” Chloe added.
After two troubled breaths taken in unison, they hobbled back to the crater.
Sammy grabbed the sword but could not find the courage to search the dead bodies, especially the one split in half.
Chloe was uncomfortable but did it without complaint.
Aside from armor and clothing, there was little.
The man had no provisions on him, and his weapon was missing.
The sword did not match his sheath so it would have to be carried unprotected.
They discovered that the soldier with a missing torso was female.
She was less armored than the man, and she had a small pouch on her waist that held two corked vials.
The liquid contents smelled strongly herbal through the corks even without opening them, but because they did not know what they were, they could not use them.
“Let’s take them anyway,” Sammy suggested.
“Someone we encounter might know what they are.”
“Okay.” Chloe placed the vials back in the pouch.
“We can put some of the grass in the pouch too.”
“What about the armor?”
The woman’s severed armor would not help them much, and the man’s fitted armor was too large for Sammy and chest too small for Chloe.
If this was Whinhlem, there was also the possibility of someone they encountered thinking they were with the Tolmyur army and attacking.
And neither of them wanted to bear the extra weight.
“We probably can’t use it, and it would be too heavy.
We already have to carry Justin.”
Chloe sighed.
“I wish looting in real life was as easy as it is in video games.”
They retrieved only the sword, the belt that the mismatched sheath was attached to, and the pouch.
Next, they gathered some of the grass, taking care not to break the spongey bubbles.
Sammy wrapped the belt around her waist and slid the sword into it.
It hung loose but did not restrict her movements.
They returned to Justin and assumed their previous positions of Sammy in front with her arms hooked under his shoulders and Chloe holding his legs.
Sammy walked backwards slowly through the tightly packed trees.
After only a few yards the small clearing vanished from sight as if it had never existed.
She knew that they would never find that location again.

* * *
One hour passed and then another.
The dense forest gave off an intense claustrophobic aura that caused Sammy’s heart to beat faster than the fumes of the strange, bubbled grass.
The sense of fear and anxiety choked her in the thick air.
Neither she nor Chloe could see any more than ten yards in any direction.
They only followed in the direction where the trees were not as dense, and that path twisted and turned like a snake slithering through the forest.
Sammy feared they could be unknowingly going in circles, but in her sense of direction she felt, or at least hoped, they had not turned enough any single direction for that to be the case.
Traveling in a straight line was simply not possible, and many of the trees were so close together that Sammy, the thinnest of the group, could not squeeze through them.
At one point, Justin moved his head as if he was about to wake but then fell still and silent.
Small beads of sweat grew on his forehead and ran down his face.
Sammy felt rising heat from her grip under his arms, and she feared that it was not from her exertion.
The cold chill in the air caused both Chloe and her to shiver.
The wind felt like late autumn threatening an approaching winter, and Sammy hoped that was not the case.

The leaves on the trees were still verdant green, but she knew nothing of the plants or climate of this world, so it could very well be autumn or winter or even summer if this world had defined seasons at all.
But on second thought, it should.
After all, Eydis had mentioned that she was born on the first day of the warm season.
They paused for frequent breaks due to their ever-increasing exhaustion.
During one of the breaks, Sammy spotted a low-hanging branch, and using the boost from the bubbled grass she risked climbing to the canopy for a vantage point above the claustrophobic forest.
The forest was an unending sea of green stretching beyond the horizon in all directions without so much as a hill or valley.
The only mark in the perfect green canopy was a darker line snaking through the forest, possibly a river or road.
The climb nearly broke Sammy, but they now had a direction.
Sammy rested for an hour before they continued in its general direction.
With renewed determination that pulled out the last dregs of energy from within, they increased their pace as they weaved through the tightly packed trees.
The forest broke open to a gap no more than thirty yards wide.
The trees stopped where the light, pumice-like sand of a riverbank began.
The bank was five yards wide, and the river was about ten or fifteen yards depending on where they looked.
The water was clear and shallow enough to wade across.
On the other side of the river, the bank spread only one or two yards wide and immediately became a steep rocky face that stood over twenty feet high.
It followed the entire length of the river they could see.
It was almost as if the entire forest beyond the river had jumped up in elevation.
Trees grew at the top not too far back from the cliff, and their many roots ran down the rock face.
The cliff itself appeared to have long veins of the soft pumice running through it, and fallen rocks and boulders sat at locations where the pumice had eroded away.
A large sheet of rock had broken away into the river.
The river bent around the fallen rocks leaving a small, elevated shelf of pumice and stone that looked large enough for a few people to sit in comfortably.
The overhanging cliff was solid rock and looked sturdy enough.
It would protect them from rain and wind.
The only problem was its proximity to the river.
The air was cooler, but Chloe would be able to help them stay warm by making a fire.
This could be their shelter for now.
Sammy lacked the energy to travel any further to find another.
When Sammy stepped out onto the sand, her foot sank about six inches.
Some of the pumice even cracked and broke under her weight.
Carrying Justin over the pumice was proving terribly strenuous, so they set him down by the water’s edge.
Chloe hobbled over to the river and looked at the water.
“It’s perfectly clear.
There’s no algae or plants or anything.
It’s just rocks.”
She cupped her hands and took a drink.
A shiver grew from her shoulders and spread down her back.
She then held her head.
“Brain freeze…”
Sammy placed her hand in the water.
It was cold, painfully cold.
She was surprised that there was no ice floating on it or built up on the edges.
“It’s clean.
Try it,” Chloe assured.
Sammy cupped her hands, and they almost immediately numbed when placed in the water.
She brought the water to her lips and drank.
Her body shivered uncontrollably as she felt the heat get sapped out of her, but the water was delicious.
It tasted cleaner than any bottled water she had ever bought from a store or that her father had imported; however, unlike Chloe, her shivers did not stop.
The air was cold near the river, and the water that felt colder than ice was a shock to her system.
She held her arms close and tucked her knees in to try to conserve warmth, but the shaking only grew in intensity.
Chloe noticed Sammy’s struggle and wrapped her body around her.
Sammy was enveloped in warmth like a heated blanket placed on her shoulders.
“Having you around is convenient.
I guess I can’t drink the water directly.
It’s too cold for me.”
“I can heat it up for you,” Chloe said with a smile.
After extreme effort in their exhaustion, now stronger after giving their bodies a short respite, they lifted Justin to their chests and shoulders and waded across the shallow river.
The water went up to Sammy’s thighs as she sank into the stone and denser pumice, and the cold water was a barrage of painful needles.
Her shaking body nearly slipped and dropped Justin a few times, but they made it across and up to the stone shelf in the overhanging cliff.
The stone was smooth, and there was a layer of pumice in the back, so they set Justin there.
Sammy and Chloe immediately stripped off their shoes and wet pants and set them aside before huddling together to warm up, or at least to warm Sammy.
Her lips were purple, and her jaw was shaking uncontrollably.
She couldn’t even speak.
“Hold onto Justin.
You’ll keep each other warm.
I’ll go get some wood and make a fire at the entrance here.”
Sammy gave a shaky nod and watched Chloe jump down from the shelf with the sword.
She crawled onto the bed of pumice and wrapped herself around Justin.
He was feverish, but that helped warm her.
A single tear fell from her eye, and she buried her face in Justin’s shoulder.
Her weak hands grasped his shirt as if his ephemeral life would vanish if she let go.
Deep down, she understood he could slip away at any moment.
None of her knowledge was helpful here.
None of the business sense she learned from her doting father would save Justin.
None of the proper etiquette or tricks to snag a well-to-do man that she learned from her mother was any help.

She was studying biology in preparation for a career in genetics, something her father was opposed to because he wanted her to inherit his trade company, but not even that had any practicality in her situation.
It would not help Justin.
“Why am I so useless?”
She clung tight to Justin and drowned in self-contempt as the minutes passed on.
