Chloe returned before the sky grew dark and pretended that she hadn’t noticed Sammy crying while clinging to Justin.
Under her arms, she held a handful of dead branches she gleaned from the forest floor.
She stacked them near the entrance and set them alight.
She then jumped down and carried up even more.
This repeated four times.
Sammy was amazed Chloe had gathered so much wood.
When they walked through the forest, they had seen little to no branches on the ground.
“Where did you find all that?” Sammy asked.
“It was just on the ground.
Once I found the first branch, I started noticing more and more.
They look perfectly dry too, so they’ll burn well.”
The way Chloe stacked the wood and stoked the fire showed a practiced hand.
Chloe likely had spent a lot of time outdoors or going camping in her youth.
Sammy was forced to realize just how much she missed growing up under her parent’s overprotection.
When Chloe was satisfied with the fire, she jumped back down to the riverbed.
She returned with Justin’s hoodie in her arms filled with the smaller grains of fine pumice from the other side of the river.
Her pink, burned skin from losing control of her own fire back at the university campus made Sammy wince as if the stinging pain was her own.
Chloe dumped the pumice next to where Sammy sat beside Justin before jumping back down and returning with another load.
Sammy wondered how Chloe had the energy to do this but then noticed Chloe’s eyes were heavily dilated.
“Are you using the grass?”
Chloe looked over her shoulder at Sammy while shaking the clinging pumice off Justin’s hoodie at the edge of the flat rock.
She then returned and sat next to the fire.
“I felt like I was going to pass out, so I had to.”
“At least we have a fire now.
We’ll worry about food first thing tomorrow.”
Chloe crawled over and evened out the pumice.
They were both exhausted and decided to sleep.
Sammy lay closest to the fire with Justin in the center and Chloe against the far wall of the crevice.
The two of them huddled as close as possible to Justin to keep him warm throughout the night, locking their legs together with his and wrapping their arms around him.
Sammy then pulled his hoodie over them as a makeshift blanket, but it only covered their torsos and barely at that.
Justin would freak if he knew that two practically naked women were holding him in his sleep, she thought.
Sammy imagined his flustered and possibly angry face as her exhaustion lulled her to sleep.

* * *
A chilling wind that brushed Sammy’s back made her snuggle closer to the warm body that heated her stomach.
Her legs entwined themselves in the ones beside her and forced out a single leg that was also hooked around them for warmth.
That leg’s owner shifted at first and became still after a slight grunt, but not before pulling the sole thin cover to her side.
A stronger chill now struck Sammy’s shoulders and side.
It caused a shiver to run down her spine, and her groggy eyes peeled open.
Her vision was dark and blurry but soon found slight focus on the man’s face beside her.
Sammy shot up with a start.
The rise and fall of Justin’s chest showed he was still breathing.
She placed her hand on his cheek and then forehead.
He was sweltering.
The fever had grown worse overnight.
She was no expert in estimating temperatures from touch, but he had to be a degree or two above one hundred.
She pulled up his shirt to check the wound with the light of her phone and found the skin flushed pink and red around the burn.
A few white blisters had grown near the edges overnight, and his abdomen was swollen.
It looked infected, but she did not know what to do.
She bit her lib and looked around futilely for someone or something that could help.
She wanted to call out for help but knew it would be no use, not this far in the middle of nowhere.
Instead, she knelt in the bed of pumice and grasped Justin’s shirt.
She buried her face in the crumpled fabric that smelled of dried blood and prayed.
“God, please…”
Sammy had used the name of god as a curse ever since she was a child, a habit she gleaned from her mother, but this was the first time she had earnestly prayed to a divine being for a miracle.
The pouch.
A single thought grew in Sammy’s mind, spoken in a voice that was not her own.
She reached over to the small pouch next to their now dry pants and pulled out the vial that smelled strongly of herbs.
Why was a soldier carrying a pouch full of vials of herbal liquid?
Was she an archer and that was poison to tip the arrows?
Or was it something else?
Was it a salve?
Her eyes flitted between the vial and the swollen wound.
The risk was too high to use it unknowingly, but if it could help, she wanted to make use of it.
She uncorked the vial, and the fumes made her cough and reel back.
She held the vial at arm’s length and plugged her nose.
The smell caused Chloe to stir and then wake.
She looked over Justin’s shoulder with one eye and saw Sammy place her finger over the small opening of the vial, shake it, and then place her finger on her tongue.
Her eyes opened wide.
“What are you doing?!”
Chloe yelled.
Sammy’s face contorted in disgust.
The flavor was foul beyond foul.
She corked the vial and fought to hold back her tears.
After a minute to collect herself, she managed to speak.
“I was thinking.” She coughed once more.
“Damn it… God, that tastes awful.”
Sammy winced and shook her head to collect herself again.
“I don’t think that this is a poison, but just in case, I wanted to test it before using it.”
“What if it is and you get sick?!”  Chloe rebuked.
“I don’t think I can take care of both of you!”
“If it’s a poison meant to kill someone, like for an arrow or something, then it should work fast.
I think… I feel fine, and aside from the flavor, my tongue is not reacting to it.”
Chloe looked at Justin’s red and swollen wound.
She realized what Sammy was thinking.
“A health potion?”
“Something like that.
I will wait an hour, and if I am fine, then I’m going to pour it on Justin’s wound.
It might help.
If it does nothing, then we are no worse off.”
“Not drink it?”
“Drink it?”
Sammy looked at Chloe quizzically.
“Well, in fantasy books and games and stuff, health potions are supposed to be drunk.”
Doubt grew on Sammy’s face.
“Unless it was some kind of antibiotic that can go through his system, I don’t think drinking it would help much.
Using it directly would probably be best.
If not, we still have the second one, and I won’t use it all at once anyway.
I’ll give it an hour.”

Realizing that the liquid might be safe if ingested but toxic if it entered the bloodstream, she made a small nick on her arm with the sword, much to Chloe’s bewilderment, and applied a little of the liquid to it.
Sammy retrieved her phone.
The battery showed 12%.
Soon she would not be able to make use of it.
When she checked the time, she saw that they had slept for 14 hours.
The sky was still dark but not like midnight.
The indigo color showed the sun would rise soon.
The nights were long.
“Let’s look for some food.
It’s been almost a day since we’ve last eaten, and Justin will only get weaker if he doesn’t eat anything.”
Sammy watched Chloe crawl over Justin.
She immediately removed her shirt and bra and handed her bra to Chloe.
“You need it more than I do.
The size is all wrong, but it’ll be better than nothing.
They hurt, right?”
“Yah,” Chloe said after retrieving the bra.
“Makes me wish I was as small as Eydis, or at least as light.”
Sammy helped Chloe slip it on.
The band just barely fit on the last hooks, and even then, it was tight.
Chloe was a few sizes bigger than Sammy, but so long as she did not move too quickly, it would hold.
Chloe rubbed and stretched her aching shoulders.
“Thanks.
If you want it back, just ask.
We can trade off using it until we find or make some proper clothing.”
There was no civilization anywhere to be found, and being forced to survive for a prolonged period of time in this massive forest was a real possibility.
If that was the case, Sammy feared Chloe was right, that they would have to make clothing and other necessities.
The search for food continued through the remainder of the hour with no success.
They traveled a ways down the river and now had to make the trek back to the thin line of smoke rising in the distance from their camp.
“We could try nibbling on the leaves to see what is edible,” Sammy suggested.
“Eating random plants would be far more dangerous than you testing that liquid on yourself.
Most plants are not safe to eat.”
“On Earth, that might be so, but here…”
Sammy was growing desperate.
Chloe had more knowledge of the outdoors, so she trusted in her judgement, but Sammy could also tell that Chloe was growing weaker at a far faster pace but was trying hard not to show it.
Sammy’s eyes were drawn to the cliff face to her right and the veins of pumice that coursed through it.
At some places, the pumice was a bubble in the rock, but for most of the cliff, it ran in thin lines.
As she admired the strange geology she had never seen before, she saw a small piece of pumice crumble from a thin vein.
Chloe noticed something slender appear briefly and then disappear into the vein.
Sammy and Chloe looked at each other and hurried across the pumice to the river.
Chloe paid no mind to the freezing water and crossed to the other side.
She placed her ear against the small hole from where the pumice fell.
“Something is moving inside.”
Chloe tried to look in, but there was no light.
She lit her hand on fire and placed her palm against the hole.
You can’t be serious, was all Sammy had time to think before Chloe shot explosive fire into the hole.
Pumice and hot smoke shot out from the vein all along the cliff face.
Mixed in with the large chunks of pumice were three long and slender creatures.
They resembled a white weasel but were skinnier with long, thin ears.
One of the creatures was unharmed by the explosion and scurried away along the river, but the other two were dazed with one singed.
They began to move.
Chloe threw another fireball at them.
When it exploded, it launched them both over the river.
One was immobile, but the third tried to run.
Sammy rushed after the injured creature and severed it in half with the sword.
Chloe waded back over the river and picked up the singed one while Sammy grabbed both halves of the other.
It was a mammal.
That much was certain.
It had little meat on it, but food was food.
They carried them back up the river and kept an eye out for any more falling pumice.
To their grave disappointment, they found none.
When they returned to the shallow cave, Sammy checked her self-inflicted cut.
The skin no longer stung and had sealed together.
She tried to spread the cut apart, but it wouldn’t.
“Chloe!
It is a healing potion, or whatever you called it!”
Sammy dropped her dead weasel and hurried to Justin’s side.
She uncorked the vial and gently poured half of it over Justin’s wound while rubbing it into the skin.
Content with the amount she used, she re-corked the vial and placed it back into the pouch with the other.
Only time would tell if external application would help.
While Sammy helped Justin, Chloe worked on prepping the rodents.
“We’re supposed to gut them, right?” Chloe asked.
“You know more about these things than I do.”
“I’ve never hunted anything.”
“And I have?
I’ll trust whatever you think is right.”
Chloe frowned but nodded.
She used the tip of the sword to cut into the belly of the long rodent and pulled out the innards.
The amount of meat on it was small.
She then grabbed one of the thinner dry sticks she had set aside and impaled the rodent on it in a zig-zag pattern so that its body folded twice over itself.
She then held it over the fire to cook and burn all the fur off.
The rodent shrunk little by little as it cooked.

A lot of air and juice crackled and fizzed from the searing meat, and by the time Chloe felt it was cooked enough to safely eat, the bones were very pronounced, and the rodent was half its former size.
Sammy finished wiping Justin down with her water magic and shirt, taking care not to wash off the herbal liquid, and looked at Chloe’s finished product.
She scrutinized it with a furrowed brow.
There was hardly any meat there.
“Did you burn it?”
Chloe shook her head.
“None of it looks burnt, I don’t think.”
She set aside the cooked animal and set the two halves of the second on two more sticks.
Chloe handed one of them to Sammy with eyes stating, “You do better.”
Sammy grabbed the stick and began roasting the upper half of her rodent.
There was hardly any smell to it, and it did cook rather fast.
She watched as air and juices fizzed out of the meat as it cooked, and eventually it looked just as shriveled as Chloe’s but slightly burnt in a few places.
She could only sigh.
“You take the whole one.
Justin and I will eat half,” Sammy said.
“We should split it evenly,” Chloe protested.
“No.
I know you aren’t doing well.
You’ve been using far too much fire magic without eating anything.
You need it more than we do.”
“What about Justin.
He needs to stay healthy to heal.” Chloe said.
“I’ll… take the… half.”
““Justin!””
Sammy and Chloe set down their skewered meat away from the fire and rushed to Justin’s side.
His eyes only opened a sliver, but he looked at them with a grin.
“How long… was I out?”
“Almost a full day.
Well, Earth day,” Chloe elaborated.
“Then, this… is not… Earth?”
Light excitement sprung up in Sammy’s chest.
If Justin was coherent enough to catch the meaning in Chloe’s words, then he was not as far gone as she had originally thought.
She felt his forehead and hers.
His fever was still high.
Only about a half hour had passed since she applied the potion, but already the skin around the wound was less pink, and the blisters noticeably shrunk.
However, the swelling had not gone down.
She began palpating the wound as gently as possible, but even light touch caused Justin to wince.
“Sorry…Yah, I think we might be on Whinhlem,” Sammy explained further.
“We are in the middle of a massive forest, and there is no sign of anyone anywhere.”
Justin closed his eyes and exhaled a weak sigh.
While Sammy and Justin talked, Chloe used the tip of the sword to scrape the meat off the bones of the rodent and then broke them into smaller pieces.
She set them on a flat rock she heated in the fire earlier to kill any microbes that might have been on it and handed it to Sammy.
“Can you eat?”
Sammy moved behind Justin and lifted him up just enough that his shoulders rested against her legs.
She then propped up the back of his head with her hands.
Sammy provided water for Chloe who used her fire magic to create a thin broth with the meat in her hands.
“Careful.
It still might be a little hot,” Chloe warned.
Justin opened his mouth, and Chloe tipped her fingers over until the thin broth trickled in.
He coughed at first but was able to drink it down with the meat.
This continued until all the meat on his half of the rodent was gone.
During this, Sammy was scraping the meat off the bones of her half with her teeth.
“There really is not much here…” Sammy mumbled.
“You sure you don’t want some of mine?”
Chloe held up her stick.
“No.
You need it more,” Sammy rejected again.
“Eat it,” Justin ordered.
Chloe looked at Justin’s weak smile and finally bit in.
They informed Justin of everything they had seen or discovered while he was passed out, including the size of the forest, the strange bubble grass, and the potion they used on him.
Justin listened quietly until they finished.
“We can’t stay here,” he finally said.
Sammy nodded.
She was thinking the same, but they did not have the energy to travel far in such high gravity.
The food they just ate would help, but they needed to find more.
It would not sustain them.
“I guess we can find food on the way.
We know what to look for now.
The animals live in the rocks.”
“We should think of a better way to carry him too,” Chloe added.
Sammy opened and closed her hands.
Her forearms, shoulder, back, legs, all of her was sore from carrying Justin, and no doubt Chloe was sore too.
“What should we do?”
“We could make a stretcher from some branches and the hoodie,” Chloe suggested.
Sammy readily agreed, but the hoodie would not be enough fabric.
“We’ll use my shirt too.”
They immediately set off with the sword to scour the forest for long straight branches, at least as straight as they could find.
They knew such a hunt would be difficult with how the branches intertwined with each other.
Sammy had to remove her pants and shoes and have Chloe warm her up after crossing the freezing river, but she was beginning to become accustomed to the chill, or at least able to endure it.
They found two branches surprisingly quick, thick as a broom handle and low enough to reach.
Every branch on every tree had kinks and bends.
The two straight branches almost looked artificial, but after chopping them off with the sword, Sammy knew they were part of the trees.
At the riverside, Chloe retrieved the hoodie from Justin and then helped Sammy slip the clothing through to create a makeshift stretcher.
When retrieving Justin, they left their pants and shoes on the other side of the river so that they would not get wet.
Justin glanced at the two women in their underwear.
Chloe at least wore Sammy’s bra.
He quickly closed his eyes.
Sammy smiled at Chloe who grew bashful.
“You know, given the situation we are in, we don’t care if you look,” Sammy teased.
“I lost a lot of blood.
I don’t need one part of me hogging whatever’s left.”
Sammy stifled the laugh that nearly leaked out and shook her head.
“If you can joke like that, you’ll be fine.”
There was no change from the last time she saw it, so she expected the medicine had done what it could with the amount she used.
She knelt next to Justin and inspected the wound.
She retrieved the used vial from the pouch and lightly rubbed the remaining liquid onto the wound and around the skin.
Justin was still rather hot to the touch, which was cause for worry.
If his fever was not subsiding, then she could not say he was truly healing.
Fevers are meant to fight infection and disease, right?
So maybe…
She wasn’t sure.
Once Sammy finished, she noticed Justin staring into her eyes.
She realized she had been making quite a face because Justin’s eyes spoke a nearly audible, “I’m alright.”
Sammy took a deep breath and nodded to Chloe to say Justin was ready to carry out.
He winced and nearly cried out in pain with every slight movement of his core.
This was another telling sign that Justin was still in terrible condition despite his assurance.
They crossed the river and set Justin on the stretcher.
Sammy checked her phone and found that it had died.
She should have turned it off when she wasn’t using it, but there was nothing she could do now.
She tossed it into the river.
It had at least made a useful clock while it had power.
Sammy crouched down at the front of the stretcher, and Chloe grabbed the back.
They worried that in the increased gravity, Justin would be too heavy for the branches, but they supported him.
They bowed just enough that their movements were cushioned and did not shake Justin too much.
The fabric held as well, but Sammy’s shirt stretched under the weight of Justin’s butt.
They took frequent breaks at Chloe’s request, and she spent most of them lying in the pumice with her eyes closed.
The forest, river, and rising cliff face looked the same no matter how far they traveled, at least at first.
Sammy initially thought it was her imagination, but after about six or seven or eight hours of walking--she was not quite sure how long without her phone--the cliff had dropped to half its height.
The river in turn doubled in width and was now too deep to cross.
They traveled a greater distance on their first day, but without eating anything substantial, they were quickly running out of energy.
The sun was high in the sky, which helped warm the air, but the wind kept its sharp edge.
Sammy felt they would have to stop soon, but in order to do so they needed to find shelter again.
“A little further.
If we don’t see anything, we’ll have to camp under the trees.”
Chloe nodded.
She was shaking, so Sammy knew that they were at their limit.

After about a half hour longer of agonizing travel, the river bent softly to the left but then made a sudden sharp turn where the cliff, now about the height of Sammy, made almost a perfect right angle.
The cliff ended and sloped to meet the pumice riverside only a few yards later.
Excitement welled up in Sammy’s chest, making it tingle.
In the distance, the forest cleared.
“Look!”
Sammy could not see Chloe’s reaction, but Chloe’s voice showed similar excitement.
“A lake?”
The river met a body of water.
The full size of it could not be seen from their distance, but there was an island in the center, and trees lined the far side.
They did not know if they would find anything at the lake, but the difference in the nearly unchanging forest was a breath of relief and hopefully a blessing for them.
Their pace increased ever so slightly, and they reached the lake before stopping for the day.
The lake was about 200 yards wide and about 400 yards long.
Like the river, the bed at the edges was nothing but pumice and pumice sand.
The water was so crystal clear that the bottom of the lake was visible.
Much to Sammy’s disappointment, there were no fish or vegetation where fish could hide in the lake.
In the center, a small island no wider than ten yards poked above the water.
It contained one lone tree that stood twice the height of the trees surrounding the lake.
Sammy and Chloe sat Justin down on the pumice near where the river met the lake.
Like each previous break, Chloe immediately laid down on the pumice.
“Chloe, can I have the other vial?”
Without opening her eyes, Chloe reached to her side and removed the potion from the pouch.
Sammy grabbed it and sat down beside Justin.
“You still alive?”
Instead of speaking, Justin only nodded.
He had been vocal three breaks ago when he told them he had to pee, and Sammy had no choice but to help him, but after that, he remained silent.
Sammy touched his cheek and found that his fever increased yet again.
She pulled up his shirt and saw faint red lines that looked like veins extending out from the wound.
The infection was worsening.
She palpated the wound, and Justin writhed weakly in pain.
Tears grew in the corner of his eyes, which hadn’t happened when she touched the wound before.
We need to get help immediately or he’ll…
Sammy bit her chapped lip to distract her from the pain stabbing at her heart.
She tried to push the worries of Justin’s health to the back of her mind, but they kept eating at her from the dark crevices they lurked in.
She took a deep breath to regain control of her emotions and uncorked the vial.
“Sorry…”
Her heartfelt apology was both in warning against the rubbing she would need to work the fluid into the skin and because of her inability to do more to help.
Justin endured the application of the medicine but passed out soon afterwards either from pain or the exhaustion of their travels.
Sammy lifted him up enough to slide the hoodie out from under him.
She then laid it over him to provide him a little shelter from the wind.
“I’m going to explore the lake,” Sammy announced.
Chloe gave a shaking thumbs-up.
Walking around the lake confirmed Sammy’s initial observations.
There was no life in it, thus no food.
The forest surrounding the lake was no different than the forest leading to it.
It was just as dense with the exact same plants.
If they could not find any wildlife, then they would be forced to start sampling plants to see what was edible.
Aside from the forest trees that could provide some cover, there was no natural shelter near the lake.
The only thing that caught Sammy’s attention was a large cavern at the bottom of the lake on the opposite side from the river.
Because there was no outlet for the lake on the surface, the water likely drained underground.
Their plan of following the river ended here.
Sammy finished walking around the lake and stood on the opposite side of the river from where Chloe and Justin lay.
“Chloe!
Can you get a fire started?!”
Chloe raised another thumbs-up and then rolled to her stomach.
By the time Sammy made it back around to them, Chloe had gathered a few sticks from the nearby trees and was stacking them.
“There’s not much dry wood here.”
Chloe’s voice was weak, but she continued working and conjured a weak fire in her hand.
She then placed her hand under the stacked wood.
The fire burned well, so Sammy drug Justin near it and sat down to rest.
“I know you are weak, but I will need your help.
I want to climb to the top of the tree in the middle of the lake,” Sammy said.
“I’m getting used to the water, but it’s still too cold for me to handle.”
“I don’t think I have the energy to swim across with you,” Chloe replied, apologetic.
“No, I will do that on my own and climb as fast as I can.
When I get back, I will need you to warm me up immediately.
The water is so cold I will probably only get about 20 minutes before I pass out.”
“Are you going to be able to climb in that state?”
“I’ll use the grass again.
It might help.
If I can’t climb it, I’ll swim back.”
“It’s too dangerous…”
“We need to find out where we are.
That tree is the perfect opportunity.”
Without waiting for Chloe’s consent, Sammy stripped naked and walked to the edge of the lake with Chloe close behind.
“The grass,” Sammy asked.
Chloe handed Sammy a single blade of the bubbled grass.
Sammy crushed it and inhaled deep.
After a few coughs, Sammy stepped onto the water.
She immediately moaned out her stupidity.
There was a use of water ven she learned from Eydis that was perfectly suited for crossing the lake.
She had planned on propelling herself across as fast as possible, but she may not even need to get wet.
Sammy channeled water ven into her feet and stepped onto the surface.
Her feet stung as if she was stepping on ice, and they slid just the same or worse.
She had difficulty standing and hopped back onto the shore.
She had practiced a little with her hands and setting her feet on the water at the edge of the pool in her swim class, but she had no practice walking on water.
She coated her hands and knees in water ven and inched out onto the water.
Her core tightened in order to keep her legs and arms from spreading out, and they shook under her increased weight.
Submerging the tips of her feet into the water, she coated them with water ven just enough to reject the water and propel her forward.
Sammy glided inch by inch across the water.
Why didn’t I think of this earlier?
Chloe wouldn’t have had to use so much of her energy warming me up.
The chill of the water crept up her arms and legs, but it was tolerable and no different than the cold winters back in Gullivan.
Foot by foot, she moved slowly across.
Her hands and feet grew numb, which increased the difficulty of not only staying upright but also propelling herself forward.
When Sammy reached about a third of the way, her right hand slipped, and her face hit the water.
The shock of the cold broke her concentration, and she slipped beneath the surface.
The bitter cold assaulted her like diving into a bed of needles.
She could not find strength to breathe, and her mind was so numb she could not concentrate enough to swim back to shore.
In panic, she flailed in the water as if she had forgotten how to swim.
She thought she heard a voice screaming her name, but it felt distant like a whisper.
Only a single thought floated in her mind.
“I’m going to drown.”
The thought that this might be her end calmed her panic as if accepting her fate.
Although she could not feel her arms and legs, she was floating.
The increased gravity had no effect on her buoyancy.
She opened her eyes and saw the island an impossible distance away.
How long had passed?
Five minutes?
Her consciousness was already fading.
The water was colder than she expected.
Can I still make it back to shore?
Sammy turned in the water and saw Chloe only a few feet from her.
Chloe’s eyes were heavily dilated.
She reached out her arm and latched onto Sammy.
Powerful warmth surged into her from their contact.
She resisted the urge to panic again and cling to Chloe, potentially dooming them both, because Chloe was already struggling to stay afloat in her lack of energy.
Together they worked to swim back to shore.
Sammy’s frozen legs could barely support her, but Chloe managed to lead her to the fire.
She was also naked and wrapped herself around Sammy to further increase their warmth.
How many times had Chloe saved her now?
Sammy was supposed to be the water mage, but she couldn’t do anything in the water.
Chloe with her fire affinity could have better swum to that island.
Sammy clung tight to Chloe.
“Sorry… I’m so useless…”
Chloe released Sammy before she had even warmed up enough to feel her fingers.
She was still wet, so the wind chill increased her shivers despite the nearby fire.
Chloe staggered over to the edge of the lake.
She can’t be…
Sammy worried that Chloe had somehow heard her thoughts, or perhaps she voiced her worried thoughts without realizing.
“You can’t swim that far in your condition!”
Chloe did not respond.
A flame lit in Chloe’s hand and grew larger and larger.
The heat dripped from it as if it was a viscous fluid and lit small flames on the pumice.
She reeled her arm back and threw the fireball.
Every few yards, the fireball popped, spitting droplets of fire into the water below and propelling it onward.
It collided with the base of the tree and erupted in a massive explosion that set the base of the tree ablaze.
The fire climbed its way up the tree and sent up a column of black smoke into the air.
Sammy’s jaw fell slack in amazement.
That fire would be a beacon to anyone or anything in the area.
They were already too weak to travel in this gravity.
Their only hope was for someone to come to them.
Satisfied, Chloe turned and walked back towards Sammy and Justin, but after a couple steps, her left leg buckled.
Chloe fell face-first into the sand.
Sammy scrambled over the pumice on her numb legs to Chloe and rolled Chloe to her back.
She pulled at Chloe’s shoulders, but she was too heavy to move in Sammy’s numb and exhausted state.
She hurried back to their clothes and grabbed the pouch for the grass to either give her enough energy to pull Chloe back to the fire or give Chloe enough of a boost to wake up.
When she opened it, she gasped.
There was no grass left.
When they gathered it, Sammy was sure they had about two dozen blades.
To Sammy’s count, they should have only used half of it so far.
Where did the other half go?
A poisonous fear crept into Sammy’s heart.

When they first left their cave, Sammy was going to take the back of the stretcher so Chloe could have a turn walking in front, but Chloe declined, stating that because Sammy was bare chested, she should walk in front out of respect for Justin.
But, what if she wanted to stay out of Sammy’s eyesight?
Each break they took, Chloe would keep her eyes closed.
As they continued traveling, Chloe never looked Sammy in the eyes and always had them closed or turned away when she was near.
She was hiding her eyes.
Chloe was already at her limit after using her fire magic so much.
Her ven was sufficient, but conversion of raw ven to fire ven required the body’s nutrients, its energy.
Sammy knew Chloe was not eating enough to sustain her use, but she did not realize just how bad off Chloe became.
Chloe had used her fire ven unsparingly to help them escape the university, and it even went out of control.
She used it in their fight at the hospital.
Now in Whinhlem, she used it to warm Sammy, keep herself warm, dry them off, start fires, and more.
Sammy relied heavily on Chloe’s magic as if it was an infinite resource, but it wasn’t.
When Chloe’s energy ran out, she said nothing to Sammy and instead relied on the boost the grass gave her to power through.
“GOD DAMN IT!”
Sammy ran back to Chloe and pulled her with all her strength.
Chloe’s limp body slid inch by inch over the sand until she reached the smaller pumice pebbles where dragging became easier and laid her near Justin by the fire.
There were now two bodies too weak to move.
Sammy was the only one still functional, and she had no hope of being able to drag both of them through the forest.
She had no hope of finding food.
Justin’s potion would be gone after the next application, and it did not seem to be helping with the infection beneath the skin.
“We aren’t going to make it.”
Sammy cradled her knees to her chest and stared at the burning tree in the middle of the lake.
The black plume rising into the sky was her only sliver of hope.

Chapter 4
 “The Guardian of the Forest”
Sammy
The sun fell below the verdant horizon, and with it, the temperature.
Sammy spent the past few hours combing the forest for dry wood and branches she could cut in order to stockpile enough wood to survive the cold night.
They had no cover or shelter this time, and with Chloe still unconscious, they would not have her extra heat, just the natural warmth of her body.
Even if Chloe was conscious, Sammy doubted Chloe had the energy to keep up her high temperature throughout the night.
Their small camp looked less like a beach and more like a snow fort.
Sammy piled the white pumice of the lakeside in a circular ring about three feet high surrounding the fire.
Chloe and Justin laid on its inner edge far enough from the fire to keep them from growing too warm.
For Justin with his high fever, hyperthermia was constantly on Sammy’s mind, just as much as hypothermia.

Sammy walked inside the small opening facing the burning tree, which was now mostly a tower of smoldering embers, and dumped her final batch of branches and sticks; final not because she felt it sufficient but because she no longer had the energy to gather more.
Her arms shook so much she could no longer hold the sword steady.
She barely had enough grip strength to hold the sword at all.
Her stomach felt like it was twisted in a knot both from being empty and because she nibbled on a piece of the large-leafed plant found on the forest floor.
It was not safe to eat, and even the small piece no larger than her thumb almost made her vomit.
In the end she ended up chewing on the white wood under the bark of the branches.
That alone did not make her sick, and it would hopefully provide some nutrients.
The wood was mildly sweet, which provided shallow comfort against her bitter reality.
The night was restless.
Sammy feared to fall into too deep a sleep.
In the middle of the night, she tried waking Chloe to no avail and used the last bit of the potion on Justin.
She leaned against the side of the pumice pile and watched the tree on the island smolder.
She was amazed that the embers never went out.
It continued to glow like a beacon, and the light almost appeared to spread further than was natural.
She fought her heavy eyelids and weary headache until she no longer had the strength.
Something woke Sammy with a jolt.
It felt like a slap in the face by a tiny hand, but when she looked around, no one was there.
The sun had risen just above the canopy and was sending golden rays through the partial cloud cover.
Chloe and Justin were still on the ground beside her.
She hurried to check Justin.
He was still breathing.
His pulse had not weakened, but the infection was visibly worse.
The entire wound was red, and the veins had spread further.
Justin’s fever was now so hot that Sammy worried he would die of the fever before the infection.
She doused him with water from her hands to cool him, and the light steam wafted up in the cool morning air.
She then moved to Chloe and found her breathing comfortably.
Chloe was not ill, but Sammy still believed she lacked the energy to do anything but rest.
About three Earth days had passed.
“We might only have a day left…”
Sammy included herself in that statement, but she was more referring to Justin.
Chloe would be fine once they located food.
In the back of her mind, a thought rose.
If Justin died, traveling would become much easier, and they might make it to civilization.
What am I thinking!
She remembered a similar thought back at the university when they were trying to escape from Jethro’s soldiers.
She thought about running then and leaving the collapsed Chloe and Justin behind.
Is this the kind of person I am?
She was both disgusted and furious at her own thoughts.
“I will not abandon them.”
Sammy ran out of the camp carrying the sword to circle around the lake and head back up the river to find more food along the shallow cliff.
She did not have the explosive power of Chloe, but if she was lucky, she might be able to flood one of those long and slender rodents out.
Unlike Chloe, she could manage the resources needed for her magic using her magic, so long as she kept the balance right and did not dehydrate so much that she could no longer conjure more water.
The moment she exited the camp, she was met by a girl about equal to Chloe in height.
She exuded the youthful beauty of a girl on the cusp of adulthood, slightly younger in appearance than Sammy.
If Sammy had to guess, the girl might have been 17 or 18 years old.
Her dark blond hair was about shoulder length and longer in the front than in the back, sitting just above her nape.
She wore nothing more than a skirt made from the matt-brown fur of some animal and held a staff in her left hand.
They both looked at each other in surprise.
Sammy was about to fall to her knees in relief but was startled by the girl’s expression.
That youthful face contorted in a pure and unadulterated malice.
She raised her staff and charged.
Sammy could only think of one reason why the girl would be so angry, the tree on the island.
It was strangely majestic in its near perfect placement.
Perhaps it had some significance to the natives of the area.
She dropped the sword and prostrated herself on the ground.
“I’m sorry about the tree, but we needed help!
Please!”
The crunch of feet racing over pumice slowed and stopped in front of Sammy.
She did not dare look up at the angry native but instead pleaded again.
“Please.
My friends are sick and injured.
We don’t have any food.”
There was no way someone from this world would know English, so she spoke one word in the only language she could think of, Elven.
“Please…”
The staff impaled the pumice an inch from Sammy’s face.
She started in surprise but did not move.
The tip of the staff grew thick roots that wrapped around Sammy’s neck, bound her arms, and rolled her to her back.
They tightened around her neck until pressure built up in her head.
The girl stood above her.
The fury in the girl’s eyes remained, unaffected by Sammy’s pleas for help, and her mouth spread in a menacing grin.
She was enjoying Sammy’s suffering.
Sammy’s mind raced to find some way to appeal to the girl who was clearly trying to kill her.
She looked at the girl’s blue eyes and her ears that looked the same as Eydis’s.
She was a High Elf.
The girl was standing right beside Sammy, so Sammy could just see part way up the girl’s fur skirt.
Two long, slender tails hung low.

Sammy recalled at lightning speed in what felt like her dying moments the stories Eydis once told her of the young High Elf girl who was taken in by her father as a wife because of the girl’s two tails.
“It can’t be… Ceil…?”
The girl’s eyes widened.
The staff broke off at the roots in a sharp point.
She raised the staff to plunge it down into Sammy.
The breaking of the roots eased some of the pressure on Sammy’s neck.
She took a quick breath and shouted with her eyes closed.
“I know Eydis FeAmel!”
The tip of the staff-made-spear stopped just above Sammy’s neck.
Tears fell and a whimper broke from Sammy’s throat.
“I know Eydis FeAmel…” she repeated.
The girl circled to Sammy’s side and stepped on her neck.
The spear remained pointed at Sammy’s face.
“You lie.
Eydis is dead.”
Sammy could not breathe, not from the foot pressing on her neck but from the shock of the first person she found in this foreign world speaking English.
The pronunciation was slightly off, but her words were unmistakably English.
“Who are you?
Why do you know the language of the sprites?”
Something about what the girl said pinged a memory deep within Sammy’s mental archives, but it was so buried that she could not pull it out.

All she knew was that it was something she heard from Justin a few days after she met Eydis, or it might have been during her first meeting with Dr. Shuman to talk about the minum that was hit by a trucker outside of Gullivan.
Either way, now was not the time to be distracted.
This High Elf spoke English.
She could communicate with her.
And most important of all, High Elves had a natural affinity to life magic.
She could heal Justin.
“It is the language of my home,” Sammy forced out through the tight pressure on her neck.
“Eydis lived there with me.
Jethro found us, and I think Eydis teleported us here to help us escape.”
The girl’s expression softened for a moment but then went rigid.
“Eydis would not live with humans!
You lie!”
The tip of the staff pressed into Sammy’s neck, and she felt the sharp tip puncture the skin followed by a burning pain.
“Who are you?!
Why are you here?!
Did Jethro send you?!”
“No!
Please,” Sammy pleaded through her tears.
“I don’t care what you do to me, but please, at least save Justin and Chloe.”
“Why should I save the life of humans?
Humans killed my family…” Ceil’s lips quivered.
“You humans took Eydis from me!”
The staff pressed harder into Sammy’s neck and dug deeper into the skin.
Sammy cried out, but with her arms bound, she could not stop her.
“Please!
Eydis is alive!
She was my friend!” Sammy pleaded.
“Lies!”
“She told me about you.
You were like a younger sister to her.
You hated living in the palace.
You did not like her father, the Emperor.
You gave names to all the palace hounds.
You preferred the bitter black bread from your hometown over the white bread of the palace.
You once stole a cake from the kitchen and shared it with the maids.
You love the color purple.”
Sammy rattled off everything she had heard about Ceil from Eydis despite not knowing if this girl was Ceil.
If she wasn’t then Sammy would die, but Eydis mentioned that having two tails was extremely rare, and so a High Elf with two tails who knew Eydis had to be Ceil.
The staff shook in Sammy’s neck, causing even more pain, but the burning subsided, and it was retracted.
Sammy opened her eyes and saw an emotion that was difficult to describe.
There was fear and bewilderment, and hidden inside the complicated expression was joy clashing with disbelief.
“You lie.”
The girl’s accusation no longer held the same strength.
“I am not lying.
I was with Eydis until a few days ago, but Jethro found us.”
Ceil shook her head.
“Why?
Why would Eydis live with humans?
Humans are our enemy.
You are our enemy!”
Ceil pointed her spear at Sammy.
“We are not with Jethro!
He is my enemy too!”
The spear froze.
“Jethro attacked my city.
So many people died…
He killed women and children too.”
Ceil stared off into nowhere.
Her mouth quivered in fear as if recalling a horrifying memory, something she had forgotten or desperately wanted to forget.
She retracted the spear and backed away in shock.
“Please.
Jethro hurt Justin.
Eydis loves him, and he got hurt trying to save her.
He’s going to die!”
Ceil shook her head.
“Eydis loves a human?
There are humans who protected Eydis?
Jethro attacked humans?”
The cogs in Ceil’s mind were visibly jamming.
“You are… Are you truly a friend of Eydis?”
“Yes,” Sammy cried.
Ceil walked over and touched the roots binding Sammy with her staff.
The roots became brittle, and Sammy broke free.
Ceil jumped back in case Sammy attacked, but Sammy only sat up and held her bleeding neck.
Ceil made no attempt to aid Sammy, but Sammy did not care.
She ran to the camp.
“Please help us.
You can use life magic, right?
Justin will die if he does not get help!”
Ceil followed with caution and peeked over the circular wall surrounding the remnants of the campfire.
Sammy pulled up Justin’s shirt to reveal the red and swollen wound on his abdomen.
“Jethro did this to him.
Can you help him?
You can use life magic, right?”
“This man is… Eydis’s… lover?”
Sammy did not know the full nature of Eydis’s relationship with Justin.
She saw them kiss, but Eydis refused to discuss her feelings about Justin.

Because Eydis seemed to enjoy the affection Justin gave her and even reciprocated it, Sammy felt she could answer in the affirmative; however, she was confident that Justin had not slept with her because of her own personal experiences dating Justin for a year.
Whether that meant they were actually lovers was up for debate.
Then again, if she debated on that ground, what then was the year she spent with him?
“Yes.” A small sinking feeling of regret pricked Sammy’s heart.
It felt like jealousy, but she knew she had no reason to be jealous.
She was the one who broke off their relationship.
“They became lovers just before Jethro showed up.
Eydis was hurt by Jethro’s assassin, so we tried to save her before Jethro could find her.”
Sammy recounted the events leading up to their arrival in this world but left out the details about Earth that would make the story hard for Ceil to follow.
Ceil’s caution ebbed enough for her to feel comfortable entering the camp, and she knelt next to Justin.
“Life magic has three schools.
Healing is the first.
Disease or death is the second.
I am of the third school.
I can control plants.”
The color drained from Sammy’s face.
“You can’t heal him?”
“I can use the other two schools as well, but I am not skilled.
Eydis is very talented with them but has trouble controlling plants.
She can make them grow, but that is all.”
After speaking, Ceil’s eyes fell away into another memory.
“If you can do anything, please,” Sammy begged.
Ceil reached out a reluctant hand to palpate the wound and then placed her hand on it.
She concentrated for a moment and then retracted it.
“There is bad blood under the skin.
We need to remove it.
Grab the sword.”
Sammy ran out of the camp and picked up the sword.
When she returned and handed it to Ceil, Ceil held the tip in the embers of the nearly dead fire and then let it sit to cool.
Ceil braced the side of the sword with one arm and slowly drove the tip in by the edge of the burn.
A stream of foul-smelling yellow pus flowed from the wound.
Ceil pressed lightly around the wound, and more drained from the cut.
“You saw the wound swell.
Why did you not drain it?” Ceil asked.
Ceil spoke as if draining the infected wound was common knowledge.
Sammy’s heart sunk into her nauseous stomach.
“I don’t know anything about healing people or injuries.
I didn’t know…”
“You did not know to drain the wound, but you know how to make medicine?
I can smell it.”
Sammy grabbed the pouch and pulled out an empty vial.
“I grabbed this from one of Jethro’s soldiers.
I did not make it.”
Ceil smelled the bottle.
“This medicine is made from beiju root.”
“Beiju?”
Ceil stopped pressing on the wound and looked at Sammy in disbelief.
“Beiju grows everywhere, all over the world.
It is a very common but weak herb.
It has a large leaf and thin stem.
It is all over this forest.”
The plant that made Sammy ill.
“The medicine comes from its roots.
It is best when aged but can work fresh.
Everyone knows of beiju.
Even animals dig it up to eat when hurt.”
Sammy’s heart sank further.
Medicine was all around them, but she did not know it.
She had less common sense than even the animals of this world.
“I will show you.”
Ceil walked away from the camp and into the nearby trees, returning with an uprooted, large-leafed plant.
She broke off the stalk on the way and only held the bulbous root.
She then rinsed the root in the river and brought it to Sammy.
She stared at Sammy, but her eyes lingered lower on Sammy’s neck, and the corner of her mouth twisted downward.
“Cut it in half and place the open side on the wound on your neck,” Ceil ordered.
Sammy did as instructed and felt a burning sting.
Ceil returned to draining Justin’s wound.
“I cannot heal the bad blood.
I can only heal the cut and skin and speed the natural healing, but that is… dangerous right now, especially with me.
Most of the bad blood is gone, but it will return.
He needs a better healer.”
“Is there somewhere we can get help?”
Ceil shook her head.
“The nearest village is many, many days away.”
“Justin will not last that long!”
“Feed him a little beiju.
It will help.”
“That’s right! Food!
Is there anything here that we can eat?” Sammy pointed to Chloe.
“She used so much fire magic that she collapsed.
We haven’t eaten anything.”
Ceil thought for a moment.
“There is little food up here.
Beiju is toxic if you eat too much.
You need to go down to the valley.”
She walked over to Chloe and placed her hand on Chloe’s forehead.
Chloe woke with a jolt but struggled to sit up.
Her eyes inspected the High Elf girl, and a tearful smile grew on her face.
“Someone came?”
“This is Ceil, Eydis’s friend from back in Amel.”
Hearing the best news possible, Chloe reached out to embrace Ceil but was pushed away with incredible force.
Ceil took two steps back.
Her breathing was ragged and her eyes were wide with fear.
“Do… do not touch me.”
Without saying another word, Ceil rushed out of the small camp.
Sammy dropped the beiju root.
“Ceil!
Wait!” she called, but Ceil only picked up pace.
Chloe looked at Sammy with eyes that asked if she had done something wrong, but then she noticed the wound on Sammy’s neck and the dried blood.
“How did you get that black mark?
What happened?”
Sammy brought her hand to her neck.
“It’s nothing.
Ceil thought we were enemies at first.
I’m fine.”
She hurried after Ceil.
Ceil was already making her way around the lake.
When Sammy called again, Ceil slowed.
Her feet did not sink into the sand and pumice as much as Sammy, so Sammy had to run to catch up.
“Please take us with you.
We don’t know anything about this forest or where to go for help.”
Ceil stopped.
Her hand gripped her staff with white knuckles, and a menacing aura radiated from her.
Sammy recoiled by instinct.
“I helped you in case you truthfully are friends with Eydis, but I will do no more.
I cannot know for sure if you are Eydis’s friends or not.
You could be doing this to capture me.
What you told me you could learn from torturing servants in the palace,” Ceil’s hand gripping her staff quivered, “or torturing Eydis.”
Sammy extended her hand but stopped.
The aura increased in intensity the moment she was about to speak in her defense.
“I hate humans!” Ceil shook.
“I hate them all!
They are the most disgusting, evil race ever created by the gods!”

Sammy knew that humans were capable of terrible, terrible atrocities, and she did not know enough about Elven culture or history to know if Elves were capable of or had committed similar atrocities to those that humans had committed in Earth’s history.

Even on a lesser and more personal level, those who professed to be Sammy’s friends in grade school had taken advantage of her naivety and ignorance because she was the sheltered daughter of a rich family.

When she finally convinced her parents to let her head out and experience life on her own after high school, her first coworkers gossiped behind her back, claiming that she was promoted to management after only a month because she was sleeping with their womanizing supervisor.
One of the first men she dated had coerced her into giving away her virginity when she was too scared to deny him.
The last man she went on a date with was half a step away from raping her there in his car and then proceeded to stalk her when she refused to contact him.
The defense class she attended with Eydis, Chloe, and Miriam was for the sole purpose of giving girls the tools to defend themselves against those with evil intentions.
Humans had the potential to be truly vile creatures.
“Not all of us are like that,” Sammy said.
Sammy’s parents sheltered and protected her.
They loved and cared for her and provided everything they could so that Sammy could be happy, even giving in to Sammy’s selfish request to go to a public high school and live on her own.
Her first true friend she met online, Jessica, provided a place for her to live in Gullivan.
When Jessica graduated and got a job at Sammy’s family company at Sammy’s request, Sammy moved to the girl’s dorm and met Chloe.
Chloe was so pure and innocent.
She only saw the good in people.
Then there was Justin.
He was flawed and prone to mistakes, but he never hesitated to help people even when that help wasn’t wanted.
His tenacity in trying to comfort Sammy after a recent breakup was what led her to dating him, even though he turned her down multiple times at first.
After they broke up, Justin never changed.
He took in Eydis, and even though there was a very real danger in associating with her, he ignored it and did everything he could to support her.
Humans had the potential for evil, but they also had immense potential for good.
“When Eydis came to our city, she was scared.
Just like you said, humans are your enemy here, and only humans live where I am from.
After Justin took her in, that fear never left.
When he tried to find a place for Eydis to live, she broke down.
She did not want to leave.
She wanted to stay because the humans she lived with were kind, and she did not know if other humans would accept her the way we had.”
The aura of hatred emanating from Chloe ebbed slowly.
“The Amelian Empire is at war with the Tolmyur Kingdom, but Chloe, Justin, and I… we are not from Tolmyur.
We do not hate the elves.
I love Eydis.
She is my best friend in the whole world.”
Tears welled up and fell from Sammy’s eyes.
Bitterness rose in her throat and made her jaw tremble.
“I hate Jethro.
I hate him.
Eydis did nothing to him or to Tolmyur, but he still tried to kill her.
When he found her, when he found us, Eydis sent us here.
She chose our safety over her own.
I don’t even know if she is okay.
I don’t know if Jethro killed her or if she escaped or anything.”
Sammy fell to her knees.
Her weary head fell limp as she cried.
“I’m worried sick about her!
I want her here with me.
I want her safe.
She sent us here.
She should know how to get here, right?
I keep praying that she would show up, that she would appear out of nowhere… I…”
Footsteps approached in the pumice.
Ceil knelt in front of Sammy and dropped her staff.
One hesitant hand reached out and touched Sammy’s trembling shoulder, and her other arm slowly wrapped around Sammy’s head.
Ceil pulled Sammy into a light embrace.
Sammy’s face nestled into Ceil’s collar bone.
Ceil was trembling just as much as Sammy.
Anger radiated from Ceil, but it was no longer directed at Sammy.
“Jethro took everything from us,” Ceil said, seething.
A wave of relief washed over Sammy, and she cried uncontrollably into Ceil’s shoulder with her tears running down Ceil’s chest.
The fear and anxiety that Sammy tried to keep bottled up spilled out in Ceil’s arms.
Ceil believed her.
She not only believed, but she had also gone through the same fear and loss because of Jethro.
Just as Ceil did not know if Eydis was alive after Jethro’s attack, Sammy did not know either.
Ceil could sympathize with Sammy.
The two held each other until Sammy was able to calm her emotions.
She sniffled and took a deep breath before separating herself from Ceil.
Ceil looked into Sammy’s eyes, the sun reflecting in Ceil’s oval irises.
“I will take you with me.”
Sammy hugged Ceil again.
“Thank you.”
Ceil shook her head.
“No.
I would be no better than those humans if I left Eydis’s friends to die.”
There was lingering animosity in Ceil’s words.
Her opinion of humans had not changed, but Sammy was grateful that she was able to at least accept her.
“Travel will be difficult.
That man and… Chloe?
They are too weak, especially him.”
“If we eat something, that will help Chloe.
Chloe and I can carry Justin.
We have over the past two days.”
“Carrying him will be dangerous, but there is no other way.
Follow me.”
Sammy followed Ceil into the forest.
They gathered the bulbs of a few more beiju.
Ceil removed her skirt and gave it to Sammy to carry them.
Sammy was amazed by Ceil’s tails.
The skin was smoother than Eydis’s and they were each over three times the length and perfectly even.
They swayed with every slight motion of Ceil’s hips.
It was mesmerizing to watch and mildly seductive.
Sammy began to understand why long tails could have such sex appeal to the elves.
A question came to Sammy’s mind when one of Ceil’s tails swung and hit a tree, causing Ceil to shiver lightly.
“Can elves control their tails?”
Ceil was surprised by the seemingly random question and placed her hand at the base of her back where the tails sprouted as if becoming self-conscious.
“No, we cannot control them well.
Forest Elves have more control, but long tails get in the way.
Shorter is better.”
Sammy recalled Chloe’s complaints about her breasts.
Larger breasts had sex appeal on Earth.
There were odd parallels.
Ceil held her fist back to stop Sammy.
She then crept forward and placed her hand on the trunk of one of the trees.
A few seconds later, that same long and slender rodent shot up from the ground entwined in roots.
Ceil grabbed it and twisted its neck before tossing it onto the fur skirt Sammy held.
“Hopefully we can find two per person,” Ceil said.
“Chloe has a fire affinity.
She needs to eat more,” Sammy argued.
“If she does not use fire magic, she will not need more, but if we find more, she can have the extra.”
Their silent hunting continued.
Sammy was unsure how Ceil knew where the rodents were.
When she asked, Ceil explained that she was concentrating on any small vibrations she felt through her bare feet from something moving underground.
They found nine rodents this way before returning to camp.
The critters were far more populous than Sammy had realized.
Sammy laid their haul on the edge of the pumice pile and returned the skirt to Ceil who would not enter the camp with a man present unless she was covered, even if the man was unconscious.
She pulled the skirt up and fastened it around her waist with the leather ties in the back.
The skirt was just long enough to conceal the tips of her tails.
Chloe watched longingly as Ceil and Sammy prepared the meat.
Ceil only removed the stomach and intestines of the rodents before setting them near the coals to cook.
“If musdel meat grows too hot, it loses too much moisture,” Ceil explained.
“The juices are healthier than the meat.
Cook it only enough to eat.”
There was little risk of overcooking with how far Ceil placed the musdel from the coals, but the fur would not burn off either.
“Do you eat it with the fur?” Sammy asked.
“The skin dries first.
It peels off easily when the meat under it is cooked.
You cannot skin it without losing too much meat.”
Sammy trusted the expert and watched intently how Ceil periodically rotated the musdel to cook it even.
If she couldn’t help Chloe and Justin with her knowledge from Earth, she was determined to learn everything she could about surviving on Whinhlem.
While the food cooked, Ceil retrieved Sammy’s discarded half of the beiju and cut it into long, thin strips with the sword.
She placed one of the strips in the blades’ deep fuller and set it over the coals.
After a minute or so, it began to sizzle, and Ceil removed it to cool.
Once cold enough, she removed the strip and tipped the sword so that the liquid in the groove ran down the blade and dripped into Justin’s mouth.
“It will help his blood,” was Ceil’s only explanation.
Sammy wished that Eydis was here instead.
Justin would be healed.
There was no doubt in her mind.
But then she berated the thought.
That was ungrateful.
She needed to be thankful.
There was no point in focusing on what Ceil could not do.
She was already helping them when it benefitted her nothing.
“This one is ready.” Ceil picked up a musdel by its now shriveled ears and tossed it to Sammy.
Sammy was starving but reluctantly handed it to Chloe.
The next would be finished soon.
There were two per person including Justin if they could find a way to feed him.
The single extra went to Chloe.
When Sammy wondered how to go about feeding him, Ceil placed her hand on Justin’s forehead.
His body twitched, but he did not wake like Chloe had.
This did not alarm Ceil.
She began eating her musdel after pulling off the fur using the ears as if it were the burnt skin of a roasted marshmallow.
It slid right off, dripping with oils.
Ceil returned her attention to Justin every few minutes while they ate.
Each time she placed her hand on a different part of him, he twitched but did not wake.
This worried Sammy more and more.
Chloe woke on the first, but after eight, Justin still hadn’t.
If he didn’t eat, he would not recover.
Healing magic relied on the body’s resources to heal, and it could not heal more than the body alone was able, according to Eydis.
“Is he going to wake?”
Sensing the worry in Sammy’s voice, Ceil gave an assuring nod.
She pointed to different points on her head and chest.
“There are wells of energy in the body at different locations.
Activating them can temporarily increase vitality and the flow of ven in the body.”
Ceil drew lines with her finger from point to point, and the movements looked very familiar.
They nearly matched what Eydis taught in her self-defense class.
When Chloe was first able to feel the ven in her body, Eydis had Chloe follow those motions to move the ven around to her hand.
The order was different, but Ceil still hit many of the same points.
Sammy repeated the motions she learned from Eydis, although sitting instead of standing.
Ceil watched with amazement.
“Eydis taught me this.
It’s how I first learned to control my ven.”
Ceil smiled.
“These well points are something taught among elves for training or use in medicine, something we learned long ago from Bydrofe, the Guardian of Whinhlem.
Most races do not believe in them, or if they do, they ignore them or have other methods.”
In other words, Sammy would have had to learn it from an elf.
She would not have learned it as a human of Tolmyur.
This was further evidence that Sammy knew Eydis.
Ceil continued activating Justin’s well points throughout the day, and Justin finally woke by the time the sun was setting.
Sammy tried to introduce Ceil, but he was not coherent enough to understand her.
With great difficulty they fed him and then let him sleep again.
By the time the sun set, Chloe was able to stand and walk around, but she was still weak.
Ceil offered to wait with them one more day before heading out.
Now that they had some meat in their stomachs, Ceil added small amounts of beiju to their meals.
When grilled over a fire, the root tasted like asparagus, but it left a numbing feeling in Sammy’s mouth.
The following day, Chloe was as active as Sammy, so Sammy returned her bra to Chloe.
They gave Chloe the largest portions of the food, because her fire magic would be useful.
Ceil was surprised that not only Chloe but also Sammy became hungry rather quickly.
Ceil could make do with two or three light meals a day, but Sammy and Chloe needed five or six.
Sammy and Ceil had to travel deeper and deeper into the forest to find enough food.
The meat was simply not that filling.
It was spongey and juicy but had little substance.
Beiju was heavier, but they could not eat too much of it without becoming sick.
Sammy and Chloe were just barely managing.
It felt to Sammy like snacking lightly throughout the day without ever eating any substantial meal, hardly sufficient to sate her hunger.
Justin woke up again around midday, so they were able to feed him, but like the first time, he was not coherent.
His fever had decreased after Ceil drained the wound, but it returned in full force by evening.
They could wait no longer.
“We leave at first light tomorrow,” Ceil announced.
They spent the rest of the day preparing.
They caught a few more musdel and anchored them underwater in the lake to preserve them until morning.
When Sammy and Chloe were reassembling the stretcher with Sammy’s shirt and Justin’s hoodie, Ceil stopped them.
She touched the branches, and root-like shoots sprouted from them and intertwined with each other to create a mesh hammock.
Sammy and Chloe were both amazed, and Sammy was glad that she would no longer have to walk around shirtless.
She was not embarrassed showing her skin.
The wind was simply cold.
Night fell and then morning came.
While Chloe and Sammy chatted idly, Ceil leaned the stretcher against the pile of pumice and sat in it to assess its strength.
She nestled in and after a moment and nodded.
“Is it comfortable?” Sammy asked.
“Do you want to try?”
Sammy walked over and pulled Ceil out.
She then sat in and leaned back.
The roots dug into her back and legs a little, but it was tolerable.
One of the roots snapped and then another.
Sammy shifted a little, and then the mesh broke.
“How much do you weigh?” Ceil asked in bewilderment.
“You should not be much heavier than me.”
Ceil was taller than Sammy by half a foot and had tails, but she was also thinner and nowhere near as endowed.
All things considered, their weights should not have been that different by appearance alone.
Sammy stood and looked at the destroyed stretcher.
She couldn’t even apologize.
If anything, she was grateful it had broken when she was in it instead of Justin.
She knew she was heavy in this world.
Ceil was not aware of the difference between people of Earth and those of Whinhlem, and Sammy avoided stating that they were from another world.
“Justin is heavier than me.
It wouldn’t have held him.
Can you fix it?”
“Not with those branches,” Ceil explained.
“They have no life remaining in them.
I used it all to make the net.”
Just like with healing, life magic could not create growth beyond the nutrient levels of the plant, and those branches were cut from their trees two days ago.
Sammy sighed and picked up the sword.
“I broke it, so I’ll chop new branches.”
“Wait.” Ceil followed Sammy and left Chloe in the camp to watch Justin and the fire.
They reached the edge of the forest where Ceil placed her hand on one of the trees.
Two parallel branches began to grow.
Thick roots sprouted between them and knotted together.
Unlike the mesh from before, the woven roots looked more like a coarse fabric than a net.
The trunk where Ceil placed her hand turned black.
Ceil quickly retracted her hand, almost fearful.
She was shaking and sweating.
Sammy recognized the symptoms.
“How much ven did you use?”
Ceil sat down and took a few deep breaths as she looked up at her work.
“I do not have much ven, and growth uses a lot.
Controlling that growth uses even more.
That took all the ven my body would give me.
I dared not go further.”
Sammy got to work chopping the branches off the tree and together they carried the new stretcher back to camp.
Using Chloe who was heavier than Justin, they made sure that the stretcher was strong enough to carry him.
There was still plenty of life left in the branches, so Ceil could further strengthen or repair the stretcher if needed when she recovered her ven.
They pulled the frozen musdel from the lake, set Justin on the stretcher, and departed.
Ceil led the way with Sammy holding the front of the stretcher and Chloe in back.
They walked to the far side of the lake where Sammy found the underwater cave and turned to enter the forest.
Like the rest of the forest, the trees were close together.
Sammy was sure she would have gotten lost without a direction.
“How do you know where to go?” Sammy asked Ceil.
“The ground is cooler where the river flows underground.
Your odd footwear prevents you from noticing.
If we go in the wrong direction, the ground warms.
I am simply following where it is cold.”
“Where does the river lead?” Chloe asked next.
“We will only be following the river until we reach the cliff.
You will see.”
Sammy trusted Ceil’s sense of direction.
After all, Ceil had found her way to them through the forest.
“We are nearly there.
Do you hear it?” Ceil asked.
Sammy and Chloe looked around and sharpened their ears, but they did not hear anything more than the wind through the trees.
“Elves must have better hearing than humans,” Chloe replied.
“You will hear it,” Ceil reassured.
Sure enough, after a few more minutes of walking, Sammy heard rumbling.
It sounded like flowing water but much more forceful.
She could not figure out what the sound was, but then Chloe figured it out.
“A waterfall!”
The dense forest grew lighter, and the trees thinned.
Sammy could only see sky in the slivers of light through the tree trunks.
When they exited the forest, Sammy had to make a conscious effort not to drop Justin.
Her mouth held slack, and tears fell from her eyes.
Before her was a scene that could only be described as paradisiacal.
The forest appeared to extend on forever when Sammy peered through the branches of the tree she climbed days ago, but what she had assumed was the horizon was actually the edge of a massive plateau.
Several other perfectly flat-topped plateaus covered with a layer of green trees towered hundreds and hundreds of feet from the forest floor.
None of them were quite as tall as the one they stood on, and a few in the distance had collapsed and lay in heaps on the valley floor.

A waterfall cascaded down the cliff from their plateau about twenty feet below them, and similar waterfalls fell from the other plateaus into rivers that snaked through the densely forested valley, their mist creating rainbows in the morning sun.
Unlike the trees that coated the tops of the plateaus in a near perfect layer of green, the forest of the valley contained a wide variety of different shades and shapes.
Huge mossy vines stretched between the tallest trees.
The largest of which that appeared sturdy enough to walk across had plants growing along them.
The trees that flooded the forest valley splashed up onto the bases of the plateaus as if attempting to climb the steep slopes.
Small patches of grassland dotted the forest, and specs of wildlife could be seen moving in them.
“Welcome to Fiorrae, land of the wind sprites.
The sprites gave me stewardship over this forest as its guardian.” Ceil stabbed her staff into the ground and sat down near the edge of the cliff after removing the tied musdel from her shoulder.
“We break here.
You will need your energy climbing down.”

Chapter 5
 “A Bet with the Wind Sprites”
Sammy
“Are we really going to have to climb down?” Chloe sat furthest from the cliff.
When her eyes shifted towards the edge and out into the open expanse, they shot back to the dirt at her feet.
“Are you afraid of heights?” Sammy asked.
“I’m not… well… A little, yah.”
This was something Sammy had not known about her friend of two years, although they had no opportunities for her fear to show until now.
The tallest building on campus was twelve floors, but Dr. Shuman’s office was only on the seventh.
If she stuck to the halls, she would not need to look out a window.
Of course, being indoors would be more comfortable than standing on a thousand-foot or higher cliff.
“We will not be climbing straight down,” Ceil explained, much to Chloe’s relief.
“Although, that would be faster.
Your cargo makes that option impossible.
We will follow fissures along the cliff side.
We should be able to reach my hut before sunset.”
Sammy gazed out at the sister plateaus and saw dark, thin, zig-zagging shadows along the cliff faces.
They looked not all too dissimilar from the cracks filled with pumice on the short ridge running along the river only on a far grander scale.
If they were visible at this distance, they would be large enough for someone to walk in.
Such large fissures of pumice would drastically weaken the stability of the plateaus, and that may have been the reason some of them collapsed over the ages.
“Although I say that,” Ceil continued, “the nearest fissure is still a short distance down the cliff, so we will need to climb down at least that much.”
“You’re kidding, right?” Chloe grew horrified.
Ceil’s eyebrows furrowed.
“Do I have any reason to lie to you?”
Chloe glanced once again at the cliff’s edge but immediately looked back at the ground.
She shook her head and whispered, “I can’t…”
Ceil sighed.
“The roots of the trees near the edge make climbing down far easier and faster, but if you are absolutely against it, the fissure should reach the surface not too far from this waterfall.”
The tension holding Chloe rigid released, and she collapsed into her lap with a heavy exhale.
“Thank goodness.”
The roar of the waterfall sounded faint in the distance.
They followed the edge of the plateau for what felt like two hours or maybe three.
Ceil brought them to a large crack in the ground that was big enough for a grown person to slide into without much trouble.
“This is the entrance.
It is small here, but it grows larger on the inside.”
Ceil climbed down first, and with a nimble hop, she disappeared from view.
Sammy was next.
She sat down and hung her legs into the crack.
Inching forward, she slid inside.
“Wah!!”
There was a sudden drop of about five feet.
The impact jarred her knees, and she stumbled forward into Ceil who was crouching to keep her head from touching the top of the crevice.
The crevice was only about four and a half feet tall.
To their right, the crevice opened into nothing but air only a few feet away.
So long as Chloe did not look to the right, Sammy felt there would be no problem.
“Send Justin next!” Sammy called.
Chloe slid Justin into the crack, and both Sammy and Ceil worked together to lower him down.
The stretcher then followed.
After they finished, Chloe slid herself in.
Sammy forgot to warn her about the sudden drop, so Chloe fell with an even louder shriek than Sammy, and Sammy had to catch her to keep her from stumbling into Justin.
“That was not so bad, was it,” Sammy said with a chuckle.
Chloe clung to Sammy with tight, sweaty fingers.
Sammy ignored the pain of Chloe’s grip and smiled, enjoying this new side of her friend.
“Take the back.
I’ll stay in front.”
After prying Chloe off, they picked up Justin and followed Ceil back in the direction of the waterfall.
The rock was flat yet course and provided good traction.
The inside of the crevice to their right was a wall of pumice as Sammy expected.
It was the same as what she saw along the river.
By the time they crossed under the waterfall, the size of the crevice increased to about ten feet high and six to eight feet wide.
The trees atop the plateau grew closer to the edge near the waterfall, and their roots fell like a tangled blanket over the edge so thick that little mist passed through.
Chloe was able to walk comfortably behind their shield against the open air.
Sudden drops in the crevice appeared a few times, but each drop was no more than three to five feet, and with how large the crevice was, jumping down and lowering Justin was simple.
“Glad we don’t have to climb?”
Sammy looked back over her shoulder at Chloe who kept her eyes on her feet now that they passed the waterfall and root barrier.
Chloe did not answer, and Sammy chuckled again.
The crevice reversed direction switching back under them, which meant that there was a larger drop than any previous.
Ceil slid down the fifteen-foot slope of eroded pumice on the inner side of the crevice and beckoned Sammy to slide down next.
After a deep breath, Sammy placed her back against the pumice and inched to the side.
Once the strong gravity took hold, she shot down the rocky sand and into Ceil who caught her before she could slide out the crevice into open air.
Following the same routine, Chloe slid Justin down followed by his stretcher, leaving her alone at the top.
“It’s not that bad, so long as we catch you before you fall to your death.”
“Sammy! You’re not helping!”
Chloe stepped out but quickly retracted her foot.
She sat down and leaned into the pumice but quickly scooted away.
Her hesitation repeated over and over again.
Each time, Chloe would look down at where Ceil and Sammy stood and saw the hundreds of feet of open air where the edge of the crevice ended.
“This is pathetic,” Ceil spat “Move that man away.”
Ceil gripped her staff and shot up the pumice wall with incredible speed, stabbing her staff in to increase leverage and traction.
When she reached Chloe, she grabbed Chloe’s arm and yanked her down.
Chloe screamed the entire slide.
Due to the combined weight of two people, they did not stop sliding until about a foot from the edge.
Ceil used her staff to brake or they would have easily slid over.
Chloe scampered towards Sammy and leaned against the pumice on the inside of the crevice.
Ceil breathed an exasperated sigh.
“We can take a short break.”
Descending the plateau took what felt like five or more hours.
The constant breaks not only to help Chloe collect herself but also to give her and Sammy a rest from carrying Justin drastically increased the time Ceil presumed they would take.
Chloe was able to breathe a sigh of relief when the leaves atop the first tree popped up from the cliff-side.
After another hour, the slope of the cliff was shallow enough for them to step out into the forest.
Unlike the top of the plateau, the trees here were large, broad-leafed, and spread well enough apart that two of Justin’s stretchers could fit lengthwise between them.
Large, moss-covered boulders littered the ground, some as large as a house.
This created beautifully picturesque scenery any direction Sammy looked that she could imagine being used for postcards or calendars, but the uneven ground made carrying Justin difficult.
The calls of various animals that Sammy had never heard floated among the trees with the faint breeze.
Not far into the forest, Sammy noticed a single large bird looking down at them from the low branch of a tree.
It was similar to a four or five foot tall hawk but with cobalt-blue, almost tropical looking plumage that had a slight metallic sheen.
Two long, jagged yellow feathers sprouted from its head and ran down its back.
The way it cocked its head and widened one eye at Sammy’s quizzical gaze almost hinted at an advanced level of intelligence for an animal.
At least that was what it felt like to Sammy.
“Do not do anything to annoy those birds,” Ceil warned.
“They think this forest is theirs, and they will gather numbers to run you out or kill you if they feel you mean trouble.”
“What are they called?” Chloe asked.
“I am not sure.
They might not have a name.
You can ask the wind sprites when we arrive.
I was planning on resting here, but there are four of them watching us.”
Sammy looked back at the strange bird and bowed her head lightly.
The bird bowed back and smiled, or what Sammy could only think was a smile.
The feathers on the sides of its head rose slightly.
Could birds smile?
While Sammy pondered whether human emotion could even be applied to birds, the large bird raised its wings and shot up through the canopy in one powerful flap.
Sammy felt the gust created from its ascent and then four more as the other birds left.
“There were five?
I could only see that one,” Sammy said.
“They are smart enough to keep out of sight.
They know me and must have been curious of you.
If they disliked you, we would have been in trouble.
I could probably fight off two of the smaller ones, but five would be impossible, especially with the two-plumed one here.”
“Are they that dangerous?” Chloe asked.
“They can use wind magic,” Ceil explained.
“Now that they’re gone, can we take a break?
My back is killing me,” Chloe whined.
“I could use one too,” Sammy said but then changed her mind.
“No, I can go longer.
If you want to switch with Chloe, we can keep going.”
“I would rather not carry him,” Ceil said.
“We will rest.”
