At the next clearing with soft underbrush, Sammy and Chloe sat Justin down.
While Chloe leaned back against a boulder to rest, Sammy helped Ceil check up on Justin.
Some of the swelling went down now that the wound had been drained, but the surface did not improve.
Ceil walked away for a moment and returned with a beiju root.
She cut it with the sword and placed the cut end on top of the wound.
The other half was diced and boiled by Chloe, and then slowly dripped into Justin’s mouth.
“You really can’t heal him with your life magic?” Sammy asked.
Ceil shook her head.
“I can only trust using healing magic on myself.
My skill in healing is no better than what beiju can do, and it might end badly.”
Ceil glanced at Sammy’s neck.
“If I had to pick one, I would use beiju and save my ven.”
Sammy gritted her teeth in frustration.
“How much longer is it going to take to get him help?”
“You could always leave him behind.
I cannot guarantee he will survive until you find him help.”
“There is no way I could do that.”
Ceil shrugged.
Her indifference to Justin’s life rubbed Sammy wrong, but Sammy could not say anything against her for it.
After all, Ceil was helping treat him.
Once Chloe said she was ready to continue, they set off.
They quickly reached a river running through the valley and followed it downstream.
“We should reach my home by nightfall at our current pace,” Ceil said with mild annoyance.
After a few more hours of walking, they stopped to rest.
Ceil bent over the river’s edge and drank from her cupped hands.
Chloe did likewise, and Sammy could only stare in awe.
“How can you drink that water?
It’s way too cold,” Sammy said.
“Cold?” Ceil looked perplexed, but then her eyebrows raised when the realization hit her.
“I have been living here for a time, so I do it out of reflex.”
Sammy was about to ask what she was doing, but Ceil continued.
“The water was the same for me at first.”
“At first?
And you can handle it now?
Did you just get used to it?
I’ve been having Chloe heat it for me or creating my own water to drink.”
Ceil looked over at Chloe.
“You’ve been heating it this whole time?
I assumed that because you are more skilled with magic you would have realized.”
“Realized what?” Now Chloe was confused.
Both Sammy and Chloe pressed Ceil for an explanation.
“I would have thought that recognizing ven would be the first thing Eydis taught you.”
“She did.
We learned to recognize our ven,” Sammy said.
“No, not your own ven, the ven in nature,” Chloe clarified.
Sammy recalled Eydis’s explanation of how ven could be found not only in people but also in the air, plants, animals, and even rocks.
“Everything in Fiorrae is saturated with ven, which makes it different than what you would find outside the forest.
The trees and ground have odd characteristics.

Although I would not like to admit it, I could only create the bed you are carrying that man in because the trees have much more life in them than normal, and the saturation makes that life easier to manipulate.
I could not have created that outside this forest.
I am not that strong in life magic yet.”
Sammy’s eyes shifted to Justin.
That was why she could manipulate the trees to that extent but couldn’t heal him.
“Then that water?”
“Yes, the enriched water is colder than ice but does not freeze because of the ven in it.
For someone with a water affinity, absorbing the ven would make it safe to drink.
I cannot use water magic, so I replace the ven in the water with my own, forcing it out.”
After hearing Ceil’s explanation, Sammy crawled to the river’s edge and lifted out some water with her cupped hand.
The water was freezing cold as expected, and the longer she held it, the number her hand became.
She did not know how to absorb ven, but she did know how to infuse her ven into something.
Sammy recalled her training with the cotton balls where she was instructed to infuse them with ven without her ven making them wet.
“But if I do that normally, I will repel the water.
If I infuse it with the goal of keeping it wet,” Sammy thought out loud.
Slowly the water in her hand warmed.
She sipped it from her hand and did not feel any chill, but with that small amount of water, there was no way to tell if this was because of her own ven or her body heat.
She cupped a larger amount of water with both hands and tried again.
The water warmed in an instant, but it still felt like a refreshing ice-cold glass of water.
“Can you drink it now?
If not, I’m still fine with heating it for you,” Chloe offered.
“Nah, I got it.
Ceil, thanks for the explanation.”
Ceil shook her head.
“Why is this forest so saturated with ven?” Chloe asked.
Ceil rotated her hand back and forth in an unfamiliar gesture.
“I am not sure.
All I know is that the sprites live here because it is saturated.
They are a race of elementals, and elementals only live in ven-rich environments.”
Ceil stood and removed her staff she had impaled in the ground.
Having witnessed it a few times now, Sammy noticed a few small roots break off the staff.
“Are you ready to go?”
The sun setting on the horizon painted the huge plateaus jutting from the forest in an amber glow.
Their shadows stretched over the valley and darkened the river Sammy, Chloe, and Ceil followed.
When the ground became almost too dark to see, Ceil deviated from the river to a small grassy field.
A thin trodden path led through the knee-high grass, and soon the grass changed to purple, feather-like flowers that were beginning to curl up and close their pedals for the night.
The forest at the end of the field was unlike the earlier forest they had traveled.
It appeared well kept, almost as if the location of every plant was meticulously chosen, and there were no dead leaves or stray twigs.
It reminded Sammy of a well-kept garden rather than a forest.
Finally, a small hut that looked as if it had grown from the forest floor came into view.
“This is where you live?” Sammy asked.
Sammy and Chloe looked around them and admired the fantasy-like garden home.
Ceil paid them no attention.
Her eyes scanned the area with worry.
When she found what she searched for, she frowned.
“Do you think I am the kind of person who would let you keep some stray animal you brought home with you?”
Sammy looked around to find the origin of the smooth tenor voice, but there was no one.
“I have my reasons,” Ceil replied.
“Reasons?
We gave you stewardship of our forest because we cannot be bothered with menial tasks, but the forest is still ours, is it not?”
Ceil’s eyes followed the bodyless voice as it circled Sammy and Chloe and stopped on Justin’s stomach.
She remained silent.
“We felt the presence of intruders and sent you to take care of them, and this is not the care we intended.
I do not assume you misinterpreted our orders.”
Ceil’s countenance fell, and her shoulders slouched.
“And humans, no less.
Are humans not your enemy?
Do you not hate them?
Did they not kill Eydis and destroy your home?”
“Eydis is still alive!” Sammy shouted at the unknown, invisible voice and immediately felt an immense pressure weighing down on her.
Both she and Chloe collapsed to the ground, dumping Justin off the stretcher behind them.
Tears fell from Sammy’s eyes from being overpowered by a single pure emotion: dread.
Some unknown force clouded her mind, constricted her body, and bound her tongue.
“I did not give you permission to speak,” the voice rebuked.
“Stop!
They are different!
They are friends of Eydis!” Ceil pleaded.
“Oh?”
The pressure slacked a little, but Sammy was still unable to move or speak, and the slight relaxation of her core caused her to vomit what little was in her stomach.
Seeing this, Ceil pleaded stronger.
“It is true!
They were with Eydis fighting against Jethro before they were separated,” Ceil explained.
“And what if that story was fabricated?
The humans have subdued our neighbors, the dryads to the east and Mountain Elves to the south but have yet to get a foothold in our forest.
Could this not be an attempt by them to infiltrate and capture you?”
Ceil gritted her teeth and fell silent.
She had no solid evidence that what the invisible voice said was false, and Sammy could not speak in defense of herself, Chloe, or Justin.
“However, I do trust your judgement.
We would not have made you steward of our forest if we did not.”
A small glint of hope rose on Ceil’s face.
“But we cannot have you ignoring our orders either.
We too need to be cautious and make certain that you have not been manipulated by the humans.
With the dryads under human control and so close by, you could have been made to believe these humans by a kissiae draught.”
“I am not--” Ceil’s voice cut off for an unknown reason, and Sammy was unable to look up to see why.
“I will have you prove to us you are not under their influence.
You will kill the loud one.
She is not important in what is to come.”
Kill me?
Sammy’s heart sank, and the chill of death sent shivers down her spine.
She could not look up to see Ceil’s reaction, and Ceil’s silence worried her even more.
Was she considering it?
In Sammy’s position, she could not resist any attempt on her life.
Please, no…
“Does it have to be Sammy?”
Relief washed over Sammy, but then the weight of Ceil’s question struck her.
“Can I kill the man?
He will not survive anyway.”
No! Not Justin!
“Mercy killing?
What would that prove?”
“Then…”
Not Chloe either!
Please, if you need to kill someone, kill me… please…
“Attack that girl, and you will not remain unscathed.
You cannot treat severe burns with your skill in healing,” the voice said.
Sammy’s eyes shifted over to the ground where Chloe hunched over.
The groundcover wilted, and embers grew where Chloe’s arms touched the soil.
“The loud one is your only option.”
Again there was silence.
The voice did not speak or push Ceil into a decision.
Sammy could only wait, and the silence continued for what felt like an eternity.
In Sammy’s heart she prayed for mercy but if a life needed to be taken then it would be hers.
“I refuse,” Ceil answered.
“Even if that means exile?
We cannot have one who sides with the enemy continue to live in our forest.”
“I am not of your forest.
You let me stay here until I could collect my thoughts and emotions.
I am fine now.
I will not kill Sammy.”
The weight bearing down on Sammy lifted.
Her heart, body, and mind ached, and in the relief that flooded her, she broke into sobbing.
Ceil knelt in front of her, and Sammy lunged at Ceil.
She wrapped her arms around Ceil’s neck, and they both fell back onto the ground.
There Sammy cried into Ceil’s shoulder, thanking her over and over again.
“She truly is a loud one.”
The invisible voice no longer held an antagonistic tone and was now more playful.
“If you were willing to kill this human, then we would know you have not yet recovered and would need more time to be prepared for your role.”
Ceil’s hand stopped rubbing Sammy’s back.
“This was not to prove my loyalty to the sprites?”
“Not at all.
It was a test of your mental health.
But, we are still going to exile you.”
Ceil sighed as if this result was expected.
Sammy’s hands balled into fists.
She lifted herself off Ceil and looked in the direction she heard the voice.
“You staked our lives on some test?!”
“No, just your life.”
The voice no longer sounded as if it was next to Sammy.
It played in her mind like a foreign thought.
This surprised her, and by a hunch, she replied through thought.
Does my life mean nothing to you?
“Both the Master of Time and the Aspect of Destruction have important roles to play.
You on the other hand are unimportant.
If Ceil decided to kill you, it would have been no major loss.”
Sammy spat out some of the vomit lingering in her mouth and swiped her arm at the air in front of her.
“Show yourself, coward!”
“Sammy, you cannot talk to the Sprite Arkhon that way!”
Ceil covered Sammy’s mouth.
“Please forgive her.
She has been through a lot.”
“Oh, it is no problem at all.
If anything, I should commend her courage, or foolishness, in lashing out at me after feeling my power firsthand.
Even you swatted at me when we first met.”
“I did not know who you were, and I was in a much darker place then…”
“No matter.
You are all tired from travels, so we will prepare a sendoff feast.”
“So you really are going to exile her?”
For the first time, Chloe spoke up from behind them.
When Sammy looked over her shoulder, she saw that Chloe had been preoccupied patting out the embers she unintentionally created.
“Ceil will accomplish nothing by staying here,” the Arkhon said.
Sammy peeled away Ceil’s hand.
“We do not need a feast.
Please, help Justin.”
“I already told you that the Master of Time has a role to play.
We will not let him die under our watch.
Relax.
He will be fine for an evening.”
You keep talking about roles.
Roles in what?
“After all you have been through, can you still say you do not know?”
Something to do with Jethro invading and searching for Eydis?
“Wash up.
We will take care of preparations in the meantime,” the Arkhon said.
“Answer me, damn it!”
Ceil quickly covered Sammy’s mouth again.
“I am sure they will watch over Justin.
The sprites are strict, but they are a kind race.
They will not leave him unattended.”
Sammy groaned through her nose and let Ceil lead her and Chloe behind the hut to a small, ground-fed spring of crystal clear water.
The area was illuminated by orange and yellow phosphorescent flowers.
Ceil shed her fur skirt and stepped in, lifting her two tails to her waist before sitting down in the water.
Chloe stripped and followed Ceil.
“Is this the same ice water as the river?” Sammy asked.
“You learned how to handle it, did you not?” Ceil asked back.
“I don’t think I could do it with this much water.”
“I’ll heat it for you.”
Chloe beckoned for Sammy to enter.
The water around Chloe began to bubble, and Ceil moved quickly to the other side of the spring.
“If it gets too hot, tell me.
I can’t really tell if most things are hot anymore.”
Sammy removed her shirt, pants, and underwear and set them beside the spring.
She mentally braced herself before stepping into the spring but found it slightly warm, not unlike an indoor pool.
When she sat down, the water was deep enough to reach her neck, a perfect depth.
Compared to what she had been through the past few days, this spring was heavenly bliss, and she felt as if she could fall asleep sitting there in the water.
“You do not hide your emotions well,” Ceil remarked, but Sammy was too relaxed to become embarrassed at whatever face she was making.
Ceil reached her hand over to the moss-like plants growing on the edge of the spring.
The moss grew rapidly, and she tore off a few pieces about the size of her fist.
She tossed one to Sammy and one to Chloe.
“Wash with this.
It will remove the dirt, and the oil it releases when crushed is good for your skin.”
A soft aroma entered Sammy’s nose.
She smelled the torn moss and found that it gave off a sweet but herbal scent.
The closest comparison she could make was a mix between dry basil and rose.
“The smell is pleasant, too,” Ceil added.
“There are so many convenient plants here, this moss, a root that heals you, and that bubbly grass,” Chloe said in mild amazement.
“There are useful plants everywhere if you know how to use them,” Ceil said.
“I am sure that is true wherever you are from.
If you are not from Tolmyur, are you from the Wilderlands?
I could not imagine living there.”
Sammy wanted to correct Ceil but could not figure out how to explain that she and Chloe were from another world.
Chloe glanced at Sammy with a crooked smile showing that she too could not think of a good way to bring it up.
When they left the spring, the once pristine water was murky which made Sammy feel a little guilty for soiling it.
Sammy’s clothes had been cleaned and folded without her knowledge in the short time they bathed.
Ceil’s fur skirt was replaced by a slimmer, tan, almost silken skirt.
It tied on the side and had a white sash that wrapped around the waist to cover the top pleats and seam.
It looked elegant, in stark contrast to the crude fur she had worn before.
Chloe was provided a similar white sash, but it was wider and longer than Ceil’s.
“What do I do with this?” Chloe asked.
Ceil looked at Chloe perplexed.
“Your breasts are that large and you have never used one before?”
“Ah!” Chloe held the sash and tried to figure out how to tie it.
Ceil’s exasperated stare forced Sammy to explain.
She held up her bra.
“We use these to support our breasts.
I have never used a bind.”
“I haven’t either,” Chloe admitted.
Ceil shook her head and walked over to help Chloe.
The way she wrapped the bind was not to compress Chloe’s breasts but support them with her back and a little help from her shoulders like a bra.
She finished the wrap by pleating the cloth to make it thinner and tied it into an intricate bow on her upper back.
The way the white fabric hung from between her shoulder blades looked like small angel wings, and Sammy secretly wished that she could wear one too.
On the other side of the hut, an impossible amount of preparation had happened in the manner of a short bath’s time.
A five-foot diameter tree had appeared from nowhere, been cut lengthwise in half to create a long table, and the other half was sectioned and carved lengthwise into a bench.
The area was lit by flaming torches that resembled tiki torches but were clearly grown to match the appearance and not crafted.
On the table sat countless unknown fruits and plants with cooked meat of various sorts sliced and arranged evenly along the middle.
There was enough food for twenty to thirty people to eat their fill.
Ceil looked at the arrangement more exhausted than surprised.
“They went overboard again.”
“They’ve done this before?” Chloe asked, excited.
She could eat her fill without worry.
“Every day for a while after I came here and just as much food.
They do not get many visitors here.
Those territorial birds tend to keep everyone out.”
Without warning, a gust of wind swept the three of them off the ground and set them gently down on the bench.
Food floated from random locations on the table and piled up on flat stones set in front of them like plates.
Sammy’s eyes darted around trying to see the invisible hands moving the food.
“I was wondering after what you said to the Sprite Arkhon, but can you really not see them,” Ceil asked.
“I can a little,” Chloe replied while sampling a small, yellow, crescent shaped berry.
“Seriously?!”
Sammy could not believe that she was the only one.
“Yah, but it’s faint.
I can only see something like an outline,” Chloe elaborated.
“If I blink, I lose them.”
Why can Chloe see them and I can’t, Sammy wondered in silence.
“Oh, it is because we are beings made of ven!”
A high-pitched feminine voice spoke from right beside Sammy’s ear making her jolt her head to the side.
“Those who are not skilled at sensing ven cannot see us.”
“This just means you are unskilled.”
The last comment was the same tenor voice of the Sprite Arkhon.
Sammy reflexively reached out to where she heard the voice to try and grab it.
She felt nothing but warm air through her fingers, which made her feel a little frustrated.
“How many of them are here?”
Chloe scanned the table and area around them.
“A lot?”
“Fifty-seven of us to be exact.”
“There are a few others.”
“But they have business elsewhere.”
Each reply came from a different voice, both male and female.
“How many sprites live in this forest?” Chloe asked.
“Aside from the fifty-seven of us?”
“Only eleven more.”
The number surprised Sammy.
“That few?”
“There are 326 sprites on Whinhlem, which is a lot, considering.”
“And that includes all the wind, earth, water, and fire sprites.”
“Enough talk.
Eat up!”
A sprig of some red plant was shoved in Sammy’s mouth the moment she opened it to ask another question.
Giving up, she decided to eat, but her eyes continued glancing around to find Justin.
She had no choice but to trust that what the Arkhon said was true, that they would take care of him.

* * *
That night, Sammy had a restless sleep.
The bedding of thick moss covered with furs was comfortable, and the smell of the furs was not too unpleasant, but her mind could not stop thinking of Justin who she had not seen all night.
The past few nights she slept huddled up next to him, and now her arms felt empty.
Worry for his health and safety plagued her mind.
She gently peeled off her fur covering to not disturb Chloe beside her.
Ceil was curled up to the side holding the tips of her two tails up between her legs and close to her chest as if they were a security blanket.
In the dark she looked more like a scared girl than the authoritative woman who had led them down a thousand-foot cliff and through the valley.
The only light in the garden forest came from the few phosphorescent plants scattered around the forest floor.
Most of the light glowed from the spring behind the hut, but it was not enough for Sammy to see well where she walked.
The evidence of the banquet that still filled her stomach to bursting had vanished as if it had never existed.
There was not even an imprint of the large tree trunk that was used as a table.
Sammy did not have a destination in mind.
She knew that she should not stray far from the hut, but at the same time, she had not seen Justin anywhere near the hut.
If she could see him, then maybe she could get some sleep, but after searching in the cold night for an unknown amount of time, there was no trace of him anywhere.
She sat down amid the purple feather-like flowers that had fully closed for the night and held her shivering arms.
“Arkhon, are you there?”
After a brief silence, Sammy felt a light warm breeze caress her cheek, and the air around her slowly warmed to a comfortable temperature.
“How could you tell?” he asked.
“Just a hunch.”
“Do you need something?”
Sammy had called out to him without a reason.
She did not know what to say or ask even though she was sure she had many questions and a few things to vent.
She scratched the itch of the mark on her neck as she ordered her thoughts.
In the end, her mind still lingered most on Justin.
“Where are you keeping Justin?”
“This way.”
Sammy was unable to see the Arkhon, so a gentle breeze pushed at her back to direct her.
It led her behind the hut past the spring into a small grove.
Justin lay on a bed of moss covered in tiny white flowers.
The scene illuminated in faint orange light of the spring gripped at her heart.
The only word that came to mind to describe it was a funeral.
She quickly grabbed Justin’s hand.
It was still warm.
“Do not worry, Sammy.
I gave my word that he would be well.
We washed and fed him as well as took care of his waste.
He is no worse than when you brought him here.”
“And no better?
Can you not treat him?
Isn’t he important to some role he has to play in this war?”
“War? An apt description, but the true war has yet to begin.
As for his role, yes he can contribute much, but even if he dies here, the war will still happen and reach its conclusion without him.
His involvement will be a benefit, but it is in no way necessary.
Same for Chloe.”
“And me?”
“Your involvement will mean nothing.
Whether you live or die, you will make no difference in what is to come.”
Sammy could not stand how casually he stated that her life was meaningless.
The anger of his test with her life at stake resurfaced.
Sammy’s shoulders shook.
She gritted her teeth to refrain from shouting at the Arkhon.
Chloe and Ceil were sleeping peacefully in the hut not too far away.
“There is nothing to be angry about.
Think of how many tens of billions of sentient lives are on this planet and how many more there are in the universe.
Not every one of them can be significant.
It just so happens that a few of those close to you are, which is astounding for you, if you think about it.
There is nothing to be ashamed of in you being normal.”
The Sprite Arkhon’s attempts at calming or assuring Sammy only fueled her anger.
“I’ll prove you wrong.”
“Oh?”
“I’ll prove you wrong.
I can’t just accept that you think I’m so worthless that I can be freely killed in some test to see if Ceil can accept humans.
My life is worth more than that!”
Realizing she just shouted, Sammy looked back towards the hut hoping that she had not disturbed Chloe and Ceil’s sleep.
The forest remained silent, and no one in the hut stirred, so Sammy took a deep breath to calm down.
“Sure, I don’t have a rare affinity like Justin or have strong magic potential like Chloe.
I don’t know anything about Whinhlem or the war or what’s going on.
That doesn’t matter.
If Justin and Chloe are going to get pulled into all this, I’ll prove that my existence is significant too.”
“Is that so?
What will you do?”
Sammy looked down at Justin, and her hand grasped his.
“First, I’ll make sure Justin recovers.
I don’t want him to be involved in a war.
He is too kind-hearted for that.
But if it is going to happen and he will be a great help, I’ll make sure he can.
Same with Chloe.”
“You will support them?
There are many who can and will take that role.”
“That’s only a start.
I don’t know enough about what’s going on, but I’ll learn.
I’ll make sure I am irreplaceable.”
The Arkhon chuckled.
“Interesting.
How about this?
If you make a meaningful contribution, I will reward you.
You have given your word, so make certain that Justin recovers and then prove that you have a role.
We will be watching.”
The chill of the night air returned, so Sammy knew the Sprite Arkhon left, but the anger and unease of their conversation remained.
What am I going to do?
She made a bet with a being far more powerful than her, but when thinking it over, there were no consequences if she failed in fulfilling her side of the bet.
It would only mean that he was right.
Sammy looked down at Justin.
She did not want to leave him alone in the forest, so she returned to the hut and grabbed a spare fur.
She nestled down in the grove next to him and wrapped them in the fur to ward off the cold.
Justin was still quite warm, hinting that his fever lingered.
“You will get better.
I promise.”
Sammy calmed down with Justin in her arms and fell asleep in the mellow orange light of the forest.

* * *
The next morning, Sammy was awoken by the tap of Ceil’s staff.
Ceil’s face looked mildly displeased, but she said nothing.
Sammy checked on Justin to find that nothing had changed and left him in the grove to follow Ceil back to the hut.
“We leave as soon as we are ready.” Ceil sat down three sacks of provisions provided by the sprites.
Chloe picked hers up and looked inside.
It contained many of the same foods from the banquet but in dried and otherwise preserved form.
“Where are we headed?”
“Somewhere we can heal Justin.”
Sammy looked at Ceil, and Ceil nodded.
“If you want to save him, then the dryads in Dhuillir are your best option.
It is about twenty to thirty days away depending on weather and other conditions, but carrying that man, maybe double.
The Mountain Elves to the south are closer, but you are liable to be attacked because you are human, and there will be little help for you there.
They surrendered to Tolmyur, but that does not mean they do not hold a grudge.
They are a race not to be angered.
While carrying the stretcher, we won’t be able to cross the plateaus to the north to enter western Vallen to seek help from the fairies either.
They lack the same veins running through them that we used to descend.
As you heard from the Sprite Arkhon, the dryads are under the control of Tolmyur.
You should be able to get them to help because you are humans, but my presence poses a problem.
The humans are looking for me.”
“Are you not coming with us?” Chloe pleaded to Ceil.
“I am.
You will not make it on your own.
You have proven that you know nothing of survival.
We will have to be careful.”
After a meal that would not cause discomfort while traveling, Chloe and Sammy retrieved Justin and set him on the stretcher now lined with fur.
Ceil looked longingly at the hut and forest garden.
“Will you miss us?” the Arkhon asked out of nowhere, even surprising Ceil.
“Not your habit of suddenly appearing, that is for certain.
But, I will miss this place.”
“Even though it is not the Amelian Palace?”
Ceil frowned.
“You know I hated the palace.
I prefer nature.”
“Of course!

If you did not, you would not have planted all those purple flowers, or replaced the tub with an outdoor spring, or transplanted the shrubs, or meticulously cleared any debris on the forest floor, or asked us to rearrange the trees, or improved on the house, or…”
“I know! I know! Stop!”
Ceil’s cheeks flushed pink.
Sammy thought that the garden was something that the sprites created, but knowing that the breathtaking beauty was Ceil’s doing made Sammy chuckle.
“Before I leave, I want to thank you for taking care of me.
I will not try to kill myself anymore.
I promise.”
“Kill yourself?”
Sammy rushed to Ceil’s side, but Ceil waved her off.
“It is nothing.”
“And the humans?” the Arkhon asked.
“I cannot forgive them, but,” Ceil looked over at Sammy and smiled.
“I suppose there are good ones out there, especially if Eydis accepted them, so I will try to be open-minded.”
“Then you are good to go.
As of now, you are officially exiled from Fiorrae,” the Arkhon announced.
Ceil began walking.
Sammy hurried back to Chloe to help carry Justin.
When the hut was almost out of sight, Sammy heard a whisper in her mind.
“I will be watching.”

Interlude
“Seething”
Eydis
Sean approached the desk with a small stack of papers, and Eydis acted like she did not notice, instead choosing to write in the personal memory journal her psychologist ordered her to keep.
“No need to ignore me,” Sean said.
“There is nothing you need to fill out or sign this time.”

Eydis finished the passage she was working on, a memory of her first official day in the Grand Amelian Council where she signed into law an ease of the ocean border restrictions around the Tolmyur Kingdom to allow the merfolk and sirens to fish in the more bounteous shoreline that was unaffected by a sudden warm current that had killed most the fish in deeper waters.

Only once she finished did she finally look Sean in the eyes, but her expression was sour, both because the stacks of paper Sean brought were always trouble for her and because that memory was not a pleasant one.
She felt pity for the pleading sirens and merfolk and argued against the council who were almost unanimously opposed to the proposal until she bent them too her will.
Her father praised her at the time, but the decision ended in disaster for all parties involved, although she still could not quite remember what happened, adding to her irritation.
Sean first handed a single letter already opened even though it was addressed to her.
“This is from the NRA.”
“NRA?
That was one of your country’s arms organizations, yes?”
She removed the letter from the envelope and scanned it over.
“Is this about the war?”
“Sort of.
They claim that because of you, the sale of personal firearms has skyrocketed.
They wanted to express their support and are asking if you were willing to cooperate with them on--”
Eydis held up her hand to silence Sean and tossed the letter to the side of her desk.
“I understand.
They want to use me to increase their political influence.
I will think about it.”
Next, Sean handed Eydis a thin stack of papers.
Eydis recognized them immediately and tossed them to the side again.
“More protests?
Where this time?”
“This one is worse than the others.
There was an organized march in Portland, Oregon, that broke out into violence when extremists got involved.
Some people thought they were being attacked and shot rioting protesters.
No deaths, but fifteen were hospitalized, and there was nearly a million dollars’ worth of damage from vandalism alone.
The city is claiming that--”
Eydis waved her hand again.
This was why she hated whenever Sean came in with stacks of paper.
She was used to helping her father sit in the Grand Council for debates, but everything that was brought to her here was of little consequence.
It could be handled by local authorities and had no effect on the nation as a whole.
She was preparing the nation for war but was continually being bothered by so many trivialities that she couldn’t help but grow frustrated.
Sean was likewise growing frustrated at Eydis’s seeming lack of concern.
“This is the last one.
We have another lawsuit; this time from some entrepreneur who claims your scare tactics caused his new business to fail by running everyone out of Gullivan.”
Sean sat the final stack of papers on the desk in front of Eydis, but she slid them to the side without even glancing at them.
“Have it dismissed like the others.
That is what war is.
This country has been at peace in their lands for so long that they do not know how to cope with an attack on their own soil.
That entrepreneur is only using me as an outlet for his anger at himself for lacking the skill to recover on his own.”
Sean paced while rubbing his forehead with his thumb and forefinger.
“You do realize that much of this could have been prevented if you kept to the script.”
Eydis looked up at Sean with a sharp glare.
“I am not going to hide who I am and lie to a country that was just attacked by a mutual enemy.”

* * *
One week ago.
After the outcry from the public reached a breaking point, the United States government gave permission to hold a press conference with Colonel Richards and Eydis as the key speakers.

Eydis had already sat in conference with the President of the United States and other federal and military leaders to explain the truth of what happened, her origin, and where this new enemy capable of magic came from.
Eydis hid nothing, and most of the faces in the room were ashen by the end.

Sean and Miriam’s testimony added validity to Eydis’s claims, and Symra’s recount of the events in Whinhlem after Eydis’s disappearance up until the experiments that sent Symra to Earth removed all doubt no matter how impossible to believe the accounts may have been to those who listened.
The consensus of the meeting was that the truth should be kept secret to prevent mass panic and political and international unrest.
The script Eydis needed to follow for the press conference was written by someone from the government, and the number of half-truths and straight fabrications leaking from the text made Eydis ill.
She could not in fair conscience spew such filth to the people who lost their loved ones to Jethro’s attack, especially when she too lost people she loved.
She was certain Justin would never forgive her if he was still alive.
She could not remember well, but she was sure that even though Justin worked hard to keep Eydis’s origins a secret, he also was not against revealing those secrets when it was needed.
How else would Miriam and Sean know everything if Justin felt no need to reveal it?
“All you need to do is follow the script.
We will take care of everything else.”
Colonel Richards handed Eydis a black beret to complete her Army Service Uniform.
She was not enlisted, but for official appearances, he requested she wear military attire with insignia designating her as a civilian service member, to which she was not opposed.
Her hair was pulled back and wound into a low bun in such a way that her hair covered and pressed her ears against her head to hide the long tips.
According to the script, her Elven origin was also to be kept secret.
They even provided mildly irritating contact lenses to make her eyes appear human.

“We would prefer you not take part in the conference,” Colonel Richards admitted, “but because your doppelganger appeared on the news in conflict with the police during one of the preliminary attacks and word leaked that you are directly connected, the press is pushing hard for your attendance.
If you do not show, the briefing might only fan the flames.”
Eydis was constantly amazed at the speed news and gossip spread in this world.

Not only did they recognize and identify Eydis from the brief appearance of the Lurr doppelganger, they were able to make connections between that event and the person aiding the Army in cleaning up the aftermath of the invasion.
She placed on the beret, and Colonel Richards adjusted it.
“I am fine with speaking.
You need not worry about me,” Eydis said flatly.
The concern did not leave Colonel Richard’s face.
“Your ability to speak is not what I am worried about.”
Colonel Richards led Eydis down the hall and through a sliding door into the small room where the press conference was held.
Shutters clapped incessantly as the press immediately began taking photos of Eydis and the Colonel before the conference even began.
Those in the seats readied their notebooks and memo pads both to take notes and to have their pre-arranged questions on hand.
Eydis and Colonel Richards stood to the side while another woman, the Press Secretary, took the podium.

Eydis would have thought that the President of this country would be the one to address his people, but Colonel Richards explained beforehand that the President had already given his address on the tragedy.

Because so little information was given--the purpose of the address was only to show his remorse and promise to investigate and strike back at those who attacked--the press had been demanding more information.
Only a brief welcome to the press by the Press Secretary preceded a recounting of the details of Jethro’s invasion.
Unlike the President’s address, the estimated number and nature of the invaders was given as well as locations of the attacks in Gullivan and the number of dead at each location.
About 1000 soldiers invaded and over 5000 citizens died in total; a little less than one-fifth were students attending the university.
Again, the Press Secretary expressed the sorrow and remorse of the President and other federal leaders.
While nothing she said was false, her address contained no information that would ready the people for the war they were now involved in.
Eydis frowned within herself.
This information helped no one.

Once her address was finished, the Press Secretary introduced Colonel Richards to give an explanation of his involvement and the operations of the Army during the invasion as well as their current efforts to aid in the aftermath.
He began with the initial abduction of Eydis from the university and the attack on the hospital when the police did not realize the attacker they captured was still armed.
This surprised Eydis, because this information was not included in what was permissible for her to speak about.
They strictly forbade her from talking about her abduction and fight with Jethro’s assassins.
Was it to prevent her from mentioning magic?
Or maybe to keep her abilities secret?
She doubted that any single person in this country’s military would be able to fight off so many men unarmed, especially when magic and Lurr were involved.

Colonel Richards continued by recounting the police’s request for aid and then addressed the attack by the minum but left out the doppelganger’s involvement, explaining that they framed a child as the threat and that Eydis intervened to help them realize who the real threat was, but regrettably, the attacker escaped.
The invasion followed.
Eydis knew that the internal workings of the military in any country were something held secret, so she was not surprised by the level of dilution in Colonel Richard’s recount.
He only detailed where his soldiers were and how they were able to coordinate with nearby cities to expedite evacuation and protection of the citizens.
He ended with an apology for lack of information on the size of the enemy forces that led to the lack of manpower in the city at the time of the invasion.
Unlike the address up until now, the information on the cleanup and recovery work was highly detailed.
When Colonel Richards finished, the press began raising their hands to ask questions, but he introduced Eydis, stating that questions will be held until after she spoke.

According to the script, all Eydis had to do was explain that she was royalty, that she had escaped these attackers after a coup that caused the death of her family, that she sought asylum in this country but did not realize that her attackers would follow in force.
They even went through the trouble of selecting cities that were involved in recent conflicts to give her a location of origin.
She would then give her side of the story about her involvement in the invasion, how she was injured and was recovering at the hospital during the time of the attack.
Their script neglected the war that was likely raging in her world and that now leaked into theirs.
It did not explain how the attackers got into the country let alone the city.
Worst and most important of all, it did not explain that this war was not over for them, and there was a very real threat that Jethro would return with a larger, more powerful force.
Everything in her speech was to ease the worries of the citizens, but creating false security would only do more harm.
Nothing in it prepared them for war.
Nothing informed them of the true strength of those who declared war against them.
Nothing informed them that the enemy had the power to appear within their borders at any time and recreate the same disaster that befell Gullivan any number of times over.
Eydis walked up to the podium amid the countless shuttering of cameras.
The press viewed her with hungry eyes waiting to hear from the one they saw as not only the center of this disaster but potentially the cause.
“If those here try to remove me, it is because there is much they do not wish the people of this country to know.
From what I have learned of your government, I trust it is not one which would resort to killing the press in order to silence the spread of information, but I will give you the choice.
Leave here and remain safe in your ignorance, or stay and learn a bit of the truth about the conflict you have found your nation involved in.”
Colonel Richards hurried to the podium to try and pull Eydis away, but he was blocked by a barrier.
He did not hit on the barrier or acknowledge it because doing so would inform the press of the existence of something invisible.
Like any who hunger for information, the press remained rooted in place and would not be moved.
This made Eydis smile.
“I am glad to see your conviction.”
Eydis removed her beret and unwound her bun.
Her fine yet full hair fell down her back without so much as a kink or curl from the tight bun it was wound in.
Her long pointed ears popped out beside her head for all the press to see.
She then brought her fingers to her eyes and removed the contacts to show her oval pupils.
The former clattering of cameras could not even compare to the noise that erupted.
The press looked on in both amazement and confusion, some possibly wondering if this was a stunt or some joke.
Colonel Richards gave the order to cut the live stream.
Security tried to coax the press to leave, but they would not budge.
“My name is Eydis FeAmel, First Princess of the Amelian Empire.
As you can see, I am not human.
I am an elf.
What you must know is that your nation is now at war, and I am the one who brought this war to you.”
The press stood and shouted questions in quick succession.
Eydis made a mental note of all she heard and promised to answer what she could to quiet the press, but first, she needed to explain what she meant.
“Where I come from, the humans and elves are at war.
My family was assassinated by a man named Jethro who is commander of the human forces.
By some stroke of fate, I found myself in your country, but by doing so, you became involved in our war.
For that, I sincerely apologize, but I had no control over the events that occurred.
I did not come here by choice, and there is no way for me to return.
What I can do and am doing is aid your military in preparation for future attacks that will most likely happen.
You have strong power in your technology, the likes of which I have never seen, but the enemy is just as powerful in ways you could only imagine.
Within that power is the ability for them to strike anywhere they please and invade any city no matter how deep within your borders it resides.
This power is something I too thought was impossible.
It is how one thousand soldiers appeared without warning inside your borders and assaulted Gullivan, and there is a high possibility that they will appear there again in far greater numbers.
Had I known they had this ability, I would have raised alarm sooner so that you would have been prepared.”

With that explanation, six of the questions Eydis heard were answered, but there were still many more, including how elves could exist and where they had been hiding all this time, the rumors of demons appearing in the city before the attack, and how eyewitnesses of the invasion said that the invading soldiers were using witchcraft or magic.
Most of these questions involved information that Eydis still felt the people of this world were not ready for, yet.
How would they react with the knowledge that Jethro had invaded from another world?
What would happen if the existence of magic was common knowledge and not something only found in this world’s fiction or fantasy or legends?

The reason that she revealed herself as an elf was to separate herself from those of this country and to become the scapegoat for any blame that might have befallen the government and military due to their shortcomings in handling this or future conflicts.
If the people could blame her instead of acting out against the government, the government could better prepare for war.
This would appease the government’s worries of political unrest, or so she hoped.
Most important was that the citizens now knew of the war.
Avoiding questions and answers involving magic or her world, Eydis answered every other question the press presented her with the truth that their government wanted to hide.

* * *
Sean sighed.
“I understand why you did it, but…” His voice trailed off.
Arguing with Eydis would accomplish nothing.
“If only he had contacted the authorities sooner.”
Sean’s voice was no more than a whisper as he was exiting the room, but Eydis’s elven ears heard it clear.
“You cannot blame Justin for this!
He was a victim like everyone else!”
Eydis’s chair fell back to the ground, and a burst of wind sent the contents atop her desk flying.
Sean was not startled by the outburst.
It was only one of far too many.
He shook his head.
“I am not blaming him.
This is all our problem.
Me, you, and Miriam included.”
“There is no point dwelling on the past.”
Miriam walked through the door and tapped Sean on the side of the head with her clipboard.
She then waved it at Eydis.
“I finally got permission.
We can talk with the old woman and giant.”
“How?
I thought they were worried that Eydis would go berserk the moment she saw them.”
Even mentioning the two officers of Jethro’s army that were captured caused Eydis’s heart to race and her stomach to churn.
Already fuming from Sean’s comment about Justin, she fought to contain her boiling anger and hatred.
They were not the ones who killed Justin, but they represented the one who did.
“It wasn’t easy, but to explain simply, Symra and I will be there to protect them from Eydis and vice versa.
Symra hasn’t been able to get any information out of them.
Interrogations have been difficult with the government preventing Symra from using any form of torture.
We might be able to get them to talk if their target is in front of them.”
“Are you really okay with putting yourself in danger like that?” Sean asked.
Miriam smiled.
“Although Symra won’t admit it, I am better at reinforcement magic than she is.
If anything, she’ll get hurt before I do, but thanks for the concern.”
She then looked sternly at Eydis.
“It all comes down to whether or not Eydis can keep her emotions in check.
Can you?”
Eydis took a few breaths to calm down and nodded.
Sean grabbed the clipboard and scanned the permission papers.
“Are they still in ADX, or did they decide to move them to Carswell?”
“Eydis hasn’t told you?
The plan was to keep the giant in ADX and move the woman to Carswell because she is not handling our world well, but the giant refuses to be separated from her.
According to Symra, he could break out at any time if he wanted, and the only reason he hasn’t is because of her.
So long as she is with him, he will not rampage.
But, the woman needs medical attention, so in the end they made special arrangements to bring the giant to Carswell with her.”
“When do we go?”
“As soon as we are ready.
We only need to tell them when.”
“We go now.”
Eydis grabbed the clip board and opened a portal.
Miriam quickly closed the door before anyone outside could see.
“They specifically asked us not to teleport.”
“That is because it makes me hard to track.”
Sean grabbed the clipboard back.
“No, it’s because if we start appearing in locations that are impossible to reach in such a short amount of time, people will start asking questions.
Only a handful of people know about your magic.”
Eydis reluctantly closed the portal.
She knew the reasoning, but given the alternative, she would rather teleport.
Air travel may be common in this world, but Eydis found it unnerving.
The concept of flying through the air in a metal tube was unnatural.
She had to take a plane to the nation’s capital the first time because she had no other way to know where it was, but she used teleportation after that.
They soon built her a small personal office in The Pentagon to keep her grounded in one place and close enough to call on when needed.
Sean and Miriam shared an apartment only a brief subway ride away and helped Eydis with everything from paperwork to training a select few soldiers that Eydis discovered had affinities to magic.
They left for the airport accompanied by two military personnel and flew to Fort Worth, Texas.
From there, Symra met them with two drivers to chauffeur them to the Federal Medical Center, Carswell.

Symra only took orders from Eydis, not the military or government, so when they requested help in monitoring the two officers that were captured, fearing the potential use of magic to escape, Eydis sent Symra.
Symra drew attention from those at the airport.
She wore a black suit with matching slacks and white blouse.
Her short, course brown hair stuck out in all directions, and her long, slightly drooping ears that had short, fine brown hair along the top were in full view.
Eydis’s ears were likewise uncovered.
Because of the press conference, they no longer had any reason to hide their identity.
A smile spread across Symra’s heavily freckled cheeks.
She genuflected, which caused even more people to stare and take pictures.
“I have awaited your arrival, my lady.
Please, come with me.”
Eydis and one of the military personnel accompanied Symra in the first car with Miriam, Sean, and the other military personnel in the second.
The drive to the FMC was silent.
Eydis meditated to control her emotions, and Symra must have realized this because she did not strike up a conversation.
When they arrived, Symra led them through the compound to the high security unit.
“We had eleven women confined here before those two arrived, but they were moved temporarily until something is worked out.”
The guard acting as a guide made idle conversation as they entered the high security compound.
“It was more due to having a man in a woman’s prison than the danger those two posed to the other prisoners.
The report that came with them said they were very well behaved.”
“Do not let them fool you,” Eydis warned.
“Either one of them could kill everyone in this prison with little effort.”
The guard gave a wry smile.
The compound was informed of the potential danger the two of them posed, but the guard did not seem to believe the old woman could be capable of much.
The nine-foot-tall giant was a different matter.
“Sorry that we could not arrange a formal meeting room.
Oyak is too weak to leave her bed.
We should be keeping her in one of the medical wings, but the security is a little laxer there, and because Borgrum will not leave her side, we have to take care of her here.”
Symra stopped in front of a cell, and the guard stood next to her.
It was a simple cement room no more than eight feet wide and fifteen feet deep.
The usual prison bed was replaced by a hospital bed, and an elderly woman was strapped into it.
An oxygen line attached to her nose, and an IV ran from her arm.
She looked at her visitors with weary glass eyes.
Sitting on the floor next to her and holding her hand was a nine-foot, broad-shouldered giant.
His beard hung low and melded into his ample chest hair, and his long, wavy brown hair was tied back into a ponytail.
He eyed Eydis with a menacing frown.
Eydis gripped the sleeve of her coat with white knuckles.
The burning pain of adrenaline surged through her veins, and she felt that if she lost even the slightest bit of willpower, she would run them both through with a wind spear.
Miriam grabbed Eydis’s hand and held it gently.
Justin’s face flashed in Eydis’s mind, and she shook Miriam’s hand away.
There were many questions that Eydis planned to ask.
She wanted to know what was happening in her world beyond the small scope of Symra’s slavery.
She wanted to know how the humans were able to invade this world and if it was possible to get back.
She wanted to know what Jethro’s plans were and why he felt the need to follow her here.
She wanted to know the reason for Tolmyur’s invasion of Amel.
All the questions flew from her mind, and only a single word slipped through her mouth.
“…why?”
Borgrum’s expression did not change.
Eydis doubted a giant had the intellectual faculties to piece together any response to a single-word question without context, but Oyak broke a smile through her cracked lips.
Her voice was no more than a quiet rasp, and without Eydis’s elven ears, she would not have heard the reply.
“Because your kind is a disease.”
Symra was the only observer who could understand the conversation.
Sean and Miriam could only trust that Eydis would find out the information they came for.
“He was not from our world.
Why did he have to die?” Eydis said.
Oyak’s eyes widened, and a weak cackle escaped her lips.
“How fitting that the one who has caused our people so much suffering now has a taste of what sorrow truly is.
If someone you cared for died, it was by your hand, not ours.”
Eydis raised her hand, but Miriam rushed in front of Eydis to block her, and Borgrum rose to one knee to cover Oyak.
Miriam’s eyes pierced Eydis.
“Remember our agreement.”
A torrent of anger surged inside Eydis’s bosom, but she lowered her hand.
Oyak cackled even harder.
“If only Jethro could see how the humans of this world have leashed the Tyrant Princess.
To see you reduced to such a pitiful state redeems us of our failure.”
“Reduced?
No, you are gravely mistaken.
Because of you, I am stronger now than I ever was in Amel.
That city you invaded belongs to the country with the strongest military in this world.
They hold the power to render our entire continent uninhabitable.
They have decided you are an enemy and have taken my side in this war.”
“That will not last.
You will betray these humans like your kind betrayed us, and when that happens, you will have two worlds against you.
Only once the elven plague is purged will there be peace.”
“The Amelian Empire is not so weak that we would fall to humans.”
A sharp pain pierced Eydis’s head.
“While you were living a peaceful life… the Empire fell to ruin!
…People live in fear and poverty… while you were laughing and chasing after a man like some bitch in heat…”
A broken memory of words spoken in her own voice played in Eydis’s mind.
She brought her hand to her head to try to numb the ensuing pain with life magic.
She staggered, and Symra grabbed her arm to support her.
“My lady, we should not drag this on much longer.
You are not well.
Let us obtain the information we need and leave.”
Symra spoke in her home dialect so only Eydis could understand.
Eydis pushed Symra away, but she was right.
The pain in her head would not subside.
She placed on a confident mask, and once composed, she stepped closer to the cell.
“For what purpose did Jethro send you all here?
The Amelian Empire has fallen, has it not?
How was he able to send such a large army to this world?”
“Do you ask a god how and for what reason the sun rises and falls each day?
All we do is for the better world Jethro will create for us.
We do not question why.”
Eydis’s irritation peaked.
“I will get no information from zealots.
This is a waste of time,” she sneered to Symra.
What did she expect to learn from soldiers who were prepared to die for the commander they worshipped?
“If Jethro desires destruction, then I will give him it.
You call me the Tyrant Princess, so a tyrant I will become.
Just as you seek an end of elfkind, I will see to it that you humans meet your end by my hand.”
Eydis turned and walked away from the cell, and those with her followed one by one as each person tried to reason about what kind of conversation just transpired.
Before leaving earshot, Oyak cackled a single warning.
“Be careful what you say in a world full of those same humans.”

Chapter 6
“Nothing but Trouble”
Ceil
“We will reach the edge of Fiorrae by tomorrow evening.”
Sammy, Chloe, and Ceil sat around a sunken fire in a small clearing of the forest.
Ceil used her staff to create roots that dug out the ground for the fire pit while Chloe gathered and dried wood.
Sammy was left to wash Justin and his clothes with her water magic because he had soiled himself, the reason for their early camp.
The sun was low in the sky but had not yet set.
Its waning glow painted the sparse clouds pastel shades of orange, red, and purple.
Justin lay next to Sammy with his head in her lap in order to take in the warmth of the flames.
Ceil watched Sammy comb her fingers through Justin’s hair while he breathed weakly, but the black mark on Sammy’s neck continued to steal the focus of her gaze.
It had not faded but instead grew ever so slightly over the course of their journey.
Chloe did not seem to notice, and neither did Sammy.
Even now Sammy was subconsciously scratching it with the forefinger of her free hand.

Just like the royal guard who pulled Ceil from her hometown and the marshal of the Gallanvale who tried to present her to Jethro, Sammy was also touched by that horrifying phantom hand although using the staff as a conduit, not directly.

The phantom only appeared at periods of heightened emotion, whether fear or anger, to attack those at whom the emotion was directed, although things Ceil used life magic on sometimes blackened without the appearance of that skeletal hand.
The number of blackened plants the sprites had to discard while Ceil worked on her garden home was staggering.
The only exceptions were when Ceil used life magic on herself or objects she nurtured with her ven, like her staff, almost making it an extension of herself.
Whatever those black marks were or whatever that hand was, it never harmed her.

Sammy’s case did not appear as severe as the soldier who vomited blood or the marshal whose hand ruptured with seeping blisters, perhaps because the phantom hand did not touch her directly, but in the first case Ceil wanted to be free of the guard, which happened as a direct result of the mark, and in the second case she desperately wanted the marshal to release his grip.
The end result was as she desired.
What about Sammy?
Ceil did not want to admit her mistaken feelings from that time when she thought Sammy was an enemy.
In her hatred, she only had one wish, that Sammy would suffer, slowly and painfully.
“What’s on your mind?”
Sammy looked back at Ceil with a weary smile.
Ceil realized that she had been staring at Sammy.
“You are on my mind.
You look terrible.
Do you not agree, Chloe?”
Chloe’s eyes startled from being drawn into the sudden conversation.
“Well, um… I don’t have a right to say anything.
I pushed myself to collapsing before you found us.”
“All the more reason you should tell Sammy not to,” Ceil sad.
“I’m fine.
Really,” Sammy assured them.
“When I first moved out on my own, I initially turned down my dad’s offer to pay for my living expenses, at least until I started school.
I ended up working three jobs.
This is nothing compared to how tired I was then.
Besides, Justin has it far worse, right?”
She should give up on him, Ceil murmured in her mind.
He had caused no shortage of trouble during their travels, and many of those troubles were shouldered by Sammy alone.
She fed him, cleaned him, and made every effort to keep him comfortable.
Chloe had to help carry him, but she did not have the same wear in her eyes.
Ceil caught Sammy on multiple occasions awake at night in order to tend to him despite knowing that she would have to help carry him come morning.
Throughout all this, Sammy never once complained.
Ceil knew nothing of his past or how Sammy was related to him.
Sammy introduced him as Eydis’s lover, but she never said what he was to her.
She eyed the two while chewing on a roasted herb.
They were both on the short side for general humans but did not look enough alike to be related.
She could possibly be another lover of the man’s or perhaps a rival of love with Eydis.
But if they were rivals, they would not be as close of friends as Sammy had expressed.
Even if Sammy was his lover, she was going to break if this continued.
His condition never grew worse, but any day he showed progress, the very next day he regressed back to the state he was the day they set out.
Not once had he become conscious, but looking at the state of his infection, that was probably for the better.
This left Sammy to shoulder the full weight of his care.
The conversation ended in awkward silence amid Ceil’s thoughts, and only the crackling of the fire could be heard as the sun slipped below the horizon and the forest grew dark.
Ceil felt there was little reason to stay awake any longer, so she convinced the others to sleep now so they could wake up early and set out at sunup.
Their usual sleeping position was Chloe in the center to keep everyone warm with Ceil on her left and Justin on her right.
Sammy would then sleep on the other side of Justin to block out the cold.
They had nothing to cover them other than their clothes, but Ceil always made sure to grow soft groundcover to make them comfortable.
As usual, Ceil was the first to fall asleep.
“Sammy?”
Ceil stirred from a soft voice considerate of those still sleeping.
“You still can’t sleep?”
“No…”
“Is it Justin?”
Ceil considered getting up to scold Sammy for not resting, but something within her told her to stay silent and listen.
“He’s part of it, but I still can’t get used to the days here.
They’re too long, and I guess I haven’t adjusted yet.
You seem fine, though.”
Chloe chuckled softly.
“I used to be rather lazy, so sleeping for a long time is not hard for me.
The days are pretty long, though.”
“And the high gravity makes lasting the day even harder.”
“I’m sure Ceil would be fine if you need to rest more.
We could even take a nap in the middle of the day.”
“No.
We need to get Justin treated as soon as possible.
He’s not getting any better.
I don’t want to delay the trip any longer than I already have.
Besides, if we are going to be stuck here, I need to get used to the long days.”
“You need to be careful.
Ceil is right.
You do look terrible.”
“I’m fine. Really.”
Ceil recalled the first days with them atop the plateau.
Their clothing was very peculiar and unlike anything she had ever seen.
They did not act like the humans of Tolmyur.
They were not violent, nor did they hate elves.
They knew and were friends with Eydis, so perhaps Eydis realized they were different from those of Tolmyur.
They must have come from somewhere far away that was different than the Amelian Empire and the Tolmyur kingdom.
Maybe the length of days changed in other locations and the gravity is different.
Ceil had heard that days were long and nights short in the far north, so perhaps they weren’t from the tundra north of the Wilderlands.
She had also heard stories of mountains that floated in faraway continents, so areas of fluctuating gravity did exist.
She had never been anywhere other than her small village or the palace until the assassinations, so other parts of the world could be very different than the Empire.
Sammy and Ceil were merely speaking this way because this place was different than some other distant land that had humans.
“Where are you going?
You are going to wake up Ceil.” Chloe stirred.
“Ceil’s a heavy sleeper.
I’m just going to meditate for a bit.”
“Meditate?”
“Yah. I want to get better at sensing ven.
Keep Justin warm for me.
I won’t be long.
When I get tired, I’ll come back to bed.”
“Okay…”
Quiet footsteps walked a short distance from the camp.
Chloe pulled Justin in closer and breathed a light but frustrated sigh.
Her voice was as quiet as a breath.
“The problem is that you are too tired to sleep.”
Ceil thought meditation would help, so she let Sammy be but also planned to scold her in the morning.
Ceil woke just before sunrise when the star-speckled black sky was transforming into a dark shade of blue.
She left the bed carefully in order to not disturb the still sleeping Chloe beside her.
Justin remained in his deathlike state, but Sammy was not next to him.
Ceil glanced around in mild panic and found Sammy sprawled on the ground on the other side of the fire pit.
Fearing the worst, she hurried to Sammy and found her sleeping, but the twitching, mild moans, and tear stains in her eyes showed that her sleep was anything but restful.
Ceil placed her hand on Sammy’s cheek.
Sammy’s eyes shot open with a shriek.
She scampered backwards away from Ceil towards the still-hot ash of yesterday’s fire.
Ceil pulled her arm before Sammy could fall into the fire pit and once again felt the incredible weight of this strange human girl.
“Sammy.
You are fine.
It is I.”
Sammy’s eyes searched her surroundings and then landed on Ceil.
Her panicked breath slowly regulated, and finally she blinked.
She looked around and then back at Ceil.
After a few breaths, Sammy nodded.
“I’m okay.
I’m okay.
I had a nightmare, that’s all.”
“Nightmare?”
Sammy sat next to Ceil and rubbed the sleep from her eyes.
“It was the attack on Gullivan, where we lived before Eydis sent us here.
But, I’m fine.
It was only a dream.”
Reliving Jethro’s attack.
Ceil pulled Sammy into a light embrace.
After she escaped the palace during the assassinations, she had nightmares about the attack on the palace.
After her maid sent her to Fiorrae to escape Jethro once again, she was plagued by constant nightmares of the attack on the Gallanvale as well.

In many of them, she tried to give herself up so that she could die and stop the slaughter of innocent people, but Jethro and the soldiers only ridiculed her or ignored her and continued the slaughter.
After each nightmare, the Sprite Arkhon would envelope her in warmth and lull her to sleep with a gentle breeze.
His voice would reassure her that everything would be alright and that she was safe.
Ceil stood and pulled Sammy to her feet.
They returned to the natural bed, and Ceil sat down in her spot on the other side of Chloe.
Chloe was awake and looking at Sammy with worry.
“Are you okay?”
“I’m fine.
I just had a nightmare,” Sammy replied.
“Again?”
“How long have these nightmares persisted?”
Ceil grew irritated that she never noticed.
“Come, you need to rest.”
Ceil patted the bed next to her.
“I should be next to Justin to keep him warm.”
“No. Forget him for now.
Chloe is taking care of that.
You need to rest for your own sake.”
There was certainly the possibility that the mark was not only worsening Sammy’s health but also her mental state, exacerbating or even causing the nightmares.
If that was the case, Ceil was responsible, although she could not admit that to Sammy.
Sammy looked at Justin and then Ceil.
Her hesitation furthered Ceil’s irritation.
She grabbed Sammy’s wrist and lead her to her side.
Sammy did not argue and lay down on the bed.
Ceil removed her own skirt and laid it across Sammy’s shoulders.
She then lay down next to Sammy and held Sammy’s head against her bosom.
“Rest.
We will wait to depart until you wake.”
With a light nod, Sammy closed her eyes.

* * *
Ceil hoped that Sammy would sleep until late morning at least, but the sun was still low in the sky when she woke.
As much as she tried, she could not convince Sammy to continue resting.
“We need to get Justin help as soon as possible.”
With that reason alone, Sammy pushed to get ready.
Chloe prepared breakfast using the same herbs from the previous evening and some meat that Ceil hunted and had Chloe dry a few days back.
Normally, Ceil would not worry about hunting meat, but Sammy ate as much as two people, and Chloe ate as much as four.
Vegetation alone was insufficient for them.
Ceil knew little about human physiology, but she felt the amount of nourishment Sammy and Chloe required was far from normal.
As usual, Ceil walked in front as the guide with Sammy and Chloe carrying Justin a few paces behind.
There were no roads through the uneven and rocky forests of Fiorrae, so Ceil moved by her sense of direction alone.
Once they traveled a ways inside the dryad forests, the forest floors would grow more level, there would be roads used by other races, and finding a dryad settlement would not be too difficult.
Ceil held out her fist to stop Sammy and Chloe.
She paced slowly while observing their surroundings.
No one was visible, but she knew something was there, watching.
“Ceil, those birds,” Sammy whispered.
Ceil turned towards where Sammy was looking and found the same large blue bird with the two long and jagged yellow plumes.
“Is that the one from before?” Sammy asked.
Ceil was certain.
If there was one, there was sure to be others.
The single bird did not pay any attention to Ceil but focused all its attention on Sammy and Chloe.
Why did they follow?
Were they still cautious of Sammy and Chloe, or worse?
This was bad.
She hurried in front of Sammy and pointed her staff at the bird.
The bird lowered his head and rustled his wings in irritation.
“These Humans are not dangerous!” Ceil called.
Two large wings extended, and the bird gripped its branch perch with its talons.
A single flap sent a powerful gust of wind that knocked Ceil to her back.
Sammy and Chloe were on the edge of the blast, and in Sammy’s exhausted state, she could not hold her ground and fell back.
Chloe barely managed to keep Justin from falling out of the stretcher.
“Did it attack us?” Chloe asked.
Ceil stood back up and again shielded Sammy and Chloe.
“No.
That was just a warning.
If it was an attack, that wind would have cut.”
The bird continued to ignore Ceil.
From where Ceil was standing, Chloe was behind her on the right and Sammy was behind on the left.
The bird was looking just to her left.
These birds were omnivorous, and Sammy was the weakest of the three.
The man was weaker, but they were not carrion scavengers.
“Sammy, stay behind me,” Ceil ordered.
“You are its target.”
“Me?” Sammy staggered to her feet.
Instead of listening to Ceil, she stood beside Ceil and started pushing her away.
“What are you doing!
You are his target!”
Ceil looked up at the bird, and his head cocked to the side.
He no longer showed any hostility and just observed.
“Leave him alone.
He only attacked because you confronted him.
There’s nothing wrong with him watching us.”
“They are predators.
I am worried that one might attack you!”
Sammy smiled.
“When that happens, I’ll trust you and Chloe to save me.”
Sammy looked back at the bird and nodded while pushing Ceil further away.
Ceil watched dumbfounded at Sammy’s complete lack of concern for her own safety as she returned to help Chloe with Justin.
After a few steps, Sammy fell to her knees.
Chloe again struggled to make sure Justin did not fall out of the stretcher.
The bird began to rustle his wings while watching Sammy.
Ceil hurried over, not to confront the potentially dangerous predator, but lift Sammy.
“That is enough.
You are not allowed to carry him anymore.”
Sammy looked at Ceil with shock and worry.
“We can’t leave Justin behind!”
Ceil loathed the words that she was about to speak.
“I will help Chloe carry him.”
She grabbed the front of the stretcher and lifted it.
As she expected, the body was rather heavy.
He was within what she felt was a tolerable carrying weight, but she was still amazed that Sammy and Chloe had carried him for so long.
Even she would grow exhausted.
Ceil watched out for the bird in the corner of her eye while they walked away.
Once the bird was out of sight, she heard the large flap and rustle of leaves that signaled the bird’s departure, a temporary departure, she was sure.
Six more similar flaps sounded from unseen locations around them.
The birds increased in number.
This worried Ceil even more.
“Sammy, you are no longer allowed to take care of him,” Ceil ordered.
“Why?!”
“I forbid it until you recover.
If you break before you find him help, I will have no other choice but to leave him behind and carry you on the stretcher instead.
Is that what you want?”
“You can’t make that decision!
And Chloe won’t leave Justin behind either!”
“This decision is mine to make because I am the one guiding you.
Either you rest or we leave him.”
“What do you have against Justin!?”
Ceil set down the stretcher.
“This is not about him.
It is about you.
I am worried about you.
Chloe is too.
She recognized that you have been too tired to even sleep well.”
“You don’t need to speak for me,” Chloe protested.
“Am I wrong?” Ceil glared at Chloe.
“No, but…”
Content with Chloe’s reply, Ceil grabbed Sammy by the shirt.
“Until you recover, I forbid you from taking care of him.
I will tend to his injury, and cleaning up after him will be Chloe’s responsibility from now on.”
“I can’t make Chloe do that!
She hasn’t seen a naked man before.
She can’t even look while I wash Justin.
There is no way she’ll be able to do it herself.”
“You cannot be serious,” Ceil groaned.
“Can you both stop speaking for me?!”
Chloe’s face flushed pink.
Ceil and Sammy stared at her in stunned silence.
“I’ll do it.
I can handle it.
I’m not a child.
I don’t want you to exhaust yourself or get sick either.
Ceil is right.
I pushed myself until I collapsed, and I regret forcing you to take care of me because of that.
We can’t take care of both you and Justin, not in the middle of nowhere.”
“Then it is decided.
Once you are better, you and Chloe can trade off and share the burden of taking care of him.
The three of us can take rotations carrying him.
We still have ten to fifteen days depending on how quickly we can find a dryad settlement.
Endure this arrangement until then.”
Ceil lifted her end of the stretcher and continued walking, not giving Sammy a moment to argue.

Chapter 7
“A Dangerous Mistake”
Sammy
“How do you cope with your nightmares?” Sammy asked Chloe.
She leaned on her arm to watch Justin beside her.
Just a moment earlier, she had another nightmare of the attack on Gullivan, and the jolt when she woke pushed Justin into Chloe, waking her.
“I haven’t been getting them too often, but…”
Chloe leaned back to look at the dark night sky.
The low cloud cover blocked out the stars and threatened rain, but Ceil assured them before they slept that rain was unlikely.
“I guess it’s because I got them a lot as a kid?”
“Why?”
“I don’t know.
I was scared of everything, and my parents thought that attributed to my nightmares.
As I got older, they happened less, but I still get them from time to time.
More than the average person, I think.”
“So you got used to them?”
“No, that’s not it.
I found my own way of coping that works for me.
You know how I like writing?
That started because of my nightmares.
When I was maybe 12 or 13, I decided to write down my nightmares.
I have a few journals full of them now.”
“You just write them down?”
“Not exactly.
I write them how I would have done the story.
I change my nightmare into the story I want.
Nightmares tend to repeat, right?
I found out that by doing that, I could sometimes change what happens in the nightmare.” Chloe chuckled lightly.
“Nightmares feel more like challenges to me now.
My nightmares are mostly lucid, so I can actively change what is happening.
It doesn’t always work… maybe half of the time I win?”
Sammy lay down on her side and snuggled up against Justin.
She placed her hand on his chest and felt the slow rise and fall.
In her nightmare, Justin was shot in the heart by Jethro and died instantly.
Jethro then proceeded to shoot Chloe, Eydis, and Miriam.
She woke when he pressed the gun against her forehead and pulled the trigger.
“My dreams aren’t even lucid.
It feels like it’s really happening.
I don’t remember coming to Whinhlem.
I don’t remember meeting Ceil or the sprites.
All I remember is the attack and that we were trying to find Eydis.
I don’t know if that will work for me.
I don’t have an imagination like yours.”
“Well,” Chloe began but then fell silent for a moment.
“You might have to find your own way to deal with it, but I’ll help think of ideas too.”
“Thanks.”
“Mm-hmm.”
The next morning, Sammy was back on Justin duty.
This was the third day she and Chloe began alternating.
In the beginning of the eight days Sammy was barred from taking care of Justin, Chloe was an embarrassed wreck.
Each time she had to bathe him or clean up after him, she was red as a tomato for the remainder of the day.
Sammy still provided water to wash Justin if there was no stream nearby, but other than that, she was forbidden from helping Chloe.
Ceil made Sammy rest whenever they had to stop for any Justin-related issue.

She felt that Sammy should wait longer before being allowed to take care of Justin again, but when Chloe began showing signs of exhaustion, Ceil gave Sammy permission, and the alternating shifts began.
Ceil would then swap out carrying Justin with whoever she felt was becoming too weak, usually Sammy.
Ceil grabbed the front of the stretcher.
“I’ll be carrying him with Chloe today.”
“Are you sure?” Sammy asked.
“You did not sleep again last night.
I can see it on your face.”
“Neither did Chloe.
We were talking together.”
“She looks more rested.
It was a nightmare again, right?
You need to get those under control.”
“It’s not that easy.”
“Yes it is.
I was able to.
So can you,” Ceil assured, but her assurance was rather curt, lacking sympathy.
Ceil began walking, so Chloe was forced to follow.
Sammy fought to control her irritation and jogged to catch up to walk next to Justin.
They continued walking through the morning and past midday.
“See how the trees are changing?” Ceil asked.
Sammy looked around at the trees.
The huge, leafy trees that would not feel out of place in a more tropical climate were being overtaken by rough-barked, smaller-leafed trees that looked more at home in a temperate climate.
For the first time, Sammy noticed mushrooms growing on the ground, and the moss that was formerly leafier was now coarse and clung evenly over the trunks and branches of the trees.
“This is the sure sign we have reached the dryad territory, Dhuillir.
There are sixteen states within Dhuillir, each with a different clan of dryad.
Dhuillir means ‘many colors’ in Elven.
Clans are defined by the type of plants they pollinate with which gives each clan a distinct appearance, but there is some intermixing.
They cultivate their specific trees within their state, making the forests a patchwork of color and the borders between tribes easily recognizable.
All the colonies were united under the Grandmatriarch Hamadryads, but they were assassinated the same night as the royal family.
