After the failure of the two clans bordering Amel in defending it from the humans, all the clans isolated themselves to protect their own clan, and one by one, they quickly surrendered to Jethro without a fight.”
“What clan’s state are we in right now?” Chloe asked.
“There are two possibilities, but this is most likely Melia.
Their skin is more grey than brown or green, and their hair is curly like the moss-looking growth on these trees.
It is not moss, though.
That is where the tree flowers.
There was one of these trees in the palace garden.
When they bloom, their trunks and branches are covered in tiny white flowers.
Dryad hair always matches the most dominant flowering tree of their region, so Melian hair looks the same.”
Sammy ran up and grasped Ceil’s hand holding the stretcher.
“Are they kind?
Will they help Justin?”
“I have never met them.
All I know about the dryads is secondhand.
Even if they are helpful, we will still need to be careful.
Melia borders the fairy nation of Vallen… or what remains of it…”

* * *
“Is that a road?” Sammy ran ahead of Ceil and Chloe to a break in the trees.
It was no more than packed and hardened soil, but the five-meter-wide path traveled in both directions until it curved out of sight.
“It is a road!”
Chloe and Ceil appeared from the forest and set Justin down on the roadside.
Ceil joined Sammy on the road to have a better look at the soil.
“This road is either being maintained or it is well traveled.”
“That’s a good thing, right?” Chloe asked from the roadside.
Ceil shook her head.
“Dryads do not use roads.
Dhuillir only has them for the convenience of other races.”
She walked over to the edge of the road near Chloe and stomped her heel into the dirt.
“This road has been widened as well.
The dirt here is less packed.”
“You’re saying that someone other than the dryads needed to widen the road?” Chloe asked after making certain Justin was comfortable and not in need of any care.
“I can only think it is the humans.
No other race would need to travel out this far or have any need to widen a road for increased traffic.”
“Will it still lead us to a village?” Sammy pleaded to Ceil for hope.
A road used by humans would be dangerous to travel, but roads also led to civilization, and Justin needed care as soon as possible.
“It should, perhaps, but we need to--”
Ceil grabbed Sammy’s wrist and pulled her off the road.
She grabbed Justin’s stretcher and drug it into the brush.
Chloe quickly followed.
Sammy poked her head out from the brush to look down the road.
“What is it?”
“Quiet.” Ceil pulled Sammy back down.
“They likely already saw us.
We need to leave. Fast.”
She grabbed the stretcher but then froze before lifting it up.
Sammy could hear a single pair of running steps in the distance that grew silent before drawing near.
Chloe held her hands against her mouth, and Ceil swiveled her head to try to find an angle where she could see through the brush without making any movements that would give her away.
Sammy’s heart pulsed with fearful adrenaline.
Even though the one who noticed them moved silently, the soft, precise steps in the dirt grew just audible as it neared.
Through a small break in the brush, Sammy saw him.
A man armored in leather carried a short bow with an arrow nocked in the string.
His light clothing and soft leather footwear muffled his movements.
After two more steps, the man disappeared.
Only his light steps remained, searching.
He was not leaving and not moving further down the road.
He knew they were near.
Sammy shot glances at Ceil and Chloe, and her panic increased when she noticed steam rising from Chloe.
Without making any noise, she motioned with her hand for Chloe to calm down.
If Chloe created any smoke, their cover would be blown.
Fear became dread when an unknown number of footsteps hurried near from down the road.
The single man was only a scout for the main group.
Even Ceil began losing her composure and displayed the same fear as Sammy and Chloe.
The silent footsteps approached the group and nearly inaudible words were spoken in a coarse, guttural language.
Armored feet then spread out over the road.
The sound of metal being removed from sheaths sent beads of cold sweat dripping down Sammy’s forehead.
The wooden creak of a bow being drawn.
Light footsteps nearing the shrubs where they hid.
The arrow released, and a shrill cry rang out over the road.
Twigs snapped and leaves rustled until something hit the forest floor not too far from them.
It was partially hidden between the trees, but Sammy recognized the blue plumage.
A single yellow feather sprouted from its head.
Chaos ensued.
Large flapping wings broke up the branches of the trees and sent them cascading down onto the forest floor.
Sammy covered Justin while Ceil and Chloe covered their own heads.
Surprised shouts accompanied frantic magic cast by the human soldiers.
The shrill “kree” of the birds intermixed with the cries of the soldiers.
Sammy did not know the numbers on either side of the fight, but by the number of cries and diminishing voices, the humans were losing more people.
A fireball exploded only a few yards from Sammy, and the concussion and heat suffocated her.
Near the explosion, two of the large birds lay charred and immobile.
“We need to leave,” Ceil whispered, but Sammy’s ears were ringing so loud she could barely hear her.
“We will take advantage of the fight.”
Ceil lifted a thicker branch that had fallen across her back and looked through the brush at the battle.
“They are evenly matched right now.
This is our best chance.
If the humans win, we will not be able to leave without being spotted, and more will come.”
Sammy lifted her head to risk a glance at the battle, but Ceil pulled her back down.
She was only able to see about ten human soldiers and maybe five of the birds.
Including the three she knew were killed already, the number of those birds had increased again.
“Grab the stretcher.
On my signal, we move slowly into the forest.”
“Shouldn’t we run,” Chloe asked.
“No.
That will draw too much attention to us.
They still have mages, and maybe an archer or two.
All it would take is for one of them to send an attack our way.”
Ceil raised her head to look at the battle.
Sammy and Chloe grabbed the ends of the stretcher and waited.
When Ceil lifted her fist, they moved.
They kept low to the ground, but now that they were away from the brush, Sammy got a clearer picture of the graphic scene.
Many human and bird corpses bloodied the packed soil.
The humans were down to six, and Sammy could only see two of the birds, the largest of which had two long and jagged yellow plumes sprouting from its head.
Sammy stopped moving.
Images of Jethro’s soldiers cutting down innocent people trying to flee the hospital flooded into her mind.
The longer she watched, the more her body began to shake.
One of the birds acted as a decoy to draw the fire by swooping down and cutting at the legs of some of the humans with its wing.
They turned to attack it, but then a large blade of wind launched by the bird Sammy knew cut into three of the soldiers and dropped them to the ground.
The bird that acted as a decoy took an arrow to the back and fell onto the side of the road, flailing momentarily before growing still.
This angered another of the birds that Sammy had not noticed who dove down from the nearby trees and clawed at a soldier’s face with its talons.
The natural weapons dug into the man’s neck and tore out flesh, but the bird’s rage was rewarded with a blade to its breast by the soldier next to it.
“What are you doing?” Ceil tried to coax Sammy forward, but she wouldn’t move.
“They are going to lose,” Sammy said.
“That’s not our problem.”
All that remained on the human side was an archer and swordsman.
On the bird’s side was the male with the two yellow plumes.
The archer nocked an arrow and fired as the bird tried to maneuver away, but the distance was too short, and the arrow hit its mark through the wing into the bird’s shoulder.
Sammy set Justin down and ran.
The soldier rushed to the downed bird fluttering on the ground and raised his sword.
The bird swung its free wing, and a blade of wind severed the soldier’s wrists mid downward swing and dissipated after cutting partway into the soldier’s neck.
The blade fell, severing a few feathers, but causing no more harm.
The archer nocked another arrow.
Sammy broke out of the brush onto the road with her sword raised.
The bowstring was drawn.
The archer took notice of Sammy’s charge and changed his aim, but he had no time.
She swung down with all her might.
The archer was forced to block the attack with his bow.
The wooden weapon buckled and snapped from the string’s tension.
Sammy lost her footing in her ill-formed attack and fell to the ground as another blade of wind flew over her into the archer.
When Sammy looked up, the headless man crumbled to the ground.
She turned to the crying bird.
Its right wing was stuck against its chest by the arrow, and it flailed on the ground with its left wing.
“What are you doing?!”
Ceil appeared from the forest, furious.
“He’s hurt!” Sammy called back.
“Leave him!
We need to flee far from here before more humans arrive!”
Sammy approached the bird but was knocked back by a strong wind from the bird’s left wing.
“Hold still!
I’m trying to help!”
The earsplitting cries from the bird made Sammy’s head ache.
She approached again.
The bird’s left wing was about to flap, so Sammy dove on top.
She pressed the wing down with her right hand and straddled the bird with her legs.
It continued to cry and bite franticly, so Sammy grabbed its beak with her other hand.
“Quiet!” she ordered.
The bird looked up at her with his large round eyes.
Sammy’s body shook with adrenaline.
The smell of blood from the many corpses behind her made her nauseous.
She took a deep breath with closed eyes to try and regain composure.
“I’m trying to help you, so stop struggling.”
Sammy removed her hand from his beak, and he cried.
She immediately grabbed it again and stared into its eyes.
“Stop,” she ordered again.
After she released his beak, he did not cry out again.
Feeling it safe, she lifted her hand from his wing and inspected the arrow.
From how she was straddling the bird, she was crushing some of the feathers of the right wing that was pinned by the arrow to his chest.
The arrow had penetrated the flesh of the wing, and the tip had passed clean through the shoulder just under the wing.
The bird could not free himself, because the arrowhead caught on its back, and his wing caught on the fletching.
“Don’t leave me behind!”
Chloe drug the stretcher with Justin out onto the road.
“Chloe, bring me the pouch!” Sammy ordered.
Chloe looked around at the devastation of the battle and stepped nervously over to Sammy.
She handed Sammy the pouch that had formerly held the strange grass and medicine.
Sammy loosened the ties and removed a vial containing a light brown liquid: condensed beiju juice.
It was not as strong as the former medicine the vial contained because it had not sat long enough to ferment and lacked other medicinal herbs, but it was more effective than raw beiju.
“You are going to use it on the bird?” Ceil watched in disbelief.
Sammy paused again to regain her composure in order to rid her mind of the images of the attack on the hospital that the putrid smell of iron in the air kept bringing to her memory.
“I made it, so I get to choose how I use it.”
She took another deep breath.
“I can make more later.”
“Even if you remove the arrow, that medicine is not going to heal the wound.
He will not be able to hunt.
He will not survive.
You are wasting your time.”
“Can you stop the bleeding?
There are two bones in the wing right here, and the arrow is caught between them.
I’m going to tear the three feathers off the arrow and slide the wing off.
Chloe, hold the wing.”
Chloe grabbed the wing on each side of where the arrow penetrated, and Sammy tore off the fletching as best she could.
Chloe then helped Sammy slide the wing off the arrow.
The bird cried out when his wing passed the rough fletching, but the wing was free.
Sammy lifted herself off the bird a little to slide out the wing she was sitting on.
The bird was about the flap, so Sammy placed both her hands on his wings to press them to the ground.
She stared back into its eyes.
“I’m not done yet.”
Sweat caused by Sammy’s internal turmoil and the exhaustion of her drastic actions dripped onto the bird’s beak from the tip of her nose.
“Ceil, the wing.”
Ceil walked behind the bird and was about to press her fingers on the wound but hesitated.
Her hand shook.
She had refused to use any healing magic on Justin, only checking his vitals with life magic and then applying herbal medicine.
When Sammy began to worry that Ceil would not stop the bleeding, Ceil took a shallow breath and quickly tapped her fingers on the wound.
She then did the same where the arrow protruded from its shoulder.
“I think I stopped the bleeding,” Ceil said.
“Let me see your sash.”
Ceil frowned but untied the sash from her waist.
Sammy used the sash to wrap around the bird to hold its right wing closed.
She then touched the arrow and pulled lightly.
The bird cried out and squirmed beneath her.
“How do we remove the arrow?” Sammy asked.
“Move,” Ceil ordered.
Ceil and Sammy quickly swapped places.
Ceil sat lower on the bird to allow Sammy to lean his head forward.
“Break off the arrowhead,” Ceil instructed.
“The quicker the snap, the cleaner it will be.
Once you do, I will remove the shaft.”
From where Sammy now sat ahead of the bird, the road full of corpses was in full view.
She immediately looked away and fought her vomit reflex.
“Do it now, or I will get off,” Ceil said.
Sammy nodded and grabbed the arrowhead.
She pulled it through a bit further so she could snap it off where it was attached to the shaft.
She gripped the shaft near the bird’s back with one hand and gripped near the arrowhead with the flat side braced against the base of her palm in her other hand.
Using all her strength, she bent the arrowhead down.
The break was not clean, and the arrowhead cut her palm a little, but the head broke off.
Ceil immediately yanked the shaft out.
In a panic, the bird flapped its left wing and blew Ceil backwards into the air.
She landed hard on her back with her skirt flipped up.
“You stupid buzzard!
We are helping you!” Ceil screamed.
She held her tails in front of her and rubbed them while shivering and wincing in pain.
She had landed on them.
Sammy quickly straddled the bird to apply her medicine to the wound in its shoulder.
The brush further back on the other side of the road rustled, and then a man ran in the opposite direction.
Ceil let go of her tails and grabbed a bow and a few arrows from a fallen soldier.
She nocked an arrow, drew the bow, and fired at the man.
Her arrow flew far left of her target.
“Chloe!
Kill him!” Ceil screamed.
Not knowing what was happening, Chloe ran beside Ceil and conjured a viscous fireball in her hand while Ceil fired another poorly aimed arrow.
Chloe tossed the ball that spat out flames as the added ven propelled it forward, but the man was too far away for the ball to hit.
It exploded on the road well behind its target, and the erupting flames of the explosion that was wider than the road threatened to catch the nearby trees on fire.
Chloe pursued, and the lone man soon ran out of sight when the road bent.
“No.
This cannot be happening.”
Ceil paced in a circle.
“This cannot be happening!”
She ran to Sammy and pulled her up by her arm.
The bird no longer struggled and only sat on his back.
“Do you have any idea what you have done?!
You should have listened to me!
We should have fled!
I was seen!
Not as some High Elf living in the woods, not as some elf acting as a guide for two humans.
I am the only elf anywhere near my age with two tails on the entire continent!”
Sammy’s face grew pale.
“Oh, shit…”
Ceil continued pacing in a circle.
“We are in Melia.
For all they know, I could have fled here from Vallen.
The dryads already surrendered to Tolmyur.
If they think the Melians were hiding me in secret and only feigning servitude…
No, if they think the Melians and I sent those birds to attack the soldiers…”
Ceil shook uncontrollably.
She fell to her knees and gripped her arms.
Her nails dug in, and fresh blood dripped down her arm.
“This will be another genocide.
First the fairies, now the dryads.
I was right.
I bring death wherever I go.
How many more are going to die because of me?
How many more?
How many?”
Sammy peeled away Ceil’s hands.
“Stop!
You are hurting yourself.”
Ceil’s bulging eyes did not see Sammy.
They hollowly looked through her into a dark memory.
“I never should have left Fiorrae.
I never should have escaped the palace.
I should have died there.
Sammy pulled Ceil into a tight embrace.
“It’s okay.
This is not your fault.
Jethro is the cause of all this.
You cannot control what he does.”
Ever since the first day she met Ceil, Sammy had the impression that Ceil was a resilient and levelheaded woman to an annoying, almost arrogant degree.

For the first time, she saw Ceil as a frail girl who had been through the same if not far worse than Sammy had in the fall of Gullivan and was still battling desperately within herself to cope with the trauma.
“I couldn’t keep up with him.
He’s too fast.”
Chloe looked at Sammy embracing the shivering elf.
“What happened?”
Sammy explained the situation, and as she did, the color slowly drained from Chloe’s face as well.
“We have to warn them!
They won’t even know why they are being attacked!” Chloe shouted.
Ceil’s breath froze, and she looked up at Chloe with ghastly horror.
Chloe panicked and tried to comfort Ceil.
“No.
It’s not your fault.
Really!”
“You’re right, though,” Sammy agreed.
“We need to warn as many dryads as we can.
We don’t know if Tolmyur will attack, but if they do, the dryads need to be prepared.”
Sammy placed her hand on Ceil’s cheek and turned her head up to look her in the eyes.
Ceil’s eyes were wrinkled in anguish, but not a single tear fell.
“Can you walk?”
Sammy grabbed Ceil’s hand and lifted her to her feet.
Ceil leaned on Sammy for support as Sammy led her in the direction the soldier fled.
If any villages were to be targeted due to their mistake, the first would be those in the direction the soldiers appeared.
“Sorry Chloe, but can you drag Justin for a while until Ceil calms down?
It should be easier on the road.”
“Yah.” Chloe hurried over to where she left Justin on the roadside and lifted the front of the stretcher.
Am I forgetting something?
Sammy stopped and looked over her shoulder.
The bird was still on his back watching Sammy walk away.
“Are you going to just lay there?
You can’t fly, so I’ll help you until you can.”
The bird cocked his head, and Sammy sighed.
She beckoned the bird to follow and then continued walking.
He flapped his free wing to right himself and then tried to fly.
The burst of wind from his lone wing sent him rolling over the road to the right.
He cried a loud “kree!” after Sammy.
She turned her head to look at his large, pleading eyes.
“You are going to have to walk.”
She pointed to her feet and stamped them to help the bird understand.
He once again righted himself and after a few light steps began trotting to catch up.
Sammy’s first impressions were not wrong.
The bird was intelligent.

Chapter 8
“A Delicate Situation”
Byurk
Soldiers pitched crude leather tents in file where possible between the small-leafed yet large trees.
Much of the groundcover was trampled flat by the many boots running around preparing camp.
The organized chaos was something Captain Byurk knew well.
He could tell by the movements of his men that they were progressing smoothly and that camp would we ready within the hour.
Before they arrived, the forest clearing was idyllic, like a well nurtured garden without so much as a rock or mushroom out of place.
Those familiar with dryads would have recognized this as a village, and now the dryads were standing still with worried expressions watching the soldiers trample their home.
They did not move for fear of getting in someone’s way and angering them.
Dryad villages made the perfect camps because they were mostly located in clearings with sparse trees, little ground cover, and plenty of space because dryads had no need of structures.
Only a few of the larger villages in Dhuillir had physical structures for the convenience of other races.
A small village in Melia on the edge of dryad territory would have no need for such accommodations.
This also removed the need to evict residents.
The soldiers could simply pitch their tents in the plentiful open space.
One young dryad a little shorter than Byurk looked at him with fearful eyes while clinging to the leg of her mother.
He walked over to the child.
The mother directed her child behind her legs.
Byurk flashed a simple smile.
“Do not be scared.
We are only passing through,” he said.
The fear in the child’s eyes grew when Byurk spoke.
His attempt to calm her had no effect.
He spoke to her in Elven, but the child did not understand.
Her mother rubbed the child’s short, mossy hair and lifted her up to hold her and reassure her in the Melian language.
I know this is the middle of nowhere, but you should teach your child the main political language of your empire.
Normally, few would find reason to travel through Melia, and there was nothing in the Melian forests to attract merchants or travelers.
The only reason the soldiers were marching through was because this was the most direct route from Amel to the last remaining fairy cities north of Dhuillir in western Vallen.

Jethro had stated that Lieutenant Soppet was having trouble with the remaining fairy resistance, but Byurk received word while at the Amelian Palace that six major fairy cities had been destroyed, not to mention the many villages in-between them.
However, Lieutenant Soppet’s forces were now running low on supplies, and they had lost many good men.
The fairies spoiled any food or other resources as they fled, and this had severely weakened the offense.
What Byurk and his men brought with them was not only reinforcements but also much needed provisions.

These could have been teleported directly by Jethro as they had in the past, but with Jethro personally involved in the campaign to find the First Princess of Amel in some other world, he was not able to provide support.
The spatial mages in Amel had also fled, so there were none whom the commanders stationed there could order to send the resources.
This left Byurk the task of bringing aid to the weary soldiers on his return from recovering from a major injury sustained in an assassination attempt by the fairies.
Fires lit one by one around the camp as the sun set over the forest canopy.
Still, this is taking far too long on foot.
Byurk owed his life to the men still fighting on the frontlines.
The assassination attempt had nearly been successful.
A flying fairy had flown over his camp at night and drove a long, wind-imbued spear through the ceiling of his tent.
The aim was lucky and impaled the side of his right breast, pinning him to the ground.
He would not have survived the journey to Dhuillir to receive aid from the dryads.
His men used all means possible to sustain him and keep him alive until word reached Jethro and Jethro could teleport him to the Amelian Palace for treatment.
Those same men were running low on resources, and his convoy would still take another twenty days or more at their current pace.
The Amelian Empire lacked domesticated pack animals, and there were far too few in Tolmyur to support the military.

What few of those lumbering desert beasts that existed were formerly in the possession of the military until Jethro became Commanding General and felt they had more purpose in the hands of farmers, stating that he would transport supplies as needed.
Even if there were more available in Tolmyur that could be spared, without Jethro they had no means to transport them to Amel.
The largest flaw of their assault on Amel with Jethro’s aid was that they had not obtained a supply line from Tolmyur.

The Stollmuk Kingdom that acted as a barrier between Tolmyur and Amel was not outright hostile--they even traded with the dwarves--but they refused entry for any military or other large groups from Tolmyur.
They could not force their way through because the Stollmuk Kingdom was similar in strength to Amel despite its size, and they were still at full power.
Jethro was their only connection to their homeland.
The sun fully set, and the final tent was pitched, Byurk’s.
He quickly inspected it before joining his men for their meager dinner.
Their meals were rationed in order to save as much of their provisions as possible.
The chefs prepared a simple thin broth soup containing a single strip of dried meat and a few chunks of diced spuds.

As a small gesture of hospitality and plea for mercy, the village matriarch offered the soldiers herbal water she claimed would help with fatigue and also offered the women of the village to service the soldiers if desired.
Byurk accepted the water without fear of any foul play but declined the service.
His men would protest, but on their rationed food, they needed to conserve as much energy as possible.
The last thing he needed was for his men to be fatigued during their march the next day because they were up all night with women.
The gesture was enough for him.
The other states in Dhuillir provided no support for his men.
Some made no attempt to hide their contempt and rancor.
The Melians were different.
Every village in Melia had provided services or food so that they had less need to use the important supplies they carried.
Melian hospitality was better than anywhere Byurk had ever visited in Tolmyur, Amel, or elsewhere.
They were an honest, goodly people, and for that he was grateful.
After dinner, Byurk gave the soldiers momentary free time before retiring for bed.
The fires roared with light revelry as the men admired the many naked dryads scattered around the camp.
Dryads were similar in body to High Elves and thus similar to human women, so quite a number of his men did not mind the differences.
They beckoned the women to join them, but the dryads left the soldiers alone at Byurk’s order.
During this time, Byurk inspected the cargo for damage or theft.
The task was long and monotonous because each soldier had their own pack that they had to carry.
This also meant that stealing a small portion of rations from one’s own pack would be difficult to notice.
To counter this, each pack of like equipment or food had the same supply count.
He only needed to check that count against the number on the ledger.
With the aid of twenty of his most trusted and educated men, counting the five thousand individual packs required a couple hours, but he only took inventory once every four days.
By the time he finished, the bustle of the camps had died down, and the soldiers were retiring to their tents.
Byurk’s final task was enforcing the curfew so that his men received adequate rest.
He walked among the tents and urged his men to hurry to bed.
He was halfway through when he heard some commotion from the far side of the village near where the road passed.
“Captain!
Captain Byurk!”
Hearing his name from the panicked shout, Byurk hastened to the edge of the camp.
He was met by a winded and sweating scout he had sent with a mobile forward party tasked with scouting out potential threats and informing Lieutenant Soppet of his arrival with supplies.
The only reason a scout would return was if some disaster had befallen the party.
“Come to my tent.
We had best not talk in the open.”
The scout and Byurk’s lieutenant joined him in his tent.
Byurk sat on a simple fur folded on the ground.
The lieutenant and scout knelt in front of him.
“Take a moment to breathe and collect your thoughts.
Whatever has happened can wait a moment to be told.”
The scout took a few deep breaths and shook his head.
“I fear this cannot wait even a moment.
I found the widow of the emperor.”
“You what?” Byurk could not believe the report.

He trusted this scout, or he would not have sent him with the forward party, but to suddenly run into the one woman that much of the army stationed in the Amelian Empire was searching for without success felt too much like a drunken hallucination.
“Is she in the custody of your company?
Or perhaps killed?”
Again, the scout shook his head.
“No.
We were attacked by a flock of those buzzards.
Our ranger noticed some people traveling the road and ran ahead to intercept.
The people hid, and in the search, he noticed one of those buzzards.
We had been clearing them from the road along the way to ensure the safety of your convoy, and there were usually only one or two, but this time there were far too many.
Our entire company was wiped out.”
“Was the wife among the people the ranger spotted?” the lieutenant asked.
“How was he sure it was the wife?”
“We killed all but one of them birds, but a woman jumped out from the brush with a sword to save the last one.”
“The wife?” the lieutenant asked.
“I know you are eager, but let him finish,” Byurk reprimanded.
“No, a human woman, or maybe half dwarf.
A High Elf and another woman appeared after, and they worked together to treat the bird.
I feel it was them who set them birds on us.
During the treatment, I saw that the High Elf had two tails.
She held each one individually.
I saw it as clearly as I see you now.”
“And instead of killing her right then, you fled?!”
Byurk placed his hand on the lieutenant’s shoulder.
“Calm yourself.
You know very well the scouts are under strict instruction not to engage no matter what happens to the company.
They are to observe, survive, and report.”
“I thought about it, I did.
But I don’t think I could have attacked her and won.
That final woman with them, I thought she was an oread at first by her appearance, but she wasn’t.
She was a strong fire mage.
Strongest I’ve ever seen.
Her power could best any minum in our army.”
This news was troubling.
Locating the wife they had searched desperately for was wonderful news, but the attack on his men and the aid of two humans, one of whom was a talented fire mage, was ominous.
“Lieutenant, how many talented human women do you know among our fire mages, either deceased, missing, or in active duty?”
The lieutenant folded his arms and thought.
After a long period of silence, he shook his head.
“None, sir.
Women in the army are few outside medics.
I am sure that if such a talented woman existed, she would have been well known among the men, or more likely wed before ever entering the army.
To my knowledge, there are no active fire mages who are women.”
The only women conscripted into the army were those who were found unable to bear children.
They tended to be older than most recruits given the time taken to discover their infertility, and they were treated no different than men.
Byurk’s lieutenant was correct in that had such a talented woman existed within Tolmyur, she would be well known.
“I thought the same,” Byurk replied.
“However…”
There was one.
“What can you tell me about her magic?
I assume she attacked you as you fled,” Byurk asked.
“I was running too hard to see clearly, but the explosion from her fire would have taken five or more mages.
It landed far behind me but nearly blew the clothes off my back.
She did that on her own.”
Very troubling, indeed.
“Your assumption that this woman was an oread is troubling.
Oreads are earth nymphs.
Are you familiar with maenads?” Byurk asked.
The scout shook his head.
“They are fire nymphs with a volatile temperament.
Nymphs normally cannot use magic, but there was one woman I knew with skill in fire magic as you explained.
She was a half-maenad hunter mercenary traveling with Commanding General Jethro and I when we first arrived in Tolmyur.
She shared his vision but could not stand the living conditions of our homeland and left not a year later after the Coastal War ended.
But, I find it hard to believe that she would side with Amel.”
“Might I add some possible insight?” the lieutenant asked.
“Speak, lieutenant.”
“We are in Dhuillir, the home of the dryads.
Kissiae can manipulate the minds of others into obedience.

Constant contact is needed to control someone, but a potent enough dose of a kissiae’s poison is enough to make someone believe a certain way or obey a single instruction, more than a kissiae is capable on her own.
These two humans, especially one of such power, could have been manipulated in such a way to see the wife of the emperor as an ally and protect her.”
“But the dryads are on our side.
The kissiae are even working directly with our Commanding General, right?”
The scout’s eyes flitted between Byurk and the Lieutenant.
Byurk nodded.
“And the Elos marshlands are far from here.”
“What if they surrendered so quickly in order to protect themselves from attack but are in truth working to help the fleeing wife?
It would be the perfect cover.
None of us have been attacked by the dryads in the past, but now they have attacked our supply routes when the campaign against the fairies is in most need of supplies.
The timing is too perfect to be a coincidence,” the lieutenant said.
Worry grew on the scout’s face.
Their camp was in the center of a dryad village.
There were soldiers on watch shifts throughout the night, but dryads specialized in stealth and guerrilla warfare.
Life magic could kill silently.
A tenth or more of the soldiers could be killed in their sleep before anyone noticed.
“Let’s not be rash,” Byurk replied.
“While I cannot rule out that these dryads do not harbor ill feelings towards us, I doubt they would go so far as attacking us.”
“Sir, with the news from the scout, there is still a risk,” the lieutenant pushed.
“Call for the matriarch.
We cannot have our fears and assumptions create danger for our convoy where there is none.”
The lieutenant left the tent with haste and returned with the village matriarch.
Extreme worry showed on her face from the hastened manner the lieutenant brought her.
She knelt and bowed forward until her nose rested on the ground.
With a shaking voice, she spoke.
“Is something wrong my Lord?”
“We have received word of a danger to my soldiers traveling through Melia.
The company we sent ahead was attacked.
This man was the only survivor,” Byurk explained.
The matriarch’s trembling increased.
“I can assure you; my village had nothing to do with any attack on your men.
We would not dare harm a human.
I can call all our sisters together.
If there are any of us missing, we will help you investigate it thoroughly.”

The Amelian Empire’s use of human to collectively refer to all those from the Tolmyur Kingdom despite the minums being the ruling class and the minum language being the major political language of the kingdom was a source of irritation to Byurk, a minum, but he understood she meant no insult by it.
The elves, and by extension the empire, had dealings with the humans long before any interaction with minums.
That misnomer was simply cultural on their part.
“That will not be needed,” Byurk replied.
The matriarch looked up at Byurk with fear and pleading.
An investigation would not be necessary if he planned to kill them all here and now.
“The ones who attacked were not dryads but a flock of blue hawks.”
“The Habha?”
“What my scout tells me is that these hawks were sent on our men by a High Elf, the missing wife of the emperor we have been searching for.”
“The wife?
Was she not in Vallen?”
Byurk stared into the matriarch’s eyes.
There was fear and confusion hiding in her deep, viridescent irises, but he did not sense any sign of deceit.
Her eyes bore the truth of her belief that the wife was still in Vallen.
This village had no foreknowledge that the wife had made it to Melia.
The fear in the Matriarch’s eyes quickly grew to terror during Byurk’s fixed stare.
She crawled to him and grasped at the skirt of his robe.
“Please.
I beg you.
We Melians have already surrendered to you.
We will not resist.
My village has not sided with the wife nor will we.
Have mercy on our land.”
The estate of the wife’s family in Amel was demolished.
The village of the wife’s youth was razed.
She took refuge in Vallen, and now only a handful of fairy cities remained in the entire kingdom.
Now that the wife appeared, the matriarch feared that the same as what was happening in Vallen would befall Melia.
“I have no intention of resorting to meaningless slaughter,” Byurk assured.
The Matriarch gripped tight the skirt of Byurk’s robe and pressed her forehead into the ground in gratitude.
“I do not think the Melians have chosen to willingly shelter the wife.
If the Habha are involved, she may have come from Fiorrae.
There are a far greater number of them there.”
Those hawks are the sole reason we have been unable to pressure the sprites to surrender, and normally the sprites do not meddle in affairs outside their territory.
“I feel that it is the sprites who have sided with the wife, and now she is taking action.
She may be in your lands, but I do not wish for war to break out in Melia.
My question is why has she chosen now to show herself?
If you know anything, tell me.”
The matriarch slowly raised her head, but her eyes did not meet Byurk’s, only staring at his chest.
Her mouth opened and closed, opened and closed again.
After licking her dry lips, she spoke.
“One who walks is among us.
That may be her reason.”
“One who walks?
What do you mean?”
The matriarch hesitated.
“This knowledge concerns the wellbeing of your people.
Telling me is in Melia’s best interest.”
The matriarch’s head lowered apologetically, so Byurk assumed that she would remain silent, but to his surprise, she complied.
“When a dryad lives to a great age, she grows roots.
Without her consent, they cling to the ground with each step to root her.”
“Hamadryads…” Byurk now understood her apologetic form.
Tolmyur had assassinated the three hamadryads at the beginning of the war.
Her apology was directed at the new hamadryad whose life could be threatened by this information.
“Yes.
When a dryad reaches the age of roots, she begins a pilgrimage to each of the dryad tribes and remains in those lands until she earns those tribes’ support as their Grandmatriarch.”
Anxiety gripped Byurk’s chest.
“Do you know how many tribes have given her their support?”
“She was born among the cedars, so we are seventh in order.
She is in Melia, so we can assume six tribes have accepted her as Grandmatriarch.”
“If Melia accepts her, she would have the support of nearly half of the tribes.” Byurk scratched the strip of grey hair along the side of his head in consternation.
Tolmyur was ignorant of Dhuillir’s politics and the new hamadryad.
This was the same as their ignorance about Ceil, the emperor’s secret wife.
Ceil’s appearance could have no other reason than her desire to meet with the new hamadryad now that the hamadryad reached the tribe closest to where she was hiding in Fiorrae.
If she persuades the hamadryad to side with her, those tribes who accepted the hamadryad would side with her also.
Should the hamadryad complete her pilgrimage and become Grandmatriarch, all of Dhuillir would side with the wife.
Without Jethro, Tolmyur could not fight two fronts against both Vallen and Dryads.
Or perhaps they could if they finished the campaign in Vallen quickly, but the losses on their side would be severe, and that could destabilize their position in the former Amelian Empire.
The presence of both Ceil and the hamadryad in Melia was an imminent threat.
“We could kill the hamadryad,” Byurk spoke under his breath, and the matriarch shrunk beneath him as if she knew this would be the decided conclusion.
He looked at her meek frame and thought again on the generosity the Melians had shown.
Most the dryads disliked warfare and were one of the first nations to surrender to Tolmyur to avoid further conflict.
Siding with the wife would bring war on a level equal to the destruction of the fairies, a terribly foolish decision.

If he could convince the hamadryad to continue their submission to Tolmyur, not only could the hamadryad unify the dryads in the truce, but she could also use the dryads to better aid the capture of the wife.
Byurk gently grasped the wrist of the matriarch and raised her to her knees.
“No, I do not desire the death of your hamadryad.
If her desire is to keep Melia and all Dhuillir safe, we will need her help.
Inform all surrounding villages that our target, Ceil, the widow of the former Emperor, has arrived in their lands.
If she comes to their village, capture her and send word to me, our forces in Vallen, and the Amelian Palace.
Warn them that if they side with her, they risk bringing Commanding General Jethro’s fury upon them.
It will be out of my hands then.
If you know where the hamadryad is, inform her that I seek audience.”
The light of hope glistened in the matriarch’s eyes.
“I will send messengers at once!”
She ran from the tent into the night.
“Have our plans changed?”
“No, lieutenant.
Our men in Vallen need these resources.
You will leave tomorrow as scheduled.”
“Me, sir?”
“I will take a party with me and meet with the hamadryad.
You will lead the rest of the convoy in my place.”
The scout bowed his head.
“With permission, I want to bring message to Amel about the wife’s sighting.”
“Perfect. Do so.
Should Jethro return from his campaign, his help in capturing her and convincing the hamadryad will be invaluable.
Get some rest and depart in the morning.”
“Sir.” The scout and lieutenant left the tent.
Byurk unfolded the fur he sat on and laid down on it.
He thought he would be elated that the widow had been located, if that was truly Ceil, but no part of this sat right with him.
Why was she working with humans?
Why would the small nation of sprites, no larger than pixies and thought to only have a population of a few hundred, ally with her?
Most concerning of all, how would the Melians and the hamadryad react to her appearance?
What if she requested or even demanded their aid?
By right, Ceil was the Empress of the Amelian Empire because the first princess had yet to take up the throne.
There may be many among the Melians who still support the former dynasty or will obey due to a sense of obligation.
The Melians do not deserve to be pulled into this war.
Byurk blew out his lantern and hoped with all his heart that Jethro would return promptly from the other world to aid in a quick capture of the widow before anything happened to Melia.

Chapter 9
“A Frog in a Well”
Jethro
“Both you and Eydis FeAmel have a much greater role to play than revenge, so I am compelled to restrain your hand.
I ask that you discontinue your plans to invade this world.”
Jethro walked down the crowded streets of an unfamiliar city with his hands in the pockets of his leather jacket.
The clothing of this world was far more comfortable than the crude material found in Tolmyur.
His robe was far too conspicuous, and without this country’s currency, Jethro was forced to make use of his spatial magic to steal clothing.
He grew a short goatee, the only style of facial hair that was not shown on the bottom of the facial composite the doppelganger created.
Without this level of caution, he would not have been able to travel unnoticed.
Again, he found himself stuck in a foreign world, except this time he entered it in open hostility, not out of scientific curiosity.
He took precautions and made preparations to be able to return to Whinhlem, but those preparations were undone by a single woman no larger than his hand, but this was only temporary.
The pulse she sent through his body before departing restrained his magic, specifically his inter-world transmission and teleportation spells.
He spent every available hour the first few weeks investigating the foreign ven in his body.

He thought at first that she had cast some form of life magic because she used it by touch, but over time he realized that it was spatial magic of an unfathomable complexity, perhaps combined with life magic for the application.
It was a barrier implemented such that it blocked any spatial ven of the specific signature created by his inter-world formulas and nothing else.
He could travel this world visiting the major cities to learn of the peoples and cultures, but the moment he tried to teleport back to Whinhlem, the flow of ven in his body seized up.
Every attempt to determine the makeup or encryption of the magic ended in failure.
It was far too complex for him to understand, and he doubted he would be able to decipher it in his lifetime.
The only positive outcome of his investigation was that the magic skillfully placed in his body had a time limit.

The woman who cast it had made no attempt to hide this, almost as if he was a scolded child sat in a chair and then told by his parent that when the clock hands were both vertical he could leave, and this frustrated him to no end.
At least he knew the identity of what did this to him.
It was a sprite.
Jethro was surprised by the number of sprites on Whinhlem.
To his knowledge, there were only two on his home world, Trattnou, and they were both well known.
They worked directly under Lord Tentopreklefit and only for observational purposes.
The sprites on Whinhlem were not only far larger in number, but they also had the freedom to organize and form their own society.
Now on Earth, there was a sprite who directly hindered his plans.
The sprites on Trattnou never used magic, so Jethro had no idea if the power of the sprite on Earth was normal.

He could have accepted failure if it was due to his own underestimation of the capabilities of the people of Earth, but to fail because of the interference of a third party with power far surpassing his own made his skin crawl.
The outcome was out of his hands from the beginning.
From what that sprite said, she planned to interfere in his capture of the princess from the start.
She likely knew everything about what was happening on Earth just like the two in his world did about everything on Trattnou.
If she was going to actively prevent Jethro from interfering in this world, his only real choice was to wait until her magic wore off.
Jethro picked up an English newspaper from the stand he passed and tossed the vendor a few coins.
He fled the continent he invaded for a small island country on the other side of the planet that also spoke English but with a heavy accent.
Or it could be more correctly stated that this country spoke the correct dialect of English because the language bore this country’s name.

Politics, trade, war, colonialization, or a combination of many different factors had spread the language throughout the world to lands far larger than the country of origin, but this world was still too primitive to have a unified language, and that limited where he could stay comfortably while waiting.
At least without a global society, his facial composite would not travel as fast, if at all, outside the country he invaded, but because there was a risk, he bought a local paper every few days.

His invasion made international news as did the princess’s press conference, but his face had yet to appear in the news in England, at least to his knowledge with the limited resources at his disposal.
A small drop of rain ruined Jethro’s plan to find a bench to peruse the paper.
He walked the streets until he found a store with a restroom.
Once inside, he opened a portal and stepped through to an abandoned studio, or at least he was sure it was abandoned.
The paved floor had a thin layer of dust, and the room was barren aside from four cement pillars.
The windows were high off the ground and had bars on them.
The metal double doors had a chain and lock on the outside.
There was no way to get inside unless one owned the key or could teleport.
This created the perfect hideaway, but it was often cold.
Jethro walked to the corner to some cardboard and a stack of papers.
He sat cross-legged on the cardboard and set aside the newspaper.
With a pen in hand, he spread the papers across the ground.
They were covered in sigils.
Most were attempts to decipher the spell cast on him by the sprite, but once he gave up on that endeavor, he started a new task.
If the spell prevented him from using his inter-world transmission and teleportation, he needed to develop a new formula.
His first few attempts involved minor changes to the original formula to enable it to keep the same functionality.
This only worked briefly.
The sprite’s spell did not react immediately, but his ven seized up before the transmission activated.
The reason was likely due to its similarity to the original, but he feared making major changes without Emer’s guidance.
Now he was approaching the issue from a different direction.
If he could not send something physical, perhaps he could send a wave or pulse or form of energy via teleportation.
The sun had set below the horizon by the time Jethro felt confident in his design, the cold studio growing almost too dark to see if not for the faint city lights outside the windows.
Because what he was sending was not physical, the formula was surprisingly simple compared to the inter-world teleportation formula that Emer had made by chance.
It also required far less ven than the inter-world transmission.

He thought about using transmission as the base instead of regular teleportation, but he would be limited in what kind of signals could be sent over due to the near-instantaneous nature of transmission.
If a code was agreed upon with the receiver beforehand, perhaps it might work, but for now that was impossible.
“Let’s see if this works.
But who to send it to?”
There was something that weighed on his mind since his invasion failed, and this would make a perfect test of the new magic.
He activated his magic, but there was no physical manifestation like the jagged rift in the air created by a normal portal.
There was no light or sound like transmission.
“Is it working?”

His ven was not blocked by the sprite’s spell, so he was certain that the magic he cast did or was doing something, and unlike teleportation which used all the ven required for it immediately, this spell slowly drained his ven while active.
“Markus, can you hear me?”.
Silence
Jethro spoke a bit louder.
“Markus, are you there?”
He then waited again but not for long.
A mildly distorted voice came from the air.
“Jethro?
Where are you?”
“Brilliant! It worked!”
Jethro shot his fists into the air ecstatic that he was able to show up the sprite that had trapped him on Earth.
“What is the meaning of this?
I cannot see you.”
“My apologies, Markus.
I am currently in another world, and I cannot make it back for a while.”
“Have you returned to your world?”
Jethro shook his head despite knowing that Markus could not see him.
“No. I am on another world that the Amelian princess fled to, surprisingly.”
“You are not the only one capable of teleporting between worlds?”
“It is a complicated story.
Due to troublesome circumstances, my teleportation back to Whinhlem is being blocked.”
“I pray this is temporary.”
“It is, but I am not completely sure when my probation here will end.”
“What need do you have of me?
You would not have contacted me this late otherwise.”
Jethro paused to think of the time difference.
Days on Earth were not exactly one half of days on Whinhlem, but close.
He was almost on the other side of the planet from the city he invaded.
If he considered that difference and estimated the time lost, but then account for the tilted axis, which meant latitude and change in tilt over time…
Too troublesome.
“I have a question.
Did an injured man appear in your study about forty or so days ago?
He was shot in the stomach with a small projectile.
There might have been two women with him.”
“I am not your personal doctor, Jethro.
I am the King’s.
If he discovered that I was making house calls, he would execute me, forget that I am the only life mage in Tolmyur.”
“That young man is worth the risk.
He is a peculiar time mage.”
“A time mage?”
“One that ignores channeling time.”
“Isn’t he simply using time magic to speed it up?”
“That is recursive reasoning.
The spell to decrease channeling time would need channeling time to cast.
And I forgot to mention he is human.”
“A human with a time affinity?
Are you trying to make a set?
I’m sorry Jethro, but I don’t think you will find one with an affinity to gravity.”
“That was not my intent.
Back to my original question.
Were you able to treat him?”
“No injured appeared in my study.”
“I figured as much.”
Jethro paced in a circle.
The Sprite altered the destination.
He might not even be on Whinhlem.
If he was still on Earth, he would have likely returned to the princess by now.
“What is the meaning of all this, Jethro?”
“My teleportation was intercepted mid cast.”
“Is that even possible?”
“I suppose it is, because it happened.
I will not go into details, but my plan was to show that man what kind of country Tolmyur is.
Given his time affinity, I assumed he would get pulled into the military and rise in rank rather quickly.”
“Following in your footsteps?”
“More allowing him to see what I saw when I first came to Tolmyur and to learn our purpose in attacking the Amelian Empire.
I forgot to mention he is a friend of the princess, and from her screams when he vanished, possibly something more.”
“By the God’s, Jethro.
What are you plotting?”
“No plotting.
This was more of a whim, but if he is not there, then nothing can be done.
I will let you rest.”
“Jethro.”
Jethro was about to end his spell when Markus spoke.
“What is it, Markus?”
Markus’s voice was hushed, which made it difficult to understand in the distortion.
“I may not be your personal life mage, but I can be.
All you need to do is give me the word, and I will do it on the King’s next examination.
You already have the blessing of most the military and the people.
We will support you.”
“I know…”
Jethro ended the spell.
The total ven expenditure from the entire conversation was about the same as a single inter-world transmission.
He leaned back and thought about Markus’s parting words.
He knew what the people thought of him and their oppression under the current King, but he had made a promise to work personally with the people.
That was not possible sitting on the throne.
Even if he became king, life for the people of Tolmyur would not suddenly improve, even in his lifetime.
The land was mostly inhospitable, and they had no means of escaping it in mass.
The Stollmuk Mountains to the west were controlled by the golems.
The golems disliked most humans but were not hostile, and due to their agreement with the Amelian Empire, humans were not allowed to enter their territory.
Even if they could, the mountains were treacherous, and what awaited them on the other side was their eternal enemy, the Amelian Empire.
To the south were the sirens, and to the east were the merfolk.
As powerful seamen as giants were, Tolmyur lacked the technology to construct ships sturdy enough to safely transport large groups through siren or merfolk territory.
Every attempt saw the ships sink before crossing the horizon, especially now that sirens and merfolk could enter their coastal waters.
The marshes to the north were controlled by the goblins.
Those who attempted to escape Tolmyur traveled north through the swamps into the wilderlands, and many had been successful, but any attempt at a large exodus ended with a massacre by the goblins.

If Jethro wanted to help the people of Tolmyur, the best option he felt he had was to reverse the events that placed them in their natural and political prison ages ago, and that meant the complete destruction of the Amelian Empire.
Jethro activated his inter-world communication spell, this time targeting the Amelian Palace.
He was unsure where to place the destination, but the one he desired to speak to would be able to sense the spatial ven.
“Emer, can you hear me?”
After calling out a few more times, he attempted a different location in the palace.
When that failed, he tried another.
He then felt embarrassed with himself.
There was little point being discreet in Amel like he had been when contacting Markus.
He targeted the central courtyard where a few soldiers were always stationed and amplified the output.
“This is your commanding general.
If you can hear me, speak.”
He could hear muffled conversations but was unable to make any sense of it.
After a moment of silence, a single voice came from the other end.
“Sir, we cannot see you.
May I ask you to report where you are?”
The soldiers would obviously be skeptical of a voice from the air.
The man speaking was likely an officer who knew about his campaign and was asking for proof or clarification of Jethro’s identity.
Jethro was grateful that his men were not so easily fooled by a voice, even if it was his.
“I am currently in the other world.
Bring Emer and any other officers on hand.
The mission to capture the princess has failed, and there is much I need to discuss.”
“Sir!”
Jethro could hear muffled footsteps and the clanking of armor.
The officer who replied gave orders to the soldiers in the courtyard, but they became too distorted for Jethro to understand.
While he waited, he began to feel slight restriction of his ven.
“I need Emer here now!”
The spell the sprite cast on him was adapting.
It did not activate instantly, but his continued use of inter-world magic triggered it.
Somehow, she programmed into the formula a method for it to actively learn and mutate.
“Hurry!”
How is this even possible?
How did that sprite create a living spell?!
Jethro heard a voice that sounded like Emer’s but he could not understand it.
“Emer!
Read the trace from this spell!
Find my location and open a portal!”
All Jethro heard was muffled replies.
“Get my location from this spell and open a portal to this world!
Do you understand me?!”
His ven seized up, and the spell collapsed.
In anger, Jethro tore the papers of sigils and threw the shreds.
Jethro cursed his own curiosity over the man who could use time magic.
If he had thought longer about how to test the new spell and who to contact first, what was most important, he could have returned to Whinhlem with Emer’s help.
If he had considered the possibility that the restriction spell would have such a delayed activation, he might have been able to return before it activated.
“You surprised me.
As expected of The Bridge between Worlds.”
A faint feminine voice spoke in Jethro’s head.
He would not mistake the voice of the one who trapped him on Earth.
Jethro looked around to find the source of the voice, but the dark cement studio was empty.
“While I commend you for your ingenuity, I feel I must also punish you.”
The small womanly figure appeared in front of his face and placed her hand on his forehead.
Another pulse surged through his body, and Jethro felt the distinct sensation of spatial magic use.
The sprite then disappeared before he could react.
“I have reset the clock.
Take the extra time to think about what you are doing.”
Jethro could not protest.
What else did he expect?
He sat back against the cold cement wall and stared into the dark.

* * *
“Jethro?”
The voice Emer heard from the peculiar spatial magic no longer responded.
According to the soldiers who summoned him, Jethro’s voice was clearer before he arrived.
Although the voice was Jethro’s, Emer could not understand it.
“Could you make out what he was saying?”
Keeya’s voice in his head gave a short reply, “No.”
Emer turned to the human officer who was there when Jethro first made contact.
“What did Jethro say before I arrived?”
The officer looked at the soldiers around him.
Emer was an elf, and although he was a slave of Jethro’s, they were unsure what they should tell him, if anything at all.
“If Jethro called for me, the information he gave was for my ears as well.”
The three officers discussed quietly.
After coming to an agreement, the initial officer stepped forward.
“All we know is that the invasion has failed.”
Like the sun rising in the clear sky on a winter morning, radiant warmth filled Emer’s chest.
The city burned when Emer tested the return spell from the other world, but somehow the princess avoided Jethro.
Such an opportunity to capture her would not come again, at least not as easily.
“You have spatial magic.
We want you to send messages to inform the commanders.”
Emer looked at the dwarf who was trying to give him orders.
“I do not serve you.
Send your own messengers.”
Angry mumblings rose from the soldiers in the courtyard.
The officers looked at Emer with displeasure.
Two of them gripped their sheathed swords.
One of the soldiers ran to the officer’s side.
“Sir, the Commanding General might be in danger.
He was yelling for the elf before you returned.”
“You have the ability to go to the other world.
You should ascertain your master’s safety,” the dwarf ordered next.
Emer smiled.
“Keeya, did you hear Jethro ask for our help?”
Keeya shook her head.
“Did he ever give us an order to save him if he was in trouble?”
“No,” she spoke in a faint voice.
The soldiers shouted in protest, and the faces of the officers grew stern.
The human officer drew his sword and stepped towards Emer.
“You betray your own master?”
“I only do as I am ordered.
Whether Jethro is in danger or not makes no difference to me.
He can stay and die in that world.”
A small tinge of pain pricked the back of Emer’s mind.
“Be careful what say,” Keeya reprimanded.
“Unless Jethro order’s me, I will not act,” Emer asserted.
“Know your place!”
The blade of the officer slashed crosswise at Emer.
The strike was not to kill, only maim.
It deflected a few inches from Emer’s arm with a metallic ring.
Such a weak strike could never break a barrier made by the Amelian Empire’s leading spatial magic expert.
Before the officer could recover from the recoil, strands of ivy grew and wrapped around the officer’s sword arm and crept up to his torso.
The officer’s wrist pulled back, and his sword pointed at his chest.
The tip of the blade slowly dug into the leather armor and pierced it.
The vines did not force his arm; they hung slack.
The man used his own strength.
He hollered a terrified scream.
The other officers and soldiers rushed to subdue Emer and Keeya, but they were stopped by Emer’s barrier.
They all watched as the officer slowly drove the blade through his chest in a terrifying display of kissiae power.
Keeya’s long ivy hair unwound from his arm and hung to the ground.
She looked around at the soldiers with listless eyes.
“No one hurt Emer.
Jethro order.”
Emer flashed a pleased grin.
“To think one of Jethro’s own officers would disobey him.
That is proper punishment for disobedience, is it not?”
The soldiers watched in shock as Emer opened a portal back to his office and stepped through, pulling Keeya’s long ivy hair after him.

Chapter 10
“The Reward for Hard Work”
Sammy
“No. Get away… Leave me alone.
Sammy!”
Sammy sat up after hearing her name called during her restless sleep.
“Get this buzzard away from me!”
She rubbed her sleep-drunk eyes until they found focus in the dark.
Beside her, Ceil leaned on her elbow with her other arm pushing at what looked like a headless bird.
His two long, yellow plumes stuck out and forward, looking not altogether unlike large moth antennae.
Sammy thought she was dreaming and rubbed her eyes again.
It was only then that she realized the large blue hawk’s head was turned around and buried into the feathers on his back.
He was sitting right where, or next to where, Ceil’s head would be should she lay back down.
This was not the first time he had nestled up next to Ceil at night, but over the past few days, Ceil was too distraught to care.
Sammy saw Ceil’s current frustration as a sign of progress after Ceil had emotionally shut down when her tails were seen.
“Stop staring and move him,” Ceil demanded.
Sammy sighed.
She reached over and gently lifted the incredibly light bird.
The two moth antennae twisted round and became the long yellow plumes they once were when his head unburied and looked at Sammy quizzically.
He snapped his beak twice in protest.
“I know.
I know.
You are only trying to help.”
She sat him down next to Justin’s head so that his feathers would help keep Justin warm.
“You don’t need to worry about Ceil.
What happened was not your fault.”
“Yes it was,” Ceil protested, pushing herself up to a slanted kneel, leaning on her right arm.
“Can you keep it down?” Chloe’s weary voice broke up the conversation.
“Sorry, Chloe,” Sammy apologized.
“We will.
Go back to sleep.”
Chloe turned her back to everyone and shifted closer to Justin to fill the small gap she created.
A few seconds later, deep breaths announced she was fast asleep already.
Sammy brushed the breast feathers of the hawk’s belly.
“See that?
We are bothering Chloe, so stay here between Justin and me, okay?”
The bird lightly snapped his beak but turned his head to his back once again creating the odd moth antennae.
“Sorry Ceil.
I didn’t even notice he had moved from here.”
Ceil shook her head with and exasperated and slightly sunken expression.
“No, you haven’t been sleeping well.
On top of that, you’ve had to take care of Justin, that buzzard… and me…”
Taking care of the bird was Sammy’s responsibility because both Chloe and Ceil felt she should have left him.
Chloe was, of course, doing her part in helping Justin, but Sammy could not leave him to her alone because she still felt personally responsible for his condition.
In Ceil’s distraught state, she only clung to Sammy, further increasing the load Sammy bore.
Sammy could not deny that she felt stretched thin like an elastic band about to snap.
Her neck and right shoulder ached considerably, and her body felt sickly.
There was no other way to describe it.
The only solace she found was that the added stress was warding away her nightmares about Jethro and the attack on Gullivan.

She had too many other things on her mind to worry about--finding help for Justin, learning enough about Whinhlem to be useful, tending to Coby’s injury so that he could survive on his own, helping Ceil’s emotional distress, the soldiers learning of Ceil’s identity and placing the dryads in danger, something Sammy was directly at fault for--but those constant worries made her feel less rested than the former nightmares.
No matter how much she meditated or tried to think of something else, those worries forced themselves to the front of her mind as if they had a life of their own.
Sammy pulled Ceil into a light embrace.
“Don’t worry about that.
We have to take care of each other when one of us is down.”
Ceil’s fingers gripped Sammy’s shirt, and her head hung apologetically.
“Let’s get to bed.”
Sammy laid Ceil down, and she clung to Sammy’s arm as she slept.
“That’s all you get,” Sammy barked.
“Kree!”
“Don’t give me that tone.
She needs it more than you.
You don’t have a fire affinity.”
The large blue bird stood taller than Sammy as she sat down eating her breakfast next to the small fire.
He clicked and snapped his beak near Chloe to beg for handouts.
The breakfast included a few strips of dried meat, which Sammy also gave the bird out of her own portion, but Chloe was given extra compared to everyone else.
The species of hawk was omnivorous, so he had already eaten his allotment of herbs and roots.
“We should not even be wasting our food on it.
You have a hard enough time taking care of Justin,” Ceil said.
“He’s healing just fine, and once he can fly again, he’ll leave.
Besides, I gathered these this morning.”
Sammy placed her hand on the far side of the bird’s beak and turned its head towards her.
He responded by rubbing its beak on the side of her head and nipping at her hair.
“This morning?
When?!”
Ceil looked exasperatedly at Sammy.
“I woke up early and couldn’t go back to sleep, so I decided to do something useful.”
Sammy knew Ceil wanted to protest, but Ceil remained silent.
Gathering food was normally Ceil’s job, but Ceil was not motivated to do anything, and her expression slowly became one of guilt.
Sammy realized her words could have been understood as a jab at Ceil, but she could not think of a way to correct herself without laying more pressure on Ceil’s emotional state.
Instead, she gave a simple and sincere smile to tell Ceil not to worry.
Being the first to finish her meal, Sammy separated a small distance from the group with the sword in hand dragging on the ground beside her.
She had little strength to lift it anymore.
She sat down and removed a wrapped eighth of a beiju bulb from the medicine bag at her waist.
Carefully using the blade near the hilt, she chopped the softened root into tiny pieces atop her thigh.
Once small enough, she placed them on a square cloth, wrapped them up, and twisted the corners to seal them in.
With her other hand, she gripped the small bubble of fabric to crush the root.
Her grip was weak, so a lot of effort was needed, making beads of sweat run down her forehead into her eyebrows in the cold morning air.
When one forearm tired, she switched to the other ignoring the juice that leaked through the fabric into her lap until the root on the inside had the consistency of mashed potatoes.
Her arms shook when finished.
She then returned to the group and placed the wad of fabric close enough to the fire to heat and steam but not catch fire.
When the juices bubbled through the fabric, she retrieved it, rinsed the dirt off with water magic, and approached the bird.
“Come here.”
The bird jumped back and flapped its free wing.
The wind kicked up dirt and extinguished the small fire, causing no small complaints from Chloe and Ceil, and it almost knocked Sammy off her weak legs.
“Oh no you don’t.”
Sammy sprung forward and grabbed the free wing, and in a repeat of his first treatment to remove the arrow, she straddled him.
“Kree!”
“Can it.
This is for your own good.”
Sammy spread the feathers on his shoulders for a better view of the arrow wound.
“See?
It’s sealing up nicely.”
She pressed the poultice on the wound and held it there as the bird’s large round eyes pleaded with her like she had betrayed him.
His melodramatic performance repeated itself every morning, alternating every other day between applying medicine on the entry or exit wound, so Sammy was not swayed.
Sammy’s arms quivered as she held down the bird as large as her and tried to hide her heavy breathing.
Beads of sweat dripped from her nose onto the bird’s beak.
Sammy’s eyes lost focus momentarily, and her head nodded forward.
When Sammy recovered and shook off her sickly exhaustion, his eyes lost their drama, only staring blankly at her.
They sat motionless until the moisture of the poultice seeped into the wound.
She tried to stand but staggered forward.
The bird swung its wing to create a gust of wind just strong enough to push her upright.
He then righted himself and clicked his beak twice.
“Thanks,” Sammy said with an exhausted grin, and she rubbed the feathers just above his beak.
“You can go back to pestering Ceil now.”
“He can what?” Ceil called from beside the fire Chloe re-stoked, having missed the entire treatment.
Without turning to face Ceil, Sammy shook her head.
“You may deny it, but his constant attention has actually helped you recover.”
Ceil did not reply, and Sammy could not see her reaction, but she was sure Ceil understood she was correct.
The clicking of a beak and Ceil’s low grumbling told Sammy all she needed to know.
Sammy rinsed the cloth thoroughly with water magic and used it to wipe the sweat off her face.
She then rinsed it again, rung it out, and returned it to the medicine pouch.
Lacking the energy to retrieve the sword, she returned to the fire to sit between Chloe and Justin and began running her fingers through his hair.
“Sammy, you keep calling the bird he or him,” Chloe said as soon as Sammy was settled.
“Have you considered naming him?”
“Do not name him,” Ceil protested while trying to keep the bird from nipping at her right ear.
“What’s the harm?
I think that’s a great idea,” Sammy said with a weak smile.
“But what kind of name?”
Chloe sat with a pensive face and her arms crossed in thought.
“With all the writing I do, I have to come up with a lot of names, and deciding on a good one is one of the hardest parts of creating a good character.”
“My family is terrible at naming,” Sammy said.
“I am named after my grandmothers.
My first name from my mom’s side, my middle name from my dad’s.”
“Did you have any pets?” Chloe asked.
“A budgie, but that’s it.
It’s a small bird,” Sammy explained for Ceil, showing the approximate size by spreading her thumb and forefinger.
“What was his name?”
“We were going to name him Budge.”
Chloe breathed and exasperated sigh, and Sammy chuckled.
“See?
We were bad at coming up with names.
But we didn’t name him Budge.
While I think it would have been cute now, as a kid, I thought it was an ugly name.
We named him Watchet.”
Chloe raised her head and looked at Sammy for an explanation.
“It’s a light blue color that matched his feathers.
No more imagination needed than knowing obscure colors… wait…”
Both Ceil and Chloe stared at Sammy until she shouted her epiphany.
“Coby!
His feathers are cobalt!
We’ll call him Coby!”
Sammy pointed at Coby and repeated his name.
“Coby!”
Coby cocked his head to the side in confusion and then mildly nipped at the tip of Ceil’s long ear without looking away from Sammy.
“Stop that!” Ceil pushed Coby’s beak away and sighed.
“Sammy, is it common for human names to end like that?”
“What do you mean?”
“Your name is Sammy.
Then you have Chloe.
You named this thing Coby.
They all end in the same sound.”
“Oh, not really.
I guess it is common for shortening names, like Thomas goes to Tommy.
My real name is Samantha, but I shorten it to Sammy.”
“Coby is short for Cobalt?”
Chloe laughed.
“No.
Cobalt is not a normal name.
Coby is an actual name, and like mine, it’s not short for anything.
Coby is just Coby, and I am Chloe.
Not all names shorten like that.
Justin doesn’t become Justy.”
Sammy chuckled.
“But Dustin does become Dusty!”
Chloe echoed Sammy’s chuckle.
“Don’t confuse her.
What we are saying is that it depends on the name.”
Ceil shook her head.
“Human culture is odd.
Why change the name you are given?
Elves would never consider doing so.
Each name has a meaning and blessing given by one’s parents, and changing that would be an insult to them.”
“Some people change their names to be truer to who they are.
For me, my parents are the ones who started calling me Sammy from as early as I can remember.”
“Then I guess that is excusable.”
“What does Ceil mean,” Chloe asked.
Ceil grew silent, then hesitant.
“You don’t need to tell us if you don’t want to,” Sammy assured her.
“No.
It is only a little embarrassing.
Most names are given with high expectations for the child’s future.
Mine is the opposite.
I was born with two tails, something extremely rare, so my mother named me Ceil.”
“Does it have something to do with tails?”
Ceil shook her head.
“It means grain.
Ceil is an ear of grain.”
Sammy did not understand the connection, but she could at least tell that there was little grand about grain.
“A woman with a strong name attracts a lot of attention.
My best friend from my hometown was named Linoa, which means strength or prowess.
She was very strong for her age.
She was a little older than me.
When palace guards came to rip me from my home, she was able to fend off one of the guards on her own until three pinned her to the ground.
Names come with blessings, and those blessings grow to fruition as the child grows.”
Ceil briefly fell silent into a memory.
“Linoa is an unusual name for a girl.
Most families give names like Eydis.
Eydis means empowerment through wisdom, fitting for the future Empress.
It is a name that begs attention.
I would already attract a lot of attention once others learned of my two tails.
Ceil is a homely name.

My mother’s hope for me was that I would live a modest life in our small farming village, but then my father sold me to the emperor against my mother’s wishes, and now here I am, empress of a fallen empire, widow of the late emperor, and causing the deaths of countless innocent people just by existing.”
Ceil stood and ripped her staff out of the ground, tearing the small roots that bound it.
“Time to depart.
We need to find a village quickly.”
Regret gripped at Sammy’s heart.
This was supposed to have been a lighthearted conversation.

Instead, they accidently stepped on a landmine they never knew existed, but setting off that landmine gave Ceil the volition to move instead of requiring Sammy to drag her along, although she knew that kind of motivation would do more harm than help to Ceil’s mental health.
Regardless of her feelings on the matter and her own desire to rest a little longer, Sammy wanted to take advantage of Ceil’s heightened willpower.
She walked over to the sword she left on the ground and placed it in her belt with a shaking arm.
When Chloe finished prepping to leave, they both took an end of Justin’s stretcher.
When Sammy reached down to grab it, Coby nipped at her hand.
“Hey!”
When she tried to grab it again, Coby nipped her once more, this time harder, drawing a little blood on the back of her hand.
“Stop that!
We need to leave!
Don’t make me tie that beak of yours.”
Coby blew Sammy to her back with a weak gust of wind from his free wing.
“Kree!” He bounced lightly between her and the stretcher.
“He doesn’t want you carrying it,” Chloe explained.
“Are you feeling okay?”
Sammy’s hands grew weak fists.
Even she felt that she would be unable to carry Justin for long, but Ceil was in no condition to carry him, and she didn’t want to force Chloe to drag him again.
That was unfair to her, and the constant agitation did not help Justin’s condition.
“I’m fine,” Sammy lied.
“I will carry him,” Ceil said, moving to the head of the stretcher, much to Sammy’s surprise.
“I cannot force you to shoulder all the burden of this journey because of me.”
Ceil placed her hand on Coby’s head and ruffled his feathers lightly.
“I noticed how weak you are, but… I was ignoring it and letting you coddle me.
Sorry.”
As if proving Chloe’s assumption, Coby gave a happy trill and hopped aside so Ceil could grab the stretcher.
Ceil glared down at Coby.
“I hope you realize that some of Sammy’s exhaustion is because of you.”
Coby ignored Ceil’s censure and stared away from the group.
“Kree!”
Everyone looked in the direction Coby was staring.
Standing next to a tree a few yards back from the clearing just off the other side of the road was a naked girl with ashen-green skin.
Her clumped, moss-like hair ran down her chest and back like long dreadlocks and obscured much of her face.
She could have been no older that sixteen if she was Human, but what struck Sammy as odd was that she appeared as if she wore a skintight body suit or body paint.
The girl had no nipples despite having breasts, and she had no belly button.
It was mildly unsettling.
“Is that…”
“A dryad,” Ceil finished for Sammy.
She hastily sat down Justin’s stretcher and broke into a sprint.
The dryad panicked and was about to flee, but Ceil shouted something in Elven that froze the girl in place.
Sammy watched with bated breath as Ceil caught up and conversed with her.
Their conversation was brief, but she meekly followed Ceil back to them.
There was only one question on Sammy’s mind, and she shouted it even before Ceil and the dryad reached them.
“Can she heal Justin?!
Can she help him?!”
Her body shook, but not from exhaustion.
She fell to her knees and pleaded with every part of her being for this girl to help Justin, but Ceil shook her head.
Sammy couldn’t breathe.
She felt betrayed.
