She held out all hope that when she met a dryad, Justin would receive the help that he so desperately needed.
“Why not?” Sammy cried, struggling to hold back her tears.
Ceil did not reply until she reached the group.
“Just because someone has a high aptitude for life magic does not mean she can use it skillfully.”
She placed her hand on the shoulder of the dryad who was just barely taller than her.
“Dryads send their youth out to relay messages to neighboring tribes.
This one is only a messenger on her way to a nearby village.
We should be able to find a shaman there to help Justin.”
Sammy sprung to her feet and grabbed the dryad by her upper arms.
“Where is the village?!”
The dryad cowered.
Ceil grabbed Sammy by her sleeve and pulled her away, knocking her to the ground with little effort.
“She is not going to tell us if you scare her.”
Ceil ignored Sammy and began questioning the dryad in Elven.
Sammy could not understand the conversation and only picked out simple words.
The more she listened, the more she caught until she realized that as the conversation progressed, Ceil used simpler and simpler Elven.
This young dryad was not fluent in the language, and Sammy prayed that they could communicate well enough that Ceil could explain their plight.
“She will take us to a village, but that is all she would agree to.
It is a day’s walk back the way we came and another half day off the road.”
The building tears fell from Sammy’s eyes, and she thanked the young dryad in Elven.
The dryad was unsure how to respond, but Ceil pulled her away and asked her to lead after picking up the front of the stretcher.
Justin would receive help.
All Sammy’s efforts to keep him alive after he nearly died saving her life would bear fruit.
That budding hope was the only thought on her mind.
Sammy watched as Ceil, Chloe, and the dryad walked onward not even realizing that she was being left behind.
A strong gust of wind from behind lifted Sammy to her weak legs, and Coby nipped at her left butt cheek to force her to hurry and catch up.
That night, she held fast to Justin, unable to sleep due to her anticipation.

* * *
“She says we are almost there,” Ceil translated for the Melian girl.
Ceil stood at the head of Justin’s stretcher once again after refusing to let Sammy carry it.

Sammy protested, because in her pride she felt that carrying Justin to those who would heal him was her responsibility, but when Ceil chastised her and told her that she would only slow them down, she consented.
She followed at Justin’s side, holding his hand the entire way.
The dense forest grew sparse.
Sammy soon saw one dryad and then another peering at them with curious gazes among the trees and shrubs.
They looked similar to the young dryad messenger except for a slightly grayer tint to their skin.
They were adults, so the young dryad’s skin color might change with age.
Her assumptions proved correct when she saw more and more dryads.
The trees cleared, and an entire community opened before them, like a gathering in a small field in the forest.
Dryads of many different ages stopped their conversations, weaving, meals, or play and stared at the unknown visitors.
The older dryads indeed had darker skin, more of a grayish-brown, with the younger appearing greener.
In the arms of an elderly Dryad was held an infant with cream colored skin like the wood beneath the bark of a young branch.
With her bald head, she looked almost human except for her tiny, pointed ears.
The messenger girl ran through the crowd and out of sight.
Ceil lowered the stretcher.
“I will find a shaman.
We will have them provide treatment before I tell them who I am and what happened.
I do not want that affecting what help they might provide.”
Sammy hugged Ceil.
“Thank you.”
Ceil’s gaze lowered in a guilty slant.
She shook her head.
“Sorry this took so long.
I will make certain he recovers.”
After promising Sammy the best, Ceil jogged ahead to converse with the awaiting villagers.
Two dryads quickly ran further into the clearing.
After a few minutes of waiting, an elderly dryad with a contrastingly young-looking face and complexion approached them.
She spoke to Ceil in fluent Elven.
Sammy couldn’t contain her excitement.
Her body quivered uncontrollably, and her stomach contracted painfully.
“Is she a shaman?
Can she help Justin?”
Instead of the panicked voice that scared the messenger, Sammy fought within her to remain calm and speak politely.
Ceil presented the dryad before Sammy.
“This is Tyree.
She is the village shaman and one of the best shamans in Melia.
She has promised to take care of him.”
Tears fell from Sammy’s eyes.
She cried her gratitude in Elven repeatedly and could not even collect herself well enough to understand the shaman’s reply.
Tyree called over two dryads to lift the stretcher and follow her through the clearing.
Ceil then nudged Coby with her foot to follow.
The villagers kept a fearful distance from him as he passed.
After hearing Ceil vouch for the ability of the shaman, Sammy knew that Justin would be alright, but doubts slowly grew and her anxiety with them.
“Can she really help him?
Will Justin be okay?”
She had clung to such thin hope for so long that even when faced with what she had prayed for so desperately, her mind would not believe it, like her hope was fake, a mirage in the desert.
She knelt immobile with Chloe at her side and waited while Ceil chatted idly with the villagers.
Ceil was then called away by the shaman, and Sammy’s anxiety grew worse.
She could not stop her body from shaking.
The more her anxiety grew, the more her body ached and the more her neck and shoulder burned.
Chloe wrapped her arm around Sammy’s shoulder and grabbed her hand.
“Everything’s going to be fine.”

At some point, a dryad child placed a small wreath of colorful braided herbs on Sammy’s head, but the kind gesture went completely unnoticed by her, including Chloe’s expression of gratitude on Sammy’s behalf.
Sammy only stared in the direction the shaman took Justin.
After what felt like an eternity, Ceil returned with a perplexed expression.
She knelt in front of Sammy and grabbed the other hand that Chloe was not holding.
“Tyree is treating Justin.
She spent a long time investigating his body because it was different than what she knew.”
Ceil’s words were not what Sammy wanted to hear.
She wanted Ceil to tell her that Justin was fine now, that he would be okay, that he would wake up and smile sarcastically at her and say, “You look terrible.”
“She wanted to know what happened to him, so I told her what you told me.
The bad blood, it infested his whole body.
She was amazed he was still alive.
He should have died long ago.
I told her we were giving him beiju to help with the bad blood, but she said that was like trying to clean a poisoned well with a single pinch of salt.”
Sammy wanted Ceil to tell her straight.
She could not bear the painful details that bore deep gouges into her heart, but she also could not muster the will to tell Ceil to skip them because deep down, she wanted to know everything.
“Most of his organs had shut down or were in a hibernating state.
All that was active was what he needed to stay alive… The piece of metal you said was still inside him was missing.
Tyree explained that even though he should have died, there was something at work that she could not explain keeping him alive.
I think the sprites did something to help him so he could survive the journey until he received treatment.
He will recover.
Tyree assured me that she could heal him.”
Sammy looked into Ceil’s reassuring eyes.
The dark clouds in her heart cleared one by one until warmth filled her bosom.
Small rapid breaths escaped her lips, and they grew into a faint laugh or a cry or somewhere in-between.
Justin would be okay.
He would recover.
I did it.
“Sammy!
Isn’t that great?!”
Chloe’s voice sounded distant.
“Sammy?”
Sammy’s arms and legs grew numb, and her laughter ceased.
She couldn’t breathe.
A stinging pain attacked her heart.
A black film spread from the edge of her vision until it met at the center, and her world grew dark.
“Sammy!”
Her limp body collapsed in Ceil and Chloe’s arms.

Chapter 11
“A Promised Warning Fulfilled”
Ceil
Ceil stood in a bed of thick clover looking down at Sammy’s flushed face.
She wanted to be frustrated with her, to reprimand Sammy for overworking and especially for not telling her how weak she had grown, but she couldn’t.
Any anger she tried to rouse drowned in her own guilt.
Her own depression forced Sammy to carry her at a time when Sammy was already close to breaking.
She promised the Sprite Arkhon that she was fine, but the moment the very real threat of her tails being revealed became reality, she regressed.
The fear and depression was swift, and where she thought she would be able to overcome it, it grabbed her in a vice and pulled her into the murky waters.
She knew she was partly to blame for Sammy’s condition.
She saw the signs of Sammy’s exhaustion as she had before--they were worse than before--but she ignored them, wallowing in her own grief.
She sat beside Sammy and grabbed her free hand, the one that was not wrapped around Justin’s arm beside her.
She lifted it and pressed the back of the hand against her forehead.
“Sorry, and thank you.”
“That would be better said when she is awake.”
Tyree walked up behind Ceil carrying the chilled cap of a dark brown mushroom and placed it around the top of Sammy’s head like a bizarre, slimy hat.
Ceil found it odd that Tyree did not use life magic to bring down Sammy’s fever, but Tyree explained that fevers often have a purpose, and that Sammy would be healthier letting it run its course.
The mushroom was only to help regulate the temperature.
“The less life magic that is used, the stronger the body will be after it recovers,” Tyree added to her previous explanation.
“Relying too heavily on external healing breeds reliance on it.
The boy’s situation was different.
His body was far beyond his ability to recover.”
Ceil placed Sammy’s hand back over her stomach and it intuitively grabbed Justin’s arm that was clasped nearby.
“However,” Tyree continued, “she had an illness besides, something dark and twisted.”
Ceil’s heart shrunk in her chest, and her eyes found the black mark on Sammy’s neck, now as large as a closed fist.
“Yes, that mark,” Tyree confirmed.
“How did she receive it?”
“I do not know,” Ceil lied, fearing to tell the truth, that she was the cause.
Dryads were beings closely connected to life, and Ceil’s magic twisted life into something unnatural.
“She had it since before we met in Fiorrae.”
“Fiorrae?” Tyree sat in thought.
“I know of no disease like this or poison from any creature that causes such a mark.
The mark remains, but I have cured the ill it has done to her.
Unless the mark is removed, the damage will return.
When she wakes, I will ask if she would like me to carve away the mark and replace it with healthy flesh, but the mark goes deep.”
“When will she wake?”
“When her body is rested.
Waking her now will help her little.”
Tyree hopped next to Ceil and knelt with her legs slightly out to the side.
Despite her age, her body was rather limber, and Ceil did not doubt that she would live for another hundred years or more, possibly even becoming a hamadryad.
“I cannot help but be confused by the both of them.”
Ceil glanced over at Tyree’s perplexed expression.
“What do you mean?
More than their injuries or Sammy’s mark?”

“I have only healed a few humans in my lifetime, and very recently at that as they pass through Melia for Vallen, so I cannot speak with any real confidence that the case of these two is not normal for some humans.
I have treated countless elves or fairies or other elfkind, so that is what I am accustomed to.
The sick or injured human soldiers I have treated were all similar, especially to you elves, but these two are different.
I am not sure I could call them human.”
“They are not human?”
Tyree’s words came as a shock to Ceil.
They looked human.
Sammy called herself human.
Even the Sprite Arkhon said they were human, and she doubted he would be mistaken.
Then again, the sprites might not have the ability to view the minute details of the body like a dryad shaman could.
“Why do you claim they are not human?”
“Their internal structure is the same as other humans and elves, but at the same time it is very different.
Their tissue, muscles, and bones are far more dense and yet far weaker.
They are frail, and I am surprised that they can function normally.
Their bodies would be under constant strain from their own weight, and I worry how long they will last.
I am surprised they lived to adulthood.
Where are they from?”
“I am not sure.
They never told me, but I do not think it was Tolmyur.
Jethro attacked their home, and he would never attack a city in the Tolmyur Kingdom.
Maybe they are from a different continent, somewhere their weight would not be a problem, like the floating isles.”
If Eydis was sent to another continent, that would explain why Jethro was having such a hard time finding her.
“Gebenmoft?
Possibly, but the beastkin are hostile to anyone from our continent and the harpies particularly so.
I doubt they would tolerate a human settlement.”
“Could they be Lurr?”
Tyree shook her head.
“No. Of that I am certain.”
Ceil breathed a sigh of relief.

Living on the edge of the Amelian Empire, Lurr were a constant threat to her small village, or so the children were taught, building both caution and fear of their ilk, but in the year and a half she lived in Heivleil, not once had a Lurr ever approached their lands, which was odd considering how common the villagers claimed Lurr attacks were in the past.
“They could simply be human but with a defect of birth common to where they are from.”
Tyree placed her hand on Ceil’s shoulder.
Ceil felt a faint pulse run through her body.
Tyree’s countenance fell slightly, but then she quickly smiled.
“I can at least say that you are an elf like any other, mostly High Elf.”
“Mostly?”
Tyree replied only with a smile and left to visit their village’s other guest, Chloe, who was currently wrestling with the village children much to the confused looks of the adults.
Ceil wanted to join in.
She had not wrestled since she was a young girl in her home village.
The palace would not tolerate such rambunctious play.
However, as an adult her tails were longer and would easily be revealed with too much motion.

She still planned on telling the village who she was and what had happened, but now that Sammy was also in the village’s care, she had to take extra precaution to gauge how they would react before explaining anything.
A chilled wind blew across Ceil’s back, so even though Sammy had a high fever, she pulled the leaf-woven blanket back over her to keep her warm.
With a parting apology that Sammy could not hear, Ceil left to walk around the village.
Ceil’s hometown was small, or at least she felt it was small only having Amel and the Gallanvale for comparison, but this dryad village made her hometown look like a thriving city.
Her town only had about two hundred residents, but this village could barely be said to reach a hundred, and in stark contrast to her hometown, this village lacked any structures.
A few trees dotted the open field, and it made Ceil wonder how or where the dryads slept.
Structures were not as important for dryads in the same way clothes were not.
The elements were not a problem.

Depending on the type of dryad, they could handle freezing temperatures or extremely hot temperatures, and although they had body heat, it was lower than other races and acceptant of large fluctuations.
Still, this was the first time Ceil had visited a dryad village, so despite her education about the people, the reality felt bizarre.
Ceil waved lightly at the dryads who greeted her as she passed.

She could tell who of them were more fluent in Elven by their greeting, whether it felt simply repeated or rehearsed or whether it was casual or natural, and only the older dryads fell into the latter category.
She spotted an anthousai with her mossy hair in full bloom with so many tiny white flowers that her hair appeared to sparkle like snow.
Beside her sat what appeared to be the eldest dryad in the village holding the youngest newborn.
She approached the trio and knelt in front of them.
“Is she this girl’s first child?” Ceil asked the elderly dryad.
The young anthousai looked at Ceil with surprise but quickly shook her head.
It seemed that despite her age, appearing one year younger than Ceil if the girl was an elf, the girl had made great effort to learn Elven.
The elderly dryad laughed.
“No, dear.
This one is mine, born just before winter began.”
Ceil tried to hold in her surprise, but she could not hide it from the keen eyes of the elderly.
“Yes, she came as a surprise to me as well, but so long as I still bloom, I may yet bear children.”
Ceil looked at the elderly dryad’s hair and found it difficult to locate any of the tiny white flowers common to Melians, but sure enough, the flowers were there.
“Of course you would expect Lemi to be the mother, but she is yet an expectant anthousai.” She then chuckled.
“However, with how full she is in bloom, she will bear a child before long, if she has not already begun rearing a child within her.
As I am the newest mother, she is learning from me how to care for the young.”
“Could you not use life magic to check if… Lemi?”
Ceil looked over to the anthousai, and the girl nodded with a toothy smile.
“I am Lemi,” the girl announced excitedly.
“Could you use life magic to check if Lemi is pregnant?”
The elderly dryad grinned as if expecting the question.
“We could, easily, but for an anthousai, we leave it to the will and surprise of nature.
Part of the enjoyment of an anthousai becoming a mother for the first time is not knowing when the joyful day will come.
After she has her first birth and her flowers start to wilt, when she is no longer an anthousai, we watch pregnancy more closely.”
The infant began to fuss, so her elderly mother placed her pointer finger in the child’s mouth.
She began sucking on it and calmed down.
“I would have thought one of your years would be close to becoming a hamadryad,” Ceil said.
“That is not my calling.
You see, not all dryads age the same.
Our shaman, Tyree, and I, we are both the same age, but from birth our callings were different.
I have born many children in my years, enough to create two villages, but Tyree has only two daughters.
The few like her may become hamadryads, but the many like me who are called to motherhood give of our lives to our children and seldom live long enough to take root.”
Ceil recalled that the three hamadryads were assassinated by the humans.
With how youthful Tyree appeared, perhaps there was hope for another hamadryad to appear.
“Do you think Tyree will become a Hamadryad?”
“She could, but compared to a hamadryad, Tyree is no more than a child.
A lot can happen before she ages enough to root.
Even for those like Tyree, few live that long, and even fewer survive the pilgrimage.”
The infant finally opened its eyes and noticed that a stranger was present, but much to Ceil’s amazement, the child did not scare.
She lifted her arms as if asking to be held.
The elderly dryad removed her finger from the child’s mouth and presented her to Ceil, but Ceil hesitated.
“I… I can’t.”
Ceil felt that her own existence was a terrible omen, and she feared deep in her heart that she would bring misfortune upon such a pure child by even touching her.
Sammy lying ill on the other side of the field made that fear ever more real.
“You would do me the greatest honor to hold my child and give her your blessing.”
“I cannot offer her any blessing.
I could only harm her.”
“Nonsense.”
The infant was thrust into Ceil’s arms.
Her head rested in the cradle of Ceil’s elbow.
She looked up at Ceil with wide, inquisitive eyes having never before seen an elf.
Ceil’s arms shook in fear of such a pure life, but the sensation only caused the infant to smile with a wide, toothless mouth.
“Give her a name,” Lemi exclaimed, bouncing in excitement.
“That is a wonderful idea,” the elderly dryad agreed.
Ceil stepped back in shock and then held out the infant for her mother to reclaim her.
“I could not possibly.
Have you not already named her?”
“Dryad children are often not named until about a full season passes, sometimes two.
I feel that is the fate of your arrival.
You approached us when we were deciding what we may call her.
This child’s fortune is to receive her name from you.”
The mother left the child in Ceil’s arms, so Ceil returned to cradling her.
Ceil stared at the hopeful smiles of the elderly and future mothers, her eyes full of the fear of being the one to determine the hope for this child’s life.
Such a role belonged to the mother and the mother alone.
However, as empress, such requests would not be uncommon if Ceil encountered a new mother, but there was no way for them to know of her true identity.
She only had the misfortune of approaching them at the most inopportune time.
“I will name her,” Ceil ceded with great reluctance.
Lemi grabbed the elderly dryad’s hand and jumped for joy.
“First, may I have your name and meaning?” Ceil asked the mother.
“Hemma, the flower, but do not feel constrained by me.
This is your blessing on the child.”

Hemma was the name of the white flowers that blossomed on the trees in Melia and is mimicked in a Melian’s hair, fitting for a mother of so many children, or perhaps she was blessed as a mother because of her name.
“I know her name.
Hanvhial.”
Lemi showed no more reaction than the joy of hearing the child’s new name, but Hemma viewed Ceil with awe.
She bowed her head in gratitude and reverence to Ceil and the child in her arms.
What the dryads needed most in these dark times were not more children; it was hope, hope of one to rejoin their scattered tribes and lead them.
Hanvhial, the Eternal One.
Through her name, Ceil blessed the child with a long life, a promise that she would grow to become a leader of the dryads, a hamadryad.
“Thank you.
We truly are blessed you survived.”
“Survived?” Ceil panicked.
She raised Hemma’s head to look in her eyes.
“Do you know who I am,” she asked with a quiet, quivering voice.
“The messenger who led you here brought with her news of your identity.”
How did she know who I was?
Did she see my tails?
I thought I was careful.
Was it when I was asleep?
“If you know who I am, then you know of the dangers that follow me.”
Hemma smiled brightly, further wrinkling her aged face.
“Yes, there are some who do fear, but I yearn for the day you reclaim your throne.
You have proven me here that you care dearly about your people.”
Ceil handed the infant back into her mother’s arms.
“How many know of me?”
Was she even safe here?
What about Sammy?
“You have no need to fear us.
You are free to stay and rest until your companions have recovered.”
“It is not you whom I fear.
I must see the matriarch.
Where is she?”
“Our village is small.
You will find her if you search.”
Ceil thanked Hemma and Lemi and ran towards the center of the village.
I can delay no longer.
They may know who I am, but they do not know what happened.
In the two days they had been in the village, Ceil had yet to meet the matriarch, spending most of her time with Sammy and Tyree.
She did not know who to look for, but the matriarch should be the eldest dryad in the village.
She glanced at each dryad as she ran but was unsure.
There were women of every age, and none as elderly-appearing as Hemma, but the matriarch could also be like Tyree, younger in appearance despite her age.
She approached two dryads who looked older than most others.
“I must speak with the matriarch.
Do you know where she is?”
“Our village is small,” one of them replied.
“You will find her if you search.”
“That does not help me.
I received that answer already.
I do not know what she looks like.”
The two dryads looked at each other, and one came upon a solution.
“Wait by your company.
We will send her to you.”
“Thank you!”
Ceil hurried back to the patch of clover where Sammy and Justin rested.
Nearby, Chloe lay on her back with the other children sitting around her or lying next to or against her.
Chloe was panting heavily having exhausted herself.
“Their bodies would be under constant strain from their own weight, and I worry how long they will last.”
Tyree’s words resounded in Ceil’s ears, and she walked to Chloe’s side with worry pricking her heart.

Chloe was the heaviest of the three humans and yet she rarely ever switched out of her position on the back end of the stretcher, she chased after the scout who discovered Ceil’s tails, and now she had spent all day playing with children.
If Sammy’s weakness was in part due to her body, then Chloe was showing extreme fortitude despite her condition.
“Are you tired,” Ceil asked, unable to think of a better greeting or way to voice her worry.
The young dryads perked up and began speaking in the Melian tongue.
They grabbed Ceil’s arms and skirt and gestured their desire to play, but Ceil did not have the time.
She tried explaining this to them, but none of the children understood Elven.
In the end, Chloe was the only one laughing.
“They have far too much energy.
After they got me to the ground, I was out.
I can’t keep up.”
“Do not push yourself.
Tyree said your bodies are… different, that you are under a lot of strain.
Is that true?”
Chloe opened her eyes and looked up at Ceil.
After a long exhale, she smiled.
“Yah, I guess.
I feel like I have all these heavy weights strapped to my body all the time.”
“And that’s the same for Sammy?”
Ceil’s anger crept out in her voice, and Chloe’s face lost its joviality.
“Yah, but I think it’s been affecting her far worse than me.”
Guilt ate at Ceil.
“Why did you not say anything?!
We could have slowed down, taken more rests!”
The children looked up at Ceil, and their startled expressions showed they thought they had done wrong, so Ceil calmed down and tousled some of their mossy hair lightly.
“I had no idea you three had this condition.
I thought humans were just heavier than elves, but Tyree said you were different than other humans.”
“Different from humans here, probably, but everyone is like us where we come from.”
Chloe looked up at the white, overcast sky.
There was a longing there, and Ceil knew it was for home.
They were strangers here in Melia, in Fiorrae, and in the Amelian Empire.
“Where did you come from?”
“From somewhere far away.
I don’t even know what direction it is from here.”
Ceil sat down, and one of the children jumped on her back and wrapped her arms around Ceil’s neck.
Another child sat in her lap and played hand games with another child beside her.
“What is it called, where you are from?” Ceil asked.
“Earth.
The city Jethro attacked, where we were living, was called Gullivan.”
Ceil’s eyes fell to the short mossy hair of the child in her lap.
She spotted a few tiny round buds that would eventually bloom into flowers that looked like hemma.
She lightly brushed the child’s hair, causing the child to giggle.
“I have never heard of such a country or city.”
“It would be a bigger shock if you did,” Chloe chuckled.
“Is living there easier for you?
Are your bodies better over there?
Do you want to go back?”
“I don’t think we can.
We don’t even know how we got here.
I mean, we think Eydis sent us, but that’s it.
And you already heard about all that.”
Chloe grabbed one of the smaller children and lifted her by her waist into the air.
She was only able to hold the child aloft for a moment before she had to lower her.
She held the child in a light embrace while the child laughed.
She then tickled the child’s sides which all the others took as a signal to pile on Chloe and tickle her back.
Chloe was laughing, but now that Ceil was aware of the constant strain that Chloe was under, she saw the pain behind Chloe’s smile.
She was playing with the children to help recover emotionally.
She was the same as Sammy with similar worries and a similar condition.
The only difference was that Chloe might have been a little stronger and Sammy a lot weaker, weaker because of Ceil.
Ceil separated herself and returned to the clover patch to watch the children play on top of Chloe.
Again she longed to join in, and if the village knew her true identity, her tails were no longer an issue.
“Should I?”
Like Sammy and Chloe, she was dealing with a heavy emotional burden, and Chloe had the correct answer.
The matriarch had not appeared yet, so she had time.
Perhaps she could grasp at this small possibility of joy.

Ceil sprung to her feet and ran towards the pile of children, but before she could reach them, large talons grabbed her arms, and with the flap of two giant wings, Ceil rose into the air fast enough to grow light-headed.
The cold wind assaulted her and made her shiver uncontrollably.
She looked up and saw a familiar blue buzzard.
“Coby!
What are you doing?!
Let me down!”
Coby flew low along the treetops.
Ceil had to swing her body and legs to avoid hitting them.
“I thought you left after you were healed!”
Despite her confusion about Coby’s actions, Ceil was relieved to see him again.
As much of a nuisance as he was, he cared for both Sammy and her in his own way, and Ceil acknowledged that.
Coby stopped and flapped his wings at the top of a tall tree.
Once Ceil grabbed onto the thin upper branches, Coby released her.
A few of the branches snapped, but the tree held her.
From her position, she could see the break in the trees far in the distance where the road passed through the forest.
Coby flew in that direction with a cry, and before he could reach the road, a fireball flew up at him followed by a few arrows.
Coby weaved in a panic to avoid the attacks.
In Melia, only one group of people would attack Coby with fire magic.
Those were humans.
There was a group of them, and they had left the road.
If they continued in her direction, they would end up at the village.
She had been sold out, and she knew by whom.
The young messenger did not learn of Ceil’s identity during their short travel together.
She knew about it beforehand.
That was why she tried to flee but stopped when Ceil ordered her.
That was why she disappeared from the village immediately after relaying her message to the matriarch.
She reported back to the humans.
“I was wrong,” Ceil bemoaned.
The dryads had surrendered to the humans, so instead of them suspecting the dryads of siding with her against Tolmyur, the humans were using the dryads to capture her.
The village was not safe.
Ceil’s heart beat heavy in trepidation.
Did Tyree refuse to heal Sammy immediately to keep her in the village?
Ceil waved her hand in wide gestures and nearly fell from the tree.
“Coby!
Take me back to the village!”
Coby returned with haste, and with a flap of his giant wings they flew off in the direction of the village.
Once near the clearing, Coby dove down, and Ceil landed on the ground with enough force to make her knees creak and a chill to run up her spine.
The dryads cleared away at the sight of the large bird, a natural predator of the dryads.
She looked around for the clover patch where Chloe and Sammy lay.
The children were no longer playing.
They huddled in fear of Coby who trotted on the ground behind Ceil.
An elderly dryad stood next to Chloe.
At a glance, Ceil knew this was the village matriarch, but she no longer had any reason to speak with her.
She wanted to accuse the matriarch of selling her out, for using Sammy to bind her here until the humans arrived, but she could not fault her for it.
This was the safest choice for them.
Ceil ignored the matriarch and ran to Chloe, who was sitting up with a child in her lap.
“We are leaving.”
“Leaving?
Why?”
“Soldiers are on their way here.
The village has tricked us.”
Ceil withheld nothing in front of the matriarch because there was little chance the matriarch of some small village could understand the language of the sprites.
Chloe looked past the children at the clover patch.
“How?
Sammy and Justin can’t leave.”
Ceil paced quickly in a circle until Coby nipped at her skirt.
“Do something useful!
Slow them down!”
She pointed in the direction of the approaching humans, and Coby understood immediately.
He flew up with enough force to knock Ceil to her back in the strength of his wind.
Traveling from the road to the village took half a day while carrying an injured man.
A small platoon of soldiers could cover that distance in half the time or faster.
This left very little time to escape and gain some distance, unless…
Ceil watched Chloe unsteadily rise to her feet.
They could only bring one.
She bit her lip and could feel her heart sink into her stomach.
Although she had no attachments to the man, Sammy cared for him dearly, and he was a friend of Chloe’s.
“We need to take Sammy and run.”
Chloe understood Ceil’s intentions.
Her mouth hung ajar in shock, but the pain in her eyes showed she comprehended the situation they were in.
Chloe had exhausted herself playing with the children, possibly another attempt to weaken their party.
Sammy was too heavy for Ceil to carry alone, and Chloe no longer had the strength either.
“We do not have a choice.
We need to take Sammy and run!”
Chloe looked around.
“Where are our bags?
The stretcher?”
Ceil realized that their meager supplies were relocated without her knowledge.
“We do not have time to search for them.”
She ran to Sammy, tore the mushroom cap and blanket off, and grabbed her under her arms.
Chloe followed and grabbed Sammy’s legs, hooking her knees in her elbows.
“Where do we run?”
“Adjacent.
If we are lucky, they’ll think we ran in the opposite direction to their approach and lose them.
We will change directions as we go.”
“Where are you going,” the matriarch called out as Ceil and Chloe began an unsteady run with Sammy in their arms.
“Leave us be!”
Ceil screamed back, not hiding her ire.
Ceil and Chloe crossed the village to the opposite side from where the soldiers were approaching.
She saw Hemma sitting against a tree near the edge of the village with Hanvhial in her arms.
“Where are you going,” Hemma called as they passed.
Ceil slowed down.
Hemma was the only dryad in the village she felt she could trust.
“Human soldiers are on their way to the village.
We have been sold out.”
The shock on Hemma’s face made Ceil’s contort in anguish.
Most the villagers may not have even been in on the betrayal.
“We will protect you,” Hemma promised.
“No!” In the shadows of Ceil’s mind, she could see this mother murdered as she tried to protect her child from the humans, just like that nymph in the Gallanvale.
All the innocent children of this village were in danger.
“No.
Helping me would sentence you all to death.
When the humans arrive, tell them that we escaped but you managed to capture one of us.
That should appease them.”
“My Lady, there is something you should know before you leave.
One who walks is in Melia, a hamadryad on pilgrimage.
Find her.
If you can show her your love for the dryads as you have shown me, she will side with you.
We all will side with you.”
“Then you all will die.
I will not have any more innocent people die for my sake.
I am sorry.”
Ceil pulled Sammy and Chloe behind her into the forest.
She could barely hear Hemma’s final words before the village was far from sight.
“Do not lose hope.”
After running for some time, they turned right and traveled perpendicular to their flight deeper into the Melian forests.

* * *
Hemma sprinted to Jenae, the village matriarch, ignoring the cries of her daughter from the shaking of her stride.
Her aged body nearly collapsed at Jenae’s feet.
“Hemma, I saw you speaking with Ceil.
What has happened?”
“Humans are approaching.
She fears we have betrayed her,” Hemma said.
“That cannot be.
We would never, could never…”
Jenae thought upon the anger in the young empress’s voice, and it cut her to her core.
That child lost everything and now feared those who should be most loyal to her.
Hemma looked over at the grove of clover to the man lying under a woven leaf blanket.
“She has left us one of her companions to save our village from the anger of the humans for her escape.
We must convince them to spare him, that he could be of use to them alive perhaps in capturing her or for information, so he may have chance to return to her.”
Jenae fell to her knees and covered her face with her hands.
Her fingers pressed hard into her forehead as her heart was racked with the pain of her own incompetence.
“How could I have let this happen?
That messenger only told us of Ceil’s identity.
She must have returned to tell the humans.
Other villages have chosen a side in the hunt.
I can only think that in her haste to inform the humans, she forgot to relay the entire message.”
“Capture the empress and send word,” Hemma guessed.
“Ceil must have known some villages were hostile but had no choice but to risk us to help her companions.
She deliberately hid her identity from us.
This must be why.
We have failed her.”
Hemma cradled her daughter close to her neck.
“She desires the unity of our people.
She named my daughter Hanvhial.”
Jenae lifted her head and viewed the infant with admiration.
“Then we must help her.
If some villages are seeking her capture, we must correct them.
We will spread the word that our empress is in our midst and is fighting for us.
We must not succumb to the humans’ plot.
I will personally seek out the hamadryad.
She must meet Lady Ceil.”
“What of her companion?
The humans might kill him.”
“I will protect him,” Tyree said, appearing behind Jenae and placing her hand on her shoulder.
“By my life, I will make certain he is reunited with her.”
“The humans will take you,” Jenae said, worried for her younger sister.
“So be it,” Tyree replied with confidence.
Jenae nodded, proud of her sister’s conviction.
“Hemma, while I seek out the hamadryad and Tyree joins Ceil’s companion in captivity, you will be matriarch.”
“Understood.” Hemma bowed low.
“Gather all the youth who are not anthousai.
Include the young adults who are not with children.
We need every able messenger.”

Chapter 12
“The Otherworldly Threat”
Byurk
“Shoot it down!”
Byurk kicked his heel into the ground.
Dirt, rock, and mud shot up like a geyser, and with a quick swipe of his hand, he removed the moisture leaving a solid earth pillar.
The incoming blade of wind impacted it and dispersed, but the pillar crumbled on top of him.
“Can no one ground that bird?!”
This same Habha had accosted them twice before, and they had driven it off, but now it returned after gaining some purpose and assaulted them with unbridled tenacity.
Byurk’s powerful defense and the dense canopy provided some protection.
Only one member of his hand-picked team was injured and not severely, but they were losing precious time.
Byurk could only trust that the Melians followed the orders in his message and captured the emperor’s wife and her companions.
“Sir, we are nearly out of arrows!”
“Use them all!
The Melians can craft us more!
And keep moving forward!
We must reach that village!”
“Sir, I am out of ven!”

Byurk raised his hand as if he was lifting a heavy stone, and earth bumped up from underneath his final exhausted fire mage, knocking him to the side as a smaller blade of wind passed by and into the trunk of a tree beside them.
The bark shattered and some of the wood splintered, but it did not cut through.
The attacks were growing weaker.
“It cannot continue the attack much longer!
Move!”
The group of thirty-two soldiers increased their march with Byurk and another earth mage focused on defense.
“I think I hit it!”
“No, the arrow just hit its feathers!”
“Less talking; more focus!”
Byurk kicked the minum beside him to the ground and dropped to avoid another blade of wind.
The soldiers behind him jumped back, and it impacted the ground between them.
The blade was small.
“Sir! I think it is retreating.”
Byurk waited for another attack, but none came, and the Habha was no longer visible.
He turned to his dirt-splattered, physically and ven exhausted party.
“I chose you all for this vital mission because you were supposed to be competent!
Why the gods could you not kill one bird?!”
Byurk’s men looked at him with shamed faces.
He wanted to tell them that had this been a stronger beast, they would all be dead.
Byurk had spent his youth hunting dragons north of Stollmuk with dwarven parties half this number.
Seeing his chosen men fail to kill a single bird was aggravating.
He took a moment to breathe out his frustration and calm down.
“Is anyone besides Mak injured?”
The men looked around at each other, and one of his archers responded.
“No, sir.”
The sole injured swordsman was wrapping the shallow cut on his left forearm.
“Sir, if I may?”
“Speak while we march.
We lost precious time.”
At his order, the men increased their march, and the archer hurried to Byurk’s side.
“That one was not like the other buzzards.
It was larger and had two yellow plumes on its head.”
“What are you saying?”
“I’ve shot many of them, and most have no plumes.”
“You are saying that one was a different breed, or the alpha?”
“Possibly, but we have never had problems killing them like this.
The forward platoon that was wiped out, if the wife is at the village, then it might have been the same one.”
“A Habha trained by the wife.”
“Exactly, sir.”
If she can raise or weaponize these birds to this degree, that wife was more of a danger than Byurk thought.
“Girl! How long until we reach the village?”
The young Melian messenger ran beside Byurk.
She was unharmed and not the least bit exhausted from their march.
Byurk could not help but be amazed at her energy.
“We are soon,” she replied in broken Elven.
“How soon?”
“Soon soon.”
“Good.” He turned back to his men.
“I know you are tired, but be prepared for another battle.
We do not know what to expect when we reach the village.”
His men roared with confidence.
They continued the march and arrived at the border of the village.
They stepped into the clearing with weapons drawn, but what met Byurk could only be described as a Melian ghost town.
There were only about thirty adult Melians, all elderly, in the clearing.
Aside from them were a handful of children and three young Melians with white, speckled hair.
“Where are all the adults?”
He looked around at his men who bore the same confused expressions.
“Bring me the matriarch!”
“I am here,” replied a very elderly Melian with skin like coarse, wrinkled fabric.
She handed the infant she carried to one of the young Melians with completely white hair and approached slowly.
“I thought you would arrive sooner, but I see you had trouble.”
“Where is the widow of the late emperor?
She was here in this village, correct?”
He looked at the messenger, and she nodded her head enthusiastically.
“Yes, she was here,” the matriarch replied.
Byurk knew instantly that the Melians had either lost her, let her escape, or they could have even helped her.
The village was empty, so there was a possibility that many of them fled in fear of retribution.
But thinking it over, they would have taken their children, even if they had no choice but to leave their elderly.
The Melians were not the type of people to save themselves if it meant abandoning their young.
They were too good-natured for that.
The state of this village made no sense.
“Tell me everything,” Byurk ordered.
“This child that brought you to our village also brought with her the one you seek.
She informed us of the High Elf’s identity, relayed her message, and left to find you.
The emperor’s wife came to us with a request to heal her companions.
We thought that would keep her here long enough for you to arrive, but she learned of your approach from her Habha, and in the confusion it caused, she escaped.”
The matriarch confirmed the suspicion of his men.
That Habha was trained by the wife.
However, the matriarch’s story did not explain the state of the village.
“What are you not telling me?
I assume your village is not made of solely children and elderly.
You would not be opposed to us searching your village.”
The matriarch smiled.
“There is no need.
Follow me.”
Byurk’s men followed behind with weapons drawn, waiting for a possible attack.
While they walked, the matriarch continued her explanation.
“The Habha caused a lot of chaos, and by the time it flew off, I presume after you given the direction it flew, we noticed the wife was missing.
We did not see which way she fled, so we sent all who were able to search for her.”
Byurk rubbed his greying beard and then looked up at the matriarch.
“That could explain the missing Melians, but where are you leading us?”
“Here.”
They approached a thick patch of clover where lay a single man covered by a blanket woven from leaves.
Beside him was the indent of where Byurk supposed another had been.
“This is one of her companions.
He is still injured and so was easy to capture.
We have him sleeping for now.”
The matriarch called to her villagers, and four approached carrying supplies, dropping them at the edge of the patch of clover.
“These are their belongings.
They were left behind.
You may search through them if you wish.”
Byurk waved his hand, and five of his men retrieved the belongings which included a staff and sword, three leather sacks, a belt, and a small medicine pouch.
The sword, belt, and pouch were standard military equipment of the Tolmyur army.
This worried Byurk because it meant that the humans accompanying the wife could in fact be soldiers that had either defected or were under some other influence.
They would not be hunter mercenaries as he thought.
Then again, they could have looted these supplies from the forward party they killed using the Habha.
Byurk did not want to believe that any soldiers from Tolmyur would defect, and that powerful fire mage was still a concern that lingered on his mind.
The sacks contained scavenged food provisions, a few skirts and sashes, and extra medicine, simple beiju from the smell.
There was nothing remarkable, and all of it could be discarded with no major loss for the wife or her party.
Byurk walked over the deep clover and peered down at the man.
“Who is he?”
“Aside from one of her companions, we do not know,” the matriarch replied.
“Wake him.”
For the first time, the matriarch looked hesitant, and this caused doubt to grow in the depths of Byurk’s mind.
“Wake him,” Byurk ordered again.
Another elderly Melian with a young face and smooth complexion approached.
“I would rather not.”
“And you are?”
The Melian bowed deeply.
“Tyree, the village’s shaman.
This man has been in my care since his arrival.
He came to us with nothing but his will keeping him alive.
I had never seen such a living corpse in all my years.”
“Is he alive?”
“Yes, but--”
“Wake him!” Byurk was losing his patience with the village.

If he could not confirm that this man was truly a member of the wife’s party, then this all could be a ruse to stall for time, and he would be forced to use undesirable methods to extract the truth from these dryads who had sided with the wife.
The matriarch and shaman exchanged a few words in the Melian language, and then the shaman walked over to the sleeping man.
“I cannot say how coherent he will be when he wakes after being so close to death.”
Byurk glared at the shaman as she placed her hand on the man’s head.
When she retracted it, nothing happened, and as Byurk waited, nothing happened still.
If the man was not slowly breathing, he would have assumed him dead.
“Do you make a fool of me?”
Much to Byurk’s surprise, the shaman glared at him.
“I restored his consciousness as you asked.
I could shock him awake for you, but with how weak his body is, it could kill him.
Is that what you want?”
Byurk sighed.
“How long?”
The shaman did not answer, so Byurk moved beside the sleeping man.
He yanked off the leaf blanket and saw the strange clothing the man wore.
He recognized it and stepped back in shock.
It resembled the clothing at the palace that Jethro obtained from the other world to disguise his assassins who sought the princess.
The tough and tightly woven blue fabric of the pants was an unmistakable sign.
“It cannot be… The other humans with the wife, did they wear strange clothing like this?
Was their clothing unlike anything from Amel or the Tolmyur Kingdom or anywhere else you have seen?”
The shaman and matriarch exchanged confused glances.
“The wife was different, but the Humans with her were dressed similarly.”
Byurk turned to his soldiers.
“We will take him with us and question him when he wakes.
We must hurry.”
“You must be gentle with him,” the shaman protested.
“We do not have such luxury.”
“Let me join you.
I will take care of him and see to it that he is healthy enough to answer your questions.”
“Perfect.
I also have a request, and if you fulfill it, I will see to it that both you and your village are rewarded.”
“Rewarded?
What is your request?” Tyree asked.
“Hurry and tie him up!”
Byurk shouted to his men, and no more than a few seconds later, two of his soldiers brought rope to bind the man.
“Before I say my request, I first demand you tell me the truth.
Do or do you not know where the wife has fled?”
The matriarch was quick to answer.
“We do not, and even if we did help her escape, we would not know where she is now or her heading.”
“Well enough.
I demand you take me to the one who walks.
I must speak with your hamadryad.
I expect you know how to find her.
The pilgrimage routes are set, are they not?”
“It is as you say,” the matriarch replied.
“That is my request.
Tyree, you will guide us.”
The archer approached Byurk with trouble in his eyes.
“Are we no longer pursuing the wife?”
“We may not be able to handle her on our own.
She has become a far greater threat than any of us or our Commanding General ever anticipated.”
“Sir?”
“She is receiving aid from the other world.”

Chapter 13
“Misdirected Hatred”
Ceil
“Please, Ceil… I need… Can we stop… just for a…”
Chloe dropped to a knee and hacked out a large wad of viscous saliva, spitting it to the side.
Her hot breath dispersed in large puffs of white in the clear night air.
She may have been stronger than Sammy, but her already exhausted body had far greater limitations than Ceil’s, something Ceil had only just learned in the village.
Ceil turned Sammy, wrapped Sammy’s arms over her shoulders and across her chest, and lifted her.
Sammy was short enough that her feet did not drag on the ground, but that did not make walking any easier.
“I will carry her.
We cannot stop.”
Although Ceil urged Chloe to keep moving, her own feet would not move faster than an unsteady walk under Sammy’s unnatural weight, and after another hour she too surrendered to exhaustion.
They had not traveled far from the village, only about the same distance the road had been, so if the humans picked up their trail, they would be upon them quickly.
The overcast clouds of earlier that day had cleared to a cold, star-filled sky.
The largest moon was bright and nearly full, casting shadows from the trees to the forest floor.
This was a night to be spotted, so they could not risk stopping, but neither she nor Chloe had the energy to move further.
Despite how much Ceil wanted to keep moving, they could not.
“We camp here, no fire,” Ceil ordered, laying Sammy on the cold forest floor.
She placed her hand on the ground and concentrated her life ven into the sparse earth.
The ground moss grew quickly, but when the ground where her fingers touched turned black, she quickly retracted her hands.
She should have been able to continue longer, but in her exhaustion, she couldn’t suppress the darkness in her that always tried to creep out whenever she manipulated life.
The patch of leafy moss was just barely large enough to fit the three of them if not a little too small.
She hoped it would be sufficient to insulate them from the cold soil.
Chloe slid Sammy onto the moss.
She removed her long-sleeved top and draped it over her.
“Why hasn’t Sammy woken?
She was just sleeping, wasn’t she?”
Ceil also found this odd, but in their flight, she lacked the freedom to worry about anything but escape.
“I do not know.
If her illness is that severe, she might not for a while.”
“Wasn’t it just exhaustion?” Chloe asked.
Ceil could not answer.
Sammy’s state could very well have been because of the mark on her neck.
Tyree claimed that she healed Sammy, but what if that was a lie and Sammy was only growing worse?
She had to find out.
Ceil took a few deep breaths to calm herself.
She was only reading Sammy’s life, not manipulating it.
No alterations or changes.
She was not healing Sammy, so the dark magic would not activate.
She had to remind herself that she had been checking that man’s vitals for days without issue, but somehow when it came to Sammy, she still feared ill might befall her.
Her trembling hand rested on Sammy’s forehead and sent a pulse through Sammy’s body.
The truth came surprisingly quickly.
“Sammy’s consciousness is clouded,” she said with relief.
Life was still twisted where the mark remained on Sammy’s neck, which she could not heal for fear of worsening it, but Tyree had told the truth.
There were no longer any adverse effects on Sammy’s health from the mark, but that did not rid Tyree of suspicion.
“Clouded?”
“Stopped, or perhaps blocked might be a better word.
That shaman must have done it to keep us in the village.
I will try to wake her.”
Ceil placed her hand on Sammy’s forehead but hesitated.
This time, she would be manipulating life even if for a moment.
She lacked skill in the healing aspects of life magic, and affecting the mind was a far more advanced form.
If she could not wake Sammy, Ceil feared that Sammy may never wake.
She could not trust another dryad village to help her, so it had to be her.
The only assurance Ceil had in her ability to attempt it safely was that locating the direct cause only involved reading the surface of Sammy’s consciousness.
Once found, the remedy should be swift, she hoped.
But she hesitated again.
Now was not the time.
“No, I will try in the morning when I am rested.
You should sleep.
I will keep first watch.”
“Okay.”
Chloe lay down and shifted close to Sammy to keep her warm.
Ceil removed her skirt and laid it over them.
She shivered naked in the cold night, but the chill would help her stay awake, in case the fear of the approaching humans was insufficient motivation to overcome her exhaustion.
The next morning came without incident.
Chloe woke Ceil at sunrise as requested.
Once her drowsiness left her, she prepared mentally for the task she postponed.
Ceil rested her hand on Sammy’s forehead and closed her eyes.
She treaded lightly in Sammy’s mind, like running her finger across the surface of water, too afraid to dip it in.
She tapped the water and felt the ripples travel, searching for the obstruction by retracing where the subtle pulse rebounded.

Even Eydis who excelled in the healing aspects of life magic was unskilled with this level of magic, but Eydis had done it to Ceil in her darkest moments of fear of the approaching announcement of her marriage to the emperor, fears that now seem so small compared to the reality Ceil was living.
Eydis touched her mind, felt her emotions, and helped block the fear, but the effort left Eydis exhausted.
Even now, Ceil could feel her ven levels plummeting the longer she was in Sammy’s mind.
She continued tapping the waters again, tracing the rebounding ripples.
The sun rose above the canopy, showering flecks of light about them.
The humans had not located them, so she felt she had time, but this did not mean they were not eagerly searching.
Ceil fought within herself whether to carry Sammy or spend as much time as needed to wake her because they could move faster with Sammy awake.

The longer her search for the obstruction in Sammy’s conscious continued, the more she felt carrying Sammy was the better option, but when a ripple returned almost immediately, she threw the questions from her mind.
“I am close.”
Chloe watched with all eagerness the two bodies still as statues, completely ignorant to the intricate search happening beyond physical sight.
Ceil tapped the still waters again, but this time no ripple formed.
The surface felt not unlike a film had been placed over it, as intangible as a thought and yet impermeable.
She could tell what lay beneath was agitated, undulating, and trying to break through.
It had to be the source that blocked her mind and kept her from waking.
Now came the moment Ceil feared, but she could not hesitate without losing the position she had spent so long locating.
She reached with the fingers of her ven and pinched the film, lifting it like a cloth from the water.
The film resisted, but Ceil forced it free.
Sammy shot up, eyes wide and with heavy breath.
She broke into a subdued cry of pain and Ceil feared she did something terribly wrong.
“Sammy!
What is wrong?!
Are you hurt?!”
Sammy reached across her chest for her shoulders, but the motion caused her to lurch forward and cry out.
“My shoulders, they’re burning,” Sammy cried in a high-pitched squeal.
Ceil sighed in relief and began massaging Sammy’s shoulders.
Chloe joined in and warmed them to help work out the tension.
“What happened?
Why do my shoulders hurt,” Sammy asked once she could tolerate the ache.
“We were carrying you.
We did not have the stretcher.
Your shoulders supported you for over half a day…”
Sammy’s weight was the obvious cause.
Had she been an elf, or at least a regular human, she would be fine.
Ceil’s anger at her own ignorance and the secret that Sammy had never told her resurfaced.
“Why did you not tell me?”
Sammy did not understand the reason for Ceil’s troubled expression.
“Why did you not tell me what kind of strain you are under every day?
Why did you never say that your own bodies are crushing you?
I would have slowed down for you.
We could have taken more time so that you would be less burdened…
I would not have forced you to take care of me…”
Ceil’s anger gave way to the guilt caused by her own weakness.
Sammy ignored Ceil’s questions and heavy emotions.
Her eyes inspected the unfamiliar forest.
There was no clearing.
There were no dryads.
They were not at the village.
“You carried me?”
She frantically looked around.
They were alone.
Just Chloe, Ceil, and her.
Justin was nowhere to be seen.
“Ceil, where is Justin?”
She grabbed Ceil’s arm.
“What happened?
Tell me!
Where is Justin?!”
Ceil stood and paced as her guilt boiled within her.
Unable to contain it any longer, it burst out in a distraught yell.
“I told you!
I warned you!
I said that if you collapsed and we had to make a choice, we would leave him behind.
Do you think I wanted to leave him?”
“You left him somewhere?”
Sammy stood unsteadily on her feet, her arms quivering in anger.
“You never cared about Justin from the beginning!
You never once referred to him by name.
You only treated him because I asked you.
To you he was nothing but extra baggage, but to me, he is everything!
I tried so hard to save him, and now that he finally got help… You abandoned him!”
“I said we had no choice!”
“You always have a fucking choice!”
Sammy threw a ball of water at Ceil, and it splashed hard against her right cheek leaving the side of her face pink.
“You had a choice, and you chose to leave him!”
Ceil’s face stung.
Despite the ball’s size, it had a lot of force behind it.
She was angry, but she did not retaliate.
When a second hit her mouth, she stood her ground.
She could not look back at Sammy.
If Sammy wanted to take out her anger, Ceil felt she had the right.
She made the decision to leave Justin.
Chloe went along with it, but the decision was hers alone.
“Sammy!
Stop!”
Ceil raised her head to see Chloe grabbing Sammy from behind.
Sammy held a third ball of water in her right hand, larger than the previous two.
She shirked Chloe off and tossed the ball.
Expecting it to only sting like the last, Ceil did not dodge it, but when it impacted her chest, it burst.
The blow knocked Ceil to her back.
Her chest burned.
That was not a ball of water thrown in anger.
That was an attack.
The guilt in Ceil’s heart vanished.
She stood and walked over to where Chloe was struggling to subdue Sammy, and kicked Sammy in the stomach.
Both Sammy and Chloe fell back into the small patch of moss.
Ceil placed her hand on the trunk of the tree beside them, and roots shot up out of the ground, wrapping tight around Sammy, binding her arms, neck, and mouth.
Chloe barely broke away before she too was ensnared.
Ceil’s face could not hide her ire.
She could tolerate Sammy’s anger.
She knew she would be angry with her decision.
But, what she could not ignore was being attacked by a human.
Ceil looked down at Sammy who had not lost her fire despite being bound.
“If you want to know the truth, I will tell you.
Yes, I hate him.”
Sammy’s face grew red.
She howled through the roots that ran across her mouth between her teeth.
“I hate him.
I cannot accept that Eydis, the future Empress of the Amelian Empire chose a human as a lover.
I admit it!
I hate humans!
I despise everything about them.
I wish they were all dead.”
The trunk of the tree where Ceil placed her hand blackened, but she did not remove it.
Withered leaves slowly drifted down.
Several of them were black and brittle, almost dissolving once they hit the ground.
“Ceil! That’s enough!”
Chloe pleaded with Ceil as she tugged at the roots that were still tightening around Sammy’s neck.
“We fled the village because those humans learned we were there.
They were so close that we did not have the time to gather our belongings and prepare a way to take you both.
If they caught us, they would have killed all of us.
I could have run off on my own, but I chose to save you!
The only human I feel I can trust!
Which is why…”
Ceil licked her lips and found the faint taste of iron from where the second ball of water cracked the corner of her lip.
“…which is why I will not forgive you if you ever raise your hand against me.”
The red anger faded from Sammy’s face, and she stared at Ceil with wide eyes.
“Do you truly believe that I wanted to leave him behind?
Do you truly believe that I wanted to betray the trust of you who I relied on and who comforted me when I fell again into darkness?”
Ceil removed her hand from the tree.
Chloe broke and pried the roots off Sammy before the blackening reached her.
The tree above them was now barren of life, slowly crumbling from the thinnest top branches.
“The dryads know he was a member of our group.
They will tell the soldiers.
Because we fled, there is a chance that the soldiers will not kill him and use him to get to us.”
Sammy sat up, and tears welled in her eyes.
“But if they think we abandoned him, they might decide he is useless to them.
There was always a chance that Justin would die one day or the next.
We finally found him help, and now he could die again?
I’m tired of chances!”
She stood up and brushed off the remaining roots, wincing in pain from moving her sore shoulders.
Her anger had not left, but she did not lash out at Ceil.
“What direction is the village?
I’m going back.”
Ceil did not answer.
If the humans were still there, or even if only a few of them were, returning would not only endanger Sammy but also the innocent dryads in the village.
Sammy grew frustrated at Ceil’s silence.
“Why did we come to Melia?
Why were we seeking out a dryad village in the first place?”
Ceil immediately understood, and her guilt resurfaced.
Her eyes fell away to the soot of the once verdant leaves on the ground.
“We came here because of Justin.
We risked running into soldiers, risked your identity being revealed to Save. His. Life!
We ran into soldiers, your identity is known, and now you want to abandon the whole reason we came here in the first place?
I’m going back.”
“I’ll take you,” Chloe replied.
When Chloe and Sammy began walking away, Ceil finally mustered the will to respond.
“Returning to that village will place them in even more danger.
They already know who I am.
We need to warn other villages, not chase after that man.”
The words Ceil spoke felt empty in her mouth.
That village chose to side with the humans, and many more would have done the same.
Her fears no longer held the same weight.
The humans were not a danger to the villages.
The villages were a danger to her.
Sammy stopped walking and turned on the ball of her foot to face Ceil one final time.
“You lived with the sprites for a while.
How much did the Arkhon tell you about this war?
You may be important, but guess what?
So is Justin.
I promised the Arkhon that Justin would survive.
Go ahead and run to the other villages.
Chloe and I will save him.”
Sammy and Chloe ran off while Ceil watched, and once they were out of sight, she dropped to her knees.
There was truth to Sammy’s words.
She heard similar about herself when her personal Namie teleported her to Fiorrae.
“Darker times are to come, but you have a purpose in this tale,” Ceil whispered under her breath, and the words repeated over and over in her mind.
She grabbed a handful of the black soot and watched as it broke into even finer powder in her grip and drifted away in the light morning breeze.
Behind her, the wide trunk of the tree cracked and split, falling to the ground on both sides of her.
The thick branches shattered on impact with the ground like fragile pottery, but she did not startle.
Why did the sprites not tell her that Justin was the same as her?
Why did the Sprite Arkhon tell only Sammy?
If he had told her, she would not have chosen to abandon him.
Or would I?
Ceil hated Justin, and she felt her reasons were not unfounded.
Humans were her enemy.
They killed her parents, her hometown, and countless innocent people to target her.
Justin was a human.
Chloe was a human.
Even Sammy was a human… but she could not hate Sammy.
“Why?
Why is Sammy so different?
What if she is not different?
She could be a human like all the others!
She could be using me to help Justin and then will turn on me like the dryads!”
Ceil’s heart ached, and she knew her own words were lies.
The sprites would not have aided them if Sammy was an enemy, especially not the Sprite Arkhon.

If Sammy did not care about her, she would not have worked herself to collapsing to take care of her, fighting through the illness that Ceil beset on her in anger, the same evil magic that could destroy an ageless tree making it no more than dust in Ceil’s hands.
Sammy’s rage at Ceil’s abandonment of Justin was because she trusted Ceil.
Sammy may be a human, but she was not like her enemies.
She was different, not just from another location, but a completely different type of human than those of the Tolmyur Kingdom.
They sheltered and befriended Eydis.
Eydis chose a lover among them, Justin.
Eydis never would have done so if they were the Amelian Empire’s enemies.
The Tolmyur Kingdom attacked Sammy’s city.
They never would have done so if they were allies.
Ceil’s enemy was not humanity.
Her enemy was the Tolmyur Kingdom.
“That is what the Sprite Arkhon wanted me to learn…”
Ceil shrunk from her own incompetence.
The truth was in front of her the entire time and yet she was so blinded by her hatred of the humans to see it, and that blindness hurt Sammy, the only person remaining that she could call a friend.
Ceil ran after Sammy and Chloe.
Her light and limber body caught up quickly to the two humans who were having trouble keeping a running pace due to their weight.
Ceil prepared for backlash from Sammy, but what Sammy said surprised her.
“Took you long enough to catch up.”
Ceil once again realized how much Sammy trusted her.
“Just so you know,” Sammy continued, “I haven’t forgiven you for abandoning Justin.”
“And I have not forgiven you for attacking me,” Ceil retorted.
“But, you have every right to be angry.
I apologize.”
Sammy smiled between heavy breaths.
“Save it for Justin when you finally meet him.”
They reached the village in only a few hours.
Sammy spent most of her time in the village unconscious, so she did not notice any difference, but Chloe and Ceil were in shock at the lack of dryads in the clearing.
“Lemi!” Ceil spotted the excessively blooming anthousai immediately and ran to her.
“Lemi, what happened here?”
She feared that the humans had done something terrible, possibly killing most of the village for suspecting them of helping her escape.
Lemi was not distraught but excited to see Ceil.
“Come. Speak with Hemma.”
Lemi led them across the clearing, and every dryad that saw Ceil and her companions followed.
Hemma sat near the bed of clover holding her daughter with her finger in her daughter’s mouth.
When she saw Ceil, she sprung to her feet and quickly passed her daughter off to another while her daughter cried in protest.
Hemma then prostrated herself in front of Ceil.
“Your Highness, I am so grateful you are safe.
Please understand that we did not call the humans here.”
Whether or not they informed the soldiers was no longer important.
Ceil reached down and pulled Hemma up by her arm.
“What happened to the village?
Where is everyone?”
Ceil steeled her emotions, preparing for the worst of news.
“Our village is safe.
By your wisdom in leaving your companion with us, we were spared.”
Relief washed over Ceil, but this was no time for rejoicing.
Justin was no longer lying in the clover.
“What of my companion?”
“They bound him in rope and carried him with them.
When their commander saw him, he grew fearful.
Who is your companion that he would inspire such terror in a commander of Tolmyur’s forces?”
Ceil looked at Sammy who was oblivious to the Elven conversation and waiting anxiously for any news of Justin.
All Ceil knew about Justin was that he was Eydis’s lover.
According to Sammy, the Sprite Arkhon said Justin was important to the war.
Did he have such a great significance that even the military leaders of Tolmyur knew of him?
Ceil began to fear that she had made a terrible mistake in leaving Justin behind.
What if he was a political figure of his homeland, like a prince--the reason Eydis chose him as her partner--and in her ignorance of his standing, she abandoned him to death?
Sammy’s overprotectiveness could be due to her position as his retainer or servant or perhaps a mistress or concubine.
What if this brought the humans of Sammy’s homeland into the war against the empire because of her foolish hatred?
Ceil’s depression and anxiety resurfaced, rising and threatening to drown her in its murk.
What had she done?
She turned to Sammy, terrified.
“Sammy… Who is Justin?
Why would Tolmyur commanders fear him?”
Sammy did not answer but grew panicked instead.
“What happened to Justin?!”
“They bound him and took him away,” Ceil answered quickly.
She turned to Hemma.
“Did the soldiers say anything?
What are they to do with him?”
“They want to question him when he wakes.
Tyree is there to protect him.
They are headed for the hamadryad.
I fear they want to use him to sway her to side with the humans against you.
Jenae, our matriarch, left ahead of them to meet first with the hamadryad.”
“Then I too will meet with the hamadryad,” Ceil said.
Hemma bowed her head in gratitude, but Ceil lifted her again.
“How may I find her?”
Hemma searched the crowd and found the one dryad who could best act as guide.
“Lemi, do you remember the locations of the villages?”
Lemi’s face brightened with excitement.
“Yes!”
“And you know the pilgrimage route.”
“Yes,” she repeated.
Ceil was shocked by the decision.
“Are you sure sending an anthousai is safe?
What if something happens to her?
She could be with child.”
Lemi’s countenance fell, and Ceil tried to assure her that her question was not due to her lack of confidence in the girl.
Hemma asserted her decision.
“Lemi was personal witness to your heart when naming my daughter.
Her testimony may be vital in convincing the hamadryad.
It must be her.”
Ceil worried about exposing an innocent girl to such dangers but then had to remind herself that despite Lemi’s appearance, she was likely four or five times Ceil’s age.
Dryads aged much slower and lived much longer than elves.
Lemi’s maturity was still in question, but she still carried the knowledge of years far beyond Ceil’s own.
“Then I will be happy to have her as a guide,” Ceil replied.
“Do you still have our belongings?”
Hemma waved her hand and a Dryad approached carrying Ceil’s staff.
“They claimed your provisions and weapons as their own, leaving only your staff.”
Ceil could do without the food, medicine, and the sword.
They could travel with only the clothing about their waists.
The staff was unremarkable in appearance, but it was irreplaceable wood from Fiorrae.
She would not find a tree with such a capacity for life in Melia or anywhere else.
“Thank you.
This is enough.”
“Hardly enough.
How could we send you against the soldiers of Tolmyur with naught but a staff?”
Ceil was taken aback by the sudden change from Hemma’s subservient attitude to the same casual tone she had used when they first met, and somehow, she felt more at ease because of it.
“Give our empress and her friends a proper sendoff.”
At Hemma’s command, the crowd of dryads scattered, including Lemi who hurried off to make preparations of her own.
Ceil, Sammy, and Chloe sat in the clover next to Hemma while they waited.
Sammy and Ceil were anxious, wanting to leave as soon as possible, but Chloe was preoccupied with Hanvhial in her arms, resting her over her chest and bouncing her lightly.
“If dryads don’t have nipples, how do they feed their babies?”
Sammy and Ceil stared dumfounded at Chloe’s out of place question and then looked at each other.
“What are you looking at me for,” Sammy protested to Ceil.
“How am I supposed to know?
Maybe they photosynthesize or something and don’t need to feed?”
Ceil felt a little embarrassed asking, but she posed Chloe’s question to Hemma.
She knew little about dryad biology, and she would never admit that she was also curious.
Hemma chuckled lightly.
“Our breasts are like yours.
They store nutrients for our young, but we can secrete it anywhere through our skin.
They do not need to suck on our breasts, although many mothers still feed this way.
Over my many years and many daughters, I found a much simpler method.”
Ceil quickly made the connection.
“When you place your finger in her mouth.”
Hemma’s smile was her affirmation.
“Although we are closer kin to plants than elves, our bodies are not all that different.”
She placed her hand on her forehead.
“We have minds like you.”
She moved her hand on her chest.
“We have hearts and lungs like you.”
To her stomach.
“We must eat to survive like you.”
She then moved her hand to her abdomen.
“Although conception is different, we rear our children like you,” and after moving her hand to her womanhood, she finished, “and we bring them into the world the same way.
There is a legend that in ancient times a powerful Grassland Elf hermit of the Celadrian created the first dryad out of a desire for companionship in his isolation.”
Ceil watched the dryads of the village.
She realized that their body proportions and facial structure was nearly identical to a High Elf.
Their ears were even the same aside from being a little shorter.
She felt the High Elves were taller but then realized that the men were taller.
All dryads were female and about as tall as High Elf women would be.
Ceil, who was short for a High Elf, was as tall as, if not a little shorter than, Lemi who in appearance was a year younger.
When Lemi grew to adulthood, she would be taller, the height of any High Elf woman.
“You might be right,” Ceil replied.
Hemma chuckled again.
“It is only a legend, but we believe it because it helps us feel a personal connection to you and your empire.
The dryads surrendered to Tolmyur out of necessity in our lack of leadership to protect each other, but if your desire is to reclaim your empire, I know the dryads will stand with you.”
“Thank you.”
Although Ceil desired revenge against the humans--no, Tolmyur, she had to remind herself--she doubted she could lead the scattered remnants of those still loyal to restore the Amelian Empire.
While Ceil explained to Chloe the answer to her question, Lemi was the first of the dryads to return.
She carried a short bow strung over her back with the string, white like a root and growing from the tips of the bow, taut across her chest.
Lemi’s preparation was likely to grow the bow.
“Are you a shaman?” Ceil asked.
“In training.
I can use healing magic and dryadic magic,” Lemi replied with youthful confidence.
Understanding her own limitations (and dangers) Ceil was grateful to finally have a healer accompany them, even if only temporarily.
Behind Lemi, dryads approached one by one carrying bags made from woven leaves or roots, bundles of plant-like fabric, parcels of medicine, and more.
The amount was excessive, and she worried about Chloe and Sammy who would have to carry it despite the constant strain of their heavy bodies.
“This is too much,” Ceil said to stop the procession.
“We provide what we can.
Take only what you need,” Hemma replied.
Ceil joined Sammy to inspect the supplies while Chloe stayed back to hold the infant.
The large sacks contained herbs, mushrooms, and other edibles.
They could both hunt and scavenge so large food stores would be excess weight.

The bundles of pale-green fabric were incredibly light cloaks, and while dryads were not known for the quality of their plant-based textiles, they were well insulating and appeared able to repel water.
They could use them as covering at night to relieve Chloe of her need to keep everyone warm, further saving on food stores.
The medicine wrapped in leaves was a paste, and from the pungent smell, beiju was one of many herbal ingredients.
It was far higher quality than what she or Sammy could create, and although they had Lemi, her accompaniment was only temporary.
The medicine would be of great value when Lemi left.
In one final drawstring pouch, Ceil found a strange herb she had never seen before.
Sammy looked over her shoulder and immediately grabbed it with excitement, running to Chloe.
“Chloe! Look!”
She held the pouch gently to not crush the herb.
When Chloe looked inside, she was also surprised but then moved the infant away as if the herb was dangerous.
“What is it?” Ceil asked.
“We landed in a patch of these when we came to Fiorrae.
They give you a kind of boost when you inhale them,” Sammy explained.
“Boost?”
Sammy carefully removed a single spongey bead and pinched it under Ceil’s nose.
The powdery yet sweet aroma shot through Ceil’s sinuses and made her reel back.
Her mild exhaustion from running back to the village was gone, and she began feeling restless, like she had to stand and move.
“We probably never would have reached that lake where we met you if we didn’t have these.”
“Do not rely too heavily on deshalu,” Hemma warned having watched the exchange.
“It can be addicting.
Save it for emergencies when you must fight or flee.
It is a very rare herb due to over-gathering, so you may have trouble finding more.”
While Ceil handed out the cloaks to everyone, one final dryad approached carrying three staffs.
They were thinner than Ceil’s but the wood appeared a far higher quality, shaped into what could be used as either a walking staff or a weapon with the pommel on one end.
Ceil retrieved one staff and checked its life capacity in the rare chance that it was superior to hers, having been crafted by a dryad, but as expected it was far weaker.
The quality of the wood was the most important factor, no matter how skilled the crafter.
She handed them out, and Lemi was the only one who rejected it.
Ceil found this odd for one who used dryadic magic but then realized that Lemi’s bow could function as a conduit all the same.
Each of the four members of Ceil’s party wore a cloak.
Sammy carried the deshalu and medicine.
