A single sack of food was divided between Ceil and Chloe.
Preparations were finished, and the party was ready to depart.
Hemma held Lemi by her cheeks and pressed their foreheads together.
“Do our village proud.”
Lemi swelled with confidence and led Ceil, Sammy, and Chloe out of the village.

Chapter 14
“The Hamadryad”
Byurk
Byurk supervised as his men quickly set up their small camp.
They had no tents or bed rolls, so the preparation was only to clear the ground, create a perimeter, and then build a fire.
His thirty-two-elite worked with fervor, not one man out of line or slow in his performance despite having kept an advanced march for the fourth day since leaving that Melian village.
The night was already half spent, and they would be marching again at sunrise, so perhaps the soldiers were only eager to finish camp preparations quickly to maximize their sleep.
The days of swift march were taking their toll on his men, but Byurk trusted they would push through.
During the Coastal Wars, Byurk had days when rest was impossible, something he continually reminded his men.
They would grow stronger in proportion to the trials they faced.
Byurk stood as last watch, and the night passed uneventfully, same as all previous.
No Melian would ever think to ambush his men at night, of that he was certain.
The Habha were another matter.
He woke his men at first light and rallied them to pick up camp and prepare to leave.
He was eager to depart because he was sure that he was close to the Melian capital.
The previous day, they ran into multiple Melians, and even now there was one in the distance watching his soldiers prepare for departure despite there being no village immediately nearby.
“How much longer until we reach the capital,” Byurk asked Tyree.
“I have told you before that we do not have a capital.
It is only a centrally located village.”
“The difference is negligible.
How long?”
“We will reach it before midday.
But before we leave, come with me.”
Byurk followed Tyree to where the man from the other world lay.
His eyes were open in small slits that lacked the energy to open fully.
The barely visible pupils found Byurk, and the man spoke.
“Minum…”
His voice was like a breathless whisper, and if Byurk was not standing over him, he would not have heard it.
Byurk had seen men close to death.
He had watched men pass from injury, exhaustion, and starvation.
He knew the many faces of men, and the face beneath him showed fear through an expression too exhausted for emotion.
This otherworldly human knew Byurk was his enemy, and that knowledge was deeply engraved in his mind.
Such a mental scar would not be created from secondhand information no matter how weak-willed the person.
There were no minums in the forward party that was wiped out by the Habha.
Given his otherworldly apparel, there was one possible explanation.
Not long after Jethro began his campaign against the city in the other world, this human from that world appeared on Whinhlem.
This man might have fought Jethro and his soldiers and was now here aiding Jethro’s enemies.
Byurk wanted to communicate but was not fortunate enough to be taught the language of that world.

The instructor Jethro captured never returned after he left with the Lurr to locate the princess, and there were few remaining at the palace who spoke English, none of whom were skilled enough to teach him while he was recovering from the failed assassination by the fairies.
This human accompanied the emperor’s wife, so his only hope was that he spoke elven.
“Can you hear me?”
The man’s eyes twitched so lightly that only a practiced eye would notice.
Byurk took the faint movement as confirmation.
“Do you understand me?”
There was no movement, but animosity slowly grew behind the blank expression.
The man was waking, his consciousness returning stronger, but Byurk did not know if he could communicate.
“What is your name?”
A reaction, although faint.
The man understood his words or at least this phrase, but he was not answering.
He slapped the man across the cheek, and the Melian shaman startled at the sudden brutality, but she did not stop him.
Byurk took this as confirmation that this level of abuse would not endanger the weakened man’s frail life.
He slapped him again.
“What is your name,” Byurk repeated.
“Captain Byurk, we are ready to depart,” one of the soldiers informed him.
“Can you not see that I am busy?”
“Sir, should we wait then?”
Byurk looked around and saw his men standing, waiting for instruction.
“Are you a bunch of recruits?” he hollered.
“No sir,” the soldiers replied in unison.
“Then think for yourselves!
There are Melians passing through the area.
Question them about the hamadryad!”
The men spread out.
“Stay within earshot and remember to be polite!
We are not their enemies!
Understood?!”
“““Yes, sir!”””

Being so close to a central town, the last thing Byurk wanted was to insult the Melians, especially when Tolmyur desperately needed the aid of the dryads now that the other world had sided with the wife of the emperor.
“Your name!”
He swung his hand again, but when it was about to impact the man’s cheek, he felt a distortion.
Only Byurk’s fingertips grazed the man’s cheek as he turned his head to avoid that slap.
The man used magic, but the ven Byurk felt had a signature that he did not recognize.
He knew what spatial magic felt like, but this was different.
The only other affinities that produced such distortions were time or gravity, and given the situation, there was only one possibility.
“Who are you?”
Byurk’s voice lost its authoritative tone.
This man was not some soldier or guard assigned to protect the wife of the emperor.
This was a time mage, a human time mage, and one who could ignore channeling time.
Time was an incredibly rare affinity for magically adept races to possess, even his fellow minums.
The last time Byurk felt such shock was when he met Jethro for the first time, and the more he thought about it, the more he realized they were similar.
They both were unnaturally heavy.
They both had incredibly rare affinities for humans.
Most importantly, this man came from another world, just like Jethro, a secret only known to a select few.
The amount of knowledge and power that Jethro possessed had drastically improved Tolmyur.
Jethro had conquered their enemy, the Amelian Empire, after only a year of planning and at the cost of only a minute fraction of their army.
If this man could do the same, he was the greatest danger to the Tolmyur Kingdom, greater even than the widow of the emperor or the princess.
Byurk drew his sword, and before the dryad could stop him, he thrust it into the heart of the man, except it stopped after barely piercing the skin.
He applied more force to the blade, but it would not move.
He felt the same odd signature.
The man’s magic rendered the blade immobile.
Byurk looked at the man’s face and found it frozen, like death, except the man was very much alive.
He was only not moving.
Byurk tried to remove the sword but couldn’t.
He let go and stepped back.
The blade remained erect as if impaled in stone until slowly the blade tipped over.
When it left the man’s skin, it fell to the ground as if gravity had grabbed hold of it once more.
Byurk immediately understood it was not gravity that grabbed hold of the blade.
It was time.
The time of the blade had stopped, or nearly stopped, the moment it pierced him.
Just as Byurk could never defeat Jethro in a duel, he would not be able to kill this man, at least if the man was awake.
“Tyree, make him sleep,” Byurk ordered as he retrieved his sword.
“I forbid you from harming him any worse than you have.”
The dryad’s dark green eyes glared at Byurk like a mother protecting her young.
“He is my patient, and I will protect his life to my death, same as the soldiers I healed for your armies.
If you want my cooperation, you will not kill him.”
“Do you have any idea the danger this man poses?”
“Danger to you or danger to us?”
“I could kill you now and request any of the passing dryads to guide us.”
Tyree’s face grew stern.
“I am one of the strongest shamans in all of Melia.
In a forest, you would die before you touch me.
I will take you to the hamadryad as promised.
If she chooses to support you and your cause, and if you still desire his death, I will not stop you.
Until then, he is under my protection.”
Byurk sized up the dryad who, while kneeling, was still taller than him.
He knew now that the village had sided with the emperor’s widow, but there was no deception in her eyes.
Hamadryads were the highest authority in Dhuillir, and this shaman respected that authority.
“Fine.
I will trust you to uphold your promise, but remember the message that was brought to your village.
Siding with the widow of the emperor and those with her will bring the wrath of our Commanding General upon your people, like the fairies of Vallen.
The Melians are too kind for such conflict, so know that my actions here are for the safety and benefit of your people.”
“Then you had best convince the hamadryad,” Tyree said, unperturbed.
Byurk sheathed his sword and walked back to the center of the small camp while Tyree rushed to heal the bleeding wound in the man’s chest and force him to sleep once more.
“Men!
Form up!
We march for the city!”
The soldiers gathered quickly, and the march continued while Byurk had his men relay what they learned from passing dryads.
He expected little in such a short time, and little was all they found.
Only four dryads were questioned, and of those four, only two spoke Elven and gave conflicting information.
“The one who walks is in the village.”
“I think the hamadryad has moved on.”
The hamadryad either is or was in the village, confirming to Byurk that Tyree was not leading them astray, and that was the most valuable piece of information he needed.
They reached the city by midmorning.
In Byurk’s march to Vallen, he had passed through many dryad villages but none this large.
It reminded him of a smaller forest city in Vallen with its structures grown from shrubs or carved out of trees.
These structures were not for the Melians but were used to accommodate the non-dryad inhabitants, although it seemed that a few Melians resided in them.
A pair of Forest Elf men walked the street with crown-like antlers around their heads and their long tails swaying behind them.
A High Elf child bartered fruit with an older Melian while the child’s mother stood and watched.

Unlike the smaller villages that dotted Melia, most the Melians of the city were clothed with skirts about their waists out of respect for those among the inhabitants who were not accustomed to nakedness.
“Where will we find the hamadryad,” Byurk asked Tyree.
“We should seek out the village’s matriarch.
Follow me.”
Tyree led Byurk’s party through the wide streets of the village, or what could have been considered streets: gaps between buildings where the grass was a little more trodden.
The residents of the town kept their distance, and those who were in the middle of conversations or bartering grew silent when Byurk and his men passed.
The Melians bowed lightly to the soldiers, but the few other residents, elves, nymphs, and other dryads glared with animosity.
A short, stout tree not unlike those in Vallen grew near the center of the village.
One side had been hollowed out to create a wide entrance that could fit all thirty-two of Byurk’s men.
Only two Melians resided in the hollow, a younger dryad and the village matriarch whom she served.
The matriarch sat cross-legged on a slightly elevated platform covered in moss with a dark green fabric over her lap.
She appeared some age between Tyree and the matriarch of Tyree’s village.
Her wrinkled cheeks smiled as she bowed, welcoming her visitors.
“I am honored to be host to a commander of Tolmyur.”
The matriarch waved her hand, and her aid quickly retrieved two moss pads for Byurk and Tyree to sit on.
“Your men look weary.
While we speak, may I offer services for them?
We have women, food, and drink.
I can also arrange entertainment.”
“I am grateful for your hospitality.
If you can restore their energy, that alone will be sufficient.”
Byurk looked back briefly at the famished faces of his men.
“And some food, but make it light.
Depending on our conversation, we may stay longer.
We will partake of your full hospitality then.”
“Of course.
Seiva, gather some shamans and see that his men are fed and rested.”
The men tried to remain professional, but excitement or relief broke the surface on a few.
After their strenuous march, Byurk could not find the will to chastise them.
Their rest and morale would help expedite their search for the hamadryad.
The soldiers followed the aid out of the room, and Byurk sat alone with Tyree and the matriarch.
The only other occupant was the bound man sitting against the wall near the entrance.
In order to best gauge the time he had, Byurk asked the most important question first.
“We came seeking audience with the hamadryad.
Is she in your village?”
The matriarch bowed her head apologetically.
“Forgive my impudence, but before I answer your question, I must first know your reason.
Tolmyur killed our three Grandmatriarchs.
I can only assume that if you knew of her during the assassinations, she would have been targeted as well.
Hamadryads are vital in unifying the sixteen tribes, and now that we have lost that leadership, I must prioritize the safety of our current Grandmatriarch candidate.”
Byurk nodded.
“Raise your head.
I take no offense to your precaution.
I also seek the unification of Dhuillir.”
The matriarch raised her head and looked into Byurk’s eyes to assess the truth of his statement.
After a moment of pensive silence, she asked the vital question.
“Why?”
Byurk understood her reluctance to believe him.
The matriarch who first informed him of the hamadryad also feared he would seek the hamadryad’s destruction.
She needed proof of his motives, and that very proof was in this room.
“Tyree, bring the man here.”
While Tyree carried out Byurk’s orders, he continued addressing the matriarch.
“Are you skilled in life magic?”
“I am.
I was a shaman before accepting my role as matriarch of this village.”
Tyree laid the unconscious man between Byurk and the matriarch.
“This man is the reason.
I want you to scan both me and him and notice the differences.”
The matriarch was confused by the request but touched Byurk’s outstretched hand.
He felt the pulse of life magic surge through his body.
She then touched the forehead of the man in front of her, and her eyes widened.
“What did you find?” he asked.
The matriarch traded glances between Byurk and the man.
“The only difference between a minum and human should be your size, but this man, is he human?”

Byurk felt reservations revealing classified information to a former enemy, but the situation called for a breach of protocol, and he was willing to receive any punishment that would follow if the classified information spread.
“He is human, but not of our world, not of Whinhlem.
His kind poses a major threat, and we do not know how many of them are in Dhuillir, the former Amelian Empire, and Whinhlem.
I seek the unification of Dhuillir so that we may gain a strong ally against them.”
The matriarch licked her lips and was about to speak but fell silent.
What Byurk told her was impossible to believe, at least if the truth was not in front of her.
She turned to Tyree for confirmation.
“Are there more of these humans?”
“There are two others that I know of who are different from the humans of Tolmyur.
I do not know if there are more of them or if they came from another world.”
Byurk could only trust that Tyree’s reply was truthful, that she did not lie due to her village allying with the widow of the emperor.
In the least, her answer was sufficient for Byurk to press the matriarch further.
“I must express the gravity of the danger each of these individuals pose.
This man before you is a time mage.
Another of his companions is a fire mage with an aptitude that surpasses any minum.
All we know about their goal is that they seek to create further conflict.”
Byurk placed both of his hands on the carved wooden floor and bowed his head to the matriarch, stunning her.
“Please, I must speak with the hamadryad.”
Byurk and eight of his fastest men sprinted through the forest with Seiva, the matriarch’s aid, acting as a guide.
Using his earth magic to kick up the ground and boost each step, Byurk kept pace with the sprint despite his small stature.

The hamadryad had left the city two days prior, and Byurk thought that they would need to continue the march, but the matriarch assured that the hamadryad could not have traveled far and must yet be close to the village.
Her information came with ill news.
The hamadryad was weak and would likely not survive her trek to the next village.
“Commander Byurk!
Look here!”
Seiva with her seemingly unlimited stamina ran a full fifty paces ahead of the group.
She stopped at what Byurk thought was a thin withered stump sticking out of the ground.
When Byurk approached, he realized that he had been terribly mistaken.
It was a brown leg with a hint of orange showing between the bark-like wrinkles of the skin.
The leg snapped off just below the knee, and small dead roots attached it to the ground.
“Increase your pace!
She should be close!”
Almost an hour later, Seiva called back, “I see them!”
In the distance were three dryads.
The one on the left was a Melian.
The other two dryads had a faint orange tint to their brown skin with thick and scaly fans of needle-like hair drooping halfway down their backs.
The dryad in the center had one hand each on the shoulders of the two dryads beside her for support as she hopped forward on her single foot.
When the three dryads heard Seiva’s shout and approach, the hamadryad stopped moving but lacked the energy to turn around.
Seiva reached them far ahead of Byurk and his men.
The hamadryad requested Seiva’s aid as she and the other two dryads helped turn her to face him.
The withered body shocked him.
Tyree compared the otherworldly human to a living corpse, but the single word that came to Byurk’s mind when looking upon the sunken and heavily cracking features of the Hamadryad was death.
She looked like the dried corpses he had seen when visiting villages that had fallen to famine in the mountainous deserts of western Tolmyur.
“You wish to speak with me, young one?”
Her voice was like grinding sand, and Byurk’s throat itched at the sound.
While Byurk collected his thoughts, the dryad of similar species to the hamadryad stared down at him with the sharp beauty of a fit adult woman.
She was either the hamadryad’s caretaker or bodyguard.
He did not doubt she was well practiced in combat.
“Speak fast,” the woman ordered.
“The longer she stands idle, the more she will take root.”
Byurk saw the hamadryad’s last foot growing roots before his very eyes.
“Tearing the roots is as painful as peeling off your own skin.
Speak.”
The glare of the unknown dryad demanded Byurk’s haste.
“What I must say is of grave importance but cannot be explained quickly.
Can you lift her so her foot does not touch?”
“The roots follow the path of life to where it connects to the soil.
If we lift her, she will take root in us or you or whoever holds her.”
“Then if life cannot find its path, will she be safe?”
The Melian and the caretaker looked at each other, confused by Byurk’s question.
“Men!
Your swords and armor!”
Byurk turned to the caretaker.
“Please walk her while I work.
I will not be long.”
While the dryads helped the hamadryad take small, painful steps, Byurk used his earth magic to dull the edges of the swords.
The thin chain-link shirts lacked leather or other biological material.
After fastening the handles together with fabric, he slipped the swords through the mail to create a small metal palanquin.
He then ordered two of his men to lift it on their shoulders.
“Place her here.”
The caretaker looked at the haphazard contraption with skepticism but did as she was asked.
The soldiers took extra care not to touch the hamadryad as she rested into the hanging chainmail.
Small roots spouted from her legs and arms as she supported herself, but once they latched onto the metal, they stopped growing.
The path to the soil had been severed.
“Incredible,” the elderly Melian said while circling the palanquin in dumbstruck amazement.
“I wish to take you back to the village to speak with you at length.
Do you feel you can manage this now?”
The hamadryad looked at the dull blades and chainmail.
She could not move from her roots, but she was content.
“Yes, I will gladly accompany you.”

Chapter 15
“Otherworldly Power”
The sun in the late afternoon sky cast the shadow of large wings across the verdant expanse.
Coby soared at incredible speed from the wind expelled by his wings.
His large round eyes moved erratically, his piercing vision glancing into every gap between every tree, visible for not even a moment, in search of the one who saved and treated him.
He had located the one she cared for and who was taken away by the human soldiers.
He saw many dryads but none that he recognized.
He saw many animals but had no time to hunt.
He only sought that one person.

* * *
Sammy fought through the exhaustion of their chase.
Lemi guided their sprint towards the fifth Melian village on the pilgrimage’s path.
By Hemma’s estimate, the hamadryad would have left Melia’s largest central village by the time they reached it, so their aim was for the city that followed.
They had traveled since before sunup at Sammy’s request and only took the briefest of breaks to snack on the food in Ceil and Chloe’s packs for energy.
Sleep-deprived and both lungs and legs burning, Sammy forced herself onward with a single thought driving her.
“Justin, please be okay.”
The branches of the trees snapped, and a cobalt blue blur dropped between Sammy and Chloe who was only a few paces ahead.
Sammy had no time to register what happened before large talons grabbed her shoulders, and she shot up into the air with a flap of large wings.
But she did not stay there.
The large bird managed two strenuous flaps before falling with Sammy back below the canopy and to the forest floor.
Sammy landed on her back with air erupting from her lungs, and her would-be captor rolled and fluttered on the ground in a ball of blue feathers.
He righted himself and shook his plumage, gawking at Sammy with a cry of frustration while feathers floated to the ground around him.
“Coby!
You need to stop suddenly grabbing people.”
Ceil ran over to Sammy to help her up, and Lemi used life magic to heal Sammy’s scratches and ease her breathing.
“Coby?” Sammy looked at the bird with tearful eyes, both from the painful impact and from seeing the companion she thought had left after he was healed.
She broke away from the care of Ceil and Lemi and tackled the large, flustered hawk to the ground.
“I’m so happy to see you.”
She wrapped her arms around his neck in a tight embrace, and Coby did not protest or attempt to break free from her grasp.
“Get off him,” Ceil ordered while pulling back on Sammy’s shoulder.
“If Coby grabbed you, there is something he needs to show you.
The same happened to me when he discovered the soldiers were approaching Lemi’s village.
He would be carrying you off somewhere if you were not so heavy,” Ceil said while straining from Sammy’s weight as she tried to pry her off Coby.
“Take me somewhere?”
Sammy released her hold on Coby and stepped back.
Coby righted himself with a light flap of his large wings.
“Kree!” He hopped and trotted away into the forest, crying again when no one followed him.
He returned to Sammy and pulled on her hair with his beak.
“Wait! Stop!”
Sammy pried her hair free from his beak, making him cry out even louder.
“Lemi, what’s in that direction,” Ceil asked.
Lemi thought for a moment, and her eyes lit up when the answer came.
“The central village is that way!
We are close to it right now.”
“Coby wants us to go to another village,” Ceil explained to Sammy.
“Do you think the hamadryad is there,” Lemi asked.
“Coby would not know we are seeking the hamadryad.
There has to be another reason.” Ceil turned to Sammy.
“Can you think of what Coby wants?”
Sammy looked into Coby’s deep black pupils.
An anxiety surfaced in her heart.
“Justin,” she whispered under her breath.
“Justin.
Coby found Justin!”
“If that is true, that is where we are headed.” Ceil turned to Lemi.
“How long until we reach the central village?”
“If we do not stop, maybe late evening,” Lemi said.
“Sammy, Justin might be at the central Melian village,” Ceil explained.
The news gave Sammy her second wind, and she ran in the direction Coby had tried to pull her.
Coby flew into the air with a profound cry and led Sammy onward with Chloe, Ceil, and Lemi quickly catching up.

The group kept up the fastest pace that Chloe and Sammy could manage, and Lemi used her life magic to ease muscle fatigue when possible, but they were force to take a break when Sammy nearly collapsed.
After a two-hour nap, they set off again at a slower pace.
Well past midnight, Coby’s cries ceased.
He flew silently in the night sky camouflaged in the darkness, but they no longer needed him as a guide.
Lemi knew where they were and that the central village was nearby.m
After another hour, faint light appeared deep in the forest.
It was subdued, only to allow visibility for the races that needed it in the dark nights.
The faint green beacon came from the top of a thick tree growing in the center of the forest clearing.
Small structures surrounded it on all sides, and all was silent in the sleepy night.
Coby landed on a branch at the edge of the clearing and silently flapped his wings, symbolizing that they had reached the destination he desired.
“Where is Justin,” Sammy asked, leaning on a tree for support.
“Entering the village is too dangerous.
If Justin is here, so are the soldiers.”
Ceil turned to Lemi.
“Can you scout out the village for us?
They should not notice one more dryad.”
Lemi looked eager but concerned.
“Anthousai normally cannot leave their village.
I would attract the villagers’ attention because I am not from this village.”
“I am not worried about the dryads.
I did not know anthousai are supposed to stay in their village, so I doubt the soldiers know.
If Sammy or Chloe or I go, we would attract the soldiers’ attention.
It must be you.”
Lemi nodded eagerly and removed her cloak.
She turned it on its side, folded it in half, and tied it about her waist like a skirt before readying her bow.

Ceil, Sammy, and Chloe looked at the weapon, curious how she could use it without ammunition, but once Lemi had her hand on both the grip and string, a straight branch grew from above the grip until it extended to the string and out forward from the bow.
Leaves sprouted for fletching where the natural arrow nocked to the string.
Ceil was amazed.
So long as Lemi nourished the life in the bow, she would have arrows.
Lemi ran low to the ground into the village without even the faintest sound to her step.
Ceil was taught that in times of war, dryads were lauded for their stealth, but here she saw a dryad’s skill firsthand.
Lemi was much older than Ceil, but mentally she was still an immature girl.
Lemi’s single arrow was probably for protection in case of an emergency, but Ceil hoped she would not do anything rash.
She waited anxiously with Sammy.
Chloe and Coby alone remained composed, but while Chloe waited patiently, Coby was scanning the village from his high perch for any sign of threat, and his silent trill signaled Lemi’s return.
She was not alone.
Another Melian followed Lemi silently out of the village.
She was elderly but did not appear quite as old as Hemma.
When the two reached Ceil, Lemi introduced her.
“This is Jenae, the matriarch of my village.”
“You went after the hamadryad,” Ceil said, realizing who might also be in the village.
Jenae nodded remorsefully.
She bowed herself to the ground before Ceil, and Ceil knew what Jenae was about to say.
After all, Hemma acted the same way after seeing her again.
“I am terribly sorry, your Highness.
I have failed you.”
“I have no time for apologies.
Get up.
What happened in your village is in the past.
I hold no ill will.”
Jenae bowed her head lower until it touched the forest floor.
“No, I have failed in my mission.
The human commander has met with the hamadryad.
She has decided to side with him.”
The news came as a shock to Ceil.
What kind of coercion had he used?
What kind of threats?
Although the news was disappointing, a more pressing matter hung on her mind, and Sammy’s anxious grip on Ceil’s arm was growing tight and painful.
“What of my companion?
Is he safe?” Ceil asked.
“He… he will likely be executed at sunrise.”
Ceil’s heartrate accelerated.
She grabbed Jenae’s arm and lifted her, and although Ceil did not know what manner of expression she was showing, Janae viewed her with terror.
“Explain!”
“Tyree told me that Byurk fears your companion and tried to kill him.
She only stopped him by promising to execute him if the hamadryad sided with Tolmyur against your companions.
Tyree is loyal to the Grandmatriarchs.
She will follow through with the execution.”
“And the hamadryad has sided with them…” Ceil’s legs grew weak.
She looked over at Sammy who begged in silence for good news, but a tear fell from Sammy’s eyes as the unspoken conversation of Ceil’s gaze told Sammy of ill fortune.
“What happened to Justin?” Sammy asked.
Ceil was about to explain Justin’s fate when she realized what Jenae had said.
The dark sky was ever so slightly growing lighter, but morning was yet still far off.
She faced Jenae with all seriousness.
“You said at sunrise.
Justin is still alive.
Where is he?”
“He is in Tyree’s care in the soldier’s camp.
There are over thirty of them.
You cannot fight them.”
“We have an entire village of dryads here.
Can we not rally them?”
“And start a war against Tolmyur?
You might be able to convince the outsiders to side with you, but the Melians will not willingly start a war.
We have already submitted to them.”
Ceil pulled Jenae up until their noses nearly touched.
“Justin’s death could spell disaster for us all.”
Moisture drained from Jenae’s face.
Ceil released her grip, and Jenae sunk back away from her.
Ceil paced, contemplating what she could do.
She could not fight the soldiers with so few on her side.
“Could Tyree be convinced to return Justin to us?”
Jenae kept her head bowed to the ground.
“She has not heard of the hamadryad’s decision, so perhaps, but we would not be able to take your companion from the soldiers’ camp unnoticed.
Their commander will return to the hamadryad at first light to hear her decision.
Once he returns to camp--”
“Enough.” Ceil rustled her hair and groaned.
“Tell me what’s going on,” Sammy pleaded, but Ceil kept thinking.
“My only option is to speak with the hamadryad.
Where is she?”
“Inside the village matriarch’s abode, the large tree in the center of the village.”
“And the soldiers’ camp?”
“Not far separate from the abode.
The soldiers are in the care of this village and are using their structures.
If you go to see the matriarch and hamadryad, you will be noticed.”
“Chloe, you are a powerful fire mage, correct?” Ceil asked.
Chloe startled from the sudden, seemingly out of place question, having been unable to follow the Elven conversation.
“I don’t know if I am that powerful.
I have nothing to compare myself against.”
“The attack you threw at the scout who saw my tails, that was your best fireball, correct?”
Chloe thought for a moment.
“I could probably do one stronger than that if I tried.
Yah, a lot stronger.”
Ceil’s eyes grew wide.
The fireball from back then was master-class, and if Chloe could produce one stronger, then she was in a class all her own.
Maybe we can fight them… but what of the village?
“Chloe, I need you to draw the soldiers out of the village.”
“Me? On my own?”
Ceil knew her request was dangerous.
If Chloe could attack the soldiers directly, she could probably do a lot of damage, but Justin was in the camp.
Her only choice was to have them chase Chloe out of the village.
“You are right.
That will not work.”
Ceil forgot that Chloe was not the same as her.
Even though Chloe was stronger than Sammy, they shared the same condition.
Chloe was heavy and slow.
The soldiers would catch her quickly.

Even if she could move quickly, possibly with the help of the deshalu grass, the number of soldiers was a major concern for a single person; however, she did have someone who was faster and very capable in a fight.
“I know what we can do.”
Ceil gathered everyone together to explain her plan.

* * *
Chloe hurried with a spring in her step through the forest circling the village.
She felt light.
Her accelerated heartrate made her body throb, and she loved the feeling.
Lemi ran a few paces in front of her, guiding her into position.
She coaxed Chloe on with silent words that Chloe could not understand, but so long as she kept pace, they would arrive in time, or at least she hoped.
The one to initiate the plan could not be conversed with but seemed intelligent enough to reason through the commands and gestures given.
Ceil had a lot of trust in Coby, but Chloe still had doubts.
Even if Coby had understood and executed the two orders Ceil had given him in the past, that did not mean he would be able to follow complicated instructions.
Chloe felt that in order to comprehend such an order without even knowing the language of the one giving it would take human-level intelligence, and even then it would be difficult.
She doubted a bird would be able to understand.
Lemi stopped at the edge of the forest and pointed to the ground after speaking a few words.
She then readied her bow and ran silently into the village.
Chloe was left alone, anxiously waiting for the start of the operation while her mind focused on the mildly sweet aroma lingering in her sinuses.
She scanned the village for any sign of disturbance, but it remained peaceful.
Everything relied on Coby, and Ceil gave no alternative if Coby failed.
Large dark wings flapped silently in the sky.
Chloe’s eyes followed Coby until he landed atop the stout tree in the center of the village.
Coby was visible in the faint glow.
His head scanned the edge of the village and stopped when facing Chloe.
She could not be sure, but she felt that Coby was staring directly at her.

He spotted her in the dark, which felt odd because she thought she read somewhere that hawks had bad night vision, but then again, this was a different world, and the knowledge she had of the animals on Earth might not apply to those on Whinhlem.
Coby flapped his large wings, shaking and breaking the thin branches at the top of the tree.
Faint voices could be heard, and in the next instant, it started.

* * *
Byurk woke to the murmuring of his men and the sound of snapping wood.
“What is that racket?”
He peeled off his woven grass blanket and sat up on his small moss bed.
The soldiers beside him who also were sleeping grew attentive quickly and looked around to assess what was happening.
The soldiers outside the small grass hut were in a panic.
Training and experience kicked in, and Byurk’s men immediately retrieved their weapons.
“What is going on!?”
Hearing Byurk’s shout, one of the soldiers at the entrance of the hut finally answered.
“That Habha has returned!”
It couldn’t be… “The wife has found us!
All men to--”
A large blade of wind cut down through the thatch roof and side wall.
The hut collapsed on top of Byurk and those inside.
The sharp grass scratched his face and hands as he scrambled to break through the reeds intertwined tightly together by their roots.
The scene outside as he broke through the natural roofing was chaos.
His men were armed and looking to the sky.
Those with bows had arrows knocked and waiting.
Two fire mages had fireballs ready but hesitated to throw them.
Everything in the village was wood.
Everything was plant matter, even the residents.
Fire was too dangerous to use inside the village.
Dryad life sap was particularly flammable.
That hesitation proved fatal as one of the mages was cut down by a blade of wind before Byurk’s eyes.
The hut beside him took most of the blow, collapsing the wall.
That hut was not being used by his men.
The three Melians inside screamed and rushed out of the entrance on the other side.
The Melians viewed the large bird with terror.
Even they feared the Habha.
“Drive that buzzard from the village!
Protect the villagers!”
Rage burned within him.
The wife of the emperor was attacking the village of her own former subjects.
“Drive it away!”
Byurk scrambled over the thatch roof and ran to the three Melians cowering beside their partially destroyed hut.
He urged them to flee with a push on their backs.
Once they began moving, other cowering Melians followed them in their flight, all except one.
A young Melian with so many white flowers in her mossy hair that it looked like matted cotton ran crouched towards the chaos, stopping near the village matriarch’s tree.
Something about the girl felt strangely familiar, but his suspicions disappeared when she peered into the sky with bow and arrow in hand.
Byurk was proud to see a Melian brave enough to confront the Habha, especially a child, but he could not allow such a young girl to endanger herself.
He ran towards her, causing her to fright.
“This is no place for a child!
Leave!”
The girl looked into his eyes with trepidation.
She shook her head.
“No, I need to…”
Byurk’s own men, a hand selected group of elite soldiers, could only manage to drive the Habha away in past attacks.
What could a child do against it?
“Your bravery is commendable, but you cannot fight it.”
Despite his words, the girl would not listen.
Her bravery was inspiring.
“Fire your one arrow and then flee.”
The girl looked at him and then at the Habha.
Now confronted with the task before her, she grew fearful.
“Shoot or I will drag you away myself!”
The girl drew the string and took aim with shaking arms.
The released arrow flew with a wide arch, and although Byurk expected little from a child, the arrow missed its mark to a surprising degree.
However, unlike the arrows of his archers, the Habha paid special attention to it and dove far to the left to avoid it despite the arrow having no chance of hitting.
The bird flapped wildly in a fluster and turned from its attack.
It left for the clearing between the village and forest, and his soldiers made chase.
Byurk turned to the girl in amazement.
“Be proud.
You have just saved your village.
Now go!”
He forcefully turned the girl and pushed her in the opposite direction with a single shove.
The girl did as instructed and ran out of sight to the other side of the matriarch’s tree.
Byurk now had a moment to think.
If the Habha was attacking, then the wife of the emperor was near or already in the village.
There were two reasons she would be there, to retrieve her companion or to see the hamadryad.
If she was attacking the village, then the possibility of her culling favor with the hamadryad was low, so the most plausible reason was her companion.
He was her goal, assuredly.
The otherworldly humans had enough power that the wife would not need the aid of the dryads.
The dryads meant nothing to her, and that was why she was willing to sacrifice them to attack his men and rescue her companion.
Byurk ran to the small hut next to his, where Tyree cared for the otherworlder.
Inside, both she and the Melian who was traveling with the hamadryad huddled together next to the otherworlder.
“The wife of the emperor has come for him.
If you wake him, can he walk?”
Tyree looked at Byurk as if he was a fool.
“I do not know how long he has been in this condition, but his muscles are atrophied.
He will not be able to walk with the weight of his body.”
“Can you not use life magic to help or force him to walk?
We need to leave here.”
“I am a Melian, not a kissiae.”
“Then you must carry him.
My men are fighting the Habha and are unable to assist.”
Byurk turned to the other Melian.
“Jenae was your name, if I recall.
I know you are elderly, but can you help her?
I will reward you however I am able.”
Jenae looked at the man and then at Tyree.
After a moment of hesitation that almost forced Byurk to plead further, she agreed.
“I will do what I can.”
“I apologize for leaving labor to the elderly, but I cannot help with my stature.
I am unskilled with ranged magic, but I can protect you from the Habhah as you flee.”
Byurk left the hut with the two Melians close behind.
One arm of the man hung around each of their shoulders, and their aged bodies hunched forward under his weight as his feet dragged on the ground.
Byurk followed the last of his straggling men through the village.
The Habha finally reached the clearing where none of the villagers would be harmed in the fight.
When Byurk reached the edge of the village, a dark orange glow grew in the forest.
The moment the Habha saw it, it shot up far into the sky with three frantic flaps and disappeared into the dark.
He knew who hid in the forest, the powerful fire mage accompanying the wife.
“We’ve been had.
Everyone scatter!” Byurk hollered.
A massive fireball like glowing orange mud spat out flames as it traveled towards his men.
Byurk could only watch as his two earth mages set up thick walls of earth in desperation when the ball hit.
The erupting flame blew Byurk to his back and left a painful ringing in his ears.
Viscous fire rained on the clearing, each drop continuing the cacophony of destruction with smaller explosions.
Many of the huts at the edge of the village were not spared from the devastation.
Fire clung to the ground, burning the very soil.
Resting on his elbow, Byurk watched the sea of fire and the living torches that were once his men quickly collapsing into the flames.
He had been involved in battles against the Goblins, Sirens, and Merfolk in defense of Tolmyur.
He had seen ships sunk, armies massacred, and villages destroyed.
He had stood face to face with dragons, but for the first time in his nearly five years of life, he felt true terror.
Before him was the great and terrible power of a single human from the other world.
Byurk turned to his stomach, his body aching from the force of the explosion.
His ears rang incessantly.
Behind him, Tyree had her hand on the man’s chest, checking him for harm.
For a moment Byurk considered returning the otherworlder to spare his men, but no.
He thrust his palm onto the ground, and his ven traveled through the earth instantly below the otherworlder’s heart.
If this otherworlder held such power as he just witnessed, especially being a time mage, then the sacrifice of he and his men would have purpose.
The formed spike never broke up through the soil.
Roots quickly bound his hands and legs, and Tyree faced him in anger.
“Where life is present, earth magic will always be inferior.
I gave my word to protect this man until the hamadryad’s decision is made.
You will not harm him.”
Veins bulged in Byurk’s head both from anger and the roots constricting his body.
“Are you blind?!
Can you not see the danger that even one of these invaders poses?!
Look around you!
The village of your fellow Melians burns as they cower in fear of those who fight for the wife of the former emperor!
These are not just Tolmyur’s enemies.
These are all our enemies!”
Jenae looked at the burning huts near her and the devastation of the field before her.
Byurk could see the hesitation in her eyes.
“Jenae, if you care for your people, you must kill him.”
“I…” Jenae looked at the otherworlder, then at Tyree.
Her nervous glances switched back and forth between the stout tree in the center of the village and the unconscious man beside her.
She was visibly troubled, and Byurk could not understand why with the evidence in front of her.
He had only one option.
“While I confront the fire mage, go see the hamadryad!
Demand her answer!”
Jenae ran unsteadily back into the village.
Byurk struggled to break free of his binds, but they held sound.
“Release me.
I am fighting for your people.
Surely you see this.”
“You are fighting for your own interests,” Tyree retorted, “but do as you please.”
The roots withered and snapped like dry reeds, and Byurk pushed himself to his feet.
“I will hold you to your promise.
If Jenae brings word in my favor, kill that man.”
Without so much of a glance back for Tyree’s acknowledgement, Byurk ran towards the inferno to rally the survivors against the fire mage.

* * *
Sammy stood frozen gazing at the plume of fire rising above the huts from the explosion that could only have been caused by Chloe.
The cry of fear sounded from all over the village, and if Sammy did not know the truth about what was happening, she would think this was an attack on the village.
“What are we doing?” she asked.
“Stop staring and move.”
Ceil grabbed Sammy’s wrist and continued pulling her through the village towards the matriarch’s tree but stopped a few huts back.
They could not progress further without word that the tree was clear.
Dryads fled past them to get as far from the danger as possible.
Mothers were holding or pulling their crying children.
Youth assisted the elderly.
A pair of elves with small antlers circling their heads like a crown conversed with each other within earshot.
She could not understand their conversation, and they soon ran towards the inferno.
“Ceil, isn’t what we are doing a bit extreme?” Sammy asked.
“We do not have much of a choice at this point,” Ceil growled over her shoulder.
“Justin is important, is he not?”

While Sammy could not deny that her desire to have Justin returned to her was so strong that her heart physically ached, she also felt bad about the terror their methods were causing the innocent villagers.
Lemi appeared from around the side of the hut, jumped when she spotted Ceil and Sammy, and ran towards them shouting.
Ceil pulled Sammy forward between the huts to the large, stout tree.
The remains of a large, collapsed grass hut lay in a heap beside the tree.
Supplies and gear littered the ground, and Sammy realized that visiting the tree without being spotted would have been impossible.
The soldiers were camped right next to it.
Ceil pulled Sammy behind Lemi into the wide entrance of the hollow, and Sammy immediately shrieked.
A palanquin created by binding six swords and some chainmail together sat atop four swords driven erect into the wood.
Resting atop the palanquin was the terrifying form of a withered woman like all the moisture had been drained from her body, causing her skin to crack in long orange lines.
Her sunken, hollow eyes followed Sammy, and Sammy could not prevent her body from shaking or tears from forming.
“Show some respect,” Ceil whispered at Sammy, pushing her to kneel on the ground.
Ceil only bowed her head briefly to the hamadryad, showing her status as an equal.
“Who may you be, child,” spoke the village matriarch sitting on her low pedestal beside the hamadryad.
Ceil stood before the village matriarch with the dignified posture engrained in her by her caretakers in the palace.
“I am Ceil, widow of Yuro Amel and Empress of the Amelian Empire.”
The matriarch shifted to her knees with an air of elegance.
“I have received word from Jenae that you were in Melia.
Forgive my rudeness, but I wish to confirm the truth of your identity.
Please extend your hand.”
Ceil did as asked.
When the matriarch’s fingers touched hers, she released a pulse directed up her arm to her shoulder and then down her spine to her tails.
“Forgive me.”
The matriarch shifted her legs forward and off her pedestal.
Once kneeling on the wooden floor, she pressed her forehead down.
“I have no time for formalities.
I must speak with the--” Ceil began.
“Your highness!”
Jenae stumbled through the entrance to the hollow in a panic.
“The minum commander, he demands the hamadryad’s answer.
I… I did not know what to say.
Are you truly on our side?”
“What of Justin?” Ceil shouted back.
Jenae’s orders were to stay with Justin to make certain Tyree did not harm him.
Hearing Justin’s name, Sammy sprung to her feet.
“What happened?
What happened to Justin?”
“Stay back and keep quiet,” Ceil ordered, but Sammy grabbed Ceil’s arm in a painful grip.
“Don’t tell me to stay quiet!
Do you have any idea what it’s like not knowing what’s going on or what anyone is saying?
Please!
Tell me what happened.”
“Everyone, be still.”
Sammy shrunk away from the course yet loud voice of the hamadryad, and Jenae immediately knelt with her forehead pressed to the floor.
“Lady Ceil, widow of Yuro, I know why you are here.
You may have only just been brought into the reign of Amel, but the time of Amel is over.
You must accept that the Amelian Empire has ended.
In this conflict, I must prioritize the dryads.
I assume Jenae has informed you of my decision to join with Tolmyur.
The dryads can no longer support you.”
Each word spoken by the Hamadryad reverberated in Ceil’s mind, and she felt so small in front of one who had lived for ages.
Deep down, Ceil knew she was not an empress, even if the title had fallen upon her shoulders.
She could not use her false authority against the hamadryad even if the other dryads recognized it.
“Jenae, you may inform young Byurk of my decision,” the Hamadryad ordered.
“As… as you will…”
“Stop! Please!”
Ceil ran to Jenae before she could finish standing.
“Wait. Please…”
Ceil’s regal demeanor vanished, and Jenae looked up at her shocked that one of Ceil’s standing would resort to pleading.
“What is it you wish to say,” the hamadryad asked.
Ceil’s shoulder’s shook, and anxiety grew in her chest.
She was not trying to rebuild her empire.
There was something more, something greater that the hamadryad was unaware of.
Ceil’s maid had told her that she had a role in something to come.
That warning was repeated by the Sprite Arkhon.
The hamadryad was right.
The Amelian Empire fell.
Once the fairies are defeated, the last opposition to Tolmyur would be extinguished.
They would win.
The current conflict was near its end.
If so, what role did the Arkhon claim Ceil had?
What role did Justin have?
Why was saving him so important if the war would soon end?
“What do you know about the coming conflict,” Ceil asked quietly through quivering lips.
“Something is going to happen.
I do not know what it is, but the sprites are preparing for it.”
She turned to face the hamadryad, unsure of her own words.
“Something is coming.
I do not know what it is, but it is greater than me, greater than restoring the Amelian Empire.”
The hamadryad closed her eyes in pensive thought.
“Child, the Commander of Tolmyur spoke the same.
He claims invaders with great power have come to Whinhlem from another world, invaders that you have taken as companions.
I cannot see outside this room, but I can feel the hearts of all dryads who have accepted me.
The dryads in the village fear you and the invaders from the other world that you accompany.”
Ceil thought she misheard.
The hamadryad was mistaken.
Invaders from another world?
And those invaders were her companions?
A terrifying shiver shot down Ceil’s back.
She turned to face Sammy who stood silently, awaiting any news of Justin.
The odd characteristics of Sammy and Chloe that even Tyree stated was not human.
Their strange conversations at night when they thought she was sleeping.
Their peculiar clothing.
Their lack of the most common of knowledge, like beiju.
The gaps in Ceils mind that caused unease ever since the first day she met Sammy and Chloe atop the plateaus of Fiorrae were finally locking together.
“Sammy? Did you come from another world?”
Ceil could not believe the words she was speaking, but the shocked expression on Sammy’s face hinted it might be true.
Ceil ran to her and clasped her shoulders.
“Tell me!
Did you come from another world?!
Are you not from Whinhlem?!”
Sammy looked into Ceil’s panicked eyes, fearing how she would react if she answered truthfully.
Would Ceil abandon Justin?
Would she become her enemy?
Over Ceil’s shoulder, the weight of the hamadryad’s hollow gaze bored into her soul.
The hamadryad already knew.
Sammy was unsure how, but the hamadryad knew that she was not from Whinhlem.
Lying to Ceil now would be dangerous.
“I’m not from Whinhlem.
Justin, Chloe, and I come from a planet called Earth.”
Ceil released her grip and tripped back, falling on her butt.
“All this time, you were from another world?”
“Why does being from another world even matter?
We were sent here by Eydis.
That much is true!”
The hamadryad spoke in a grating but commanding tone, causing both Ceil and Sammy to shrink.
Ceil turned to the hamadryad and nodded before facing Sammy once more.
“The Hamadryad has already heard the Tolmyur commander’s story and now wants to hear yours.”
“Then tell her.
Everything I told you about what happened to us is true.”
“I want the whole truth!” Ceil shouted.
“Who are you?
Who are Chloe and Justin?
Why did Eydis choose Justin?
Why does the Sprite Arkhon acknowledge him?”
“It’s not just Justin.
Chloe is also important according to the Arkhon.
I’m the only one of us who isn’t…
I’ll tell you everything.”
While Ceil translated for the hamadryad, Sammy recounted how she met Eydis and how she learned what happened the night of the Assassination.
She explained how Eydis settled into life on Earth quickly, became an instructor at her university, taught them magic, and over time grew closer and closer to Justin.
She explained how Eydis’s anxiety grew worse after Jethro’s men abducted her, how she taught them combat magic and worked with the police and military to protect the city.
Eydis became hospitalized in an attack where they used an innocent elf girl as bait, and then Jethro invaded with an army.
The soldiers were willing to destroy the entire city to capture Eydis.
When Sammy, Justin, and Chloe finally reached Eydis, Jethro was there.
“And if it wasn’t for Eydis sending us to Whinhlem, Jethro would have killed us.
See?
Everything is the same as I told you.
Being from another world doesn’t change anything.”
The hamadryad spoke, and Ceil translated the question for Sammy.
“Are there any more humans from your world here?”
“We were the only ones Eydis sent.
I mean, Jethro can send people between worlds too, so I don’t know.
Me, Justin, and Chloe are the only people from Earth that I know about.”
“Are humans from your world planning to invade?”
“I don’t know!
If Eydis survived Jethro’s attack, maybe she would ask for their help.”
“Are you certain that the humans of your world would side with Eydis, or would they support Jethro.”
“Support Jethro?” Sammy stomped towards the hamadryad.
“Sammy, calm down,” Ceil whispered, but Sammy ignored her.
“Have you even been listening to me?!
Jethro attacked my city!
Tons of people died!
I don’t know if the city is even there anymore!
Of course we would not side with Jethro!
Is that head of yours hollow?!”
Ceil tried to pull Sammy away, but Sammy held fast using her weight to anchor herself.
“You cannot speak to a Hamadryad like that.
She is the same rank as the Sprite Arkhon.”
“Lemi, Help me.”
“I don’t care.”
Sammy’s eyes never wavered.
She stared deep into the sunken gaze of the hamadryad.
When Lemi grabbed Sammy’s other arm, they were able to pull Sammy away.
“Tell her so that it can get through that shriveled head of hers,” Sammy ordered again, refusing to kneel back down.
“Tell her that we attacked this village because you abandoned Justin and let those soldiers take him.
Tell her that he’s going to die if she sides with those soldiers.
Tell her that I promised the Arkhon I would protect him!
Tell her!”
The hamadryad’s expression never changed.
She watched the commotion with repose, and a single word froze Ceil in place.
“You seriously want me to translate what you said,” Ceil asked Sammy in a fearful yet quiet voice.
“Every single word,” Sammy replied, never breaking her glare at the hamadryad.
Ceil’s mind was in a panic.
She would have thought Sammy learned after what happened when she talked back to the Sprite Arkhon.
Perhaps the concept of authority did not exist on Sammy’s world, but it was very important on Whinhlem.
The rulers of highly organized societies inherited their thrones, but in much of the world, the leaders were the strongest, whether by the nature of the selection process or by rule of power.
Dryadic magic grew stronger with age, and Ceil did not doubt that even in the hamadryad’s withered state, she could kill them easily if she desired.
“Translate,” the hamadryad ordered again, and Ceil could not disobey out of fear of greater wrath than what Sammy’s insults alone would incur.
“Please be open-minded,” Ceil pleaded.
“Sammy has little respect for authority and even spoke out against the Sprite Arkhon.”
After her small plea, Ceil repeated every word Sammy said, and Lemi, Jenae, and the village matriarch all bowed their faces to the ground in fear of the hamadryad’s wrath.
The only dryad in the room who did not become submissive was the hamadryad’s guard.
A wooden spear grew from the floor at her feet.
She snapped it off and marched towards Sammy.
“Please, stop,” Ceil begged standing in front of Sammy who remained unperturbed.
The hamadryad tore her hand from the edge of the palanquin and raised it to stop her guard’s advance.
“I requested the truth, and the child obeyed.
She has done no wrong.”
The guard returned to her position behind the hamadryad, but the spear remained firmly grasped in her hand.
Lemi jumped up and embraced Sammy while Ceil sighed quietly in relief.
“I commend honesty in any form,” the hamadryad continued.
“This child speaks her truth as did that young commander, and yet both truths conflict.
However, this child’s story has a weight that I cannot ignore.
Lady Ceil, is it true that you are on errand from the Sprite Arkhon?”
Ceil struggled to think of a clear answer.
She was banished from Fiorrae because the Sprite Arkhon wanted her to accomplish her duty or fate, but he never explained the nature of her fate.
The only person given a direct task was Sammy, and that task was to find help for Justin, a task that Ceil had played a detrimental role in.
If the hamadryad had asked if she had the support of the Sprite Arkhon, then she felt she could answer in the affirmative, but she could not honestly say she was working on his behalf.
“No, I am not on errand for him, but saving that man, Justin, is a task the Sprite Arkhon has given Sammy."
“If I side with the commander, then that man’s life is forfeit?” the hamadryad asked.
Ceil looked over to Jenae who quickly rose to kneel.
“Yes,” she answered.
“My village shaman, Tyree, will execute him on the commander’s order if the commander earns your favor.
She honors your word more than our village’s promise to Ceil.”
“Lady Ceil, relay my words to Sammy.
Hamadryads pilgrimage to connect our hearts with our people before taking root and becoming a Grandmatriarch.
Failure to complete our pilgrimage means that our people are not connected under the same Grandmatriarch.
To prevent this, a guard from the hamadryad’s village of birth is provided to protect the hamadryad or kill her if the hamadryad is incapable of completing the pilgrimage.
My decision to side with the young commander was to earn Tolmyur’s favor in my absence.
As you were honest with me, I will be honest with you.
I cannot complete my pilgrimage.”
The Melians in the room stared in shock at the news, and the hamadryad’s guard hung her head in remorse.
Sammy grabbed Ceil’s shoulder.
“She can’t complete her pilgrimage?
What does that mean for Justin?”
“Becoming a Grandmatriarch was not my calling,” the hamadryad continued.
“I was a mother of many, and by chance I lived long enough to also bear roots.
My life is frail as you can see, and my body can no longer support itself.
Even as I sit here, my body grows weak, and I will die unless I take root.
I will not last until the end of the pilgrimage.
I cannot take your side, nor can I take the commander’s.”
“Then what about Justin,” Sammy cried after hearing Ceil’s translation.
“I promised to save him.
I cannot lose him…”
“If the hamadryad does not take a side, what will Tyree do?
Will she return Justin to us,” Ceil asked Jenae.
“She will continue to protect him,” Jenae assured Ceil, “but I doubt she will be able to safely return him.
The commander was desperate to kill even one of your companions.
He tried again after witnessing your companion’s magic.
I fear he will order his men to kill both Tyree and him if the hamadryad does not take his side.”
When Ceil translated Jenae’s reply, Sammy broke down into tears.
“So no matter what happens, Justin will be killed?”
Sammy knelt before the palanquin and grasped the swords supporting the two corners.
She bowed her head low, careful to not apply any strength to her hands or pull at the swords.
The posture matched perfect Elven manner, surprising not only Ceil but also the hamadryad.
Ceil never taught Sammy Elven mannerisms, so Sammy could only have learned this from Eydis.
She too knelt before the hamadryad.
“Can nothing be done?” Ceil asked.
“Hamadryads hold authority respective to their age.
For this reason, the matriarchs are the eldest in each village.
Grandmatriarchs likewise are the eldest of all dryads and rule all of Dhuillir.
Even before the death of our three Grandmatriarchs, there is one dryad, a kissiae, who is older than them all.
And yet, even she is only an infant to the Sprite Arkhon.
Age is authority to us.
Dryads are the longest living of the mortal races, but the Sprite Arkhon is from an ancient age before dryads.
If his will is to save this Justin, then I am bound by duty to obey.
Regrettably, I can do nothing as I am.
If we were in Kedra, as the eldest of the Kedros, I could order my daughters to save Justin, but here in Melia I have no right to order these people to die.”
“Did you not just say that age is authority?” Sammy asked.
“An ancient custom long forgotten after dryads joined under the Amelian banner.
Only the eldest of dryads still hold to that tradition.
Here in Melia, I am a Grandmatriarch candidate.
Nothing more.”
When Ceil translated the ill news, she expected Sammy to break down into a fit of crying or rave about in anger, but instead, she released her hold on the swords and sat in thought.
“If you became a Grandmatriarch, would the Melians listen?
Do you have to finish the pilgrimage to become a Grandmatriarch?”
Ceils eyes grew wide.
She posed the question to the hamadryad and village matriarch, and the latter answered.
“Before the Amelian Empire and the unification of Dhuillir, various tribes had their own Grandmatriarchs, born and rooted in their home tribe.
It was a time of war and strife between dryads.
The rule that a hamadryad must be killed if she cannot visit all the states of Dhuillir prevents such a division.
By unifying all tribes under the same hamadryad, no conflict between tribes is possible.”
“If the hamadryad roots herself right now, who would obey her,” Sammy asked.
“Only those who have accepted me,” the Hamadryad replied, “but even among them, there will be many who will change their hearts and reject me because I have not completed my pilgrimage.
Some remember tales of the great wars and may see my existence as a threat.”
Sammy stood and stared at the hamadryad with conviction in her eyes.
“The Sprite Arkhon wants Justin to survive, and you said that you must obey the Arkhon.
You have your answer.”
Ceil’s body quivered with anticipation after translating Sammy’s declaration.
She watched as Sammy and the hamadryad stared at each other.
The other dryads were silent, and the tension in the wide room of the hollow in the stout tree was palpable.
In the silent standoff of wills, the hamadryad moved first.
She painfully tore off her other hand and leg from the palanquin and dangled her leg off the side.
“Lady Ceil, when this war is over, promise that you will kill me,” the Hamadryad said.
When the hamadryad shifted her body to the edge, the guard raised her spear and aimed for the hamadryad’s back.
An arrow from Lemi’s bow hit the guard’s arm just above the elbow, and her elbow quickly swelled and burst, severing her arm and dropping the spear.
Before the guard could fashion another weapon or reach for the hamadryad, Sammy had an orb of water ready and threw it at the guard.
The force of the burst knocked the guard to her back.
“Run!” Lemi cried.
When the Hamadryad slid off the palanquin, Lemi immediately pulled both Sammy and Ceil out of the tree’s hollow with Jenae stumbling close behind.

Chapter 16
“The Division of the Masses”
“Coby! Help!”
Chloe stumbled through the forest, fleeing for her life.
When she attacked the soldiers chasing Coby, she was stunned frozen by the power of her own attack.
She watched the field burn as if hypnotized by the dancing flames.
She did not think to move from her position, and before she realized, ten soldiers and two elves were bearing down on her.
An arrow to her left arm woke her from her trance, and she fled fueled by her fear and the deshalu grass lingering in her system.
She held her arm tight just above the arrow to try and slow the bleeding.

The pain was unbearable, and she could not spare even a moment to remove the arrow and sear the wound, not with the arrows and spikes of ice whizzing past her head and impacting the trees she weaved through.
Ceil’s plan was for Chloe to immediately fall back to their original position on the other side of the village, but in her frantic sprint she was moving further and further away from the village.
The orange glows of the flames were still visible, but the subdued blue glow of the tree in the center of the village was not.
The further she fled, the further she was from help, so she risked changing course ninety degrees to bring her closer to the village.
The two Forest Elves quickly reacted to the shift in their target’s direction and bounded in a straight line to intercept.
Their agile legs built for the hunt propelled them forward over the uneven forest floor.
Chloe could hear their feet approaching beside her, and the first elf was soon upon her.
He grabbed her arm to restrain her but immediately released his grip with a hiss, shaking his hand.
Chloe continued fleeing, but the elf did not give up.
His next attempt was to grab her binding to avoid her skin.
When he gripped the bow on her back, Chloe dropped her center of gravity, turned, locked her arm under his and with a twist of her shoulders, he curled over his arm onto his back.
The man expected to be finished off, but Chloe fled.
The second Forest Elf passed the first, and his downed partner shouted something in a language that did not sound like the Elven that Eydis spoke.
He caught Chloe swiftly with one arm across her chest over her binding and the other gripping her pants at her hip and attempted to pull her to the ground.
Chloe grabbed his wrists at her waist and across her chest, and with a slight shift of her hips and her left foot planted forward, her posture locked.
Chloe felt a surge of energy flow to her hand and into the man.
His posture buckled and he was on his back with Chloe still holding one wrist.
The elf, far older than the first, looked up at her with shock as Chloe released him and ran towards the village.
The blue glow at the center of the village was again in sight, driving Chloe faster.
If she could at least reach the clearing, she could use her magic to defend herself instead of relying solely on the self-defense skills taught her by Eydis, but the village felt impossibly far away.
The effects of the deshalu grass were ebbing, and Chloe could feel her feet growing heavier.
An ice spike grazed her cheek, but the sharp tip melted on contact with her hot skin making the impact feel like she was pelted with a large rock.
The soldiers gained a lot of ground due to the two elves who caught her, and those two elves were once again gaining fast.
Chloe pushed her legs faster.
Far in the distance, the clearing was visible through the trees.
The elves caught up but instead of trying to capture her as before, they kept their distance on each side, running between the trees.
Chloe could only think that they were going to close off her path of escape to prevent her from reaching the clearing, but to her surprise, they only kept pace.
The elder of the two shouted something at her that was distinctly Elven, but Chloe could not understand.
She deeply wished she could tell them that she was not their enemy even though she attacked their village, but they would never believe her.
“Coby!”
Chloe cried in desperation for the only other member of her group who was not meeting with the hamadryad, but she questioned how Coby could find her in the middle of a dense forest at night.
Chloe’s exhaustion was peaking.
She slowed for only a single breath, and an arrow hit her back.
Her lungs felt like they burst into flames, and her hope of rescue burned up with them.
She collapsed onto the forest floor with the village clearing only twenty yards ahead of her.
Immediately the two elves were on her, and Chloe knew her time had come.
Chloe closed her eyes to accept her fate as the taste of blood filled her mouth with each painful breath, but instead of a swift end, her wrists were seized, and she was pulled towards the village.
She opened her eyes to see the two elves dragging her with haste into the clearing.
The younger of the two moaned in agony from the heat of her touch.
Chloe could feel the skin of their hands blistering on her wrists.
A quick end would not come for her.
She knew she would pay for each life she extinguished.
She tried to cry out Coby’s name, but all that left her mouth was a blood-filled cough.

* * *
“They caught her! Hurry!”
Byurk urged his men forward.
That woman was quick on her feet, as fast as his men if not faster.
She was clearly conditioned in hit-and-run tactics.
He was grateful for the two spriggans who came to his aid.
If not for them, his ranger would not have been able to line up a shot, and she may have gotten away or worse, attacked again.
Even injured, she was still dangerous, so he needed to catch up and finish her before she could harm anyone else.
When Byurk and his men entered the clearing, he saw the two spriggans holding her wrists in pain.
This woman had the rare ability to superheat her body without harming herself, a flameskin.
The longer they held her, the more the spriggans would be injured, but if they let go, she could retaliate.
“Hold her still!”
Byurk lifted his foot to stomp down and shoot a spike up under her, but the ground shook, knocking him off balance.
The phosphorescent light from the large stout tree in the center of the village faded, and the tree withered.
Byurk knew now that he had been terribly mistaken.
He thought that the wife was here to retrieve her companion, but she had come for the hamadryad.
The wilting of the village matriarch’s tree was a terrible omen.
If the wife was willing to attack a dryad village, was she even willing to kill the hamadryad to prevent the unified dryads from aiding Tolmyur?
That level of cruelty was indefensible, even in war.
The widow of the emperor was sabotaging her own subjects’ future.
Byurk questioned running to the hamadryad’s aid.
The ground shook, and the huts near the matriarch’s tree collapsed.
Should he protect the union between the dryads and Tolmyur to fight the invasion, or should he kill what invaders he could now?
The ground shook again, and Byurk made his decision.
“Kill that woman!
I will protect the hamadryad!”
Byurk sprinted towards the village, earth magic boosting each step.
Around the clearing, dryads who had fled into the forest during the initial attack were reappearing and heading towards the village with haste.
Only now that their matriarch and hamadryad were in danger did they find the will to fight back?
Byurk forced the criticism from his mind and entered the village.
The few dryads who had not fled the village stood motionless staring at the withered tree.
Roots slithered across the ground, and with each step, the tiny roots attempted to latch onto his feet.
As he neared the tree, the roots grew large and thick, destroying the huts as they spread, but they no longer grasped at Byurk.
Above his head, Byurk saw the Habha fly south towards where his men were executing the otherworlder.
Hopefully they killed her already and could focus on the new threat unabated.
He wished his men well in his mind and continued through the maze of roots as thick as he towards the center of the village.
The matriarch’s tree grew brittle, and branches snapped and fell.
In their place, large boughs of cedar broke through the dead wood.
In the wide opening of the hollow of the tree, he saw the form of a beautiful woman.
Her single leg fused to the roots spreading out in all directions, and from her arms clasped high above her head grew branches that pierced the ceiling.
Before Byurk’s eyes, the connection from the roots at her feet to the branches above her head grew thicker into the trunk of a tree.
Her back pressed against it as if bound by chains and hanging, but there was no displeasure in her full lips and downward gaze.
“My apologies, young commander.
I have made my decision.”
Her voice no longer grated like sand but carried the beauty of a melody.
The wheel of time had reversed its course and returned the aged woman her youth, a resurrection and beginning of the next stage of a dryad’s life.
Byurk looked around at the room and saw the withered bodies of the village matriarch and the hamadryad’s guard crushed and mangled between the roots.
No one else was present, not even Jenae who was to inform Tyree of the matriarch’s decision.
“And what was your decision,” Byurk asked with fear pricking the back of his neck.
“One far elder to me with greater authority than I has sided with those from the other world, and I must obey.
I express my gratitude that you were willing to build positive relations with the dryads, and for that I will spare you against the will of Lady Ceil, but I must order you to leave this land.
You are no longer welcome here.
I have ordered my children to retrieve the man you hold prisoner.
Abandon him or face the wrath of Melia.”
Despite his fear, anger boiled within Byurk’s stomach.
“The Amelian Empire has fallen!
The widow has no authority!
She has expressed open hostility to the dryads!
How can you choose to obey her over the looming threat of these invaders?!”
The hamadryad shook her head, and the air of apology graced her perfect face.
“I do not know whether these humans from Earth are a danger to Whinhlem.
Lady Ceil’s authority is not what swayed me but the conviction of those from Earth and the will of the Lord of the Sprites.
I will die in atonement for my decision when this war is over.”
Not wanting to hear more, Byurk ran out of the hollow.
He lost the hamadryad’s support, so his only choice now was to kill the invading humans here in the village if at all possible.

* * *
Tyree glared down at her elder sister who lay prostrate on the ground in a fit of apology.
“How could you let this happen?
Was Lady Ceil’s goal not the unification of Dhuillir?
How could you let her convince that hamadryad to divide our people?
I can no longer feel her.
How many Melians like me are not united under her?
How many of the tribes of Dhuillir do not even know her?”
Through the grass, Tyree felt the approach of small feet from the village.
Byurk hid behind a smoldering hut, and Tyree could feel his ven searching the ground for the location of Ceil’s companion.
She sent a root through the ground to grab his leg and pull him across the grass to her.
“I told you that you cannot kill him so long as he is under my protection. However…”
Melians approached from the village and forest clearing, avoiding the burning ground.
“The Grandmatriarch demands he be returned,” one of them called to Tyree.
“That is not our Grandmatriarch,” Tyree shouted.
“That is a rot in our land that threatens to divide not just the Melians but all of Dhuillir.”
She pulled Byurk to his feet and presented him before the crowd.
“Tolmyur has sought to unify Dhuillir against a common enemy, the same enemy that has destroyed your village and stole that chance of unity from us for perhaps another thousand years or more.”
All around her, Tyree could see the hearts of many of the Melians changing, their conviction weakening in their expressions.
“Even now you can feel the division between us.
This hamadryad will send your daughters against their sisters.
She is a poison that threatens to pull Dhuillir into another era of civil war, and this village needs to unite to kill her before that division spreads outside of Melia.”
Byurk watched the crowd rally under the words of Tyree.

She spoke in the Melian language, so he could not understand the meaning, but what he knew was that they no longer approached with the intent to retrieve the otherworlder as the hamadryad had commanded.
There was a division growing among the Melians, and although the division might help his cause, he feared where it might lead.
He wanted to spare the Melians from conflict.
The widow of the emperor not only brought conflict to them, but she also created conflict between them.
War was unavoidable.
His only hope was to end it as quickly as possible, or perhaps he could direct it away from Melia.
“I do not know your tongue, but I know the hearts of people.
I can see the conflict that the hamadryad has caused, and I do not desire that any Melian be forced to raise her hand against her own.
The hamadryad has told me that she will atone for her decision with her death at the end of the war.
The quickest route to unity is to end the war and have the hamadryad obey her word.
I have discovered the means for a Grandmatriarch candidate to safely pilgrimage without trial or pain.
I promise that Tolmyur will guide the next candidate through her pilgrimage and unite Dhuillir.
The widow of Emperor Yuro is in your village.
Find her so that we may discuss the ending of this war.
Tell the other Melians in the village!”

* * *
Ceil, Sammy, and Lemi stood at the edge of the village and watched as cedar boughs broke through and continued to grow out of the stout tree.
The conical tip of a cedar slowly rose from the top, towering into the dark sky.
“I thought she was almost dead,” Ceil said in awe.
“Hamadryads have to struggle constantly to keep their roots from growing, but once they let them grow, they drain all life near them and grow quickly.
Sometimes dryads get caught and become life for the hamadryad.
It is viewed as an honor, but I could not let you be trapped like that,” Lemi explained.
“Is Justin going to be okay now?”
Sammy’s anxiety never diminished even after convincing the hamadryad to side with them.
“I cannot say,” Ceil replied honestly.
“What do you mean you cannot say!?”
“I do not know where Jenae went, but she probably ran back to tell Tyree that the hamadryad sided with us.”
Sammy grabbed Lemi’s arm.
“Why didn’t we follow Jenae!?”
Lemi shrunk away from Sammy, so Ceil pushed her away from the cowering girl.
“She ran another direction when we fled.
You saw how quickly those roots were growing.
If we turned back, we would have been caught in it.
We should return to our meeting spot.”
“What about Justin,” Sammy shrieked, well past her breaking point.
Ceil took a breath to prevent herself from shouting back.
She understood Sammy’s worry and anger, and any retaliation would set Sammy off worse than before.
“Sammy, the reason you convinced the hamadryad to take root here was so that she could command the dryads to retrieve him for us.
Trust that she will obey her word.”
Sammy nodded reluctantly. “Okay.”
