Ceil held Sammy’s wrist and pulled her south towards their agreed meeting spot where she hoped Chloe was waiting, but as they neared the southwest side of the village, she saw Coby frantically attacking from the air.
“Coby!”
When Coby heard Ceil, he cried back, but did not turn from his assault.
Ceil and Lemi broke into a sprint, leaving Sammy trailing behind.
Ceil saw Coby and one Forest Elf fighting ten soldiers.
A younger, injured Forest Elf huddled on the ground shielding Chloe.
Chloe was immobile and two arrows protruded from her back and arm.
Ceil’s heart raced.

When she gave Chloe her orders, she thought that Chloe would be able to attack and then flee in the panic her attack would inevitably cause, but watching how easily the soldiers were perfectly avoiding both Coby and the Forest Elf’s wind attacks while simultaneously counterattacking, she knew these were not average infantry.
Even after an attack as powerful as the explosion she saw, there would be some who could avoid the damage and retaliate immediately.
Lemi nocked an arrow and fired, but her target cut the arrow down with his sword.
Ceil and Lemi’s existence known, a few soldiers changed their target.
An archer fired an arrow back at Lemi, and instead of dodging it, Lemi blocked it with her forearm.
The arrow penetrated through, but she tore it out without any show of pain, nocked it in her own bow, and fired it back.
The torn wound on her arm slowly repaired itself.
Coby aimed at the distracted soldiers, but in the open field, they anticipated the trajectory of the wind blade and sidestepped away.
“That must be the wife,” one of the soldiers called, and they all changed their target from Chloe to Ceil.
A swordsman charged at Ceil, and Ceil realized that her staff was still inside the matriarch’s tree.
Without a conduit, she was limited in what magic she could use.
Life was her only element and it only worked by contact.
She reached down and used the roots in the grass to bind the charging soldiers’ feet, but the roots alone were too weak.
He stumbled, but each step tore the roots away.
She was not powerful enough to bind him with such thin roots.
She needed a tree or at least her staff, but with no other option, she tried again.
The swordsman stumbled, and when he was about to regain his footing, he froze.
Lines of black crept up his face, and his skin sagged.
Lemi landed an arrow in his chest.
Like the arrow that hit the hamadryad’s guard, the impact site ruptured in a spray of blood, killing him instantly, but the blood was blackened, no longer its natural crimson hue.
The grass between her and the downed soldier wilted black and flaked into powder.
Ceil shuddered but pushed onward, searching for her next target.
A thin wall of ice grew, dividing the soldiers from their targets.
The frozen trail originated from the village where two High Elves knelt with their hands on the ground.
Four dryads ran past them.
“Commander Byurk demands a ceasefire,” one of the dryads called out.
“He wishes to speak with Lady Ceil.”
The soldiers, visible through the thin wall of ice, stepped back and lowered their weapons.
Ceil ran towards Chloe.
The Forest Elf covering her had a deep gash across his back and left arm and was bleeding out quickly.
She pulled him off to inspect Chloe and saw that the Forest Elf was terribly burnt where he held her.
Chloe’s clothes were smoldering and falling off her, and the arrows in her back and arm were black and smoking.
“Lemi! Hurry!
We need a healer!”
Ceil tried placing her hand on Chloe to check if she was alive, but her fingers stung the moment they touched Chloe’s skin.
Lemi was about to do the same, so Ceil pulled her hand back.
“Do not touch her.
You will burn.”
Burns were the only form of damage incurable for dryads.
If the Dryads cannot touch Chloe, how can we heal her?
“Move,” Sammy ordered, pushing Ceil aside.
“She’s overheating.”
She conjured a large sphere of water and dropped it on Chloe, sending an explosion of steam in all directions.
“Has this happened before,” Ceil asked, shielding her face from the near-scalding mist.
Sammy dropped a second and third sphere, but Chloe would not cool.
“Damn it.
We need ice magic.”
“Lemi, bring those High Elves here quickly!
And a shaman!” Ceil ordered.
Lemi ran towards the village while Sammy continued dropping water.
“Lady Ceil, I apologize for our inability to protect her,” the elder Forest Elf said, kneeling and bowing his head.
“We were unaware she worked for you until she used the royal arts.
By then, we were too late.
Although the scale cannot be balanced, please accept my son’s sacrifice as compensation.”
“Chloe is not dead yet and neither is your son,” Ceil replied.
“There is nothing to balance.”
“The High Elves!” Lemi returned with the two High Elves who created the ice wall.
“I need you to cool her down.
Use ice magic directly,” Ceil ordered.
“But that will harm her,” the High Elf warned.
“It will not.
Stop when there is no more steam.
Lemi, what about the shaman?”
“None of the dryads there were shamans,” Lemi said worriedly.
“Then you need to heal them.
Start with the Forest Elf and then move to Chloe when she cools.”
Ceil sat back as Lemi tended to the large gash on the Forest Elf while the two High Elves tried to coat Chloe with frost only to have steam blow back in their faces with incredible force.
The soldiers on the other side of the ice wall scoffed and jeered at the failed attempts to heal Chloe, and Ceil fought within herself not to order those near her to silence them.
When Ceil felt she was about to snap, Coby landed atop the wall and knocked a few of the unprepared soldiers to their backs with a single flap of his large wings.
Coby’s cry of triumph was met with the drawing of swords.
“Stand down!”
A crowd of dryads approached from the east side of the village.
A minum led them, the commander of the soldiers.
Tyree walked beside him, her hand on a stretcher carried by two young dryads.
“Justin!” Sammy jumped to her feet and pressed her hands against the ice wall.
Although the scene was distorted through the clear ice, she knew it was him.
There could be no other.
Ceil stood next to Sammy and placed her hand on her shoulder.
Together they watched the approaching parade as anxiety wracked Ceil’s mind.
The hamadryad chose to side with her, but the demand for ceasefire and the Tolmyur commander leading the procession felt to Ceil like he held the dryads’ favor, not the hamadryad.
The soldiers parted as the commander approached.
He stood on the other side of the wall, and although he was half Ceil’s height, she felt so small in front of him.
On her side of the wall were a few elves and only a handful of dryads, but over half the entire village stood behind him.
The commander stepped forward and spoke.
“Ceil, widow of late Emperor Yuro of Amel, I am here to discuss the ending of this war, but first I must express my utter disgust of your actions here in Melia.”

Chapter 17
“End-war Negotiations”
Ceil
Disgust?
Ceil’s mind ran scattered attempting to recall all she had done in Melia.
From the day they entered Melian lands, they traveled in search of a village to heal Justin.
Sammy protected Coby which led to the extermination of a scouting party.
The loss of a scouting party was common in war and nothing to warrant disgust.
She found a village and built positive relations with them amid gross misunderstandings.
The dryads were subjects of the Amelian Empire, so relying on their aid was nothing to warrant disgust.
If there was anything that Ceil felt disgust over, it was her ignorance of Justin’s role in whatever was to come that led her to abandon him.

She traveled as quick as possible to recover him, and when they located him in this village, she was careful to only target the Tolmyur soldiers, enemies of all the Amelian Empire, including the dryads.
She was eliminating the enemies of the dryads, and that was nothing to warrant disgust, especially in a war.
With Sammy’s help, she convinced the hamadryad to take her side so that she could recover Justin.
Part of the village was destroyed, but the huts could be regrown quickly, and now the dryads had a Grandmatriarch when the hamadryad would not have been able to complete the pilgrimage.
These were victories.
“If I have done anything to warrant the disgust of a commander of Tolmyur, it is because I have overpowered you.
My actions here have been a benefit to Melia and all Dhuillir,” Ceil announced to the enemy commander.
“I find it troubling that you can spew such filth in front of every Melian before you,” Byurk replied.
“Or are you so ignorant that you believe your actions righteous?”
Tyree scowled, causing Ceil’s heart to sink, and Ceil began to doubt what she had accomplished.
The displeased faces of the crowd were deafening in their silence, and Ceil could barely maintain her composure.
What did I do?
“As a ruler of the Amelian Empire, you cannot be so ignorant of Dhuillir politics and history.

You knew full well that by forcing the hamadryad to take root before completing her pilgrimage you would divide the states of Dhuillir into two conflicting factions, those who are connected to the hamadryad and will support you and those who have surrendered to Tolmyur and have no connection to the hamadryad.
Even among those who have accepted the hamadryad there is contention.
There are many like the Melians behind me who fear the civil conflict that such a division will inevitably cause.
You have brought war to a peaceful people who want nothing to do with the conflict between Tolmyur and elves.”
Ceil once again felt as if she was drowning in the murky depths of her heart.
She grasped at the air above her, trying to pull herself out or stay afloat, but she found no hold.
Every slight movement sunk her deeper.
She brought war to Dhuillir.
Ceil’s hand clasped that thought, and she straightaway pulled herself out of the murk.
Fire welled in her chest from the destruction she had seen at the hands of the Tolmyur Kingdom.
“I brought war?
I brought war to the Amelian Empire?!
If you want to speak of division, who was it that killed the three Grandmatriarchs of Dhuillir?
Who was it that first destroyed that unity?
Are the dryads worse off now that they have partial unity than when they had none?
Tolmyur is the one who attacked us and assassinated the royal family.
You are the enemy that killed the leaders of all the sovereign states of the empire.
You brought war to our peaceful nation, not I!”
“Your nation only obtained that peace at our expense.
I cannot speak for the orders of my Commanding General that brought war and destroyed your oppressive empire, but I can testify that we have no ill will against the dryads.
Commanding General Jethro has made an alliance with the most ancient dryad race, the kissiae, and Dhuillir has remained mostly untouched in this conflict.
Before you bring war to their forests and force mother to fight against daughter and sister against sister, I demand an end to this conflict.
Surrender yourself and show that you do care for your former subjects.”
“If you care for the dryads, you can end this war by leaving the Amelian Empire and returning to your homeland.”
“You are mistaken.
Tolmyur has no ill will against the dryads, but we cannot let the crimes of your people go unpunished.”
“After hearing that, do you think I will simply surrender myself to you?
Your accusations are nothing more than you choking on the very air you breathe.”
“What then is your plan?
Will you force the dryads to die for you so that you might take back your throne?
How do you plan on compensating them for the lives lost?
Or do you plan on abusing your authority by demanding their sacrifice?”
Ceil watched the gazes of the dryads through the thinning ice.
Her chest felt as if it was being sucked inward.

The hamadryad told her all the dryads would not be connected, but Ceil could never admit that she was ignorant of the dangers that a hamadryad taking root before completing her pilgrimage could cause to the stability of Dhuillir, that it would divide them.
I do not want anyone else to die because of me.
“I did not convince the hamadryad to force Dhuillir to fight for me.
I needed her help to rescue my companion, the injured man in Tyree’s care.
I had no other goal.”
A smile grew on the commander’s face, and Ceil realized she had fallen prey to a cleverly hidden trap.
Her stunned visage only widened the commander’s smile.
“I suppose you would not be willing to make a trade, your life for the otherworlder’s?”
Ceil remained silent, unsure how to respond without falling deeper into the minum’s plot.
“I assumed not.
If what you said is true, I have a proposal.
I do not desire war to come to the peaceful land of Dhuillir, a feeling I realize now that you also share.
I challenge you to battle in Vallen.
The fairies are in active opposition against us and challenge our successful defeat of the Amelian Empire.”
Color drained from Ceil’s face.
“You only attacked the fairies because they protected me!”
“Be that as it may, the conflict has grown beyond whether you were hidden there or not.
Because you were the cause of their fall, join them in their fight for survival.
If you defeat us, you have shown your right to rule.
If you fall, then your death will bring an end to this conflict.
Meet me in battle, and I will return your companion in good health.
If your otherworld invaders are as strong as I have seen, you may have a chance.

If you flee or take too long and the conflict in Vallen ends, then the life of your companion is forfeit, and I do not doubt my Commanding General will make certain that destruction follows you wherever you flee until the end of your days.”
Lemi touched Ceil’s shoulder, startling her.
“Chloe is still really hot, but she has cooled enough for treatment.”
Ceil looked behind her and saw Chloe laying on her stomach while an elderly dryad worked frantically to heal the arrow wound in her back.
The number of dryads on Ceil’s side of the wall had increased, but she did not know if they were figuratively on her side or whether they also supported the Tolmyur commander.
She looked at Sammy whose face was so close to the wall of ice that her worried breaths were melting a hole through the wall.
Justin remained as still as death on the other side.
Ceil wondered if she could somehow steal Justin away.
Sammy had suffered far too long because of him and even more because Ceil had abandoned him to capture.
Coby understood the sprite language, so if she gave him the order, no one on the commander’s side would understand, but then she remembered what happened when Coby tried to carry Sammy away.

Justin was heavier than her, or perhaps they were the same weight now with how malnourished Justin had become, but Coby could not lift him, and even if he could, well-trained soldiers could attack before he flew back up out of harm’s way.
His ascent would assuredly be slowed by Justin’s unnatural weight.
“Your answer?” Byurk pressed.
Ceil looked at her companions.
Could she carry them with her to war?
Deep down she wanted to abandon Justin.
Was he truly so important to be worth dividing Dhuillir and going to war?
Why did the Sprite Arkhon place him as her equal in the coming conflict?
What was the coming conflict?
Was the battle in Vallen only a part or was it an unimportant or disconnected precursor to what is to come?
Ceil felt trapped.
No matter what decision she made, danger would follow, and people would die.
She wanted to break down and cry out her anxiety, her fears, and her inadequacy.
All she could do was follow where this torrential river carried her.
“If you can promise me that you will return my companion in full health, I accept.
I will meet you in battle in Vallen.”
“Then we are in agreement.”
The commander stomped his foot, and jagged earth shot up from beneath the wall, shattering it.
“Justin!” Sammy jumped over the broken ice and was only able to touch him before four soldiers grabbed her and pushed her back.
She fell into the jagged ice and watched with watery eyes as the soldiers retrieved the stretcher from the dryads and walked away.
Ceil watched Sammy remorsefully as she grasped the commander’s outstretch wrist to seal their agreement.
A voice from the shadows of her heart told her to use her cursed magic to poison him, but he had an army of dryads on his side.
Such action would only create conflict and potentially drown the village in battle once more, making her out to be the enemy of the dryads he claimed she was.
They did not need to clasp wrists to seal their agreement.
Ceil knew he was testing her conviction.
When their hands parted, the commander turned his back without another word and followed after his soldiers.

Epilogue
“The Unknown”
Sammy watched the soldiers disappear into the forest.
The sharp ice dug into her back, but the pain was nothing compared to watching Justin be carried away again when she was close enough to touch him.
“Why?
What happened?
Why are they taking Justin away?
Didn’t we come all this way to save him?” Sammy looked up at Ceil who could only stare silently with a guilty countenance.
“Why did you let him go?” Sammy stood and confronted Ceil.
“Why did you let him go?!”
She pushed Ceil with all her weight, and Ceil staggered back, nearly falling to the ground.
“Chloe nearly died!
You destroyed this village!
And then you just let Justin go?!”
“I had no choice…” Ceil said apologetically.
“You always have a--” Sammy cut herself off and screamed into the air in anger, frustration, and sorrow.
Ceil knelt and bowed her forehead to the ground.
The elves, nymphs, and dryads who saw gasped in shock that the Empress of the Amelian Empire would bow before another.
“Please understand.
There was nothing I could do,” Ceil said, fighting to hold in her own spiraling emotions.
“I don’t want to hear it!”
Sammy stomped off away from the crowd towards the forest.
Coby trotted behind her, but she pushed him away.
“I need to be alone.”
He cried in protest but did not follow.
Sammy wandered until she found a small, secluded trench through the forest floor.
She sat down in it with her knees tucked to her chest and cried into her arms.
She had always regretted breaking up with Justin, and she could not deny feeling jealous every time he and Eydis were affectionate with each other.
She wanted to turn back time and apologize for treating him poorly to make her feel better about her decision.
From the moment he took that bullet for her, she wanted to set everything right.
She still loved him, and she mourned every second she saw him suffering.
Every morning, she woke with the fear that Justin had passed in the night.
She was so close to getting him back but then had to watch as he was carried away again.
Some deal was struck between Ceil and the soldiers, a deal without her input and one she could not understand.
Ceil abandoned him while Sammy sat and watched, ignorant of what was going on around her.
“Why am I so useless…?”
Sammy dug her fingers into the moist soil and squeezed it in her hand.
“Why can’t I do anything?!”
She tossed the dirt at the embankment of the trench across from her in a fit of rage and self-loathing.
Wad of dirt after wad of dirt peppered the embankment until Sammy’s fingernails stung and bled.
She hunched over and placed her face in the dirt, crying out her agony.
A warm wind enveloped Sammy like a blanket.
The dirt and dead leaves beneath her grew into a soft patch of grass with budding yellow flowers.
Moss and red clover covered the embankment of the trench, and the sweet aroma filled her nose.
Sammy looked around and saw petals falling from nowhere as if appearing from the air.
Tears streamed from her eyes, and she choked as she tried to speak.
“I’m sorry, Arkhon.
I couldn’t keep my promise.
I couldn’t save Justin… You were right.”
“I disagree.”
The Arkhon’s smooth tenor voice, appearing as if he sat in front of her, held the tone of a loving father comforting his crying daughter.
“You upheld your promise splendidly.
Justin found the aid he needed and is now in fair health.
His strength will recover in time.”
“But I lost him.
The soldiers took him away.”
“That was never part of our challenge.”
“I don’t care about the challenge!
I just want Justin to be here with me…”
Sammy tried to hold back her sobs, but they broke through in hiccups and coughs.
She wiped her nose and cheeks, only serving to smear dirt across her face.
“My, you are a noisy one.
Because you could not understand the agreement between Ceil and Byurk, I am pleased to inform you that Justin will be returned to you in Vallen, the land of the fairies.
Ceil agreed to meet him there to spare the dryads further conflict.”
The Arkhon chuckled heartedly, catching Sammy off guard.
She looked forward into the empty air in front of her where the voice emanated.
“We sprites have something you might call a collective foresight.
Together we can predict future events with a fair level of accuracy.
I must say that you surprised us.
The dryads were never supposed to be part of the coming battles in Amel, but you not only single handedly pulled them into it, you set them against each other.
None of us saw that coming!”
The Arkhon laughed again.
Sammy stared blankly in front of her.
She felt like her heart stopped beating.
She couldn’t understand how any of her actions could have caused an entire nation to join the war, let alone split on opposing sides.
“Didn’t you say that Ceil and those soldiers agreed to leave for the land of the fairies so that the dryads don’t get involved?”
“Do you really expect two sides in a war to not use every tool at their disposal?
I had my doubts when you said that you would place your mark on the conflict, but you may be right.”
“This is not what I meant!”
“Well, the ripple is small, but you have proved me wrong.
You have reminded us that the sprites are not omniscient, a reminder that many of us desperately needed, I’ll have you know.
As per our agreement, I will reward you.”
“I don’t want to be rewarded for this!” Sammy shouted.
“Come now.”
The light warm breeze circled Sammy’s head as did the Arkhon’s voice.
“I am not giving you anything extraordinary, only something minor, and equal to your meager contribution.
Think of it as bringing you closer to your goal of standing with your friends.”
Sammy looked down at her dirt-encrusted and lightly bleeding fingers.
She wanted to be strong like Chloe, commanding like Ceil, and caring like Justin.
She felt minuscule compared to them, especially knowing that they were so important that sprites in Whinhlem knew and recognized them despite Chloe and Justin being from Earth.
“Of everything you have experienced since arriving here in Whinhlem, what is it that you regret most, besides Justin being carried away, of course.”
“You can’t return Justin to me?
You can use spatial magic, right?”
“Yes, I could, rather easily in fact, but I am curious where your ripple will lead.
I do not want to agitate the water now.
Something else, if you will.”
“Wait…” Sammy looked around her.
She felt the soft grass that had grown so suddenly.
She smelled the sweet aroma of the clover.
“You can use life magic?”
“Of course.
How else do you think we prevented Justin from dying until you found help?”
“Don’t tell me… You had the ability to heal Justin all along, didn’t you?”
“Our original plan was to surprise you all with Justin in top shape before you left Ceil’s little garden.
I was looking forward to the joyous reunion, but your bet with me sounded far more intriguing.”
Sammy grasped at the voice by her left ear and felt the warm wind sift through her fingers.
“You could have healed Justin but instead you let him suffer?!”
“Who am I to deprive you of your determination?”
“Don’t you dare shift the blame to me!”
Sammy conjured an orb of water and threw it at the most recent direction of the voice, but it flew unobstructed until it hit the embankment of the trench.
“You should have told me you were planning to heal him!”
The warm air brushed across Sammy’s right cheek.
“To be honest, our job is to observe and maintain.
Gyea would be furious if she knew we were directly interfering.
Plus, the more we personally interfere, the more inaccurate our foresight becomes.
Your decision to find help for Justin was beneficial to us in that regard.
Justin is healthy and he will be returned to you.
That much I can promise, so please calm down.”
“You expect me to calm down?!”
“Need help?”
Sammy felt a tiny hand touch her forehead, and she blacked out.
Sammy’s body fell limp to the side, but the Arkhon swept her up in a gentle breeze to lay her down gently on the soft moss of the embankment.

The sprites were not omniscient, but through the combined observations of many sprites across countless worlds and the detailed visions of probability inherent to their being, they could calculate with almost certainty how the future would unfold.
Very minor alterations of distant future predictions were not unheard of, but short-term predictions were always completely accurate.
And yet, this woman was not only invisible to their foresight, but her actions also never played into their predictions.
“Peculiar. Perhaps I should expect much from you.”
The Arkhon brushed away the dirt and tears from Sammy’s face.
He cleaned the dirt from her hands and healed her split fingernails.
She had such passion that he could not help but feel moved.
For the first time in an age, the Arkhon felt guilt that his curiosity had caused someone’s suffering.
“Those with the most passion are the easiest to understand.
When you are here before me, I know what you think.
I know what you will say or do, but the moment you leave my sight, you become invisible to me.
I can only see through the actions of those around you.”
The Arkhon brushed Sammy’s bangs and watched as she gasped in weak and troubled breaths.
His eyes fell to the black mark on Sammy’s neck that even now continued to spread at a rate nearly unnoticeable to a mortal eye.
That corrupted mark would try and weaken her again, and the longer it remained, the more powerful it would grow as it fed on Sammy’s soul.
The curse seemed awfully similar to the malady affecting Bydrofe.
He wiped his hand over the mark and extracted it like a dark mist from her neck.
It pulsed angrily in the air, lashing out small tendrils to cling back onto Sammy and finding no interest in him.
He was not the curse’s target.
The Archon froze the curse in time and sent it back to Fiorrae to be researched along with the other corrupted plants that withered black and died as Ceil tended her forest garden home.
Sammy’s breath eased and grew peaceful in deep and comfortable slumber away from her troubles.
“Peculiar, indeed.
As for your deepest regret, perhaps I should give you the same gift I gave Jethro.
Although, I did give him his for free due to the role he would play.
How about I make yours more… universal.
My treat.
It is a paltry gift, but surely you will make great use of it.”

* * *
Byurk looked at his nine remaining men.
The attack by that fire mage singlehandedly eliminated most of his party.
The defenses of the earth mages were nothing against that strange flame that clung to the ground like oil.
Not even his fire mage could withstand the heat.
This was the power that would await them in Vallen when they met the wife in battle.
“Who of you is fit to send a message to the palace?” he asked his men.
“I am.” The sole remaining ranger stepped forward.
“You were originally conscripted to be a scout, if I recall.”
“Yes sir, but they changed my position after seeing my skill with a bow.”
“Well enough.
I need you to inform the generals at the palace of everything that has transpired here.
Inform them that we will be meeting the widow in battle at Vallen at their last remaining fairy cities.
Most importantly, make certain you impress upon them the power we have witnessed in the humans from the other world.
All able units not required to hold the capital should march for Vallen.
We will need every able man if we are to win.
If our Commanding General has returned from his campaign, inform him first.”
The ranger tapped his fist to his chest.
“Yes sir.
I will run with urgency, even if I die once my message is relayed.”

* * *
Ceil walked slowly through the village as the morning light broke through the horizon.
She viewed the destruction of the village, the destruction she caused.
The dryads had no material possessions, but the elfkind and nymphs near the center of the village were scavenging through the roots for their possessions buried in their collapsed huts.
Ceil could not look at them from the weight of guilt born by her ignorance.
She had abused her authority, thinking that because she was the empress of a fallen empire that everything she did was permissible.
The hamadryad was correct.
Her empire was no more.
She was not an empress.
She was only a farm girl raised in a palace and who just happened to be the widow of the last emperor.
Ceil climbed over the roots in front of the matriarch’s tree and entered the hollow.
“You look troubled, child.”
Ceil could not look up at the hamadryad.
She did not reply.
After all, what could she say?
The hamadryad did not want to take root here.
She would have preferred to die rather than divide Dhuillir.
Ceil searched the broken hollow, turning away from the mangled bodies of the matriarch and guard who failed to escape.
In the back behind the hamadryad, she found what she was searching for.
Roots bound her staff.
She placed her hand on the brittle wood and found it dead.
All life that was once in it had become nourishment for the hamadryad.
Now that the life was lost, it could not return.
She placed her hand on the roots and used life magic to uncoil them.
She headed for the exit with staff in hand.
“Do not regret your decisions, Lady Ceil.
The true quality of a leader is not in always choosing the best course but in making the most out of both the good and the bad paths you have taken.”
“You only say this because you feel I have made the wrong choice.”
Ceil walked out into the village, cradling her dead staff to her chest like a doll.
She climbed over the roots and circled to the north side of the village that was far less damaged and entered the largest hut.
Jenae and Lemi sat side by side next to Chloe.
Steam rose from her body in the humid morning air, but she was breathing peacefully.
“Has Sammy not returned?” Lemi asked with concern.
“Coby was watching her from a distance, so I am sure she will be fine.
We should leave her alone for a while.”
Ceil sat down on the other side of Chloe and caressed her staff.
Lemi looked at the staff, and as a shaman, she could tell the conduit was dead.
“Are you going to grow a new one?”
“I am not as skilled as you in dryadic or healing magic.
This wood came from Fiorrae.
I will have to use a branch of one of the trees here and nourish it for a while, but it will not be the same.”
“Why not ask the hamadryad for a branch.
Hers will probably be stronger,” Jenae suggested.
“I would rather not,” Ceil said flatly.
“I figured as much, so I asked her for you,” spoke a voice above them.
Ceil looked up and saw the Arkhon floating above her head.
Lemi yelped, and Jenae stared with wide eyes.
A red cedar staff appeared from the air and dropped on Ceil’s head.
She caught it quickly before it fell onto Chloe and rubbed the sting on her head.
“Did that wake you up a bit?
Stop looking so glum.
I thought you promised me you would be alright after you left Fiorrae.”
Ceil ignored him and checked the life of the staff.
The capacity was not as strong as the wood from Fiorrae, but it was not much weaker either.
“You will find it far less malleable than your last staff, so think of it as a tool to train with.”
Ceil gripped her new staff and felt the smooth wood that teemed with life.
There was a weight on her mind that she could only ask now with the Sprite Arkhon present.
“Why did you not tell me that Justin and Chloe were the same as me?”
“The same?”
“I mean, important in the war.
You told Sammy, and I made a terrible mistake because I did not know.”
The Arkhon landed on Ceil’s shoulder and patted her lightly on her cheek.
“Quite simple.
If you felt obligated to trust them and work with them, then you would not have grown.
You came to your own conclusions on what to think and how to view Chloe and Justin.
And mistakes are an important part of growth.”
“I feel sorry for Sammy, though.”
“Because of Justin?”
“Of course that is part of it, but she tries so hard.
Is she not like them or me?”
“To be honest, I do not know.
She might be a dark horse in all of this.”
Ceil looked at the Arkhon in confusion.
“What is a horse?”
The Arkhon patted Ceil on the nose and hopped into the air.
“I have business elsewhere, so I must be leaving.
Take care of Sammy.
I am excited to see how she grows.”
Sammy appeared suddenly on the floor beside Ceil, unconscious and weak-breathed.
“Sammy?
What happened to her?” Ceil asked, worried.
“Nothing you need to worry about.
She just needs rest.
I expect her to sleep for about a day and a half, maybe two.
Do not let any of the dryads touch her.
I do not want their inferior life magic to mess anything up.”
